<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Song of the Broad-Axe</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Song of the Broad-Axe</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>W<FONT SIZE=-1>EAPON</FONT> shapely, naked, wan,

<BR>Head from the mother's bowels drawn,

<BR>Wooded flesh and metal bone, limb only one and lip only one,

<BR>Gray-blue leaf by red-heat grown, helve produced from a little

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seed sown,

<BR>Resting the grass amid and upon,

<BR>To be lean'd and to lean on.



<P>&nbsp;Strong shapes and attributes of strong shapes, masculine trades,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sights and sounds,

<BR>Long varied train of an emblem, dabs of music,

<BR>Fingers of the organist skipping staccato over the keys of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; great organ.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Welcome are all earth's lands, each for its kind,

<BR>Welcome are lands of pine and oak,



<P>&nbsp;Welcome are lands of the lemon and fig,

<BR>Welcome are lands of gold,

<BR>Welcome are lands of wheat and maize, welcome those of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grape,

<BR>Welcome are lands of sugar and rice,

<BR>Welcome the cotton-lands, welcome those of the white potato and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sweet potato,

<BR>Welcome are mountains, flats, sands, forests, prairies,

<BR>Welcome the rich borders of rivers, table-lands, openings,

<BR>Welcome the measureless grazing-lands, welcome the teeming soil

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of orchards, flax, honey, hemp;

<BR>Welcome just as much the other more hard-faced lands,

<BR>Lands rich as lands of gold or wheat and fruit lands,

<BR>Lands of mines, lands of the manly and rugged ores,

<BR>Lands of coal, copper, lead, tin, zinc,

<BR>Lands of iron&amp;emdash;lands of the make of the axe.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>The log at the wood-pile, the axe supported by it,

<BR>The sylvan hut, the vine over the doorway, the space clear'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for a garden,

<BR>The irregular tapping of rain down on the leaves after the storm

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is lull'd,

<BR>The wailing and moaning at intervals, the thought of the sea,

<BR>The thought of ships struck in the storm and put on their beam

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ends, and the cutting away of masts,

<BR>The sentiment of the huge timbers of old-fashion'd houses and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; barns,

<BR>The remember'd print or narrative, the voyage at a venture of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men, families, goods,

<BR>The disembarkation, the founding of a new city,

<BR>The voyage of those who sought a New England and found it,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the outset anywhere,

<BR>The settlements of the Arkansas, Colorado, Ottawa, Willamette,

<BR>The slow progress, the scant fare, the axe, rifle, saddle-bags;

<BR>The beauty of all adventurous and daring persons,

<BR>The beauty of wood-boys and wood-men with their clear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untrimm'd faces,



<P>&nbsp;The beauty of independence, departure, actions that rely on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; themselves,

<BR>The American contempt for statutes and ceremonies, the boundless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; impatience of restraint,

<BR>The loose drift of character, the inkling through random types,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the solidification;

<BR>The butcher in the slaughter-house, the hands aboard schooners and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sloops, the raftsmen, the pioneer,

<BR>Lumbermen in their winter camp, daybreak in the woods, stripes of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; snow on the limbs of trees, the occasional

snapping,

<BR>The glad clear sound of one's own voice, the merry song, the natural

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life of the woods, the strong day's work,

<BR>The blazing fire at night, the sweet taste of supper, the talk, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bed of hemlock-boughs and the bear-skin;

<BR>The house-builder at work in cities or anywhere,

<BR>The preparatory jointing, squaring, sawing, mortising,

<BR>The hoist-up of beams, the push of them in their places, laying them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; regular,

<BR>Setting the studs by their tenons in the mortises according as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they were prepared,

<BR>The blows of mallets and hammers, the attitudes of the men, their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; curv'd limbs,

<BR>Bending, standing, astride the beams, driving in pins, holding on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by posts and braces,

<BR>The hook'd arm over the plate, the other arm wielding the axe,

<BR>The floor-men forcing the planks close to be nail'd,

<BR>Their postures bringing their weapons downward on the bearers,

<BR>The echoes resounding through the vacant building;

<BR>The huge storehouse carried up in the city well under way,

<BR>The six framing-men, two in the middle and two at each end, carefully

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bearing on their shoulders a heavy stick for

a cross-beam,

<BR>The crowded line of masons with trowels in their right hands rapidly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; laying the long side-wall, two hundred feet

from front to rear,

<BR>The flexible rise and fall of backs, the continual click of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trowels striking the bricks,



<P>&nbsp;The bricks one after another each laid so workmanlike in its place,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and set with a knock of the trowel-handle,

<BR>The piles of materials, the mortar on the mortar-boards, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steady replenishing by the hod-men;

<BR>Spar-makers in the spar-yard, the swarming row of well-grown

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; apprentices,

<BR>The swing of their axes on the square-hew'd log shaping it toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the shape of a mast,

<BR>The brisk short crackle of the steel driven slantingly into the pine,

<BR>The butter-color'd chips flying off in great flakes and slivers,

<BR>The limber motion of brawny young arms and hips in easy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; costumes,

<BR>The constructor of wharves, bridges, piers, bulk-heads, floats,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stays against the sea;

<BR>The city fireman, the fire that suddenly bursts forth in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; close-pack'd square,

<BR>The arriving engines, the hoarse shouts, the nimble stepping and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; daring,

<BR>The strong command through the fire-trumpets, the falling in line,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the rise and fall of the arms forcing the

water,

<BR>The slender, spasmic, blue-white jets, the bringing to bear of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hooks and ladders and their execution,

<BR>The crash and cut away of connecting wood-work, or through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; floors if the fire smoulders under them,

<BR>The crowd with their lit faces watching, the glare and dense

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shadows;

<BR>The forger at his forge-furnace and the user of iron after him,

<BR>The maker of the axe large and small, and the welder and temperer,

<BR>The chooser breathing his breath on the cold steel and trying the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; edge with his thumb,

<BR>The one who clean-shapes the handle and sets it firmly in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the socket;

<BR>The shadowy processions of the portraits of the past users also,

<BR>The primal patient mechanics, the architects and engineers,

<BR>The far-off Assyrian edifice and Mizra edifice,

<BR>The Roman lictors preceding the consuls,

<BR>The antique European warrior with his axe in combat,



<P>&nbsp;The uplifted arm, the clatter of blows on the helmeted head,

<BR>The death-howl, the limpsy tumbling body, the rush of friend

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and foe thither,

<BR>The siege of revolted lieges determin'd for liberty,

<BR>The summons to surrender, the battering at castle gates, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; truce and parley,

<BR>The sack of an old city in its time,

<BR>The bursting in of mercenaries and bigots tumultuously and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; disorderly,

<BR>Roar, flames, blood, drunkenness, madness,

<BR>Goods freely rifled from houses and temples, screams of women

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the gripe of brigands,

<BR>Craft and thievery of camp-followers, men running, old persons

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; despairing,

<BR>The hell of war, the cruelties of creeds,

<BR>The list of all executive deeds and words just or unjust,

<BR>The power of personality just or unjust.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>Muscle and pluck forever!

<BR>What invigorates life invigorates death,

<BR>And the dead advance as much as the living advance,

<BR>And the future is no more uncertain than the present,

<BR>For the roughness of the earth and of man encloses as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; much as the delicatesse of the earth and of

man,

<BR>And nothing endures but personal qualities.



<P>&nbsp;What do you think endures?

<BR>Do you think a great city endures?

<BR>Or a teeming manufacturing state? or a prepared constitution?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or the best built steamships?

<BR>Or hotels of granite and iron? or any chef-d' oeuvres of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; engineering, forts, armaments?



<P>&nbsp;Away! these are not to be cherish'd for themselves,

<BR>They fill their hour, the dancers dance, the musicians play

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for them,

<BR>The show passes, all does well enough of course,

<BR>All does very well till one flash of defiance.



<P>&nbsp;A great city is that which has the greatest men and women,

<BR>If it be a few ragged huts it is still the greatest city in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whole world.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>The place where a great city stands is not the place of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stretch'd wharves, docks, manufactures, deposits

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; produce merely,

<BR>Nor the place of ceaseless salutes of new-comers or the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; anchor-lifters of the departing,

<BR>Nor the place of the tallest and costliest buildings or shops

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; selling goods from the rest of the earth,

<BR>Nor the place of the best libraries and schools, nor the place

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; where money is plentiest,

<BR>Nor the place of the most numerous population.



<P>&nbsp;Where the city stands with the brawniest breed of orators

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and bards,

<BR>Where the city stands that is belov'd by these, and loves them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in return and understands them,

<BR>Where no monuments exist to heroes but in the common

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; words and deeds,

<BR>Where thrift is in its place, and prudence is in its place,

<BR>Where the men and women think lightly of the laws,

<BR>Where the slave ceases, and the master of slaves ceases,

<BR>Where the populace rise at once against the never-ending

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; audacity of elected persons,

<BR>Where fierce men and women pour forth as the sea to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whistle of death pours its sweeping and unript

waves,

<BR>Where outside authority enters always after the precedence of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inside authority,

<BR>Where the citizen is always the head and ideal, and President,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mayor, Governor and what not, are agents for

pay,

<BR>Where children are taught to be laws to themselves, and to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; depend on themselves,

<BR>Where equanimity is illustrated in affairs,

<BR>Where speculations on the soul are encouraged,

<BR>Where women walk in public processions in the streets the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as the men,



<P>&nbsp;Where they enter the public assembly and take places the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as the men;

<BR>Where the city of the faithfulest friends stands,

<BR>Where the city of the cleanliness of the sexes stands,

<BR>Where the city of the healthiest fathers stands,

<BR>Where the city of the best-bodied mothers stands,

<BR>There the great city stands.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>How beggarly appear arguments before a defiant deed!

<BR>How the floridness of the materials of cities shrivels before

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a man's or woman's look!



<P>&nbsp;All waits or goes by default till a strong being appears;

<BR>A strong being is the proof of the race and of the ability of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the universe,

<BR>When he or she appears materials are overaw'd,

<BR>The dispute on the soul stops,

<BR>The old customs and phrases are confronted, turn'd back,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or laid away.



<P>&nbsp;What is your money-making now? what can it do now?

<BR>What is your respectability now?

<BR>What are your theology, tuition, society, traditions, statute-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; books, now?

<BR>Where are your jibes of being now?

<BR>Where are your cavils about the soul now?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>A sterile landscape covers the ore, there is as good as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the best for all the forbidding appearance,

<BR>There is the mine, there are the miners,

<BR>The forge-furnace is there, the melt is accomplish'd, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hammers-men are at hand with their tongs and

hammers,

<BR>What always served and always serves is at hand.



<P>&nbsp;Than this nothing has better served, it has served all,

<BR>Served the fluent-tongued and subtle-sensed Greek, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long ere the Greek,

<BR>Served in building the buildings that last longer than any,



<P>&nbsp;Served the Hebrew, the Persian, the most ancient Hindustanee,

<BR>Served the mound-raiser on the Mississippi, served those whose

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; relics remain in Central America,

<BR>Served Albic temples in woods or on plains, with unhewn pillars

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the druids,

<BR>Served the artificial clefts, vast, high, silent, on the snow-cover'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hills of Scandinavia,

<BR>Served those who time out of mind made on the granite walls

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rough sketches of the sun, moon, stars, ships,

ocean waves,

<BR>Served the paths of the irruptions of the Goths, served the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pastoral tribes and nomads,

<BR>Served the long distant Kelt, served the hardy pirates of the Baltic,

<BR>Served before any of those the venerable and harmless men of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ethiopia,

<BR>Served the making of helms for the galleys of pleasure and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; making of those for war,

<BR>Served all great works on land and all great works on the sea,

<BR>For the mediaeval ages and before the mediaeval ages,

<BR>Served not the living only then as now, but served the dead.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>I see the European headsman,

<BR>He stands mask'd, clothed in red, with huge legs and strong

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; naked arms,

<BR>And leans on a ponderous axe.



<P>&nbsp;(Whom have you slaughter'd lately European headsman?

<BR>Whose is that blood upon you so wet and sticky?)



<P>&nbsp;I see the clear sunsets of the martyrs,

<BR>I see from the scaffolds the descending ghosts,

<BR>Ghosts of dead lords, uncrown'd ladies, impeach'd ministers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rejected kings,

<BR>Rivals, traitors, poisoners, disgraced chieftains and the rest.



<P>&nbsp;I see those who in any land have died for the good cause,

<BR>The seed is spare, nevertheless the crop shall never run out,



<P>&nbsp;(Mind you O foreign kings, O priests, the crop shall never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; run out.)



<P>&nbsp;I see the blood wash'd entirely away from the axe,

<BR>Both blade and helve are clean,

<BR>They spirt no more the blood of European nobles, they clasp

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; no more the necks of queens.



<P>&nbsp;I see the headsman withdraw and become useless,

<BR>I see the scaffold untrodden and mouldy, I see no longer any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; axe upon it,

<BR>I see the mighty and friendly emblem of the power of my own

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; race, the newest, largest race.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>9</CENTER>





<P>(America! I do not vaunt my love for you,

<BR>I have what I have.)



<P>&nbsp;The axe leaps!

<BR>The solid forest gives fluid utterances,

<BR>They tumble forth, they rise and form,

<BR>Hut, tent, landing, survey,

<BR>Flail, plough, pick, crowbar, spade,

<BR>Shingle, rail, prop, wainscot, jamb, lath, panel, gable,

<BR>Citadel, ceiling, saloon, academy, organ, exhibition-house,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; library,

<BR>Cornice, trellis, pilaster, balcony, window, turret, porch,

<BR>Hoe, rake, pitchfork, pencil, wagon, staff, saw, jack-plane,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mallet, wedge, rounce,

<BR>Chair, tub, hoop, table, wicket, vane, sash, floor,

<BR>Work-box, chest, string'd instrument, boat, frame, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what not,

<BR>Capitols of States, and capitol of the nation of States,

<BR>Long stately rows in avenues, hospitals for orphans or for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poor or sick,

<BR>Manhattan steamboats and clippers taking the measure of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all seas.



<P>&nbsp;The shapes arise!

<BR>Shapes of the using of axes anyhow, and the users and all that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; neighbors them,



<P>&nbsp;Cutters down of wood and haulers of it to the Penobscot or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Kennebec,

<BR>Dwellers in cabins among the Californian mountains or by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; little lakes, or on the Columbia,

<BR>Dwellers south on the banks of the Gila or Rio Grande, friendly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gatherings, the characters and fun,

<BR>Dwellers along the St. Lawrence, or north in Kanada, or down

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by the Yellowstone, dwellers on coasts and

off coasts,

<BR>Seal-fishers, whalers, arctic seamen breaking passages through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the ice.



<P>&nbsp;The shapes arise!

<BR>Shapes of factories, arsenals, foundries, markets,

<BR>Shapes of the two-threaded tracks of railroads,

<BR>Shapes of the sleepers of bridges, vast frameworks, girders,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arches,

<BR>Shapes of the fleets of barges, tows, lake and canal craft, river

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; craft,

<BR>Ship-yards and dry-docks along the Eastern and Western seas,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and in many a bay and by-place,

<BR>The live-oak kelsons, the pine planks, the spars, the hackmatack-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; roots for knees,

<BR>The ships themselves on their ways, the tiers of scaffolds, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; workmen busy outside and inside,

<BR>The tools lying around, the great auger and little auger, the adze,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bolt, line, square, gouge, and bead-plane.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>10</CENTER>





<P>The shapes arise!

<BR>The shape measur'd, saw'd, jack'd, join'd, stain'd,

<BR>The coffin-shape for the dead to lie within in his shroud,

<BR>The shape got out in posts, in the bedstead posts, in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; posts of the bride's bed,

<BR>The shape of the little trough, the shape of the rockers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beneath, the shape of the babe's cradle,

<BR>The shape of the floor-planks, the floor-planks for dancer's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feet,

<BR>The shape of the planks of the family home, the home of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; friendly parents and children,



<P>&nbsp;The shape of the roof of the home of the happy young man and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; woman, the roof over the well-married young

man and woman,

<BR>The roof over the supper joyously cook'd by the chaste wife, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joyously eaten by the chaste husband, content

after his day's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; work.



<P>&nbsp;The shapes arise!

<BR>The shape of the prisoner's place in the court-room, and of him

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or her seated in the place.

<BR>The shape of the liquor-bar lean'd against by the young rum-drinker

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the old rum-drinker,

<BR>The shape of the shamed and angry stairs trod by sneaking footsteps,

<BR>The shape of the sly settee, and the adulterous unwholesome couple,

<BR>The shape of the gambling-board with its devilish winnings and losings,

<BR>The shape of the step-ladder for the convicted and sentenced murderer,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the murderer with haggard face and pinion'd

arms,

<BR>The sheriff at hand with his deputies, the silent and white-lipp'd

crowd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the dangling of the rope.



<P>&nbsp;The shapes arise!

<BR>Shapes of doors giving many exits and entrances,

<BR>The door passing the dissever'd friend flush'd and in haste,

<BR>The door that admits good news and bad news,

<BR>The door whence the son left home confident and puff'd up,

<BR>The door he enter'd again from a long and scandalous absence,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; diseas'd, broken down, without innocence,

without means.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>11</CENTER>





<P>Her shape arises,

<BR>She less guarded than ever, yet more guarded than ever,

<BR>The gross and soil'd she moves among do not make her gross

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and soil'd,

<BR>She knows the thoughts as she passes, nothing is conceal'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from her,



<P>&nbsp;She is none the less considerate or friendly therefor,

<BR>She is the best belov'd, it is without exception, she has no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reason to fear and she does not fear,

<BR>Oaths, quarrels, hiccupp'd songs, smutty expressions are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; idle to her as she passes,

<BR>She is silent, she is possess'd of herself, they do not offend

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her,

<BR>She receives them as the laws of Nature receive them, she

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is strong,

<BR>She too is a law of Nature &amp;emdash; there is no law stronger

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than she is.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>12</CENTER>





<P>The main shapes arise!

<BR>Shapes of Democracy total, result of centuries,

<BR>Shapes ever projecting other shapes,

<BR>Shapes of turbulent manly cities,

<BR>Shapes of the friends and home-givers of the whole earth,

<BR>Shapes bracing the earth and braced with the whole earth.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Song of the Redwood-Tree</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Song of the Redwood-Tree</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>A C<FONT SIZE=-1>ALIFORNIA</FONT> song,

<BR>A prophecy and indirection, a thought impalpable to breathe

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as air,

<BR>A chorus of dryads, fading, departing, or hamadryads departing,

<BR>A murmuring, fateful, giant voice, out of the earth and sky,

<BR>Voice of a mighty dying tree in the redwood forest dense.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Farewell my brethren</I>,

<BR><I>Farewell O earth and sky, farewell ye neighboring waters</I>,

<BR><I>My time has ended, my term has come</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Along the northern coast,

<BR>Just back from the rock-bound shore and the caves,

<BR>In the saline air from the sea in the Mendocino country,

<BR>With the surge for base and accompaniment low and hoarse,

<BR>With crackling blows of axes sounding musically driven by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strong arms,

<BR>Riven deep by the sharp tongues of the axes, there in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; redwood forest dense,

<BR>I heard the mighty tree its death-chant chanting.



<P>&nbsp;The choppers heard not, the camp shanties echoed not,

<BR>The quick-ear'd teamsters and chain and jack-screw men

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heard not,

<BR>As the wood-spirits came from their haunts of a thousand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; years to join the refrain,

<BR>But in my soul I plainly heard.



<P>&nbsp;Murmuring out of its myriad leaves,

<BR>Down from its lofty top rising two hundred feet high,

<BR>Out of its stalwart trunk and limbs, out of its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; foot-thick bark,



<P>&nbsp;That chant of the seasons and time, chant not of the past

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; only but the future.



<P>&nbsp;<I>You untold life of me</I>,

<BR><I>And all you venerable and innocent joys</I>,

<BR><I>Perennial hardy life of me with joys 'mid rain and</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; many a summer sun</I>,

<BR><I>And the white snows and night and the wild winds</I>;

<BR><I>O the great patient rugged joys, my soul's strong joys</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unreck'd by man</I>,

<BR><I>(For know I bear the soul befitting me, I too have</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consciousness, identity</I>,

<BR><I>And all the rocks and mountains have, and all the earth,)</I>

<BR><I>Joys of the life befitting me and brothers mine</I>,

<BR><I>Our time, our term has come</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Nor yield we mournfully majestic brothers</I>,

<BR><I>We who have grandly fill'd our time</I>;

<BR><I>With Nature's calm content, with tacit huge delight</I>,

<BR><I>We welcome what we wrought for through the past</I>,

<BR><I>And leave the field for them</I>.

<BR><I>For them predicted long</I>,

<BR><I>For a superber race, they too to grandly fill their time</I>,

<BR><I>For them we abdicate, in them ourselves ye forest kings!</I>

<BR><I>In them these skies and airs, these mountain peaks,</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Shasta, Nevadas</I>,

<BR><I>These huge precipitious cliffs, this amplitude, these</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; valleys, far Yosemite</I>,

<BR><I>To be in them absorb'd, assimilated</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Then to a loftier strain,

<BR>Still prouder, more ecstatic rose the chant,

<BR>As if the heirs, the deities of the West,

<BR>Joining with master-tongue bore part.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Not wan from Asia's fetiches</I>,

<BR><I>Nor red from Europe's old dynastic slaughter-house</I>,

<BR><I>(Area of murder-plots of thrones, with scent left yet</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of wars and scaffolds everywhere,)</I>

<BR><I>But come from Nature's long and harmless throes,</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; peacefully builded thence</I>,



<P>&nbsp;<I>These virgin lands, lands of the Western shore</I>,

<BR><I>To the new culminating man, to you, the empire new</I>,

<BR><I>You promis'd long, we pledge, we dedicate</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>You occult deep volitions</I>,

<BR><I>You average spiritual manhood, purpose of all, pois'd</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on yourself, giving not taking law</I>,

<BR><I>You womanhood divine, mistress and source of all, whence</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life and love and aught that comes from

life and love</I>,

<BR><I>You unseen moral essence of all the vast materials of</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; America, (age upon age working in death

the same as life</I>,)

<BR><I>You that, sometimes known, oftener unknown, really shape and</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mould the New World, adjusting it to Time

and Space</I>,

<BR><I>You hidden national will lying in your abysms, conceal'd</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but ever alert</I>,

<BR><I>You past and present purposes tenaciously pursued, may-be</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unconscious of yourselves</I>,

<BR><I>Unswerv'd by all the passing errors, perturbations of the</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; surface</I>;

<BR><I>You vital, universal, deathless germs, beneath all creeds,</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arts, statutes, literatures</I>,

<BR><I>Here build your homes for good, establish here, these areas</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; entire, lands of the Western shore</I>,

<BR><I>We pledge, we dedicate to you</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>For man of you, your characteristic race</I>,

<BR><I>Here may he hardy, sweet, gigantic grow, here tower</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; proportionate to Nature</I>,

<BR><I>Here climb the vast pure spaces unconfined, uncheck'd by</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wall or roof</I>,

<BR><I>Here laugh with storm or sun, here joy, here patiently inure</I>,

<BR><I>Here heed himself, unfold himself, (not others' formulas</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heed,) here fill his time</I>,

<BR><I>To duly fall, to aid, unreck'd at last</I>,

<BR><I>To disappear, to serve</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Thus on the northern coast,

<BR>In the echo of teamsters' calls and the clinking chains, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the music of choppers' axes,



<P>&nbsp;The falling trunk and limbs, the crash, the muffled shriek,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the groan,

<BR>Such words combined from the redwood-tree, as of voices

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ecstatic, ancient and rustling,

<BR>The century-lasting, unseen dryads, singing, withdrawing,

<BR>All their recesses of forests and mountains leaving,

<BR>From the Cascade range to the Wasatch, or Idaho far, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Utah,

<BR>To the deities of the modern henceforth yielding,

<BR>The chorus and indications, the vistas of coming humanity,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the settlements, features all,

<BR>In the Mendocino woods I caught.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>The flashing and golden pageant of California,

<BR>The sudden and gorgeous drama, the sunny and ample lands,

<BR>The long and varied stretch from Puget sound to Colorado

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; south,

<BR>Lands bathed in sweeter, rarer, healthier air, valleys and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mountain cliffs,

<BR>The fields of Nature long prepared and fallow, the silent,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cyclic chemistry,

<BR>The slow and steady ages plodding, the unoccupied surface

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ripening, the rich ores forming beneath;

<BR>At last the New arriving, assuming, taking possession,

<BR>A swarming and busy race settling and organizing everywhere,

<BR>Ships coming in from the whole round world, and going out

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to the whole world,

<BR>To India and China and Australia and the thousand island

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; paradises of the Pacific,

<BR>Populous cities, the latest inventions, the steamers on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rivers, the railroads, with many a thrifty

farm, with machinery,

<BR>And wood and wheat and the grape, and diggings of yellow gold.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>But more in you than these, lands of the Western shore,

<BR>(These but the means, the implements, the standing-ground,)



<P>&nbsp;I see in you, certain to come, the promise of thousands of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; years, till now deferr'd,

<BR>Promis'd to be fulfill'd, our common kind, the race.



<P>&nbsp;The new society at last, proportionate to Nature,

<BR>In man of you, more than your mountain peaks or stalwart

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trees imperial,

<BR>In woman more, far more, than all your gold or vines, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; even vital air.



<P>&nbsp;Fresh come, to a new world indeed, yet long prepared,

<BR>I see the genius of the modern, child of the real and ideal,

<BR>Clearing the ground for broad humanity, the true America,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heir of the past so grand,

<BR>To build a grander future.

<PRE>1874&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Song of Myself</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Song of Myself</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>CELEBRATE</FONT> myself, and sing myself,

<BR>And what I assume you shall assume,

<BR>For every atom belonging to me as good belongs to you.



<P>&nbsp;I loafe and invite my soul,

<BR>I lean and loafe at my ease observing a spear of summer grass.



<P>&nbsp;My tongue, every atom of my blood, form'd from this soil,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this air,

<BR>Born here of parents born here from parents the same, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their parents the same,

<BR>I, now thirty-seven years old in perfect health begin,

<BR>Hoping to cease not till death.



<P>&nbsp;Creeds and schools in abeyance,

<BR>Retiring back a while sufficed at what they are, but never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forgotten,

<BR>I harbor for good or bad, I permit to speak at every hazard,

<BR>Nature without check with original energy.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Houses and rooms are full of perfumes, the shelves are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crowded with perfumes,

<BR>I breathe the fragrance myself and know it and like it,

<BR>The distillation would intoxicate me also, but I shall not let it.



<P>&nbsp;The atmosphere is not a perfume, it has no taste of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; distillation, it is odorless,

<BR>It is for my mouth forever, I am in love with it,

<BR>I will go to the bank by the wood and become undisguised

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and naked,

<BR>I am mad for it to be in contact with me.



<P>&nbsp;The smoke of my own breath,

<BR>Echoes, ripples, buzz'd whispers, love-root, silk-thread,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crotch and vine,

<BR>My respiration and inspiration, the beating of my heart, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; passing of blood and air through my lungs,

<BR>The sniff of green leaves and dry leaves, and of the shore and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dark-color'd sea-rocks, and of hay in the

barn,

<BR>The sound of the belch'd words of my voice loos'd to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eddies of the wind,

<BR>A few light kisses, a few embraces, a reaching around of arms,

<BR>The play of shine and shade on the trees as the supple boughs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wag,

<BR>The delight alone or in the rush of the streets, or along the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fields and hill-sides,

<BR>The feeling of health, the full-noon trill, the song of me rising

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from bed and meeting the sun.



<P>&nbsp;Have you reckon'd a thousand acres much? have you reckon'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the earth much?

<BR>Have you practis'd so long to learn to read?

<BR>Have you felt so proud to get at the meaning of poems?



<P>&nbsp;Stop this day and night with me and you shall possess the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; origin of all poems,

<BR>You shall possess the good of the earth and sun, (there are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; millions of suns left,)

<BR>You shall no longer take things at second or third hand, nor

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; look through the eyes of the dead, nor feed

on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spectres in books,

<BR>You shall not look through my eyes either, nor take things

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from me,

<BR>You shall listen to all sides and filter them from your self.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>I have heard what the talkers were talking, the talk of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beginning and the end,

<BR>But I do not talk of the beginning or the end.



<P>&nbsp;There was never any more inception than there is now,

<BR>Nor any more youth or age than there is now,

<BR>And will never be any more perfection than there is now,

<BR>Nor any more heaven or hell than there is now.



<P>&nbsp;Urge and urge and urge,

<BR>Always the procreant urge of the world.

<BR>Out of the dimness opposite equals advance, always

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; substance and increase, always sex,

<BR>Always a knit of identity, always distinction, always a breed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of life.



<P>&nbsp;To elaborate is no avail, learn'd and unlearn'd feel that it is

so.



<P>&nbsp;Sure as the most certain sure, plumb in the uprights, well

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; entretied, braced in the beams,

<BR>Stout as a horse, affectionate, haughty, electrical,

<BR>I and this mystery here we stand.



<P>&nbsp;Clear and sweet is my soul, and clear and sweet is all that is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not my soul.



<P>&nbsp;Lack one lacks both, and the unseen is proved by the seen,

<BR>Till that becomes unseen and receives proof in its turn.



<P>&nbsp;Showing the best and dividing it from the worst age vexes age,

<BR>Knowing the perfect fitness and equanimity of things, while

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they discuss I am silent, and go bathe and

admire myself.



<P>&nbsp;Welcome is every organ and attribute of me, and of any man

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hearty and clean,

<BR>Not an inch nor a particle of an inch is vile, and none shall be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; less familiar than the rest.



<P>&nbsp;I am satisfied &amp;emdash; I see, dance, laugh, sing;

<BR>As the hugging and loving bed-fellow sleeps at my side

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through the night, and withdraws at the peep

of the day

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with stealthy tread,

<BR>Leaving me baskets cover'd with white towels swelling the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; house with their plenty,

<BR>Shall I postpone my acceptation and realization and scream

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at my eyes,

<BR>That they turn from gazing after and down the road,

<BR>And forthwith cipher and show me to a cent,

<BR>Exactly the value of one and exactly the value of two, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; which is ahead?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>Trippers and askers surround me,

<BR>People I meet, the effect upon me of my early life or the ward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and city I live in, or the nation,

<BR>The latest dates, discoveries, inventions, societies, authors

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; old and new,

<BR>My dinner, dress, associates, looks, compliments, dues,

<BR>The real or fancied indifference of some man or woman I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; love,

<BR>The sickness of one of my folks or of myself, or ill-doing or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; loss or lack of money, or depressions or exaltations,

<BR>Battles, the horrors of fratricidal war, the fever of doubtful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; news, the fitful events;

<BR>These come to me days and nights and go from me again,

<BR>But they are not the Me myself.

<BR>Apart from the pulling and hauling stands what I am,

<BR>Stands amused, complacent, compassionating, idle,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unitary,

<BR>Looks down, is erect, or bends an arm on an impalpable

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; certain rest,

<BR>Looking with side-curved head curious what will come next,

<BR>Both in and out of the game and watching and wondering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at it.



<P>&nbsp;Backward I see in my own days where I sweated through fog

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with linguists and contenders,

<BR>I have no mockings or arguments, I witness and wait.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>I believe in you my soul, the other I am must not abase itself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to you,

<BR>And you must not be abased to the other.



<P>&nbsp;Loafe with me on the grass, loose the stop from your throat,

<BR>Not words, not music or rhyme I want, not custom or lecture,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not even the best,

<BR>Only the lull I like, the hum of your valved voice.



<P>&nbsp;I mind how once we lay such a transparent summer

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; morning,

<BR>How you settled your head athwart my hips and gently turn'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; over upon me,

<BR>And parted the shirt from my bosom-bone, and plunged your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tongue to my bare-stript heart,

<BR>And reach'd till you felt my beard, and reach'd till you held

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my feet.



<P>&nbsp;Swiftly arose and spread around me the peace and knowledge

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that pass all the argument of the earth,

<BR>And I know that the hand of God is the promise of my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; own,

<BR>And I know that the spirit of God is the brother of my own,

<BR>And that all the men ever born are also my brothers, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; women my sisters and lovers,



<P>&nbsp;And that a kelson of the creation is love,

<BR>And limitless are leaves stiff or drooping in the fields,

<BR>And brown ants in the little wells beneath them,

<BR>And mossy scabs of the worm fence, heap'd stones, elder,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mullein and poke-weed.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>A child said <I>What is the grass?</I> fetching it to me with full

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hands,

<BR>How could I answer the child? I do not know what it is any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more than he.



<P>&nbsp;I guess it must be the flag of my disposition, out of hopeful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; green stuff woven.



<P>&nbsp;Or I guess it is the handkerchief of the Lord,

<BR>A scented gift and remembrancer designedly dropt,

<BR>Bearing the owner's name someway in the corners, that we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; may see and remark, and say <I>Whose?</I>



<P>&nbsp;Or I guess the grass is itself a child, the produced babe of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; vegetation.



<P>&nbsp;Or I guess it is a uniform hieroglyphic,

<BR>And it means, Sprouting alike in broad zones and narrow

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; zones,

<BR>Growing among black folks as among white,

<BR>Kanuck, Tuckahoe, Congressman, Cuff, I give them the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; same, I receive them the same.



<P>&nbsp;And now it seems to me the beautiful uncut hair of graves.



<P>&nbsp;Tenderly will I use you curling grass,

<BR>It may be you transpire from the breasts of young men,

<BR>It may be if I had known them I would have loved them,

<BR>It may be you are from old people, or from offspring taken

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soon out of their mothers' laps,

<BR>And here you are the mothers' laps.



<P>&nbsp;This grass is very dark to be from the white heads of old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mothers,

<BR>Darker than the colourless beards of old men,

<BR>Dark to come from under the faint red roofs of mouths.



<P>&nbsp;O I perceive after all so many uttering tongues,

<BR>And I perceive they do not come from the roofs of mouths

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for nothing.



<P>&nbsp;I wish I could translate the hints about the dead young men

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and women,

<BR>And the hints about old men and mothers, and the offspring

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; taken soon out of their laps.



<P>&nbsp;What do you think has become of the young and old men?

<BR>And what do you think has become of the women and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; children?



<P>&nbsp;They are alive and well somewhere,

<BR>The smallest sprout shows there is really no death,

<BR>And if ever there was it led forward life, and does not wait at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the end to arrest it,

<BR>And ceas'd the moment life appear'd.



<P>&nbsp;All goes onward and outward, nothing collapses,

<BR>And to die is different from what any one supposed, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; luckier.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>Has any one supposed it lucky to be born?

<BR>I hasten to inform him or her it is just as lucky to die, and I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know it.



<P>&nbsp;I pass death with the dying and birth with the new-wash'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; babe, and am not contain'd between my hat

and boots,

<BR>And peruse manifold objects, no two alike and every one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; good,

<BR>The earth good and the stars good, and their adjuncts all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; good.



<P>&nbsp;I am not an earth nor an adjunct of an earth,

<BR>I am the mate and companion of people, all just as immortal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and fathomless as myself,

<BR>(They do not know how immortal, but I know.)



<P>&nbsp;Every kind for itself and its own, for me mine male and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; female,

<BR>For me those that have been boys and that love women,

<BR>For me the man that is proud and feels how it stings to be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slighted,



<P>&nbsp;For me the sweet-heart and the old maid, for me mothers and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the mothers of mothers,

<BR>For me lips that have smiled, eyes that have shed tears,

<BR>For me children and the begetters of children.



<P>&nbsp;Undrape! you are not guilty to me, nor stale nor discarded,

<BR>I see through the broadcloth and gingham whether or no,

<BR>And am around, tenacious, acquisitive, tireless, and cannot

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be shaken away.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>The little one sleeps in its cradle,

<BR>I lift the gauze and look a long time, and silently brush away

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flies with my hand.



<P>&nbsp;The youngster and the red-faced girl turn aside up the bushy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hill,

<BR>I peeringly view them from the top.



<P>&nbsp;The suicide sprawls on the bloody floor of the bedroom,

<BR>I witness the corpse with its dabbled hair, I note where the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pistol has fallen.



<P>&nbsp;The blab of the pave, tires of carts, sluff of boot-soles, talk

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the promenaders,

<BR>The heavy omnibus, the driver with his interrogating thumb,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the clank of the shod horses on the granite

floor,

<BR>The snow-sleighs, clinking, shouted jokes, pelts of snow-balls,

<BR>The hurrahs for popular favorites, the fury of rous'd mobs,

<BR>The flap of the curtain'd litter, a sick man inside borne to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hospital,

<BR>The meeting of enemies, the sudden oath, the blows and fall,

<BR>The excited crowd, the policeman with his star quickly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; working his passage to the centre of the crowd,

<BR>The impassive stones that receive and return so many echoes,

<BR>What groans of over-fed or half-starv'd who fall sunstruck or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in fits,

<BR>What exclamations of women taken suddenly who hurry

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; home and give birth to babes,



<P>&nbsp;What living and buried speech is always vibrating here, what

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; howls restrain'd by decorum,

<BR>Arrests of criminals, slights, adulterous offers made,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; acceptances, rejections with convex lips,

<BR>I mind them or the show or resonance of them&amp;emdash;I come and

I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; depart.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>9</CENTER>





<P>The big doors of the country barn stand open and ready,

<BR>The dried grass of the harvest-time loads the slow-drawn

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wagon,

<BR>The clear light plays on the brown gray and green intertinged,

<BR>The armfuls are pack'd to the sagging mow.



<P>&nbsp;I am there, I help, I came stretch'd atop of the load,

<BR>I felt its soft jolts, one leg reclined on the other,

<BR>I jump from the cross-beams and seize the clover and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; timothy,

<BR>And roll head over heels and tangle my hair full of wisps.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>10</CENTER>





<P>Alone far in the wilds and mountains I hunt,

<BR>Wandering amazed at my own lightness and glee,

<BR>In the late afternoon choosing a safe spot to pass the night,

<BR>Kindling a fire and broiling the fresh-kill'd game,

<BR>Falling asleep on the gather'd leaves with my dog and gun by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my side.



<P>&nbsp;The Yankee clipper is under her sky-sails, she cuts the sparkle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and scud,

<BR>My eyes settle the land, I bend at her prow or shout joyously

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from the deck.



<P>&nbsp;The boatmen and clam-diggers arose early and stopt for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>I tuck'd my trowser-ends in my boots and went and had a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; good time;

<BR>You should have been with us that day round the chowder-kettle.



<P>&nbsp;I saw the marriage of the trapper in the open air in the far

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; west, the bride was a red girl,

<BR>Her father and his friends sat near cross-legged and dumbly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; smoking, they had moccasins to their feet

and large

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thick blankets hanging from their shoulders,

<BR>On a bank lounged the trapper, he was drest mostly in skins,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his luxuriant beard and curls protected his

neck, he held

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his bride by the hand,

<BR>She had long eyelashes, her head was bare, her coarse straight

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; locks descended upon her voluptuous limbs

and reach'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to her feet.



<P>&nbsp;The runaway slave came to my house and stopt outside,

<BR>I heard his motions crackling the twigs of the woodpile,

<BR>Through the swung half-door of the kitchen I saw him limpsy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and weak,

<BR>And went where he sat on a log and led him in and assured

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him,

<BR>And brought water and fill'd a tub for his sweated body and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bruis'd feet,

<BR>And gave him a room that enter'd from my own, and gave

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him some coarse clean clothes,

<BR>And remember perfectly well his revolving eyes and his awkwardness,

<BR>And remember putting plasters on the galls of his neck and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ankles;

<BR>He staid with me a week before he was recuperated and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pass'd north,

<BR>I had him sit next me at table, my fire-lock lean'd in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; corner.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>11</CENTER>





<P>Twenty-eight young men bathe by the shore,

<BR>Twenty-eight young men and all so friendly;

<BR>Twenty-eight years of womanly life and all so lonesome.



<P>&nbsp;She owns the fine house by the rise of the bank,

<BR>She hides handsome and richly drest aft the blinds of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; window.



<P>&nbsp;Which of the young men does she like the best?

<BR>Ah the homeliest of them is beautiful to her.



<P>&nbsp;Where are you off to, lady? for I see you,

<BR>You splash in the water there, yet stay stock still in your room.



<P>&nbsp;Dancing and laughing along the beach came the twenty-ninth bather,

<BR>The rest did not see her, but she saw them and loved them.



<P>&nbsp;The beards of the young men glisten'd with wet, it ran from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their long hair,

<BR>Little streams pass'd all over their bodies.



<P>&nbsp;An unseen hand also pass'd over their bodies,

<BR>It descended tremblingly from their temples and ribs.



<P>&nbsp;The young men float on their backs, their white bellies bulge

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to the sun, they do not ask who seizes fast

to them,

<BR>They do not know who puffs and declines with pendant and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bending arch,

<BR>They do not think whom they souse with spray.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>12</CENTER>





<P>The butcher-boy puts off his killing-clothes, or sharpens his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; knife at the stall in the market,

<BR>I loiter enjoying his repartee and his shuffle and break-down.



<P>&nbsp;Blacksmiths with grimed and hairy chests environ the anvil,

<BR>Each has his main-sledge, they are all out, there is a great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heat in the fire.



<P>&nbsp;From the cinder-strew'd threshold I follow their movements,

<BR>The lithe sheer of their waists plays even with their massive

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arms,

<BR>Overhand the hammers swing, overhand so slow, overhand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; so sure,

<BR>They do not hasten, each man hits in his place.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>13</CENTER>





<P>The negro holds firmly the reins of his four horses, the block

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swags underneath on its tied-over chain,

<BR>The negro that drives the long dray of the stone-yard, steady

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and tall he stands pois'd on one leg on the

string-piece,

<BR>His blue shirt exposes his ample neck and breast and loosens

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; over his hip-band,

<BR>His glance is calm and commanding, he tosses the slouch of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his hat away from his forehead,

<BR>The sun falls on his crispy hair and mustache, falls on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; black of his polish'd and perfect limbs.



<P>&nbsp;I behold the picturesque giant and love him, and I do not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stop there,

<BR>I go with the team also.



<P>&nbsp;In me the caresser of life wherever moving, backward as well

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as forward sluing,

<BR>To niches aside and junior bending, not a person or object

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; missing,

<BR>Absorbing all to myself and for this song.



<P>&nbsp;Oxen that rattle the yoke and chain or halt in the leafy shade,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what is that you express in your eyes?

<BR>It seems to me more than all the print I have read in my life.



<P>&nbsp;My tread scares the wood-drake and wood-duck on my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; distant and day-long ramble,

<BR>They rise together, they slowly circle around.



<P>&nbsp;I believe in those wing'd purposes,

<BR>And acknowledge red, yellow, white, playing within me,

<BR>And consider green and violet and the tufted crown intentional,

<BR>And do not call the tortoise unworthy because she is not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; something else,

<BR>And the jay in the woods never studied the gamut, yet trills

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pretty well to me,

<BR>And the look of the bay mare shames silliness out of me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>14</CENTER>





<P>The wild gander leads his flock through the cool night,

<BR><I>Ya-honk</I> he says, and sounds it down to me like an invitation,

<BR>The pert may suppose it meaningless, but I listening close,

<BR>Find its purpose and place up there toward the wintry sky.



<P>&nbsp;The sharp-hoof'd moose of the north, the cat on the housesill,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the chickadee, the prairie-dog,

<BR>The litter of the grunting sow as they tug at her teats,

<BR>The brood of the turkey-hen and she with her half-spread

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wings,

<BR>I see in them and myself the same old law.



<P>&nbsp;The press of my foot to the earth springs a hundred

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; affections,

<BR>They scorn the best I can do to relate them.



<P>&nbsp;I am enamour'd of growing out-doors,

<BR>Of men that live among cattle or taste of the ocean or woods,

<BR>Of the builders and steerers of ships and the wielders of axes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and mauls, and the drivers of horses,

<BR>I can eat and sleep with them week in and week out.



<P>&nbsp;What is commonest, cheapest, nearest, easiest, is Me,

<BR>Me going in for my chances, spending for vast returns,

<BR>Adorning myself to bestow myself on the first that will take

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>Not asking the sky to come down to my good will,

<BR>Scattering it freely forever.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>15</CENTER>





<P>The pure contralto sings in the organ loft,

<BR>The carpenter dresses his plank, the tongue of his foreplane

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whistles its wild ascending lisp,

<BR>The married and unmarried children ride home to their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thanksgiving dinner,

<BR>The pilot seizes the king-pin, he heaves down with a strong

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arm,

<BR>The mate stands braced in the whale-boat, lance and harpoon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are ready,



<P>&nbsp;The duck-shooter walks by silent and cautious stretches,

<BR>The deacons are ordain'd with cross'd hands at the altar,

<BR>The spinning-girl retreats and advances to the hum of the big

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wheel,

<BR>The farmer stops by the bars as he walks on a First-day loafe

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and looks at the oats and rye,

<BR>The lunatic is carried at last to the asylum a confirm'd case,

<BR>(He will never sleep any more as he did in the cot in his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mother's bedroom;)

<BR>The jour printer with gray head and gaunt jaws works at his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; case,

<BR>He turns his quid of tobacco while his eyes blurr with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; manuscript;

<BR>The malform'd limbs are tied to the surgeon's table,

<BR>What is removed drops horribly in a pail;

<BR>The quadroon girl is sold at the auction-stand, the drunkard

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nods by the bar-room stove,

<BR>The machinist rolls up his sleeves, the policeman travels his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beat, the gate-keeper marks who pass,

<BR>The young fellow drives the express-wagon, (I love him,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; though I do not know him;)

<BR>The half-breed straps on his light boots to compete in the race,

<BR>The western turkey-shooting draws old and young, some lean

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on their rifles, some sit on logs,

<BR>Out from the crowd steps the marksman, takes his position,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; levels his piece;

<BR>The groups of newly-come immigrants cover the wharf or levee,

<BR>As the woolly-pates hoe in the sugar-field, the overseer views

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them from his saddle,

<BR>The bugle calls in the ball-room, the gentlemen run for their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; partners, the dancers bow to each other,

<BR>The youth lies awake in the cedar-roof'd garret and harks to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the musical rain,

<BR>The Wolverine sets traps on the creek that helps fill the Huron,

<BR>The squaw wrapt in her yellow-hemm'd cloth is offering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; moccasins and bead-bags for sale,

<BR>The connoisseur peers along the exhibition-gallery with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; half-shut eyes bent sideways,



<P>&nbsp;As the deck-hands make fast the steamboat the plank is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thrown for the shore-going passengers,

<BR>The young sister holds out the skein while the elder sister

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; winds it off in a ball, and stops now and

then for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; knots,

<BR>The one-year wife is recovering and happy having a week ago

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; borne her first child,

<BR>The clean-hair'd Yankee girl works with her sewing-machine

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or in the factory or mill,

<BR>The paving-man leans on his two-handed rammer, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reporter's lead flies swiftly over the note-book,

the signpainter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is lettering with blue and gold,

<BR>The canal boy trots on the tow-path, the book-keeper counts

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at his desk, the shoemaker waxes his thread,

<BR>The conductor beats time for the band and all the performers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; follow him,

<BR>The child is baptized, the convert is making his first professions,

<BR>The regatta is spread on the bay, the race is begun, (how the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; white sails sparkle!)

<BR>The drover watching his drove sings out to them that would stray,

<BR>The pedler sweats with his pack on his back, (the purchaser

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; higgling about the odd cent;)

<BR>The bride unrumples her white dress, the minute-hand of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clock moves slowly,

<BR>The opium-eater reclines with rigid head and just-open'd lips,

<BR>The prostitute draggles her shawl, her bonnet bobs on her

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tipsy and pimpled neck,

<BR>The crowd laugh at her blackguard oaths, the men jeer and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wink to each other,

<BR>(Miserable! I do not laugh at your oaths nor jeer you;)

<BR>The President holding a cabinet council is surrounded by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; great Secretaries,

<BR>On the piazza walk three matrons stately and friendly with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; twined arms,

<BR>The crew of the fish-smack pack repeated layers of halibut in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the hold,

<BR>The Missourian crosses the plains toting his wares and his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cattle,



<P>&nbsp;As the fare-collector goes through the train he gives notice by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the jingling of loose change,

<BR>The floor-men are laying the floor, the tinners are tinning the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; roof, the masons are calling for mortar,

<BR>In single file each shouldering his hod pass onward the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; laborers;

<BR>Seasons pursuing each other the indescribable crowd is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gather'd, it is the fourth of Seventh-month,

(what salutes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of cannon and small arms!)

<BR>Seasons pursuing each other the plougher ploughs, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mower mows, and the winter-grain falls in

the ground;

<BR>Off on the lakes the pike-fisher watches and waits by the hole

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the frozen surface,

<BR>The stumps stand thick round the clearing, the squatter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strikes deep with his axe,

<BR>Flatboatmen make fast towards dusk near the cotton-wood

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or pecan-trees,

<BR>Coon-seekers go through the regions of the Red river or through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those drain'd by the Tennessee, or through

those of the Arkansas,

<BR>Torches shine in the dark that hangs on the Chattahooche or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Altamahaw,

<BR>Patriarchs sit at supper with sons and grandsons and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; great-grandsons around them,

<BR>In walls of adobie, in canvas tents, rest hunters and trappers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; after their day's sport,

<BR>The city sleeps and the country sleeps,

<BR>The living sleep for their time, the dead sleep for their time,

<BR>The old husband sleeps by his wife and the young husband

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sleeps by his wife;

<BR>And these tend inward to me, and I tend outward to them,

<BR>And such as it is to be of these more or less I am,

<BR>And of these one and all I weave the song of myself.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>16</CENTER>





<P>I am of old and young, of the foolish as much as the wise,

<BR>Regardless of others, ever regardful of others,

<BR>Maternal as well as paternal, a child as well as a man,

<BR>Stuff'd with the stuff that is coarse and stuff'd with the stuff

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that is fine,



<P>&nbsp;One of the Nation of many nations, the smallest the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the largest the same,

<BR>A Southerner soon as a Northerner, a planter nonchalant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and hospitable down by the Oconee I live,

<BR>A Yankee bound my own way ready for trade, my joints the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; limberest joints on earth and the sternest

joints on earth,

<BR>A Kentuckian walking the vale of the Elkhorn in my deer-skin

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leggings, a Louisianian or Georgian,

<BR>A boatman over lakes or bays or along coasts, a Hoosier,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Badger, Buck-eye;

<BR>At home on Kanadian snow-shoes or up in the bush, or with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fishermen off Newfoundland,

<BR>At home in the fleet of ice-boats, sailing with the rest and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tacking,

<BR>At home on the hills of Vermont or in the woods of Maine,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or the Texan ranch,

<BR>Comrade of Californians, comrade of free North-Westerners,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (loving their big proportions,)

<BR>Comrade of raftsmen and coalmen, comrade of all who shake

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hands and welcome to drink and meat,

<BR>A learner with the simplest, a teacher of the thoughtfullest,

<BR>A novice beginning yet experient of myriads of seasons,

<BR>Of every hue and caste am I, of every rank and religion,

<BR>A farmer, mechanic, artist, gentleman, sailor, quaker,

<BR>Prisoner, fancy-man, rowdy, lawyer, physician, priest.



<P>&nbsp;I resist any thing better than my own diversity,

<BR>Breathe the air but leave plenty after me,

<BR>And am not stuck up, and am in my place.



<P>&nbsp;(The moth and the fish-eggs are in their place,

<BR>The bright suns I see and the dark suns I cannot see are in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their place,

<BR>The palpable is in its place and the impalpable is in its place.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>17</CENTER>





<P>These are really the thoughts of all men in all ages and lands,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they are not original with me,

<BR>If they are not yours as much as mine they are nothing, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; next to nothing,



<P>&nbsp;If they are not the riddle and the untying of the riddle they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are nothing,

<BR>If they are not just as close as they are distant they are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nothing.



<P>&nbsp;This is the grass that grows wherever the land is and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; water is,

<BR>This the common air that bathes the globe.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>18</CENTER>





<P>With music strong I come, with my cornets and my drums,

<BR>I play not marches for accepted victors only, I play marches

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for conquer'd and slain persons.



<P>&nbsp;Have you heard that it was good to gain the day?

<BR>I also say it is good to fall, battles are lost in the same spirit

in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; which they are won.



<P>&nbsp;I beat and pound for the dead,

<BR>I blow through my embouchures my loudest and gayest for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them.



<P>&nbsp;Vivas to those who have fail'd!

<BR>And to those whose war-vessels sank in the sea!

<BR>And to those themselves who sank in the sea!

<BR>And to all generals that lost engagements, and all overcome

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heroes!

<BR>And the numberless unknown heroes equal to the greatest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heroes known!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>19</CENTER>





<P>This is the meal equally set, this the meat for natural hunger,

<BR>It is for the wicked just the same as the righteous, I make

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; appointments with all,

<BR>I will not have a single person slighted or left away,

<BR>The kept-woman, sponger, thief, are hereby invited,

<BR>The heavy-lipp'd slave is invited, the venerealee is invited;

<BR>There shall be no difference between them and the rest.



<P>&nbsp;This is the press of a bashful hand, this the float and odor of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hair,



<P>&nbsp;This the touch of my lips to yours, this the murmur of yearning,

<BR>This the far-off depth and height reflecting my own face,

<BR>This the thoughtful merge of myself, and the outlet again.



<P>&nbsp;Do you guess I have some intricate purpose?

<BR>Well I have, for the Fourth-month showers have, and the mica

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on the side of a rock has.



<P>&nbsp;Do you take it I would astonish?

<BR>Does the daylight astonish? does the early redstart twittering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through the woods?

<BR>Do I astonish more than they?



<P>&nbsp;This hour I tell things in confidence,

<BR>I might not tell everybody, but I will tell you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>20</CENTER>





<P>Who goes there? hankering, gross, mystical, nude;

<BR>How is it I extract strength from the beef I eat?



<P>&nbsp;What is a man anyhow? what am I? what are you?



<P>&nbsp;All I mark as my own you shall offset it with your own,

<BR>Else it were time lost listening to me.



<P>&nbsp;I do not snivel that snivel the world over,

<BR>That months are vacuums and the ground but wallow and filth.



<P>&nbsp;Whimpering and truckling fold with powders for invalids,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; conformity goes to the fourth-remov'd,

<BR>I wear my hat as I please indoors or out.



<P>&nbsp;Why should I pray? why should I venerate and be ceremonious?



<P>&nbsp;Having pried through the strata, analyzed to a hair, counsel'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with doctors and calculated close,

<BR>I find no sweeter fat than sticks to my own bones.



<P>&nbsp;In all people I see myself, none more and not one a barley-corn

less,

<BR>And the good or bad I say of myself I say of them.



<P>&nbsp;I know I am solid and sound,

<BR>To me the converging objects of the universe perpetually flow,

<BR>All are written to me, and I must get what the writing means.



<P>&nbsp;I know I am deathless,

<BR>I know this orbit of mine cannot be swept by a carpenter's compass,

<BR>I know I shall not pass like a child's carlacue cut with a burnt

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stick at night.



<P>&nbsp;I know I am august,

<BR>I do not trouble my spirit to vindicate itself or be understood,

<BR>I see that the elementary laws never apologize,

<BR>(I reckon I behave no prouder than the level I plant my house

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by, after all.)



<P>&nbsp;I exist as I am, that is enough,

<BR>If no other in the world be aware I sit content,

<BR>And if each and all be aware I sit content.



<P>&nbsp;One world is aware and by far the largest to me, and that is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself,

<BR>And whether I come to my own to-day or in ten thousand or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ten million years,

<BR>I can cheerfully take it now, or with equal cheerfulness I can

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wait.



<P>&nbsp;My foothold is tenon'd and mortis'd in granite,

<BR>I laugh at what you call dissolution,

<BR>And I know the amplitude of time.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>21</CENTER>





<P>I am the poet of the Body and I am the poet of the Soul,

<BR>The pleasures of heaven are with me and the pains of hell are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with me,

<BR>The first I graft and increase upon myself, the latter I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; translate into a new tongue.



<P>&nbsp;I am the poet of the woman the same as the man,

<BR>And I say it is as great to be a woman as to be a man,

<BR>And I say there is nothing greater than the mother of men.



<P>&nbsp;I chant the chant of dilation or pride,

<BR>We have had ducking and deprecating about enough,

<BR>I show that size is only development.



<P>&nbsp;Have you outstript the rest? are you the President?

<BR>It is a trifle, they will more than arrive there every one, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; still pass on.



<P>&nbsp;I am he that walks with the tender and growing night,

<BR>I call to the earth and sea half-held by the night.



<P>&nbsp;Press close bare-bosom'd night&amp;emdash;press close magnetic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nourishing night!

<BR>Night of south winds&amp;emdash;night of the large few stars!

<BR>Still nodding night&amp;emdash;mad naked summer night.



<P>&nbsp;Smile O voluptuous cool-breath'd earth!

<BR>Earth of the slumbering and liquid trees!

<BR>Earth of departed sunset&amp;emdash;earth of the mountains misty-topt!

<BR>Earth of the vitreous pour of the full moon just tinged with blue!

<BR>Earth of shine and dark mottling the tide of the river!

<BR>Earth of the limpid gray of clouds brighter and clearer for my sake!

<BR>Far-swooping elbow'd earth&amp;emdash;rich apple-blossom'd earth!

<BR>Smile, for your lover comes.



<P>&nbsp;Prodigal, you have given me love&amp;emdash;therefore I to you

give

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; love!

<BR>O unspeakable passionate love.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>22</CENTER>





<P>You sea! I resign myself to you also&amp;emdash;I guess what you mean,

<BR>I behold from the beach your crooked inviting fingers,

<BR>I believe you refuse to go back without feeling of me,

<BR>We must have a turn together, I undress, hurry me out of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sight of the land,

<BR>Cushion me soft, rock me in billowy drowse,

<BR>Dash me with amorous wet, I can repay you.



<P>&nbsp;Sea of stretch'd ground-swells,

<BR>Sea breathing broad and convulsive breaths,

<BR>Sea of the brine of life and of unshovell'd yet always-ready

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; graves,

<BR>Howler and scooper of storms, capricious and dainty sea,

<BR>I am integral with you, I too am of one phase and of all phases.



<P>&nbsp;Partaker of influx and efflux, I, extoller of hate and conciliation,

<BR>Extoller of amies and those that sleep in each others' arms.



<P>&nbsp;I am he attesting sympathy,

<BR>(Shall I make my list of things in the house and skip the house

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that supports them?)



<P>&nbsp;I am not the poet of goodness only, I do not decline to be the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poet of wickedness also.



<P>&nbsp;What blurt is this about virtue and about vice?

<BR>Evil propels me and reform of evil propels me, I stand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indifferent,

<BR>My gait is no fault-finder's or rejecter's gait,

<BR>I moisten the roots of all that has grown.



<P>&nbsp;Did you fear some scrofula out of the unflagging pregnancy?

<BR>Did you guess the celestial laws are yet to be work'd over and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rectified?



<P>&nbsp;I find one side a balance and the antipodal side a balance,

<BR>Soft doctrine as steady help as stable doctrine,

<BR>Thoughts and deeds of the present our rouse and early start.



<P>&nbsp;This minute that comes to me over the past decillions,

<BR>There is no better than it and now.



<P>&nbsp;What behaved well in the past or behaves well to-day is not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; such a wonder,

<BR>The wonder is always and always how there can be a mean

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; man or an infidel.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>23</CENTER>





<P>Endless unfolding of words of ages!

<BR>And mine a word of the modern, the word En-Masse.



<P>&nbsp;A word of the faith that never balks,

<BR>Here or henceforward it is all the same to me, I accept Time

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; absolutely.



<P>&nbsp;It alone is without flaw, it alone rounds and completes all,

<BR>That mystic baffling wonder alone completes all.



<P>&nbsp;I accept Reality and dare not question it,

<BR>Materialism first and last imbuing.



<P>&nbsp;Hurrah for positive science! long live exact demonstration!

<BR>Fetch stonecrop mixt with cedar and branches of lilac,

<BR>This is the lexicographer, this the chemist, this made a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grammar of the old cartouches,

<BR>These mariners put the ship through dangerous unknown

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seas,

<BR>This is the geologist, this works with the scalpel, and this is a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mathematician.



<P>&nbsp;Gentlemen, to you the first honors always!

<BR>Your facts are useful, and yet they are not my dwelling,

<BR>I but enter by them to an area of my dwelling.



<P>&nbsp;Less the reminders of properties told my words,

<BR>And more the reminders they of life untold, and of freedom

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and extrication,

<BR>And make short account of neuters and geldings, and favor

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men and women fully equipt,

<BR>And beat the gong of revolt, and stop with fugitives and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them that plot and conspire.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>24</CENTER>





<P>Walt Whitman, a kosmos, of Manhattan the son,

<BR>Turbulent, fleshy, sensual, eating, drinking and breeding.



<P>&nbsp;No sentimentalist, no stander above men and women or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; apart from them,

<BR>No more modest than immodest.



<P>&nbsp;Unscrew the locks from the doors!

<BR>Unscrew the doors themselves from their jambs!



<P>&nbsp;Whoever degrades another degrades me,

<BR>And whatever is done or said returns at last to me.



<P>&nbsp;Through me the afflatus surging and surging, through me the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; current and index.



<P>&nbsp;I speak the pass-word primeval, I give the sign of democracy,

<BR>By God! I will accept nothing which all cannot have their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; counterpart of on the same terms.



<P>&nbsp;Through me many long dumb voices,

<BR>Voices of the interminable generation of prisoners and slaves,

<BR>Voices of the diseas'd and despairing and of thieves and dwarfs,

<BR>Voices of cycles of preparation and accretion,

<BR>And of the threads that connect the stars, and of wombs and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the father-stuff,

<BR>And of the rights of them the others are down upon,

<BR>Of the deform'd, trivial, flat, foolish, despised,

<BR>Fog in the air, beetles rolling balls of dung.



<P>&nbsp;Through me forbidden voices,

<BR>Voices of sexes and lusts, voices veil'd and I remove the veil,

<BR>Voices indecent by me clarified and transfigur'd.



<P>&nbsp;I do not press my fingers across my mouth,

<BR>I keep as delicate around the bowels as around the head and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heart,

<BR>Copulation is no more rank to me than death is.



<P>&nbsp;I believe in the flesh and the appetites,

<BR>Seeing, hearing, feeling, are miracles, and each part and tag

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of me is a miracle.



<P>&nbsp;Divine am I inside and out, and I make holy whatever I touch

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or am touch'd from,

<BR>The scent of these arm-pits aroma finer than prayer,

<BR>This head more than churches, bibles, and all the creeds.



<P>&nbsp;If I worship one thing more than another it shall be the spread

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of my own body, or any part of it,

<BR>Translucent mould of me it shall be you!

<BR>Shaded ledges and rests it shall be you!

<BR>Firm masculine colter it shall be you!

<BR>Whatever goes to the tilth of me it shall be you!

<BR>You my rich blood! your milky stream pale strippings of my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life!

<BR>Breast that presses against other breasts it shall be you!

<BR>My brain it shall be your occult convolutions!

<BR>Root of wash'd sweet-flag! timorous pond-snipe! nest of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; guarded duplicate eggs! it shall be you!

<BR>Mix'd tussled hay of head, beard, brawn, it shall be you!

<BR>Trickling sap of maple, fibre of manly wheat, it shall be you!

<BR>Sun so generous it shall be you!

<BR>Vapors lighting and shading my face it shall be you!

<BR>You sweaty brooks and dews it shall be you!
