<BR>Winds whose soft-tickling genitals rub against me it shall be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you!

<BR>Broad muscular fields, branches of live oak, loving lounger in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my winding paths, it shall be you!

<BR>Hands I have taken, face I have kiss'd, mortal I have ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; touch'd, it shall be you.



<P>&nbsp;I dote on myself, there is that lot of me and all so luscious,

<BR>Each moment and whatever happens thrills me with joy,

<BR>I cannot tell how my ankles bend, nor whence the cause of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my faintest wish,

<BR>Nor the cause of the friendship I emit, nor the cause of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; friendship I take again.



<P>&nbsp;That I walk up my stoop, I pause to consider if it really be,

<BR>A morning-glory at my window satisfies me more than the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; metaphysics of books.



<P>&nbsp;To behold the day-break!

<BR>The little light fades the immense and diaphanous shadows,

<BR>The air tastes good to my palate.



<P>&nbsp;Hefts of the moving world at innocent gambols silently rising,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; freshly exuding,

<BR>Scooting obliquely high and low.



<P>&nbsp;Something I cannot see puts upward libidinous prongs,

<BR>Seas of bright juice suffuse heaven.



<P>&nbsp;The earth by the sky staid with, the daily close of their junction,

<BR>The heav'd challenge from the east that moment over my head,

<BR>The mocking taunt, See then whether you shall be master!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>25</CENTER>





<P>Dazzling and tremendous how quick the sun-rise would kill

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>If I could not now and always send sun-rise out of me.



<P>&nbsp;We also ascend dazzling and tremendous as the sun,

<BR>We found our own O my soul in the calm and cool of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day-break.



<P>&nbsp;My voice goes after what my eyes cannot reach,

<BR>With the twirl of my tongue I encompass worlds and volumes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of worlds.



<P>&nbsp;Speech is the twin of my vision, it is unequal to measure itself,

<BR>It provokes me forever, it says sarcastically,

<BR><I>Walt you contain enough, why don't you let it out then</I>?



<P>&nbsp;Come now I will not be tantalized, you conceive too much of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; articulation,

<BR>Do you not know O speech how the buds beneath you are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; folded?

<BR>Waiting in gloom, protected by frost,

<BR>The dirt receding before my prophetical screams,

<BR>I underlying causes to balance them at last,



<P>&nbsp;My knowledge my live parts, it keeping tally with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; meaning of all things,

<BR>Happiness, (which whoever hears me let him or her set out in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; search of this day.)



<P>&nbsp;My final merit I refuse you, I refuse putting from me what I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; really am,

<BR>Encompass worlds, but never try to encompass me,

<BR>I crowd your sleekest and best by simply looking toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you.



<P>&nbsp;Writing and talk do not prove me,

<BR>I carry the plenum of proof and every thing else in my face,

<BR>With the hush of my lips I wholly confound the skeptic.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>26</CENTER>





<P>Now I will do nothing but listen,

<BR>To accrue what I hear into this song, to let sounds contribute

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; toward it.



<P>&nbsp;I hear bravuras of birds, bustle of growing wheat, gossip of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flames, clack of sticks cooking my meals.

<BR>I hear the sound I love, the sound of the human voice,

<BR>I hear all sounds running together, combined, fused or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; following,

<BR>Sounds of the city and sounds out of the city, sounds of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day and night,

<BR>Talkative young ones to those that like them, the loud laugh

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of work-people at their meals,

<BR>The angry base of disjointed friendship, the faint tones of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sick,

<BR>The judge with hands tight to the desk, his pallid lips

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pronouncing a death-sentence,

<BR>The heave'e'yo of stevedores unlading ships by the wharves,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the refrain of the anchor-lifters,

<BR>The ring of alarm-bells, the cry of fire, the whirr of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swift-streaking engines and hose-carts with

premonitory

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tinkles and color'd lights,

<BR>The steam-whistle, the solid roll of the train of approaching

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cars,



<P>&nbsp;The slow march play'd at the head of the association marching

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; two and two,

<BR>(They go to guard some corpse, the flag-tops are draped with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; black muslin.)



<P>&nbsp;I hear the violoncello, ('tis the young man's heart's complaint,)

<BR>I hear the key'd cornet, it glides quickly in through my ears,

<BR>It shakes mad-sweet pangs through my belly and breast.



<P>&nbsp;I hear the chorus, it is a grand opera,

<BR>Ah this indeed is music&amp;emdash;this suits me.



<P>&nbsp;A tenor large and fresh as the creation fills me,

<BR>The orbic flex of his mouth is pouring and filling me full.



<P>&nbsp;I hear the train'd soprano (what work with hers is this?)

<BR>The orchestra whirls me wider than Uranus flies,

<BR>It wrenches such ardors from me I did not know I possess'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>It sails me, I dab with bare feet, they are lick'd by the indolent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waves,

<BR>I am cut by bitter and angry hail, I lose my breath,

<BR>Steep'd amid honey'd morphine, my windpipe throttled in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fakes of death,

<BR>At length let up again to feel the puzzle of puzzles,

<BR>And that we call Being.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>27</CENTER>





<P>To be in any form, what is that?

<BR>(Round and round we go, all of us, and ever come back

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thither,)

<BR>If nothing lay more develop'd the quahaug in its callous shell

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; were enough.



<P>&nbsp;Mine is no callous shell,

<BR>I have instant conductors all over me whether I pass or stop,

<BR>They seize every object and lead it harmlessly through me.



<P>&nbsp;I merely stir, press, feel with my fingers, and am happy,

<BR>To touch my person to some one else's is about as much as I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; can stand.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>28</CENTER>





<P>Is this then a touch? quivering me to a new identity,

<BR>Flames and ether making a rush for my veins,

<BR>Treacherous tip of me reaching and crowding to help them,

<BR>My flesh and blood playing out lightning to strike what is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hardly different from myself,

<BR>On all sides prurient provokers stiffening my limbs,

<BR>Straining the udder of my heart for its withheld drip,

<BR>Behaving licentious toward me, taking no denial,

<BR>Depriving me of my best as for a purpose,

<BR>Unbuttoning my clothes, holding me by the bare waist,

<BR>Deluding my confusion with the calm of the sunlight and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pasture-fields,

<BR>Immodestly sliding the fellow-senses away,

<BR>They bribed to swap off with touch and go and graze at the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; edges of me,

<BR>No consideration, no regard for my draining strength or my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; anger,

<BR>Fetching the rest of the herd around to enjoy them a while,

<BR>Then all uniting to stand on a headland and worry me.



<P>&nbsp;The sentries desert every other part of me,

<BR>They have left me helpless to a red marauder,

<BR>They all come to the headland to witness and assist against

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me.



<P>&nbsp;I am given up by traitors,

<BR>I talk wildly, I have lost my wits, I and nobody else am the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; greatest traitor,

<BR>I went myself first to the headland, my own hands carried me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there.



<P>&nbsp;You villain touch! what are you doing? my breath is tight in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; its throat,

<BR>Unclench your floodgates, you are too much for me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>29</CENTER>





<P>Blind loving wrestling touch, sheath'd hooded sharp-tooth'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; touch!

<BR>Did it make you ache so, leaving me?



<P>&nbsp;Parting track'd by arriving, perpetual payment of perpetual

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; loan,

<BR>Rich showering rain, and recompense richer afterward.



<P>&nbsp;Sprouts take and accumulate, stand by the curb prolific and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; vital,

<BR>Landscapes projected masculine, full-sized and golden.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>30</CENTER>





<P>All truths wait in all things,

<BR>They neither hasten their own delivery nor resist it,

<BR>They do not need the obstetric forceps of the surgeon,

<BR>The insignificant is as big to me as any,

<BR>(What is less or more than a touch?)



<P>&nbsp;Logic and sermons never convince,

<BR>The damp of the night drives deeper into my soul.



<P>&nbsp;(Only what proves itself to every man and woman is so,

<BR>Only what nobody denies is so.)



<P>&nbsp;A minute and a drop of me settle my brain,

<BR>I believe the soggy clods shall become lovers and lamps,

<BR>And a compend of compends is the meat of a man or woman,

<BR>And a summit and flower there is the feeling they have for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; each other,

<BR>And they are to branch boundlessly out of that lesson until it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; becomes omnific,

<BR>And until one and all shall delight us, and we them.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>31</CENTER>





<P>I believe a leaf of grass is no less than the journey-work of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the stars,

<BR>And the pismire is equally perfect, and a grain of sand, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the egg of the wren,

<BR>And the tree-toad is a chef-d'oeuvre for the highest,

<BR>And the running blackberry would adorn the parlors of heaven,

<BR>And the narrowest hinge in my hand puts to scorn all machinery,



<P>&nbsp;And the cow crunching with depress'd head surpasses any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; statue,

<BR>And a mouse is miracle enough to stagger sextillions of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; infidels.



<P>&nbsp;I find I incorporate gneiss, coal, long-threaded moss, fruits,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grains, esculent roots,

<BR>And am stucco'd with quadrupeds and birds all over,

<BR>And have distanced what is behind me for good reasons,

<BR>But call any thing back again when I desire it.



<P>&nbsp;In vain the speeding or shyness,

<BR>In vain the plutonic rocks send their old heat against my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; approach,

<BR>In vain the mastodon retreats beneath its own powder'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bones,

<BR>In vain objects stand leagues off and assume manifold shapes,

<BR>In vain the ocean setting in hollows and the great monsters

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lying low,

<BR>In vain the buzzard houses herself with the sky,

<BR>In vain the snake slides through the creepers and logs,

<BR>In vain the elk takes to the inner passes of the woods,

<BR>In vain the razor-bill'd auk sails far north to Labrador,

<BR>I follow quickly, I ascend to the nest in the fissure of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cliff.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>32</CENTER>





<P>I think I could turn and live with animals, they're so placid

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and self-contain'd,

<BR>I stand and look at them long and long.



<P>&nbsp;They do not sweat and whine about their condition,

<BR>They do not lie awake in the dark and weep for their sins,

<BR>They do not make me sick discussing their duty to God,

<BR>Not one is dissatisfied, not one is demented with the mania of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; owning things,

<BR>Not one kneels to another, nor to his kind that lived thousands

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of years ago,

<BR>Not one is respectable or unhappy over the whole earth.



<P>&nbsp;So they show their relations to me and I accept them,

<BR>They bring me tokens of myself, they evince them plainly in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their possession.



<P>&nbsp;I wonder where they get those tokens,

<BR>Did I pass that way huge times ago and negligently drop

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them?



<P>&nbsp;Myself moving forward then and now and forever,

<BR>Gathering and showing more always and with velocity,

<BR>Infinite and omnigenous, and the like of these among them,

<BR>Not too exclusive toward the reachers of my remembrancers,

<BR>Picking out here one that I love, and now go with him on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brotherly terms.



<P>&nbsp;A gigantic beauty of a stallion, fresh and responsive to my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; caresses,

<BR>Head high in the forehead, wide between the ears,

<BR>Limbs glossy and supple, tail dusting the ground,

<BR>Eyes full of sparkling wickedness, ears finely cut, flexibly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; moving.



<P>&nbsp;His nostrils dilate as my heels embrace him,

<BR>His well-built limbs tremble with pleasure as we race around

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and return.

<BR>I but use you a minute, then I resign you, stallion,

<BR>Why do I need your paces when I myself out-gallop them?

<BR>Even as I stand or sit passing faster than you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>33</CENTER>





<P>Space and Time! now I see it is true, what I guess'd at,

<BR>What I guess'd when I loaf'd on the grass,

<BR>What I guess'd while I lay alone in my bed,

<BR>And again as I walk'd the beach under the paling stars of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; morning.



<P>&nbsp;My ties and ballasts leave me, my elbows rest in sea-gaps,

<BR>I skirt sierras, my palms cover continents,

<BR>I am afoot with my vision.



<P>&nbsp;By the city's quadrangular houses&amp;emdash;in log huts, camping

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with lumbermen,

<BR>Along the ruts of the turnpike, along the dry gulch and rivulet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bed,

<BR>Weeding my onion-patch or hoeing rows of carrots and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; parsnips, crossing savannas, trailing in forests,

<BR>Prospecting, gold-digging, girdling the trees of a new

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; purchase,

<BR>Scorch'd ankle-deep by the hot sand, hauling my boat down

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the shallow river,

<BR>Where the panther walks to and fro on a limb overhead, where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the buck turns furiously at the hunter,

<BR>Where the rattlesnake suns his flabby length on a rock, where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the otter is feeding on fish,

<BR>Where the alligator in his tough pimples sleeps by the bayou,

<BR>Where the black bear is searching for roots or honey, where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the beaver pats the mud with his paddle-shaped

tail;

<BR>Over the growing sugar, over the yellow-flower'd cotton

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; plant, over the rice in its low moist field,

<BR>Over the sharp-peak'd farm house, with its scallop'd scum

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and slender shoots from the gutters,

<BR>Over the western persimmon, over the long-leav'd corn, over

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the delicate blue-flower flax,

<BR>Over the white and brown buckwheat, a hummer and buzzer

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there with the rest,

<BR>Over the dusky green of the rye as it ripples and shades in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breeze;

<BR>Scaling mountains, pulling myself cautiously up, holding on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by low scragged limbs,

<BR>Walking the path worn in the grass and beat through the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leaves of the brush,

<BR>Where the quail is whistling betwixt the woods and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wheatlot,

<BR>Where the bat flies in the Seventh-month eve, where the great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gold-bug drops through the dark,

<BR>Where the brook puts out of the roots of the old tree and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flows to the meadow,

<BR>Where cattle stand and shake away flies with the tremulous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shuddering of their hides,



<P>&nbsp;Where the cheese-cloth hangs in the kitchen, where andirons

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; straddle the hearth-slab, where cobwebs fall

in festoons

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from the rafters;

<BR>Where trip-hammers crash, where the press is whirling its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cylinders,

<BR>Where the human heart beats with terrible throes under its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ribs,

<BR>Where the pear-shaped balloon is floating aloft, (floating in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it myself and looking composedly down,)

<BR>Where the life-car is drawn on the slip-noose, where the heat

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hatches pale-green eggs in the dented sand,

<BR>Where the she-whale swims with her calf and never forsakes it,

<BR>Where the steam-ship trails hind-ways its long pennant of smoke,

<BR>Where the fin of the shark cuts like a black chip out of the water,

<BR>Where the half-burn'd brig is riding on unknown currents,

<BR>Where shells grow to her slimy deck, where the dead are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; corrupting below;

<BR>Where the dense-starr'd flag is borne at the head of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; regiments,

<BR>Approaching Manhattan up by the long-stretching island,

<BR>Under Niagara, the cataract falling like a veil over my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; countenance,

<BR>Upon a door-step, upon the horse-block of hard wood

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; outside,

<BR>Upon the race-course, or enjoying picnics or jigs or a good

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; game of base-ball,

<BR>At he-festivals, with blackguard gibes, ironical license,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bull-dances, drinking, laughter,

<BR>At the cider-mill tasting the sweets of the brown mash,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sucking the juice through a straw,

<BR>At apple-peelings wanting kisses for all the red fruit I find,

<BR>At musters, beach-parties, friendly bees, huskings,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; house-raisings;

<BR>Where the mocking-bird sounds his delicious gurgles, cackles,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; screams, weeps,

<BR>Where the hay-rick stands in the barn-yard, where the dry-stalks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are scatter'd, where the brood-cow waits in

the hovel,



<P>&nbsp;Where the bull advances to do his masculine work, where the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stud to the mare, where the cock is treading

the hen,

<BR>Where the heifers browse, where geese nip their food with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; short jerks,

<BR>Where sun-down shadows lengthen over the limitless and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lonesome prairie,

<BR>Where herds of buffalo make a crawling spread of the square

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; miles far and near,

<BR>Where the humming-bird shimmers, where the neck of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long-lived swan is curving and winding,

<BR>Where the laughing-gull scoots by the shore, where she laughs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her near-human laugh,

<BR>Where bee-hives range on a gray bench in the garden half hid

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by the high weeds,

<BR>Where band-neck'd partridges roost in a ring on the ground

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with their heads out,

<BR>Where burial coaches enter the arch'd gates of a cemetery,

<BR>Where winter wolves bark amid wastes of snow and icicled

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trees,

<BR>Where the yellow-crown'd heron comes to the edge of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; marsh at night and feeds upon small crabs,

<BR>Where the splash of swimmers and divers cools the warm

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; noon,

<BR>Where the katy-did works her chromatic reed on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; walnut-tree over the wall,

<BR>Through patches of citrons and cucumbers with silver-wired

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leaves,

<BR>Through the salt-lick or orange glade, or under conical firs,

<BR>Through the gymnasium, through the curtain'd saloon,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through the office or public hall;

<BR>Pleas'd with the native and pleas'd with the foreign, pleas'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the new and old,

<BR>Pleas'd with the homely woman as well as the handsome,

<BR>Pleas'd with the quakeress as she puts off her bonnet and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; talks melodiously,

<BR>Pleas'd with the tune of the choir of the whitewash'd church,

<BR>Pleas'd with the earnest words of the sweating Methodist

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; preacher, impress'd seriously at the camp-meeting;

<BR>Looking in at the shop-windows of Broadway the whole

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forenoon, flatting the flesh of my nose on

the thick plate glass,



<P>&nbsp;Wandering the same afternoon with my face turn'd up to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clouds, or down a lane or along the beach,

<BR>My right and left arms round the sides of two friends, and I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the middle;

<BR>Coming home with the silent and dark-cheek'd bush-boy,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (behind me he rides at the drape of the day,)

<BR>Far from the settlements studying the print of animals' feet,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or the moccasin print,

<BR>By the cot in the hospital reaching lemonade to a feverish

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; patient,

<BR>Nigh the coffin'd corpse when all is still, examining with a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; candle;

<BR>Voyaging to every port to dicker and adventure,

<BR>Hurrying with the modern crowd as eager and flickle as any,

<BR>Hot toward one I hate, ready in my madness to knife him,

<BR>Solitary at midnight in my back yard, my thoughts gone from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me a long while,

<BR>Walking the old hills of Judaea with the beautiful gentle God

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by my side,

<BR>Speeding through space, speeding through heaven and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stars,

<BR>Speeding amid the seven satellites and the broad ring, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the diameter of eighty thousand miles,

<BR>Speeding with tail'd meteors, throwing fire-balls like the rest,

<BR>Carrying the crescent child that carries its own full mother in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; its belly,

<BR>Storming, enjoying, planning, loving, cautioning,

<BR>Backing and filling, appearing and disappearing,

<BR>I tread day and night such roads.



<P>&nbsp;I visit the orchards of spheres and look at the product,

<BR>And look at quintillions ripen'd and look at quintillions green.



<P>&nbsp;I fly those flights of a fluid and swallowing soul,

<BR>My course runs below the soundings of plummets.



<P>&nbsp;I help myself to material and immaterial,

<BR>No guard can shut me off, no law prevent me.



<P>&nbsp;I anchor my ship for a little while only,

<BR>My messengers continually cruise away or bring their returns

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me.



<P>&nbsp;I go hunting polar furs and the seal, leaping chasms with a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pike-pointed staff, clinging to topples of

brittle and blue.



<P>&nbsp;I ascend to the foretruck,

<BR>I take my place late at night in the crow's-nest,

<BR>We sail the arctic sea, it is plenty light enough,

<BR>Through the clear atmosphere I stretch around on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wonderful beauty,

<BR>The enormous masses of ice pass me and I pass them, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; scenery is plain in all directions,

<BR>The white-topt mountains show in the distance, I fling out

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my fancies toward them,

<BR>We are approaching some great battle-field in which we are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soon to be engaged,

<BR>We pass the colossal outposts of the encampment, we pass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with still feet and caution,

<BR>Or we are entering by the suburbs some vast and ruin'd city,

<BR>The blocks and fallen architecture more than all the living

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cities of the globe.



<P>&nbsp;I am a free companion, I bivouac by invading watchfires,

<BR>I turn the bridegroom out of bed and stay with the bride

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself,

<BR>I tighten her all night to my thighs and lips.



<P>&nbsp;My voice is the wife's voice, the screech by the rail of the stairs,

<BR>They fetch my man's body up dripping and drown'd.



<P>&nbsp;I understand the large hearts of heroes,

<BR>The courage of present times and all times,

<BR>How the skipper saw the crowded and rudderless wreck of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the steamship, and Death chasing it up and

down the storm,

<BR>How he knuckled tight and gave not back an inch, and was faithful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of days and faithful of nights,

<BR>And chalk'd in large letters on a board, <I>Be of good cheer, we</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; will not desert you;</I>



<P>&nbsp;How he follow'd with them and tack'd with them three days

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and would not give it up,

<BR>How he saved the drifting company at last,

<BR>How the lank loose-gown'd women look'd when boated

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from the side of their prepared graves,

<BR>How the silent old-faced infants and the lifted sick, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sharp-lipp'd unshaved men;

<BR>All this I swallow, it tastes good, I like it well, it becomes mine,

<BR>I am the man, I suffer'd, I was there.



<P>&nbsp;The disdain and calmness of martyrs,

<BR>The mother of old, condemn'd for a witch, burnt with dry

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wood, her children gazing on,

<BR>The hounded slave that flags in the race, leans by the fence,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blowing, cover'd with sweat,

<BR>The twinges that sting like needles his legs and neck, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; murderous buckshot and the bullets,

<BR>All these I feel or am.



<P>&nbsp;I am the hounded slave, I wince at the bite of the dogs,

<BR>Hell and despair are upon me, crack and again crack the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; marksmen,

<BR>I clutch the rails of the fence, my gore dribs, thinn'd with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ooze of my skin,

<BR>I fall on the weeds and stones,

<BR>The riders spur their unwilling horses, haul close,

<BR>Taunt my dizzy ears and beat me violently over the head with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whip-stocks.



<P>&nbsp;Agonies are one of my changes of garments,

<BR>I do not ask the wounded person how he feels, I myself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; become the wounded person,

<BR>My hurts turn livid upon me as I lean on a cane and observe.



<P>&nbsp;I am the mash'd fireman with breast-bone broken,

<BR>Tumbling walls buried me in their debris,

<BR>Heat and smoke I inspired, I heard the yelling shouts of my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; comrades,

<BR>I heard the distant click of their picks and shovels,

<BR>They have clear'd the beams away, they tenderly life me forth.



<P>&nbsp;I lie in the night air in my red shirt, the pervading hush is

for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my sake,

<BR>Painless after all I lie exhausted but not so unhappy,

<BR>White and beautiful are the faces around me, the heads are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bared of their fire-caps,

<BR>The kneeling crowd fades with the light of the torches.



<P>&nbsp;Distant and dead resuscitate,

<BR>They show as the dial or move as the hands of me, I am the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clock myself.



<P>&nbsp;I am an old artillerist, I tell of my fort's bombardment,

<BR>I am there again.



<P>&nbsp;Again the long roll of the drummers,

<BR>Again the attacking cannon, mortars,

<BR>Again to my listeing ears the cannon responsive.



<P>&nbsp;I take part, I see and hear the whole,

<BR>The cries, curses, roar, the plaudits for well-aim'd shots,

<BR>The ambulanza slowly passing trailing its red drip,

<BR>Workmen searching after damages, making indispensable

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; repairs,

<BR>The fall of grenades through the rent roof, the fan-shaped

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; explosion,

<BR>The whizz of limbs, heads, stone, wood, iron, high in the air.



<P>&nbsp;Again gurgles the mouth of my dying general, he furiously

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waves with his hand,

<BR>He gasps through the clot <I>Mind not me&amp;emdash;mind</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the entrenchments</I>.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>34</CENTER>





<P>Now I tell what I knew in Texas in my early youth,

<BR>(I tell not the fall of Alamo,

<BR>Not one escaped to tell the fall of Alamo,

<BR>The hundred and fifty are dumb yet at Alamo,)

<BR>'Tis the tale of the murder in cold blood of four hundred and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; twelve young men.



<P>&nbsp;Retreating they had form'd in a hollow square with their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; baggage for breastworks,

<BR>Nine hundred lives out of the surrounding enemy's, nine

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; times their number, was the price they took

in advance,

<BR>Their colonel was wounded and their ammunition gone,

<BR>They treated for an honorable capitulation, receiv'd writing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and seal, gave up their arms and march'd back

prisoners

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of war.



<P>&nbsp;They were the glory of the race of rangers,

<BR>Matchless with horse, rifle, song, supper, courtship,

<BR>Large, turbulent, generous, handsome, proud, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; affectionate,

<BR>Bearded, sunburnt, drest in the free costume of hunters,

<BR>Not a single one over thirty years of age.



<P>&nbsp;The second First-day morning they were brought out in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; squads and massacred, it was beautiful early

summer,

<BR>The work commenced about five o'clock and was over by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eight.



<P>&nbsp;None obey'd the command to kneel,

<BR>Some made a mad and helpless rush, some stood stark and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; straight,

<BR>A few fell at once, shot in the temple or heart, the living and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dead lay together,

<BR>The maim'd and mangled dug in the dirt, the new-comers saw

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them there,

<BR>Some half-kill'd attempted to crawl away,

<BR>These were despatch'd with bayonets or batter'd with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blunts of muskets.

<BR>A youth not seventeen years old seiz'd his assassin till two

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more came to release him,

<BR>The three were all torn and cover'd with the boy's blood.



<P>&nbsp;At eleven o'clock began the burning of the bodies;

<BR>That is the tale of the murder of the four hundred and twelve

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; young men.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>35</CENTER>





<P>Would you hear of an old-time sea-fight?

<BR>Would you learn who won by the light of the moon and stars?

<BR>List to the yarn, as my grandmother's father the sailor told it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me.



<P>&nbsp;Our foe was no skulk in his ship I tell you, (said he,)

<BR>His was the surly English pluck, and there is no tougher or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; truer, and never was, and never will be;

<BR>Along the lower'd eve he came horribly raking us.



<P>&nbsp;We closed with him, the yards entangled, the cannon touch'd,

<BR>My captain lash'd fast with his own hands.



<P>&nbsp;We had receiv'd some eighteen pound shots under the water,

<BR>On our lower-gun-deck two large pieces had burst at the first

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fire, killing all around and blowing up overhead.



<P>&nbsp;Fighting at sun-down, fighting at dark,

<BR>Ten o'clock at night, the full moon well up, our leaks on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gain, and five feet of water reported,

<BR>The master-at-arms loosing the prisoners confined in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; after-hold to give them a chance for themselves.



<P>&nbsp;The transit to and from the magazine is now stopt by the sentinels,

<BR>They see so many strange faces they do not know whom to trust.



<P>&nbsp;Our frigate takes fire,

<BR>The other asks if we demand quarter?

<BR>If our colors are struck and the fighting done?



<P>&nbsp;Now I laugh content, for I hear the voice of my little captain,

<BR><I>We have not struck</I>, he composedly cries, <I>we have just begun</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; our part of the fighting</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Only three guns are in use,

<BR>One is directed by the captain himself against the enemy's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; main-mast,

<BR>Two well serv'd with grape and canister silence his musketry

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and clear his decks.



<P>&nbsp;The tops alone second the fire of this little battery, especially

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the main-top,

<BR>They hold out bravely during the whole of the action.



<P>&nbsp;Not a moment's cease,

<BR>The leaks gain fast on the pumps, the fire eats toward the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; powder-magazine.



<P>&nbsp;One of the pumps has been shot away, it is generally thought

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; we are sinking.



<P>&nbsp;Serene stands the little captain,

<BR>He is not hurried, his voice is neither high nor low,

<BR>His eyes give more light to us than our battle-lanterns.



<P>&nbsp;Toward twelve there in the beams of the moon they surrender

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to us.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>36</CENTER>





<P>Stretch'd and still lies the midnight,

<BR>Two great hulls motionless on the breast of the darkness,

<BR>Our vessel riddled and slowly sinking, preparations to pass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to the one we have conquer'd,

<BR>The captain on the quarter-deck coldly giving his orders

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through a countenance white as a sheet,

<BR>Near by the corpse of the child that serv'd in the cabin,

<BR>The dead face of an old salt with long white hair and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; carefully curl'd whiskers,

<BR>The flames spite of all that can be done flickering aloft and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; below,

<BR>The husky voices of the two or three officers yet fit for duty,

<BR>Formless stacks of bodies and bodies by themselves, dabs of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flesh upon the masts and spars,

<BR>Cut of cordage, dangle of rigging, slight shock of the soothe

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of waves,

<BR>Black and impassive guns, litter of powder-parcels, strong

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; scent,

<BR>A few large stars overhead, silent and mournful shining,

<BR>Delicate sniffs of sea-breeze, smells of sedgy grass and fields

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by the shore, death-messages given in charge

to survivors,



<P>&nbsp;The hiss of the surgeon's knife, the gnawing teeth of his saw,

<BR>Wheeze, cluck, swash of falling blood, short wild scream, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long, dull, tapering groan,

<BR>These so, these irretrievable.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>37</CENTER>





<P>You laggards there on guard! look to your arms!

<BR>In at the conquer'd doors they crowd! I am possess'd!

<BR>Embody all presences outlaw'd or suffering,

<BR>See myself in prison shaped like another man,

<BR>And feel the dull unintermitted pain,

<BR>For me the keepers of convicts shoulder their carbines and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; keep watch,

<BR>It is I let out in the morning and barr'd at night.



<P>&nbsp;Not a mutineer walks handcuff'd to jail but I am handcuff'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to him and walk by his side,

<BR>(I am less the jolly one there, and more the silent one with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sweat on my twitching lips.)



<P>&nbsp;Not a youngster is taken for larceny but I go up too, and am

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tried and sentenced.



<P>&nbsp;Not a cholera patient lies at the last gasp but I also lie at

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; last gasp,

<BR>My face is ash-color'd, my sinews gnarl, away from me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; people retreat.



<P>&nbsp;Askers embody themselves in me and I am embodied in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>I project my hat, sit shame-faced, and beg.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>38</CENTER>





<P>Enough! enough! enough!

<BR>Somehow I have been stunn'd. Stand back!

<BR>Give me a little time beyond my cuff'd head, slumbers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dreams, gaping,

<BR>I discover myself on the verse of a usual mistake.



<P>&nbsp;That I could forget the mockers and insults!

<BR>That I could forget the trickling tears and the blows of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bludgeons and hammers!

<BR>That I could look with a separate look on my own crucifixion

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and bloody crowning!



<P>&nbsp;I remember now,

<BR>I resume the overstaid fraction,

<BR>The grave of rock multiplies what has been confided to it, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to any graves,

<BR>Corpses rise, gashes heal, fastenings roll from me.



<P>&nbsp;I troop forth replenish'd with supreme power, one of an

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; average unending procession,

<BR>Inland and sea-coast we go, and pass all boundary lines,

<BR>Our swift ordinances on their way over the whole earth,

<BR>The blossoms we wear in our hats the growth of thousands of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; years.



<P>&nbsp;Eleves, I salute you! come forward!

<BR>Continue your annotations, continue your questionings.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>39</CENTER>





<P>The friendly and flowing savage, who is he?

<BR>Is he waiting for civilization, or past it and mastering it?



<P>&nbsp;Is he some Southwesterner rais'd out-doors? is he Kanadian?

<BR>Is he from the Mississippi country? Iowa, Oregon, California?

<BR>The mountains? prairie-life, bush-life? or sailor from the sea?



<P>&nbsp;Wherever he goes men and women accept and desire him,

<BR>They desire he should like them, touch them, speak to them,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stay with them.



<P>&nbsp;Behavior lawless as snow-flakes, words simple as grass,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; uncomb'd head, laughter, and naivet&egrave;,

<BR>Slow-stepping feet, common features, common modes and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; emanations,

<BR>They descend in new forms from the tips of his fingers,



<P>&nbsp;They are wafted with the odor of his body or breath, they fly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; out of the glance of his eyes.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>40</CENTER>





<P>Flaunt of the sunshine I need not your bask&amp;emdash;lie over!

<BR>You light surfaces only, I force surfaces and depths also.



<P>&nbsp;Earth! you seem to look for something at my hands,

<BR>Say, old top-knot, what do you want?



<P>&nbsp;Man or woman, I might tell how I like you, but cannot,

<BR>And might tell what it is in me and what it is in you, but cannot,

<BR>And might tell that pining I have, that pulse of my nights and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; days.



<P>&nbsp;Behold, I do not give lectures or a little charity,

<BR>When I give I give myself.



<P>&nbsp;You there, impotent, loose in the knees,

<BR>Open your scarf'd chops till I blow grit within you,

<BR>Spread your palms and life the flaps of your pockets,

<BR>I am not to be denied, I compel, I have stores plenty and to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spare,

<BR>And any thing I have I bestow.



<P>&nbsp;I do not ask who you are, that is not important to me,

<BR>You can do nothing and be nothing but what I will infold

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you.



<P>&nbsp;To cotton-field drudge or cleaner of privies I lean,

<BR>On his right cheek I put the family kiss,

<BR>And in my soul I swear I never will deny him.



<P>&nbsp;On women fit for conception I start bigger and nimbler

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; babes,

<BR>(This day I am jetting the stuff of far more arrogant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; republics.)



<P>&nbsp;To any one dying, thither I speed and twist the knob of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; door,



<P>&nbsp;Turn the bed-clothes toward the foot of the bed,

<BR>Let the physician and the priest go home.



<P>&nbsp;I seize the descending man and raise him with resistless will,

<BR>O despairer, here is my neck,

<BR>By God, you shall not go down! hang your whole weight

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon me.



<P>&nbsp;I dilate you with tremendous breath, I buoy you up,

<BR>Every room of the house do I fill with an arm'd force,

<BR>Lovers of me, bafflers of graves.



<P>&nbsp;Sleep&amp;emdash;I and they keep guard all night,

<BR>Not doubt, not disease shall dare to lay finger upon you,

<BR>I have embraced you, and henceforth possess you to myself,

<BR>And when you rise in the morning you will find what I tell

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you is so.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>41</CENTER>





<P>I am he bringing help for the sick as they pant on their backs,

<BR>And for strong upright men I bring yet more needed help.



<P>&nbsp;I heard what was said of the universe,

<BR>Heard it and heard it of several thousand years;

<BR>It is middling well as far as it goes&amp;emdash;but is that all?



<P>&nbsp;Magnifying and applying come I,

<BR>Outbidding at the start the old cautious hucksters,

<BR>Taking myself the exact dimensions of Jehovah,

<BR>Lithographing Kronos, Zeus his son, and Hercules his grandson,

<BR>Buying drafts of Osiris, Isis, Belus, Brahma, Buddha,

<BR>In my portfolio placing Manito loose, Allah on a leaf, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crucifix engraved,

<BR>With Odin and the hideous-faced Mexitli and every idol and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; image,

<BR>Taking them all for what they are worth and not a cent more,

<BR>Admitting they were alive and did the work of their days,

<BR>(They bore mites as for unfledg'd birds who have now to rise

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and fly and sing for themselves,)



<P>&nbsp;Accepting the rough deific sketches to fill out better in myself,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bestowing them freely on each man and woman

I see,

<BR>Discovering as much or more in a framer framing a house,

<BR>Putting higher claims for him there with his roll'd-up sleeves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; driving the mallet and chisel,

<BR>Not objecting to special revelations, considering a curl of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; smoke or a hair on the back of my hand just

as curious

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as any revelation,

<BR>Lads ahold of fire-engines and hook-and-ladder ropes no less

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me than the gods of the antique wars,

<BR>Minding their voices peal through the crash of destruction,

<BR>Their brawny limbs passing safe over charr'd laths, their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; white foreheads whole and unhurt out of the

flames;

<BR>By the mechanic's wife with her babe at her nipple

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; interceding for every person born,

<BR>Three scythes at harvest whizzing in a row from three lusty

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; angels with shirts bagg'd out at their waists,

<BR>The snag-tooth'd hostler with red hair redeeming sins past

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and to come,

<BR>Selling all he possesses, traveling on foot to fee lawyers for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his brother and sit by him while he is tried

for forgery;

<BR>What was strewn in the amplest strewing the square rod

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; about me, and not filling the square rod then,

<BR>The bull and the bug never worshipp'd half enough,

<BR>Dung and dirt more admirable than was dream'd,

<BR>The supernatural of no account, myself waiting my time to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be one of the supremes,

<BR>The day getting ready for me when I shall do as much good

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as the best, and be as prodigious;

<BR>By my life-lumps! becoming already a creator,

<BR>Putting myself here and now to the ambush'd womb of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shadows.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>42</CENTER>





<P>A call in the midst of the crowd,

<BR>My own voice, orotund sweeping and final.



<P>&nbsp;Come my children,

<BR>Come my boys and girls, my women, household and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; intimates,



<P>&nbsp;Now the performer launches his nerve, he has pass'd his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prelude on the reeds within.



<P>&nbsp;Easily written loose-finger'd chords&amp;emdash;I feel the thrum

of your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; climax and close.



<P>&nbsp;My head slues round on my neck,

<BR>Music rolls, but not from the organ,

<BR>Folks are around me, but they are no household of mine.



<P>&nbsp;Ever the hard unsunk ground,

<BR>Ever the eaters and drinkers, ever the upward and downward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sun, ever the air and the ceaseless tides,

<BR>Ever myself and my neighbors, refreshing, wicked, real,

<BR>Ever the old inexplicable query, ever that thorn'd thumb,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that breath of itches and thirsts,

<BR>Ever the vexer's <I>hoot! hoot</I>! till we find where the sly one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hides and bring him forth,

<BR>Ever love, ever the sobbing liquid of life,

<BR>Ever the bandage under the chin, ever the trestles of death.



<P>&nbsp;Here and there with dimes on the eyes walking,

<BR>To feed the greed of the belly the brains liberally spooning,

<BR>Tickets buying, taking, selling, but in to the feast never once

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; going,

<BR>Many sweating, ploughing, thrashing, and then the chaff for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; payment receiving,

<BR>A few idly owning, and they the wheat continually claiming.



<P>&nbsp;This is the city and I am one of the citizens,

<BR>Whatever interests the rest interests me, politics, wars,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; markets, newspapers, schools,

<BR>The mayor and councils, banks, tariffs, steamships, factories,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stocks, stores, real estate and personal estate.



<P>&nbsp;The little plentiful manikins skipping around in collars and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tail'd coats,

<BR>I am aware who they are, (they are positively not worms or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fleas,)

<BR>I acknowledge the duplicates of myself, the weakest and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shallowest is deathless with me,



<P>&nbsp;What I do and say the same waits for them,

<BR>Every thought that flounders in me the same flounders in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them.



<P>&nbsp;I know perfectly well my own egotism,

<BR>Know my omnivorous lines and must not write any less,

<BR>And would fetch you whoever you are flush with myself.



<P>&nbsp;Not words of routine this song of mine,

<BR>But abruptly to question, to leap beyond yet nearer bring;

<BR>This printed and bound book&amp;emdash;but the printer and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; printing-office boy?

<BR>The well-taken photographs&amp;emdash;but your wife or friend close

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and solid in your arms?

<BR>The black ship mail'd with iron, her mighty guns in her

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; turrets&amp;emdash;but the pluck of the captain

and engineers?

<BR>In the houses the dishes and fare and furniture&amp;emdash;but the

host

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and hostess, and the look out of their eyes?

<BR>The sky up there&amp;emdash;yet here or next door, or across the way?

<BR>The saints and sages in history&amp;emdash;but you yourself?

<BR>Sermons, creeds, theology&amp;emdash;but the fathomless human brain,

<BR>And what is reason? and what is love? and what is life?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>43</CENTER>





<P>I do not despise you priests, all time, the world over,

<BR>My faith is the greatest of faiths and the least of faiths,

<BR>Enclosing worship ancient and modern and all between

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ancient and modern,

<BR>Believing I shall come again upon the earth after five

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thousand years,

<BR>Waiting responses from oracles, honoring the gods, saluting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sun,

<BR>Making a fetich of the first rock or stump, powowing with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sticks in the circle of obis,

<BR>Helping the llama or brahmin as he trims the lamps of the idols,

<BR>Dancing yet through the streets in a phallic procession, rapt

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and austere in the woods a gymnosophist,

<BR>Drinking mead from the skull-cup, to Shastas and Vedas

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; admirant, minding the Koran,



<P>&nbsp;Walking the teokallis, spotted with gore from the stone and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; knife, beating the serpent-skin drum,

<BR>Accepting the Gospels, accepting him that was crucified,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; knowing assuredly that he is divine,

<BR>To the mass kneeling or the puritan's prayer rising, or sitting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; patiently in a pew,

<BR>Ranting and frothing in my insane crisis, or waiting dead-like

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; till my spirit arouses me,

<BR>Looking forth on pavement and land, or outside of pavement

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and land,

<BR>Belonging to the winders of the circuit of circuits.



<P>&nbsp;One of that centripetal and centrifugal gang I turn and talk

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; like a man leaving charges before a journey.



<P>&nbsp;Down-hearted doubters dull and excluded,

<BR>Frivolous, sullen, moping, angry, affected, dishearten'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; atheistical,

<BR>I know every one of you, I know the sea of torment, doubt,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; despair and unbelief.



<P>&nbsp;How the flukes splash!

<BR>How they contort rapid as lightning, with spasms and spouts

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of blood!



<P>&nbsp;Be at peace bloody flukes of doubters and sullen mopers,

<BR>I take my place among you as much as among any,

<BR>The past is the push of you, me, all, precisely the same,

<BR>And what is yet untried and afterward is for you, me, all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; precisely the same.



<P>&nbsp;I do not know what is untried and afterward,

<BR>But I know it will in its turn prove sufficient, and cannot fail.



<P>&nbsp;Each who passes is consider'd, each who stops is consider'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not a single one can it fail.



<P>&nbsp;It cannot fail the young man who died and was buried,

<BR>Nor the young woman who died and was put by his side,

<BR>Nor the little child that peep'd in at the door, and then drew

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; back and was never seen again,



<P>&nbsp;Nor the old man who has lived without purpose, and feels it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with bitterness worse than gall,

<BR>Nor him in the poor house tubercled by rum and the bad disorder,

<BR>Nor the numberless slaughter'd and wreck'd, nor the brutish

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; koboo call'd the ordure of humanity,

<BR>Nor the sacs merely floating with open mouths for food to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slip in,

<BR>Nor any thing in the earth, or down in the oldest graves of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the earth,

<BR>Nor any thing in the myriads of spheres, nor the myriads of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myriads that inhabit them,

<BR>Nor the present, nor the least wisp that is known.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>44</CENTER>





<P>It is time to explain myself&amp;emdash;let us stand up.



<P>&nbsp;What is known I strip away,

<BR>I launch all men and women forward with me into the Unknown.



<P>&nbsp;The clock indicates the moment&amp;emdash;but what does eternity

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indicate?



<P>&nbsp;We have thus far exhausted trillions of winters and summers,

<BR>There are trillions ahead, and trillions ahead of them.



<P>&nbsp;Births have brought us richness and variety,

<BR>And other births will bring us richness and variety.



<P>&nbsp;I do not call one greater and one smaller,

<BR>That which fills its period and place is equal to any.



<P>&nbsp;Were mankind murderous or jealous upon you, my brother,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my sister?

<BR>I am sorry for you, they are not murderous or jealous upon me,

<BR>All has been gentle with me, I keep no account with lamentation,

<BR>(What have I to do with lamentation?)



<P>&nbsp;I am an acme of things accomplish'd, and I an encloser of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; things to be.



<P>&nbsp;My feet strike an apex of the apices of the stairs,

<BR>On every step bunches of ages, and larger bunches between

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the steps,

<BR>All below duly travel'd, and still I mount and mount.



<P>&nbsp;Rise after rise bow the phantoms behind me,

<BR>Afar down I see the huge first Nothing, I know I was even

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there,

<BR>I waited unseen and always, and slept through the lethargic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mist,

<BR>And took my time, and took no hurt from the fetid carbon.



<P>&nbsp;Long I was hugg'd close&amp;emdash;long and long.



<P>&nbsp;Immense have been the preparations for me,

<BR>Faithful and friendly the arms that have help'd me.



<P>&nbsp;Cycles ferried my cradle, rowing and rowing like cheerful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; boatmen,

<BR>For room to me stars kept aside in their own rings,

<BR>They sent influences to look after what was to hold me.



<P>&nbsp;Before I was born out of my mother generations guided me,

<BR>My embryo has never been torpid, nothing could overlay it.



<P>&nbsp;For it the nebula cohered to an orb,

<BR>The long slow strata piled to rest it on,

<BR>Vast vegetables gave it sustenance,

<BR>Monstrous sauroids transported it in their mouths and deposited

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it with care.



<P>&nbsp;All forces have been steadily employ'd to complete and delight

me,

<BR>Now on this spot I stand with my robust soul.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>45</CENTER>





<P>O span of youth! ever-push'd elasticity!

<BR>O manhood, balanced, florid and full.



<P>&nbsp;My lovers suffocate me,

<BR>Crowding my lips, thick in the pores of my skin,

<BR>Jostling me through streets and public halls, coming naked to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me at night,

<BR>Crying by day <I>Ahoy</I>! from the rocks of the river, swinging

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and chirping over my head,

<BR>Calling my name from flower-beds, vines, tangled underbrush,

<BR>Lighting on every moment of my life,

<BR>Bussing my body with soft balsamic busses,

<BR>Noiselessly passing handfuls out of their hearts and giving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them to be mine.



<P>&nbsp;Old age superbly rising! O welcome, ineffable grace of dying

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; days!



<P>&nbsp;Every condition promulges not only itself, it promulges what

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grows after and out of itself,

<BR>And the dark hush promulges as much as any.



<P>&nbsp;I open my scuttle at night and see the far-sprinkled systems,

<BR>And all I see multiplied as high as I can cipher edge but the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rim of the farther systems.



<P>&nbsp;Wider and wider they spread, expanding, always expanding,

<BR>Outward and outward and forever outward.



<P>&nbsp;My sun has his sun and round him obediently wheels,

<BR>He joins with his partners a group of superior circuit,

<BR>And greater sets follow, making specks of the greatest inside

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them.



<P>&nbsp;There is no stoppage and never can be stoppage,

<BR>If I, you, and the worlds, and all beneath or upon their surfaces,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; were this moment reduced back to a pallid

float, it would

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not avail in the long run,

<BR>We should surely bring up again where we now stand,

<BR>And surely go as much farther, and then farther and farther.



<P>&nbsp;A few quadrillions of eras, a few octillions of cubic leagues,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; do not hazard the span or make it impatient,

<BR>They are but parts, any thing is but a part.



<P>&nbsp;See ever so far, there is limitless space outside of that,

<BR>Count ever so much, there is limitless time around that.



<P>&nbsp;My rendezvous is appointed, it is certain,

<BR>The Lord will be there and wait till I come on perfect terms,

<BR>The great Camerado, the lover true for whom I pine will be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>46</CENTER>





<P>I know I have the best of time and space, and was never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; measured and never will be measured.



<P>&nbsp;I tramp a perpetual journey, (come listen all!)

<BR>My signs are a rain-proof coat, good shoes, and a staff cut

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from the woods,

<BR>No friend of mine takes his ease in my chair,

<BR>I have no chair, no church, no philosophy,

<BR>I lead no man to a dinner-table, library, exchange,

<BR>But each man and each woman of you I lead upon a knoll,

<BR>My left hand hooking you round the waist,

<BR>My right hand pointing to landscapes of continents and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; public road.



<P>&nbsp;Not I, not any one else can travel that road for you,

<BR>You must travel it for yourself.



<P>&nbsp;It is not far, it is within reach,

<BR>Perhaps you have been on it since you were born and did not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know,

<BR>Perhaps it is everywhere on water and on land.



<P>&nbsp;Shoulder your duds dear son, and I will mine, and let us

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hasten forth,

<BR>Wonderful cities and free nations we shall fetch as we go.



<P>&nbsp;If you tire, give me both burdens, and rest the chuff of your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hand on my hip,

<BR>And in due time you shall repay the same service to me,

<BR>For after we start we never lie by again.



<P>&nbsp;This day before dawn I ascended a hill and look'd at the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crowded heaven,

<BR>And I said to my spirit <I>When we become the enfolders of those</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; orbs, and the pleasure and knowledge of

every thing in</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them, shall we be fill'd and satisfied

then</I>?

<BR>And my spirit said <I>No, we but level that lift to pass and</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; continue beyond</I>.



<P>&nbsp;You are also asking me questions and I hear you,

<BR>I answer that I cannot answer, you must find out for yourself.



<P>&nbsp;Sit a while dear son,

<BR>Here are biscuits to eat and here is milk to drink,

<BR>But as soon as you sleep and renew yourself in sweet clothes,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I kiss you with a good-by kiss and open the

gate for your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; egress hence.



<P>&nbsp;Long enough have you dream'd contemptible dreams,

<BR>Now I wash the gum from your eyes,

<BR>You must habit yourself to the dazzle of the light and of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every moment of your life.



<P>&nbsp;Long have you timidly waded holding a plank by the shore,

<BR>Now I will you to be a bold swimmer,

<BR>To jump off in the midst of the sea, rise again, nod to me,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shout, and laughingly dash with your hair.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>47</CENTER>





<P>I am the teacher of athletes,

<BR>He that by me spreads a wider breast than my own proves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the width of my own,

<BR>He most honors my style who learns under it to destroy the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; teacher.



<P>&nbsp;The boy I love, the same becomes a man not through derived

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; power, but in his own right,

<BR>Wicked rather than virtuous out of conformity or fear,

<BR>Fond of his sweetheart, relishing well his steak,

<BR>Unrequited love or a slight cutting him worse than sharp

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steel cuts,



<P>&nbsp;First-rate to ride, to fight, to hit the bull's eye, to sail a

skiff,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to sing a song or play on the banjo,

<BR>Preferring scars and the beard and faces pitted with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; small-pox over all latherers,

<BR>And those well-tann'd to those that keep out of the sun.



<P>&nbsp;I teach straying from me, yet who can stray from me?

<BR>I follow you whoever you are from the present hour,

<BR>My words itch at your ears till you understand them.



<P>&nbsp;I do not say these things for a dollar or to fill up the time

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; while I wait for a boat,

<BR>(It is you talking just as much as myself, I act as the tongue of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you,

<BR>Tied in your mouth, in mine it begins to be loosen'd.)



<P>&nbsp;I swear I will never again mention love or death inside a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; house,

<BR>And I swear I will never translate myself at all, only to him or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her who privately stays with me in the open

air.



<P>&nbsp;If you would understand me go to the heights or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; water-shore,

<BR>The nearest gnat is an explanation, and a drop or motion of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waves a key,

<BR>The maul, the oar, the hand-saw, second my words.



<P>&nbsp;No shutter'd room or school can commune with me,

<BR>But roughs and little children better than they.



<P>&nbsp;The young mechanic is closest to me, he knows me well,

<BR>The woodman that takes his axe and jug with him shall take

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me with him all day,

<BR>The farm-boy ploughing in the field feels good at the sound

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of my voice,

<BR>In vessels that sail my words sail, I go with fishermen and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seamen and love them.



<P>&nbsp;The soldier camp'd or upon the march is mine,

<BR>On the night ere the pending battle many seek me, and I do

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not fail them,



<P>&nbsp;On that solemn night (it may be their last) those that know

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me seek me.



<P>&nbsp;My face rubs to the hunter's face when he lies down alone in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his blanket,

<BR>The driver thinking of me does not mind the jolt of his wagon,

<BR>The young mother and old mother comprehend me,

<BR>The girl and the wife rest the needle a moment and forget

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; where they are,

<BR>They and all would resume what I have told them.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>48</CENTER>





<P>I have said that the soul is not more than the body,

<BR>And I have said that the body is not more than the soul,

<BR>And nothing, not God, is greater to one than one's self is,

<BR>And whoever walks a furlong without sympathy walks to his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; own funeral drest in his shroud,

<BR>And I or you pocketless of a dime may purchase the pick of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the earth,

<BR>And to glance with an eye or show a bean in its pod

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; confounds the learning of all times,

<BR>And there is no trade or employment but the young man

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; following it may become a hero,

<BR>And there is no object so soft but it makes a hub for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wheel'd universe,

<BR>And I say to any man or woman, Let your soul stand cool

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and composed before a million universes.



<P>&nbsp;And I say to mankind, Be not curious about God,

<BR>For I who am curious about each am not curious about

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; God,

<BR>(No array of terms can say how much I am at peace about

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; God and about death.)



<P>&nbsp;I hear and behold God in every object, yet understand God

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not in the least,

<BR>Nor do I understand who there can be more wonderful than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself.



<P>&nbsp;Why should I wish to see God better than this day?

<BR>I see something of God each hour of the twenty-four, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; each moment then,

<BR>In the faces of men and women I see God, and in my own

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; face in the glass,

<BR>I find letters from God dropt in the street, and every one is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sign'd by God's name,

<BR>And I leave them where they are, for I know that wheresoe'er

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I go,

<BR>Others will punctually come for ever and ever.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>49</CENTER>





<P>And as to you Death, and you bitter hug of mortality, it is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; idle to try to alarm me.



<P>&nbsp;To his work without flinching the accoucheur comes,

<BR>I see the elder-hand pressing receiving supporting,

<BR>I recline by the sills of the exquisite flexible doors,

<BR>And mark the outlet, and mark the relief and escape.



<P>&nbsp;And as to you Corpse I think you are good manure, but that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; does not offend me,

<BR>I smell the white roses sweet-scented and growing,

<BR>I reach to the leafy lips, I reach to the polish'd breasts of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; melons.



<P>&nbsp;And as to you Life I reckon you are the leavings of many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; deaths,

<BR>(No doubt I have died myself ten thousand times before.)



<P>&nbsp;I hear you whispering there O stars of heaven,

<BR>O suns&amp;emdash;O grass of graves&amp;emdash;O perpetual transfers

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; promotions,

<BR>If you do not say any thing how can I say any thing?



<P>&nbsp;Of the turbid pool that lies in the autumn forest,

<BR>Of the moon that descends the steeps of the soughing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; twilight,

<BR>Toss, sparkles of day and dusk&amp;emdash;toss on the black stems that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; decay in the muck,

<BR>Toss to the moaning gibberish of the dry limbs.



<P>&nbsp;I ascend from the moon, I ascend from the night,

<BR>I perceive that the ghastly glimmer is noonday sunbeams

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reflected,

<BR>And debouch to the steady and central from the offspring

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; great or small.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>50</CENTER>





<P>There is that in me&amp;emdash;I do not know what it is&amp;emdash;but

I know it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is in me.



<P>&nbsp;Wrench'd and sweaty&amp;emdash;calm and cool then my body becomes,

<BR>I sleep&amp;emdash;I sleep long.



<P>&nbsp;I do not know it&amp;emdash;it is without name&amp;emdash;it is

a word unsaid,

<BR>It is not in any dictionary, utterance, symbol.



<P>&nbsp;Something it swings on more than the earth I swing on,

<BR>To it the creation is the friend whose embracing awakes me.



<P>&nbsp;Perhaps I might tell more. Outlines! I plead for my brothers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sisters.



<P>&nbsp;Do you see O my brothers and sisters?

<BR>It is not chaos or death&amp;emdash;it is form, union, plan&amp;emdash;it

is eternal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life&amp;emdash;it is Happiness.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>51</CENTER>





<P>The past and present wilt&amp;emdash;I have fill'd them, emptied them,

<BR>And proceed to fill my next fold of the future.



<P>&nbsp;Listener up there! what have you to confide to me?

<BR>Look in my face while I snuff the sidle of evening,

<BR>(Talk honestly, no one else hears you, and I stay only a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; minute longer.)



<P>&nbsp;Do I contradict myself?

<BR>Very well then I contradict myself,

<BR>(I am large, I contain multitudes.)



<P>&nbsp;I concentrate toward them that are nigh, I wait on the door-slab.



<P>&nbsp;Who has done his day's work? who will soonest be through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with his supper?

<BR>Who wishes to walk with me?



<P>&nbsp;Will you speak before I am gone? will you prove already too

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; late?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>52</CENTER>





<P>The spotted hawk swoops by and accuses me, he complains

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of my gab and my loitering.



<P>&nbsp;I too am not a bit tamed, I too am untranslatable,

<BR>I sound my barbaric yawp over the roofs of the world.



<P>&nbsp;The last scud of day holds back for me,

<BR>It flings my likeness after the rest and true as any on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shadow'd wilds,

<BR>It coaxes me to the vapor and the dusk.



<P>&nbsp;I depart as air, I shake my white locks at the runaway sun,

<BR>I effuse my flesh in eddies, and drift it in lacy jags.



<P>&nbsp;I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love,

<BR>If you want me again look for me under your boot-soles.



<P>&nbsp;You will hardly know who I am or what I mean,

<BR>But I shall be good health to you nevertheless,

<BR>And filter and fibre your blood.



<P>&nbsp;Failing to fetch me at first keep encouraged,

<BR>Missing me one place search another,

<BR>I stop somewhere waiting for you.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1855&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Inscriptions</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<B><I>Inscriptions</I></B></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ONE'S-SELF I SING</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>NE'S-SELF</FONT> I sing, a simple separate person,

<BR>Yet utter the word Democratic, the word En-Masse.



<P>&nbsp;Of physiology from top to toe I sing,

<BR>Not physiognomy alone nor brain alone is worthy for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Muse, I say the Form complete is worthier far,

<BR>The Female equally with the Male I sing.



<P>&nbsp;Of Life immense in passion, pulse, and power,

<BR>Cheerful, for freest action form'd under the laws divine,

<BR>The Modern Man I sing.

<PRE>1867&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AS I PONDER'D IN SILENCE</H2></CENTER>

As I ponder'd in silence,

<BR>Returning upon my poems, considering, lingering long,

<BR>A Phantom arose before me with distrustful aspect,

<BR>Terrible in beauty, age, and power,

<BR>The genius of poets of old lands,

<BR>As to me directing like flame its eyes,

<BR>With finger pointing to many immortal songs,

<BR>And menacing voice, <I>What singest thou</I>? it said,

<BR><I>Know'st thou not there is but one theme for ever-enduring bards</I>?

<BR><I>And that is the theme of War, the fortune of battles</I>,

<BR><I>The making of perfect soldiers</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Be it so</I>, then I answer'd,

<BR><I>I too haughty Shade also sing war, and a longer and greater one</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than any</I>,

<BR><I>Waged in my book with varying fortune, with flight, advance</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and retreat, victory deferr'd and wavering</I>,

<BR><I>(Yet methinks certain, or as good as certain, at the last,) the</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; field the world</I>,

<BR><I>For life and death, for the Body and for the eternal Soul</I>,

<BR><I>Lo, I too am come, chanting the chant of battles</I>,

<BR><I>I above all promote brave soldiers</I>.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

IN CABIN'D SHIPS AT SEA</H2></CENTER>

I<FONT SIZE=-1>N</FONT> cabin'd ships at sea,

<BR>The boundless blue on every side expanding,

<BR>With whistling winds and music of the waves, the large

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; imperious waves,

<BR>Or some lone bark buoy'd on the dense marine,

<BR>Where joyous full of faith, spreading white sails,

<BR>She cleaves the ether mid the sparkle and the foam of day, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; under many a star at night,

<BR>By sailors young and old haply will I, a reminiscence of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land, be read,

<BR>In full rapport at last.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Here are our thoughts, voyagers' thoughts</I>,

<BR><I>Here not the land, firm land, alone appears</I>, may then by them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be said,

<BR><I>The sky o'erarches here, we feel the undulating deck beneath</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; our feet</I>,

<BR><I>We feel the long pulsation, ebb and flow of endless motion</I>.

<BR><I>The tones of unseen mystery, the vague and vast suggestions of</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the briny world, the liquid-flowing syllables</I>,

<BR><I>The perfume, the faint creaking of the cordage, the melancholy</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rhythm</I>,

<BR><I>The boundless vista and the horizon far and dim are all here</I>,

<BR><I>And this is ocean's poem</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Then falter not O book, fulfil your destiny,

<BR>You not a reminiscence of the land alone,

<BR>You too as a lone bark cleaving the ether, purpos'd I know

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not whither, yet ever full of faith,

<BR>Consort to every ship that sails, sail you!

<BR>Bear forth to them folded my love, (dear mariners, for you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I fold it here in every leaf;)



<P>&nbsp;Speed on my book! spread your white sails my little bark

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; athwart the imperious waves,

<BR>Chant on, sail on, bear o'er the boundless blue from me to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every sea,

<BR>This song for mariners and all their ships.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO FOREIGN LANDS</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>HEARD</FONT> that you ask'd for something to prove this

puzzle the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; New World,

<BR>And to define America, her athletic Democracy,

<BR>Therefore I send you my poems that you behold in them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what you wanted.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO A HISTORIAN</H2></CENTER>

Y<FONT SIZE=-1>OU</FONT> who celebrate bygones,

<BR>Who have explored the outward, the surfaces of the races,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the life that has exhibited itself,

<BR>Who have treated of man as the creature of politics, aggregates,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rulers and priests,

<BR>I, habitan of the Alleghanies, treating of him as he is in himself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in his own rights,

<BR>Pressing the pulse of the life that has seldom exhibited itself,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (the great pride of man in himself),

<BR>Chanter of Personality, outlining what is yet to be,

<BR>I project the history of the future.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO THEE OLD CAUSE</H2></CENTER>

To thee old cause!

<BR>Thou peerless, passionate, good cause,

<BR>Thou stern, remorseless, sweet idea,

<BR>Deathless throughout the ages, races, lands,

<BR>After a strange sad war, great war for thee,

<BR>(I think all war through time was really fought, and ever will

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be really fought, for thee,)

<BR>These chants for thee, the eternal march of thee.



<P>&nbsp;(A war O soldiers not for itself alone,

<BR>Far, far more stood silently waiting behind, now to advance

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in this book.)



<P>&nbsp;Thou orb of many orbs!

<BR>Thou seething principle! thou well-kept, latent germ! thou

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; centre!

<BR>Around the idea of thee the war revolving,

<BR>With all its angry and vehement play of causes,

<BR>(With vast results to come for thrice a thousand years,)

<BR>These recitatives for thee,&amp;emdash;my book and the war are one,

<BR>Merged in its spirit I and mine, as the contest hinged on thee,

<BR>As a wheel on its axis turns, this book unwitting to itself,

<BR>Around the idea of thee.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

EID&Oacute;LONS</H2></CENTER>

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I <FONT SIZE=-1>MET</FONT> a seer,

<BR>Passing the hues and objects of the world,

<BR>The fields of art and learning, pleasure, sense,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To glean eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Put in thy chants said he,

<BR>No more the puzzling hour nor day, nor segments, parts, put

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in,

<BR>Put first before the rest as light for all and entrance-song of all,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; That of eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ever the dim beginning,

<BR>Ever the growth, the rounding of the circle,

<BR>Ever the summit and the merge at last, (to surely start again,)

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Eid&oacute;lons! eid&oacute;lons!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ever the mutable,

<BR>Ever materials, changing, crumbling, re-cohering,

<BR>Ever the ateliers, the factories divine,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Issuing eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Lo, I or you,

<BR>Or woman, man, or state, known or unknown,

<BR>We seeming solid wealth, strength, beauty build,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; But really build eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The ostent evanescent,

<BR>The substance of an artist's mood or savan's studies long,

<BR>Or warrior's, martyr's, hero's toils,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To fashion his eid&oacute;lon.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Of every human life,

<BR>(The units gather'd, posted, not a thought, emotion, deed, left out,)

<BR>The whole or large or small summ'd, added up,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In its eid&oacute;lon.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The old, old urge,

<BR>Based on the ancient pinnacles, lo, newer, higher pinnacles,

<BR>From science and the modern still impell'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The old, old urge, eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The present now and here,
