<BR>America's busy, teeming, intricate whirl,

<BR>Of aggregate and segregate for only thence releasing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To-day's eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; These with the past,

<BR>Of vanish'd lands, of all the reigns of kings across the sea,

<BR>Old conquerors, old campaigns, old sailor's voyages,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Joining eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Densities, growth, fa&ccedil;ades,

<BR>Strata of mountains, soils, rocks, giant trees,

<BR>Far-born, far-dying, living long, to leave,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Eid&oacute;lons everlasting.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Exalt&egrave;, rapt, ecstatic,

<BR>The visible but their womb of birth,

<BR>Of orbic tendencies to shape and shape and shape,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The mighty earth-eid&oacute;lon.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; All space, all time,

<BR>(The stars, the terrible perturbations of the suns,

<BR>Swelling, collapsing, ending, serving their longer, shorter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; use,)

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Fill'd with eid&oacute;lons only.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The noiseless myriads,

<BR>The infinite oceans where the rivers empty,

<BR>The separate countless free identities, like eyesight,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The true realities, eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Not this the world,

<BR>Nor these the universes, they the universes,

<BR>Purport and end, ever the permanent life of life,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Eid&oacute;lons, eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Beyond thy lectures learn'd professor,

<BR>Beyond thy telescope or spectroscope observer keen, beyond

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all mathematics,

<BR>Beyond the doctor's surgery, anatomy, beyond the chemist

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with his chemistry,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The entities of entities, eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Unfixed yet fix'd,

<BR>Ever shall be, ever have been and are,

<BR>Sweeping the present to the infinite future,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Eid&oacute;lons, eid&oacute;lons, eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The prophet and the bard,

<BR>Shall yet maintain themselves, in higher stages yet,

<BR>Shall mediate to the Modern, to Democracy, interpret yet to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; God and eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And thee my soul,

<BR>Joys, ceaseless exercises, exaltations,

<BR>Thy yearning amply fed at last, prepared to meet,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thy mates, eid&oacute;lons.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thy body permanent,

<BR>The body lurking there within thy body,

<BR>The only purport of the form thou art, the real I myself,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; An image, an eid&oacute;lon.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thy very songs not in thy songs,

<BR>No special strains to sing, none for itself,

<BR>But from the whole resulting, rising at last and floating,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; A round full-orb'd eid&oacute;lon.

<PRE>1876&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1876</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FOR HIM I SING</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>OR</FONT> him I sing,

<BR>I raise the present on the past,

<BR>(As some perennial tree out of its roots, the present on the past,)

<BR>With time and space I him dilate and fuse the immortal laws,

<BR>To make himself by them the law unto himself.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHEN I READ THE BOOK</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HEN</FONT> I read the book, the biography famous,

<BR>And is this then (said I) what the author calls a man's life?

<BR>And so will some one when I am dead and gone write my life?

<BR>(As if any man really knew aught of my life,

<BR>Why even I myself I often think know little or nothing of my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; real life,

<BR>Only a few hints, a few diffused faint clews and indirections

<BR>I seek for my own use to trace out here.)

<PRE>1867&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

BEGINNING MY STUDIES</H2></CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>EGINNING</FONT> my studies the first step pleas'd me so

much,

<BR>The mere fact consciousness, these forms, the power of motion,

<BR>The least insect or animal, the senses, eyesight, love,

<BR>The first step I say awed me and pleas'd me so much,

<BR>I have hardly gone and hardly wish'd to go any farther,

<BR>But stop and loiter all the time to sing it in ecstatic songs.

<PRE>1867&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

BEGINNERS</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>OW</FONT> they are provided for upon the earth, (appearing

at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; intervals,)

<BR>How dear and dreadful they are to the earth,

<BR>How they inure to themselves as much as to any&amp;emdash;what a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; paradox appears their age,

<BR>How people respond to them, yet know them not,

<BR>How there is something relentless in their fate all times,

<BR>How all times mischoose the objects of their adulation and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reward,

<BR>And how the same inexorable price must still be paid for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; same great purchase.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO THE STATES</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>O</FONT> the States or any one of them, or any city of the

States,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <I>Resist much, obey little</I>,

<BR>Once unquestioning obedience, once fully enslaved,

<BR>Once fully enslaved, no nation, state, city, of this earth, ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; afterward resumes its liberty.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ON JOURNEYS THROUGH THE STATES</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>N</FONT> journeys through the States we start,

<BR>(Ay through the world, urged by these songs,

<BR>Sailing henceforth to every land, to every sea,)

<BR>We willing learners of all, teachers of all, and lovers of all.



<P>&nbsp;We have watch'd the seasons dispensing themselves and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; passing on,

<BR>And have said, Why should not a man or woman do as much

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as the seasons, and effuse as much?



<P>&nbsp;We dwell a while in every city and town,

<BR>We pass through Kanada, the North-east, the vast valley of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Mississippi, and the Southern States,

<BR>We confer on equal terms with each of the States,

<BR>We make trial of ourselves and invite men and women to hear,

<BR>We say to ourselves, Remember, fear not, be candid,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; promulge the body and the soul,

<BR>Dwell a while and pass on, be copious, temperate, chaste,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; magnetic,

<BR>And what you effuse may then return as the seasons return,

<BR>And may be just as much as the seasons.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO A CERTAIN CANTATRICE</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>ERE</FONT>, take this gift,

<BR>I was reserving it for some hero, speaker, or general,

<BR>One who should serve the good old cause, the great idea, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; progress and freedom of the race,

<BR>Some brave confronter of despots, some daring rebel;

<BR>But I see that what I was reserving belongs to you just as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; much as to any.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ME IMPERTURBE</H2></CENTER>

M<FONT SIZE=-1>E</FONT> imperturbe, standing at ease in Nature,

<BR>Master of all or mistress of all, aplomb in the midst of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; irrational things,

<BR>Imbued as they, passive, receptive, silent as they,

<BR>Finding my occupation, poverty, notoriety, foibles, crimes,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; less important than I thought,

<BR>Me toward the Mexican sea, or in the Mannahatta or the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Tennessee, or far north or inland,

<BR>A river man, or a man of the woods or of any farm-life of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; these States or of the coast, or the lakes or Kanada,

<BR>Me wherever my life is lived, O to be self-balanced for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contingencies,

<BR>To confront night, storms, hunger, ridicule, accidents,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rebuffs, as the trees and animals do.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SAVANTISM</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HITHER</FONT> as I look I see each result and glory retracing

itself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and nestling close, always obligated,

<BR>Thither hours, months, years&amp;emdash;thither trades, compacts,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; establishments, even the most minute,

<BR>Thither every-day life, speech, utensils, politics, persons,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; estates;

<BR>Thither we also, I with my leaves and songs, trustful,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; admirant,

<BR>As a father to his father going takes his children along with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE SHIP STARTING</H2></CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>O</FONT>, the unbounded sea,

<BR>On its breast a ship starting, spreading all sails, carrying even

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her moonsails,

<BR>The pennant is flying aloft as she speeds she speeds so stately

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;below emulous waves press forward,

<BR>They surround the ship with shining curving motions and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; foam.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

I HEAR AMERICA SINGING</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>HEAR</FONT> America singing, the varied carols I hear,

<BR>Those of mechanics, each one singing his as it should be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blithe and strong,

<BR>The carpenter singing his as he measures his plank or beam,

<BR>The mason singing his as he makes ready for work, or leaves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; off work,

<BR>The boatman singing what belongs to him in his boat, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; deck-hand singing on the steamboat deck,

<BR>The shoemaker singing as he sits on his bench, the hatter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; singing as he stands,

<BR>The wood-cutter's song, the ploughboy's on his way in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; morning, or at noon intermission or at sundown,

<BR>The delicious singing of the mother, or of the young wife at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; work, or of the girl sewing or washing,

<BR>Each singing what belongs to him or her and to none else,

<BR>The day what belongs to the day&amp;emdash;at night the party of young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fellows, robust, friendly,

<BR>Singing with open mouths their strong melodious songs.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHAT PLACE IS BESIEGED?</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HAT</FONT> place is besieged, and vainly tries to raise

the siege?

<BR>Lo, I send to that place a commander, swift, brave, immortal,

<BR>And with him horse and foot, and parks of artillery,

<BR>And artillery-men, the deadliest that ever fired gun.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

STILL THOUGH THE ONE I SING</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>TILL</FONT> though the one I sing,

<BR>(One, yet of contradictions made,) I dedicate to Nationality,

<BR>I leave in him revolt, (O latent right of insurrection! O

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; quenchless, indispensable fire!)

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SHUT NOT YOUR DOORS</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>HUT</FONT> not your doors to me proud libraries,

<BR>For that which was lacking on all your well-fill'd shelves, yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; needed most, I bring,

<BR>Forth from the war emerging, a book I have made,



<P>&nbsp;The words of my book nothing, the drift of it every thing,

<BR>A book separate, not link'd with the rest nor felt by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; intellect,

<BR>But you ye untold latencies will thrill to every page.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

POETS TO COME</H2></CENTER>

P<FONT SIZE=-1>OETS</FONT> to come! orators, singers, musicians to come!

<BR>Not to-day is to justify me and answer what I am for,

<BR>But you, a new brood, native, athletic, continental, greater

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than before known,

<BR>Arouse! for you must justify me.



<P>&nbsp;I myself but write one or two indicative words for the future,

<BR>I but advance a moment only to wheel and hurry back in the darkness.



<P>&nbsp;I am a man who, sauntering along without fully stopping,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; turns a casual look upon you and then averts his

face,

<BR>Leaving it to you to prove and define it,

<BR>Expecting the main things from you.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO YOU</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>TRANGER</FONT>, if you passing meet me and desire to speak

to me,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; why should you not speak to me?

<BR>And why should I not speak to you?

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THOU READER</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HOU</FONT> reader throbbest life and pride and love the

same as I,

<BR>Therefore for thee the following chants.

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Song of the Exposition</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Song of the Exposition</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>(A<FONT SIZE=-1>H</FONT> little recks the laborer,

<BR>How near his work is holding him to God,

<BR>The loving Laborer through space and time.)



<P>&nbsp;After all not to create only, or found only,

<BR>But to bring perhaps from afar what is already

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; founded,

<BR>To give it our own identity, average, limitless, free,

<BR>To fill the gross the torpid bulk with vital religious

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fire,

<BR>Not to repel or destroy so much as accept, fuse, rehabilitate,

<BR>To obey as well as command, to follow more than to lead,

<BR>These also are the lessons of our New World;

<BR>While how little the New after all, how much the Old,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Old World!



<P>&nbsp;Long and long has the grass been growing,

<BR>Long and long has the rain been falling,

<BR>Long has the globe been rolling round.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Come Muse migrate from Greece and Ionia,

<BR>Cross out please those immensely overpaid accounts,

<BR>That matter of Troy and Achilles' wrath, and &AElig;neas</q>,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Odysseus' wanderings,

<BR>Placard&nbsp;<qq>Removed</qq> and&nbsp;<qq>To Let</qq> on the rocks

of your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; snowy Parnassus,

<BR>Repeat at Jerusalem, place the notice high on Jaffa's gate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and on Mount Moriah,

<BR>The same on the walls of your German, French and Spanish

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; castles, and Italian collections,

<BR>For know a better, fresher, busier sphere, a wide, untried

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; domain awaits, demands you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>Responsive to our summons,

<BR>Or rather to her long-nurs'd inclination,

<BR>Join'd with an irresistible, natural gravitation,

<BR>She comes! I hear the rustling of her gown,

<BR>I scent the odor of her breath's delicious fragrance,

<BR>I mark her step divine, her curious eyes a-turning, rolling,

<BR>Upon this very scene.



<P>&nbsp;The dame of dames! can I believe then,

<BR>Those ancient temples, sculptures classic, could none of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them retain her?

<BR>Nor shades of Virgil and Dante, nor myriad memories,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poems, old associations, magnetize and hold

on to her?

<BR>But that she's left them all &amp;emdash; and here?



<P>&nbsp;Yes, if you will allow me to say so,

<BR>I, my friends, if you do not, can plainly see her,

<BR>The same undying soul of earth's, activity's, beauty's,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heroism's expression,

<BR>Out from her evolutions hither come, ended the strata of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her former themes,



<P>&nbsp;Hidden and cover'd by to-day's, foundation of to-day's,

<BR>Ended, deceas'd through time, her voice by Castaly's fountain,

<BR>Silent the broken-lipp'd Sphynx in Egypt, silent all those

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; century-baffling tombs,

<BR>Ended for aye the epics of Asia's, Europe's helmeted warriors,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ended the primitive call of the muses,

<BR>Calliope's call forever closed, Clio, Melpomene, Thalia dead,

<BR>Ended the stately rhythmus of Una and Oriana, ended the quest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the Holy Graal,

<BR>Jerusalem a handful of ashes blown by the wind, extinct,

<BR>The Crusaders' streams of shadowy midnight troops sped with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sunrise,

<BR>Amadis, Tancred, utterly gone, Charlemagne, Roland, Oliver

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gone,

<BR>Palmerin, ogre, departed, vanish'd the turrets that Usk from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; its waters reflected,

<BR>Arthur vanish'd with all his knights, Merlin and Lancelot and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Galahad, all gone, dissolv'd utterly like

an exhalation;

<BR>Pass'd! pass'd! for us, forever pass'd, that once so mighty

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; world, now void, inanimate, phantom world,

<BR>Embroider'd, dazzling, foreign world, with all its gorgeous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; legends, myths,

<BR>Its kings and castles proud, its priests and warlike lords

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and courtly dames,

<BR>Pass'd to its charnel vault, coffin'd with crown and armor on,

<BR>Blazon'd with Shakspere's purple page,

<BR>And dirged by Tennyson's sweet sad rhyme.



<P>&nbsp;I say I see, my friends, if you do not, the illustrious emigr&eacute;,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (having it is true in her day, although the

same, changed,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; journey'd considerable,)

<BR>Making directly for this rendezvous, vigorously clearing a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; path for herself, striding through the confusion,

<BR>By thud of machinery and shrill steam-whistle undismay'd,

<BR>Bluff'd not a bit by drain-pipe, gasometers, artificial fertilizers,

<BR>Smiling and pleas'd with palpable intent to stay,

<BR>She's here, install'd amid the kitchen ware!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>But hold &amp;emdash; don't I forget my manners?

<BR>To introduce the stranger, (what else indeed do I live to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chant for?) to thee Columbia;

<BR>In liberty's name welcome immortal! clasp hands,

<BR>And ever henceforth sisters dear be both.



<P>&nbsp;Fear not O Muse! truly new ways and days receive,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; surround you,

<BR>I candidly confess a queer, queer race, of novel fashion,

<BR>And yet the same old human race, the same within, without,

<BR>Faces and hearts the same, feelings the same, yearnings the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; same,

<BR>The same old love, beauty and use the same.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>We do not blame thee elder World, nor really separate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ourselves from thee,

<BR>(Would the son separate himself from the father?)

<BR>Looking back on thee, seeing thee to thy duties, grandeurs,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through past ages bending, building,

<BR>We build to ours to-day.



<P>&nbsp;Mightier than Egypt's tombs,

<BR>Fairer than Grecia's, Roma's temples,

<BR>Prouder then Milan's statued, spired, cathedral,

<BR>More picturesque than Rhenish castle-keeps,

<BR>We plan even now to raise, beyond them all,

<BR>Thy great cathedral sacred industry, no tomb,

<BR>A keep for life for practical invention.



<P>&nbsp;As in a waking vision,

<BR>E'en while I chant I see it rise, I scan and prophesy outside

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and in,

<BR>Its manifold ensemble.



<P>&nbsp;Around a palace, loftier, fairer, ampler than any yet,

<BR>Earth's modern wonder, history's seven outstripping,

<BR>High rising tier on tier with glass and iron fa&ccedil;ades,

<BR>Gladdening the sun and sky, enhued in cheerfulest hues,



<P>&nbsp;Bronze, lilac, robin's-egg, marine and crimson,

<BR>Over whose golden roof shall flaunt, beneath thy banner

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Freedom,

<BR>The banners of the States and flags of every land,

<BR>A brood of lofty, fair, but lesser palaces shall cluster.



<P>&nbsp;Somewhere within their walls shall all that forwards perfect

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; human life be started,

<BR>Tried, taught, advanced, visibly exhibited.



<P>&nbsp;Not only all the world of works, trade, products,

<BR>But all the workmen of the world here to be represented.



<P>&nbsp;Here shall you trace in flowing operation,

<BR>In every state of practical, busy movement, the rills of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; civilization,

<BR>Materials here under your eye shall change their shape as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; if by magic,

<BR>The cotton shall be pick'd almost in the very field,

<BR>Shall be dried, clean'd, ginn'd, baled, spun into thread

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and cloth before you,

<BR>You shall see hands at work at all the old processes and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all the new ones,

<BR>You shall see the various grains and how flour is made and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; then bread baked by the bakers,

<BR>You shall see the crude ores of California and Nevada passing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on and on till they become bullion,

<BR>You shall watch how the printer sets type, and learn what a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; composing-stick is,

<BR>You shall mark in amazement the Hoe press whirling its cylinders,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shedding the printed leaves steady and fast,

<BR>The photograph, model, watch, pin, nail, shall be created

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before you.



<P>&nbsp;In large calm halls, a stately museum shall teach you the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; infinite lessons of minerals,

<BR>In another, woods, plants, vegetation shall be illustrated

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; in another animals, animal life

and development.



<P>&nbsp;One stately house shall be the music house,

<BR>Others for other arts &amp;emdash; learning, the sciences, shall

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all be here,



<P>&nbsp;None shall be slighted, none but shall here be honor'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; help'd, exampled.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>(This, this and these, America, shall be <I>your</I> pyramids and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; obelisks,

<BR>Your Alexandrian Pharos, gardens of Babylon,

<BR>Your temple at Olympia.)



<P>&nbsp;The male and female many laboring not,

<BR>Shall ever here confront the laboring many,

<BR>With precious benefits to both, glory to all,

<BR>To thee America, and thee eternal Muse.



<P>&nbsp;And here shall ye inhabit powerful Matrons!

<BR>In your vast state vaster than all the old,

<BR>Echoed through long, long centuries to come,

<BR>To sound of different, prouder songs, with stronger themes,

<BR>Practical, peaceful life, the people's life, the People themselves,

<BR>Lifted, illumin'd, bathed in peace &amp;emdash; elate, secure in peace.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>Away with themes of war! away with war itself!

<BR>Hence from my shuddering sight to never more return that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; show of blacken'd, mutilated corpses!

<BR>That hell unpent and raid of blood, fit for wild tigers or for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lop-tongued wolves, not reasoning men,

<BR>And in its stead speed industry's campaigns,

<BR>With thy undaunted armies, engineering,

<BR>Thy pennants labor, loosen'd to the breeze,

<BR>Thy bugles sounding loud and clear.



<P>&nbsp;Away with old romance!

<BR>Away with novels, plots and plays of foreign courts,

<BR>Away with love-verses, sugar'd in rhyme, the intrigues,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amours of idlers,

<BR>Fitted for only banquets of the night where dancers to late

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; music slide,

<BR>The unhealthy pleasures, extravagant dissipation of the few,



<P>&nbsp;With perfumes, heat and wine, beneath the dazzling chandeliers.



<P>&nbsp;To you ye reverent sane sisters,

<BR>I raise a voice for far superber themes for poets and for art,

<BR>To exalt the present and the real,

<BR>To teach the average man the glory of his daily walk and trade,

<BR>To sing in songs how exercise and chemical life are never to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be baffled,

<BR>To manual work for each and all, to plough, hoe, dig,

<BR>To plant and tend the tree, the berry, vegetables, flowers,

<BR>For every man to see to it that he really do something, for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every woman too;

<BR>To use the hammer and the saw, (rip, or cross-cut,)

<BR>To cultivate a turn for carpentering, plastering, painting,

<BR>To work as tailor, tailoress, nurse, hostler, porter,

<BR>To invent a little, something ingenious, to aid the washing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cooking, cleaning,

<BR>And hold it no disgrace to take a hand at them themselves.



<P>&nbsp;I say I bring thee Muse to-day and here,

<BR>All occupations, duties broad and close,

<BR>Toil, healthy toil and sweat, endless, without cessation,

<BR>The old, old practical burdens, interests, joys,

<BR>The family, parentage, childhood, husband and wife,

<BR>The house-comforts, the house itself and all its belongings,

<BR>Food and its preservation, chemistry applied to it,

<BR>Whatever forms the average, strong, complete, sweet-blooded

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; man or woman, the perfect longeve personality,

<BR>And helps its present life to health and happiness, and shapes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; its soul,

<BR>For the eternal real life to come.



<P>&nbsp;With latest connections, works, the inter-transportation of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the world,

<BR>Steam-power, the great express lines, gas, petroleum,

<BR>These triumphs of our time, the Atlantic's delicate cable,

<BR>The Pacific railroad, the Suez canal, the Mont Cenis and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Gothard and Hoosac tunnels, the Brooklyn bridge,



<P>&nbsp;This earth all spann'd with iron rails, with lines of steamships

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; threading every sea,

<BR>Our own rondure, the current globe I bring.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>And thou America,

<BR>Thy offspring towering e'er so high, yet higher Thee above

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all towering,

<BR>With Victory on thy left, and at thy right hand Law;

<BR>Thou Union holding all, fusing, absorbing, tolerating all,

<BR>Thee, ever thee, I sing.



<P>&nbsp;Thou, also thou, a World,

<BR>With all thy wide geographies, manifold, different, distant,

<BR>Rounded by thee in one &amp;emdash; one common orbic language,

<BR>One common indivisible destiny for All.



<P>&nbsp;And by the spells which ye vouchsafe to those your ministers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in earnest,

<BR>I here personify and call my themes, to make them pass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before ye.



<P>&nbsp;Behold, America! (and thou, ineffable guest and sister!)

<BR>For thee come trooping up thy waters and thy lands;

<BR>Behold! thy fields and farms, thy far-off woods and mountains,

<BR>As in procession coming.



<P>&nbsp;Behold, the sea itself,

<BR>And on its limitless, heaving breast, the ships;

<BR>See, where their white sails, bellying in the wind, speckle the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; green and blue,

<BR>See, the steamers coming and going, steaming in or out of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; port,

<BR>See, dusky and undulating, the long pennants of smoke.



<P>&nbsp;Behold, in Oregon, far in the north and west,

<BR>Or in Maine, far in the north and east, they cheerful axemen,

<BR>Wielding all day their axes.



<P>&nbsp;Behold, on the lakes, thy pilots at their wheels, thy oarsmen,

<BR>How the ash writhes under those muscular arms!



<P>&nbsp;There by the furnace, and there by the anvil,

<BR>Behold thy sturdy blacksmiths swinging their sledges,

<BR>Overhand so steady, overhand they turn and fall with joyous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clank,

<BR>Like a tumult of laughter.



<P>&nbsp;Mark the spirit of invention everywhere, thy rapid patents,

<BR>Thy continual workshops, foundries, risen or rising,

<BR>See, from their chimneys how the tall flame-fires stream.



<P>&nbsp;Mark, thy interminable farms, North, South,

<BR>Thy wealthy daughter-states, Eastern and Western,

<BR>The varied products of Ohio, Pennsylvania, Missouri,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Georgia, Texas, and the rest,

<BR>Thy limitless crops, grass, wheat, sugar, oil, corn,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rice, hemp, hops,

<BR>Thy barns all fill'd, the endless freight-train and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bulging storehouse,

<BR>The grapes that ripen on thy vines, the apples in thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; orchards,

<BR>Thy incalculable lumber, beef, pork, potatoes, thy coal,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy gold and silver,

<BR>The inexhaustible iron in thy mines.



<P>&nbsp;All thine, O sacred Union!

<BR>Ships, farms, shops, barns factories, mines,

<BR>City and State, North, South, item and aggregate,

<BR>We dedicate, dread Mother, all to thee!



<P>&nbsp;Protectress absolute, thou! bulwark of all!

<BR>For well we know that while thou givest each and all,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (generous as God,)

<BR>Without thee neither all nor each, nor land, home,

<BR>Nor ship, nor mine, nor any here this day secure,

<BR>Nor aught, nor any day secure.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>9</CENTER>





<P>And thou, the Emblem waving over all!

<BR>Delicate beauty, a word to thee, (it may be salutary,)



<P>&nbsp;Remember thou hast not always been as here to-day so

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; comfortably ensovereign'd,

<BR>In other scenes than these have I observ'd thee flag,

<BR>Not quite so trim and whole and freshly blooming in folds

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of stainless silk,

<BR>But I have seen thee bunting, to tatters torn upon thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; splinter'd staff,

<BR>Or clutch'd to some young color-bearer's breast with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; desperate hands,

<BR>Savagely struggled for, for life or death, fought over long,

<BR>'Mid cannons' thunder-crash and many a curse and groan

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and yell, and rifle-volleys cracking sharp,

<BR>And moving masses as wild demons surging, and lives as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nothing risk'd,

<BR>For thy mere remnant grimed with dirt and smoke and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sopp'd in blood,

<BR>For sake of that, my beauty, and that thou might'st dally

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as now secure up there,

<BR>Many a good man have I seen go under.



<P>&nbsp;Now here and these and hence in peace, all thine, O flag!

<BR>And here and hence for thee, O universal Muse! and thou for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them!

<BR>And here and hence O Union, all the work and workmen thine!

<BR>None separate from thee &amp;emdash; henceforth One only, we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and thou,

<BR>(For the blood of the children, what is it, only the blood maternal?

<BR>And lives and works, what are they all at last, except the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; roads to faith and death?)



<P>&nbsp;While we rehearse our measureless wealth, it is for thee, dear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mother,

<BR>We own it all and several to-day indissoluble in thee;

<BR>Think not our chant, our show, merely for products gross or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lucre &amp;emdash; it is for thee, the soul

in thee, electric, spiritual!

<BR>Our farms, inventions, crops, we own in thee! cities and States

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in thee!

<BR>Our freedom all in thee! our very lives in thee!

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Birds of Passage</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Birds of Passage</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SONG OF THE UNIVERSAL</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>C<FONT SIZE=-1>OME</FONT> said the Muse,

<BR>Sing me a song no poet yet has chanted,

<BR>Sing me the universal.



<P>&nbsp;In this broad earth of ours,

<BR>Amid the measureless grossness and the slag,

<BR>Enclosed and safe within its central heart,

<BR>Nestles the seed perfection.



<P>&nbsp;By every life a share or more or less,

<BR>None born but it is born, conceal'd or unconceal'd the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seed is waiting.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Lo! keen-eyed towering science,

<BR>As from tall peaks the modern overlooking,

<BR>Successive absolute fiats issuing.



<P>&nbsp;Yet again, lo! the soul, above all science,

<BR>For it has history gather'd like husks around the globe,

<BR>For it the entire star-myriads roll through the sky.



<P>&nbsp;In spiral routes by long detours,

<BR>(As a much-tacking ship upon the sea,)

<BR>For it the partial to the permanent flowing,

<BR>For it the real to the ideal tends.



<P>&nbsp;For it the mystic evolution,

<BR>Not the right only justified, what we call evil also

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; justified.



<P>&nbsp;Forth from their masks, no matter what,

<BR>From the huge festering trunk, from craft and guile

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and tears,

<BR>Health to emerge and joy, joy universal.



<P>&nbsp;Out of the bulk, the morbid and the shallow,

<BR>Out of the bad majority, the varied countless frauds

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of men and states,

<BR>Electric, antiseptic yet, cleaving, suffusing all,

<BR>Only the good is universal.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>Over the mountain-growths disease and sorrow,

<BR>An uncaught bird is ever hovering, hovering,

<BR>High in the purer, happier air.



<P>&nbsp;From imperfection's murkiest cloud,

<BR>Darts always forth one ray of perfect light,

<BR>One flash of heaven's glory.



<P>&nbsp;To fashion's, custom's discord,

<BR>To the mad Babel-din, the deafening orgies,

<BR>Soothing each lull a strain is heard, just heard,

<BR>From some far shore the final chorus sounding.



<P>&nbsp;O the blest eyes, the happy hearts,

<BR>That see, that know the guiding thread so fine,

<BR>Along the mighty labyrinth.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>And thou America,

<BR>For the scheme's culmination, its thought and its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reality,

<BR>For these (not for thyself) thou hast arrived.



<P>&nbsp;Thou too surroundest all,

<BR>Embracing carrying welcoming all, thou too by path-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ways broad and new,

<BR>To the ideal tendest.



<P>&nbsp;The measur'd faiths of other lands, the grandeurs of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the past,

<BR>Are not for thee, but grandeurs of thine own,

<BR>Deific faiths and amplitudes, absorbing, comprehending

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all,

<BR>All eligible to all.



<P>&nbsp;All, all for immortality,

<BR>Love like the light silently wrapping all,

<BR>Nature's amelioration blessing all,

<BR>The blossoms, fruits of ages, orchards divine and certain,

<BR>Forms, objects, growths, humanities, to spiritual images

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ripening.



<P>&nbsp;Give me O God to sing that thought,

<BR>Give me, give him or her I love this quenchless faith

<BR>In Thy ensemble, whatever else withheld withhold not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from us,

<BR>Belief in plan of Thee enclosed in Time and Space,

<BR>Health, peace, salvation universal.



<P>&nbsp;Is it a dream?

<BR>Nay but the lack of it the dream,

<BR>And failing it life's lore and wealth a dream,

<BR>And all the world a dream.

<PRE>1874&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

PIONEERS! O PIONEERS!</H2></CENTER>

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

C<FONT SIZE=-1>OME</FONT> my tan-faced children,

<BR>Follow well in order, get your weapons ready,

<BR>Have you your pistols? have you your sharp-edged axes?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

For we cannot tarry here,

<BR>We must march my darlings, we must bear the brunt of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; danger,

<BR>We the youthful sinewy races, all the rest on us depend,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

O you youths, Western youths,

<BR>So impatient, full of action, full of manly pride and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; friendship,

<BR>Plain I see you Western youths, see you tramping with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; foremost,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Have the elder races halted?

<BR>Do they droop and end their lesson, wearied over there

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beyond the seas?



<P>&nbsp;We take up the task eternal, and the burden and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lesson,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

All the past we leave behind,

<BR>We debouch upon a newer mightier world, varied world,

<BR>Fresh and strong the world we seize, world of labor and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the march,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

We detachments steady throwing,

<BR>Down the edges, through the passes, up the mountains steep,

<BR>Conquering, holding, daring, venturing as we go the unknown

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ways,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

We primeval forests felling,

<BR>We the rivers stemming, vexing we and piercing deep the mines

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; within,

<BR>We the surface broad surveying, we the virgin soil upheaving,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Colorado men are we,

<BR>From the peaks gigantic, from the great sierras and the high

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; plateaus,

<BR>From the mine and from the gully, from the hunting trail we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; come,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

From Nebraska, from Arkansas,

<BR>Central inland race are we, from Missouri, with the continental

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blood intervein'd,

<BR>All the hands of comrades clasping, all the Southern, all the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Northern,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

O resistless restless race!

<BR>O beloved race in all! O my breast aches with tender love for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all!

<BR>O I mourn and yet exult, I am rapt with love for all,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Raise the mighty mother mistress,

<BR>Waving high the delicate mistress, over all the starry mistress,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (bend your heads all,)

<BR>Raise the fang'd and warlike mistress, stern, impassive,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; weapon'd mistress,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

See my children, resolute children,

<BR>By those swarms upon our rear we must never yield or falter,

<BR>Ages back in ghostly millions frowning there behind us urging,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

On and on the compact ranks,

<BR>With accessions ever waiting, with the places of the dead

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; quickly fill'd,

<BR>Through the battle, through defeat, moving yet and never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stopping,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

O to die advancing on!

<BR>Are there some of us to droop and die? has the hour come?

<BR>Then upon the march we fittest die, soon and sure the gap is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fill'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

All the pulses of the world,

<BR>Falling in they beat for us, with the Western movement beat,

<BR>Holding single or together, steady moving to the front, all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for us,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Life's involv'd and varied pageants,

<BR>All the forms and shows, all the workmen at their work,

<BR>All the seamen and the landsmen, all the masters with their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slaves,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

All the hapless silent lovers,

<BR>All the prisoners in the prisons, all the righteous and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wicked,



<P>&nbsp;All the joyous, all the sorrowing, all the living, all the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dying,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

I too with my soul and body,

<BR>We, a curious trio, picking, wandering on our way,

<BR>Through these shores amid the shadows, with the apparitions

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pressing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Lo, the darting bowling orb!

<BR>Lo, the brother orbs around, all the clustering suns and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; planets,

<BR>All the dazzling days, all the mystic nights with dreams,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

These are of us, they are with us,

<BR>All for primal needed work, while the followers there in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; embryo wait behind,

<BR>We to-day's procession heading, we the route for travel

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clearing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

O you daughters of the West!

<BR>O you young and elder daughters! O you mothers and you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wives!

<BR>Never must you be divided, in our ranks you move united,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Minstrels latent on the prairies!

<BR>(Shrouded bards of other lands, you may rest, you have

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; done your work,)

<BR>Soon I hear you coming warbling, soon you rise and tramp

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amid us,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Not for delectations sweet,

<BR>Not the cushion and the slipper, not the peaceful and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; studious,

<BR>Not the riches safe and palling, not for us the tame

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; enjoyment,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Do the feasters gluttonous feast?

<BR>Do the corpulent sleepers sleep? have they lock'd and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bolted doors?

<BR>Still be ours the diet hard, and the blanket on the ground,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Has the night descended?

<BR>Was the road of late so toilsome? did we stop discouraged

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nodding on our way?

<BR>Yet a passing hour I yield you in your tracks to pause

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; oblivious,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Till with sound of trumpet,

<BR>Far, far off the daybreak call&amp;emdash;hark! how loud and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clear I hear it wind,

<BR>Swift! to the head of the army!&amp;emdash;swift! spring to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your places,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Pioneers! O pioneers!



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO YOU</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HOEVER</FONT> you are, I fear you are walking the walks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of dreams,

<BR>I fear these supposed realities are to melt from under your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feet and hands,

<BR>Even now your features, joys, speech, house, trade, manners,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; troubles, follies, costume, crimes, dissipate

away from you,

<BR>Your true soul and body appear before me,

<BR>They stand forth out of affairs, out of commerce, shops, work,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; farms, clothes, the house, buying, selling,

eating, drinking,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; suffering, dying.



<P>&nbsp;Whoever you are, now I place my hand upon you, that you be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my poem,

<BR>I whisper with my lips close to your ear,

<BR>I have loved many women and men, but I love none better than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you.



<P>&nbsp;O I have been dilatory and dumb,

<BR>I should have made my way straight to you long ago,



<P>&nbsp;I should have blabb'd nothing but you, I should have chanted

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nothing but you.



<P>&nbsp;I will leave all and come and make the hymns of you,

<BR>None has understood you, but I understand you,

<BR>None has done justice to you, you have not done justice

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to yourself,

<BR>None but has found you imperfect, I only find no imperfection

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in you,

<BR>None but would subordinate you, I only am he who will never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consent to subordinate you,

<BR>I only am he who places over you no master, owner, better,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; God, beyond what waits intrinsically in yourself.



<P>&nbsp;Painters have painted their swarming groups and the centre-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; figure of all,

<BR>From the head of the centre-figure spreading a nimbus of gold-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; color'd light,

<BR>But I paint myriads of heads, but paint no head without its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nimbus of gold-color'd light,

<BR>From my hand from the brain of every man and woman it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; streams, effulgently flowing forever.



<P>&nbsp;O I could sing such grandeurs and glories about you!

<BR>You have not known what you are, you have slumber'd upon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yourself all your life,

<BR>Your eyelids have been the same as closed most of the time,

<BR>What you have done returns already in mockeries,

<BR>(Your thrift, knowledge, prayers, if they do not return in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mockeries, what is their return?)



<P>&nbsp;The mockeries are not you,

<BR>Underneath them and within them I see you lurk,

<BR>I pursue you where none else has pursued you,

<BR>Silence, the desk, the flippant expression, the night, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accustom'd routine, if these conceal you from

others or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from yourself, they do not conceal you from

me,

<BR>The shaved face, the unsteady eye, the impure complexion, if

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; these balk others they do not balk me,

<BR>The pert apparel, the deform'd attitude, drunkenness, greed,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; premature death, all these I part aside.



<P>&nbsp;There is no endowment in man or woman that is not tallied in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you,

<BR>There is no virtue, no beauty in man or woman, but as good is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in you,

<BR>No plunk, no endurance in others, but as good is in you,

<BR>No pleasure waiting for others, but an equal pleasure waits

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for you.



<P>&nbsp;As for me, I give nothing to any one except I give the like

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; carefully to you,

<BR>I sing the songs of the glory of none, not God, sooner than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I sing the songs of the glory of you.



<P>&nbsp;Whoever you are! claim your own at any hazard!

<BR>These shows of the East and West are tame compared to you,

<BR>These immense meadows, these interminable rivers, you are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; immense and interminable as they,

<BR>These furies, elements, storms, motions of Nature, throes of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; apparent dissolution, you are he or she who

is master or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mistress over them,

<BR>Master or mistress in your own right over Nature, elements,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pain, passion, dissolution.



<P>&nbsp;The hopples fall from your ankles, you find an unfailing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sufficiency,

<BR>Old or young, male or female, rude, low, rejected by the rest,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whatever you are promulges itself,

<BR>Through birth, life, death, burial, the means are provided,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nothing is scanted,

<BR>Through angers, losses, ambition, ignorance, ennui, what you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are picks its way.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FRANCE</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>The 18th Year of these States</I></CENTER>





<P>A <FONT SIZE=-1>GREAT</FONT> year and place,

<BR>A harsh discordant natal scream out-sounding, to touch the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mother's heart closer than any yet.



<P>&nbsp;I walk'd the shores of my Eastern sea,

<BR>Heard over the waves the little voice,

<BR>Saw the divine infant where she woke mournfully wailing, amid

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the roar of cannon, curses, shouts, crush

of falling buildings,

<BR>Was not so sick from the blood in the gutters running, nor from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the single corpses, nor those in heaps, nor

those borne away

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the tumbrils,

<BR>Was not so desperate at the battues of death&amp;emdash;was not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; so shock'd at the repeated fusillades of the

guns.



<P>&nbsp;Pale, silent, stern, what could I say to that long-accrued

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; retribution?

<BR>Could I wish humanity different?

<BR>Could I wish the people made of wood and stone?

<BR>Or that there be no justice in destiny or time?



<P>&nbsp;O liberty! O mate for me!

<BR>Here too the blaze, the grape-shot and the axe, in reserve,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to fetch them out in case of need,

<BR>Here too, though long represt, can never be destroy'd,

<BR>Here too could rise at last murdering and ecstatic,

<BR>Here too demanding full arrears of vengeance.



<P>&nbsp;Hence I sign this salute over the sea,

<BR>And I do not deny that terrible red birth and baptism,

<BR>But remember the little voice that I heard wailing, and wait

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with perfect trust, no matter how long,

<BR>And from to-day sad and cogent I maintain the bequeath'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cause, as for all lands,

<BR>And I send these words to Paris with my love,

<BR>And I guess some chansonniers there will understand them,

<BR>For I guess there is latent music yet in France, floods of it,

<BR>O I hear already the bustle of instruments, they will soon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be drowning all that would interrupt them,

<BR>O I think the east wind brings a triumphal and free march,

<BR>It reaches hither, it swells me to joyful madness,

<BR>I will run transpose it in words, to justify it,

<BR>I will yet sing a song for you ma femme.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MYSELF AND MINE</H2></CENTER>

M<FONT SIZE=-1>YSELF</FONT> and mine gymnastic ever,

<BR>To stand the cold or heat, to make good aim with a gun, to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sail a boat, to manage horses, to beget superb

children,

<BR>To speak readily and clearly, to feel at home among common

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; people,

<BR>And to hold our own in terrible positions on land and sea.



<P>&nbsp;Not for an embroiderer,

<BR>(There will always be plenty of embroiderers, I welcome

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them also,)

<BR>But for the fibre of things and for inherent men and women.



<P>&nbsp;Not to chisel ornaments,

<BR>But to chisel with free stroke the heads and limbs of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; plenteous supreme Gods, that the States may

realize

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them walking and talking.



<P>&nbsp;Let me have my own way,

<BR>Let others promulge the laws, I will make no account of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the laws,

<BR>Let others praise eminent men and hold up peace, I hold up

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; agitation and conflict,

<BR>I praise no eminent man, I rebuke to his face the one that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; was thought most worthy.



<P>&nbsp;(Who are you? and what are you secretly guilty of all your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life?

<BR>Will you turn aside all your life? will you grub and chatter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all your life?

<BR>And who are you, blabbing by rote, years, pages, languages,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reminiscences,

<BR>Unwitting to-day that you do not know how to speak properly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a single word?)



<P>&nbsp;Let others finish specimens, I never finish specimens,

<BR>I start them by exhaustless laws as Nature does, fresh and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; modern continually.



<P>&nbsp;I give nothing as duties,

<BR>What others give as duties I give as living impulses,

<BR>(Shall I give the heart's action as a duty?)



<P>&nbsp;Let others dispose of questions, I dispose of nothing, I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arouse unanswerable questions,

<BR>Who are they I see and touch, and what about them?

<BR>What about these likes of myself that draw me so close

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by tender directions and indirections?



<P>&nbsp;I call to the world to distrust the accounts of my friends,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but listen to my enemies, as I myself do,

<BR>I charge you forever reject those who would expound

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me, for I cannot expound myself,

<BR>I charge that there be no theory or school founded out

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of me,

<BR>I charge you to leave all free, as I have left all free.



<P>&nbsp;After me, vista!

<BR>O I see life is not short, but immeasurably long,

<BR>I henceforth tread the world chaste, temperate, an early

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; riser, a steady grower,

<BR>Every hour the semen of centuries, and still of centuries.

<BR>I must follow up these continual lessons of the air, water,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth,

<BR>I perceive I have no time to lose.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

YEAR OF METEORS</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(1859-60)</CENTER>





<P>Y<FONT SIZE=-1>EAR</FONT> of meteors! brooding year!

<BR>I would bind in words retrospective some of your deeds

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and signs,

<BR>I would sing your contest for the 19th Presidentiad,

<BR>I would sing how an old man, tall, with white hair,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mounted the scaffold in Virginia,

<BR>(I was at hand, silent I stood with teeth shut close, I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; watch'd,



<P>&nbsp;I stood very near you old man when cool and indifferent,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but trembling with age and your unheal'd wounds,

you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mounted the scaffold;)

<BR>I would sing in my copious song your census returns of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; States,

<BR>The tables of population and products, I would sing of your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ships and their cargoes,

<BR>The proud black ships of Manhattan arriving, some fill'd with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; immigrants, some from the isthmus with cargoes

of gold,

<BR>Songs thereof would I sing, to all that hitherward comes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; would I welcome give,

<BR>And you would I sing, fair stripling! welcome to you from me,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; young prince of England!

<BR>(Remember you surging Manhattan's crowds as you pass'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with your cortege of nobles?

<BR>There in the crowds stood I, and singled you out with attachment;)

<BR>Nor forget I to sing of the wonder, the ship as she swam up

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my bay,

<BR>Well-shaped and stately the Great Eastern swam up my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bay, she was 600 feet long,

<BR>Her moving swiftly surrounded by myriads of small craft I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forget not to sing;

<BR>Nor the comet that came unannounced out of the north

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flaring in heaven,

<BR>Nor the strange huge meteor-procession dazzling and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clear shooting over our heads,

<BR>(A moment, a moment long it sail'd its balls of unearthly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; light over our heads,

<BR>Then departed, dropt in the night, and was gone;)

<BR>Of such, and fitful as they, I sing &amp;emdash; with gleams

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from them would I gleam and patch these chants,

<BR>Your chants, O year all mottled with evil and good

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; year of forebodings!

<BR>Year of comets and meteors transient and strange

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; lo! even here one equally transient

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strange!

<BR>As I flit through you hastily, soon to fall and be gone,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what is this chant,

<BR>What am I myself but one of your meteors?

<PRE>(1860?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WITH ANTECEDENTS</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>W<FONT SIZE=-1>ITH</FONT> antecedents,

<BR>With my fathers and mothers and the accumulations of past

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ages,

<BR>With all which, had it not been, I would not now be here, as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I am,

<BR>With Egypt, India, Phenicia, Greece and Rome,

<BR>With the Kelt, the Scandinavian, the Alb and the Saxon,

<BR>With antique maritime ventures, laws, artisanship, wars and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; journeys,

<BR>With the poet, the skald, the saga, the myth, and the oracle,

<BR>With the sale of slaves, with enthusiasts, with the troubadour,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the crusader, and the monk,

<BR>With those old continents whence we have come to this new

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; continent,

<BR>With the fading kingdoms and kings over there,

<BR>With the fading religions and priests,

<BR>With the small shores we look back to from our own large and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; present shores,

<BR>With countless years drawing themselves onward and arrived

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at these years,

<BR>You and me arrived &amp;emdash; America arrived and making

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this year,

<BR>This year! sending itself ahead countless years to come.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>O but it is not the years &amp;emdash; it is I, it is You,

<BR>We touch all laws and tally all antecedents,

<BR>We are the skald, the oracle, the monk and the knight, we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; easily include them and more,

<BR>We stand amid time beginningless and endless, we stand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amid evil and good,

<BR>All swings around us, there is as much darkness as light,

<BR>The very sun swings itself and its system of planets around

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; us,

<BR>Its sun, and its again, all swing around us.

<BR>As for me, (torn, stormy, amid these vehement days,)

<BR>I have the idea of all, and am all and believe in all,



<P>&nbsp;I believe materialism is true and spiritualism is true, I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reject no part.

<BR>(Have I forgotten any part? any thing in the past?

<BR>Come to me whoever and whatever, till I give you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; recognition.)

<BR>I respect Assyria, China, Teutonia, and the Hebrews,

<BR>I adopt each theory, myth, god, and demi-god,

<BR>I see that the old accounts, bibles, genealogies, are true,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; without exception,

<BR>I assert that all past days were what they must have been,

<BR>And that they could no-how have been better than they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; were,

<BR>And that to-day is what it must be, and that America is,

<BR>And that to-day and America could no-how be better than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they are.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>In the name of these States and in your and my name, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Past,

<BR>And in the name of these States and in your and my name,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Present time.

<BR>I know that the past was great and the future will be great,

<BR>And I know that both curiously conjoint in the present time,

<BR>(For the sake of him I typify, for the common average man's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sake, your sake if you are he,)

<BR>And that where I am or you are this present day, there is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the centre of all days, all races,

<BR>And there is the meaning to us of all that has ever come of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; races and days, or ever will come.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Memories of President Lincoln</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B><I><FONT SIZE=+3>Memories of President Lincoln</FONT></I></B></CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>WHEN LILACS LAST IN THE DOORYARD BLOOM'D</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>hen</FONT> lilacs last in the dooryard bloom'd,

<BR>And the great star early droop'd in the western sky in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; night,

<BR>I mourn'd, and yet shall mourn with ever-returning spring.



<P>&nbsp;Ever-returning spring, trinity sure to me you bring,

<BR>Lilac blooming perennial and drooping star in the west,

<BR>And thought of him I love.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

O powerful western fallen star!

<BR>O shades of night&amp;emdash;O moody, tearful night!

<BR>O great star disappear'd&amp;emdash;O the black murk that hides the

star!

<BR>O cruel hands that hold me powerless&amp;emdash;O helpless soul of

me!

<BR>O harsh surrounding cloud that will not free my soul.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

In the dooryard fronting an old farm-house near the white-wash'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; palings,

<BR>Stands the lilac-bush tall-growing with heart-shaped leaves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of rich green,

<BR>With many a pointed blossom rising delicate, with the perfume

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strong I love,

<BR>With every leaf a miracle&amp;emdash;and from this bush in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dooryard,

<BR>With delicate-color'd blossoms and heart-shaped leaves of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rich green,

<BR>A spring with its flower I break.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

In the swamp in secluded recesses,

<BR>A shy and hidden bird is warbling a song.



<P>&nbsp;Solitary the thrush,

<BR>The hermit withdrawn to himself, avoiding the settlements,

<BR>Sings by himself a song.



<P>&nbsp;Song of the bleeding throat,

<BR>Death's outlet song of life, (for well dear brother I know,

<BR>If thou wast not granted to sing thou would'st surely die.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>5</CENTER>

Over the breast of the spring, the land, amid cities,

<BR>Amid lanes and through old woods, where lately the violets

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; peep'd from the ground, spotting the gray

debris,

<BR>Amid the grass in the fields each side of the lanes, passing the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; endless grass,

<BR>Passing the yellow-spear'd wheat, every grain from its shroud

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the dark-brown fields uprisen,

<BR>Passing the apple-tree blows of white and pink in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; orchards,

<BR>Carrying a corpse to where it shall rest in the grave,

<BR>Night and day journeys a coffin.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>6</CENTER>

Coffin that passes through lanes and streets,

<BR>Through day and night with the great cloud darkening the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land,

<BR>With the pomp of the inloop'd flags with the cities draped in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; black,

<BR>With the show of the States themselves as of crape-veil'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; women standing,

<BR>With processions long and winding and the flambeaus of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; night,

<BR>With the countless torches lit, with the silent sea of faces and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the unbared heads,

<BR>With the waiting depot, the arriving coffin, and the sombre
