<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; faces,

<BR>With dirges through the night, with the thousand voices

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rising strong and solemn,

<BR>With all the mournful voices of the dirges pour'd around the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; coffin,

<BR>The dim-lit churches and the shuddering organs&amp;emdash;where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amid these you journey,

<BR>With the tolling tolling bells' perpetual clang,

<BR>Here, coffin that slowly passes,

<BR>I give you my sprig of lilac.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>7</CENTER>

(Nor for you, for one alone,

<BR>Blossoms and branches green to coffins all I bring,

<BR>For fresh as the morning, thus would I chant a song for you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; O sane and sacred death.



<P>&nbsp;All over bouquets of roses,

<BR>O death, I cover you over with roses and early lilies,

<BR>But mostly and now the lilac that blooms the first,

<BR>Copious I break, I break the sprigs from the bushes,

<BR>With loaded arms I come, pouring for you,

<BR>For you and the coffins all of you O death.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>8</CENTER>

O western orb sailing the heaven,

<BR>Now I know what you must have meant as a month since I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; walk'd,

<BR>As I walk'd in silence the transparent shadowy night,

<BR>As I saw you had something to tell as you bent to me night

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; after night,

<BR>As you droop'd from the sky low down as if to my side,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (while the other stars all look'd on,)

<BR>As we wander'd together the solemn night, (for something I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know not what kept me from sleep,)

<BR>As the night advanced, and I saw on the rim of the west how

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; full you were of woe,

<BR>As I stood on the rising ground in the breeze in the cool

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; transparent night,

<BR>As I watch'd where you pass'd and was lost in the netherward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; black of the night,

<BR>As my soul in its trouble dissatisfied sank, as where you sad

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; orb,

<BR>Concluded, dropt in the night, and was gone.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>9</CENTER>

Sing on there in the swamp,

<BR>O singer bashful and tender, I hear your notes, I hear your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; call,

<BR>I hear, I come presently, I understand you,

<BR>But a moment I linger, for the lustrous star has detain'd me,

<BR>The star my departing comrade holds and detains me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>10</CENTER>

O how shall I warble myself for the dead one there I loved?

<BR>And how shall I deck my song for the large sweet soul that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; has gone?

<BR>And what shall my perfume be for the grave of him I love?



<P>&nbsp;Sea-winds blown from east and west,

<BR>Blown from the Eastern sea and blown from the Western sea,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; till there on the prairies meeting,

<BR>These and with these and the breath of my chant,

<BR>I'll perfume the grave of him I love.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>11</CENTER>

O what shall I hang on the chamber walls?

<BR>And what shall the pictures be that I hang on the walls,

<BR>To adorn the burial-house of him I love?



<P>&nbsp;Pictures of growing spring and farms and homes,

<BR>With the Fourth-month eve at sundown, and the gray smoke

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lucid and bright,

<BR>With floods of the yellow gold of the gorgeous, indolent,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sinking sun, burning, expanding the air,

<BR>With the fresh sweet herbage under foot, and the pale green

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leaves of the trees prolific,

<BR>In the distance the flowing glaze, the breast of the river, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a wind-dapple here and there,

<BR>With ranging hills on the banks, with many a line against the sky,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and shadows,

<BR>And the city at hand with dwellings so dense, and stacks of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chimneys,

<BR>And all the scenes of life and the workshops, and the workmen

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; homeward returning.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>12</CENTER>

Lo, body and soul&amp;emdash;this land,

<BR>My own Manhattan with spires, and the sparkling and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hurrying tides, and the ships,

<BR>The varied and ample land, the South and the North in the light,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ohio's shores and flashing Missouri,

<BR>And ever the far-spreading prairies cover'd with grass and corn.



<P>&nbsp;Lo, the most excellent sun so calm and haughty,

<BR>The violet and purple morn with just-felt breezes,

<BR>The gentle soft-born measureless light,

<BR>The miracle spreading bathing all, the fulfill'd noon,

<BR>The coming eve delicious, the welcome night and the stars,

<BR>Over my cities shining all, enveloping man and land.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>13</CENTER>

Sing on, sing on you gray-brown bird,

<BR>Sing from the swamps, the recesses, pour your chant from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the bushes,

<BR>Limitless out of the dusk, out of the cedars and pines.



<P>&nbsp;Sing on dearest brother, warble your reedy song,

<BR>Loud human song, with voice of uttermost woe.



<P>&nbsp;O liquid and free and tender!

<BR>O wild and loose to my soul&amp;emdash;O wondrous singer!

<BR>You only I hear&amp;emdash;yet the star holds me, (but will soon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; depart,)

<BR>Yet the lilac with mastering odor holds me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>14</CENTER>

Now while I sat in the day and look'd forth,

<BR>In the close of the day with its light and the fields of spring,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the farmers preparing their crops,

<BR>In the large unconscious scenery of my land with its lakes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and forests,

<BR>In the heavenly aerial beauty, (after the perturb'd winds and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the storms,)

<BR>Under the arching heavens of the afternoon swift passing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the voices of children and women,

<BR>The many-moving sea-tides, and I saw the ships how they sail'd,

<BR>And the summer approaching with richness, and the fields all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; busy with labor,

<BR>And the infinite separate houses, how they all went on, each

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with its meals and minutia of daily usages,

<BR>And the streets how their throbbings throbb'd, and the cities

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pent&amp;emdash;lo, then and there,

<BR>Falling upon them all and among them all, enveloping me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the rest,

<BR>Appear'd the cloud, appear'd the long black trail,

<BR>And I knew death, its thought, and the sacred knowledge of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death.



<P>&nbsp;Then with the knowledge of death as walking one side of me,

<BR>And the thought of death close-walking the other side of me,

<BR>And I in the middle as with companions, and as holding the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hands of companions,

<BR>I fled forth to the hiding receiving night that talks not,

<BR>Down to the shores of the water, the path by the swamp in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the dimness,

<BR>To the solemn shadowy cedars and ghostly pines so still.



<P>&nbsp;And the singer so shy to the rest receiv'd me,

<BR>The gray-brown bird I know receiv'd us comrades three,

<BR>And he sang the carol of death, and a verse for him I love.



<P>&nbsp;From deep secluded recesses,

<BR>From the fragrant cedars and the ghostly pines so still,

<BR>Came the carol of the bird.



<P>&nbsp;And the charm of the carol rapt me,

<BR>As I held as if by their hands my comrades in the night,

<BR>And the voice of my spirit tallied the song of the bird.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Come lovely and soothing death</I>,

<BR><I>Undulate round the world, serenely arriving, arriving,</I>

<BR><I>In the day, in the night, to all, to each</I>,

<BR><I>Sooner or later delicate death</I>



<P>&nbsp;<I>Prais'd be the fathomless universe</I>,

<BR><I>For life and joy, and for objects and knowledge curious</I>,

<BR><I>And for love, sweet love&amp;emdash;but praise! praise! praise</I>!

<BR><I>For the sure-enwinding arms of cool-enfolding death</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Dark mother always gliding near with soft feet</I>,

<BR><I>Have none chanted for thee a chant of fullest welcome</I>?

<BR><I>Then I chant it for thee, I glorify thee above all</I>,

<BR><I>I bring thee a song that when thou must indeed come, come</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unfalteringly</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Approach strong deliveress</I>,

<BR><I>When it is so, when thou hast taken them I joyously sing the</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dead</I>,

<BR><I>Lost in the loving floating ocean of thee</I>,

<BR><I>Laved in the flood of thy bliss O death</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>From me to thee glad serenades</I>,

<BR><I>Dances for thee I propose saluting thee, adornments and</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feastings for thee</I>,

<BR><I>And the sights of the open landscape and the high-spread sky</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are fitting</I>,

<BR><I>And life and the fields, and the huge and thoughtful night</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>The night in silence under many a star</I>,

<BR><I>The ocean shore and the husky whispering wave whose voice I</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know</I>,

<BR><I>And the soul turning to thee O vast and well-veil'd death</I>,

<BR><I>And the body gratefully nestling close to thee</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Over the tree-tops I float thee a song</I>,

<BR><I>Over the rising and sinking waves, over the myriad fields and the

prairies wide</I>,

<BR><I>Over the dense-pack'd cities all and the teeming wharves and</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ways</I>,

<BR><I>I float this carol with joy, with joy to thee O death</I>.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>15</CENTER>

To the tally of my soul,

<BR>Loud and strong kept up the gray-brown bird,

<BR>With pure deliberate notes spreading filling the night.

<BR>Loud in the pines and cedars dim,

<BR>Clear in the freshness moist and the swamp-perfume,

<BR>And I with my comrades there in the night.



<P>&nbsp;While my sight that was bound in my eyes unclosed,

<BR>As to long panoramas of visions.



<P>&nbsp;And I saw askant the armies,

<BR>I saw as in noiseless dreams hundreds of battle-flags,

<BR>Borne through the smoke of the battles and pier'd with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; missiles I saw them,

<BR>And carried hither and yon through the smoke, and torn and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bloody,

<BR>And at last but a few shreds left on the staffs, (and all in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; silence,)

<BR>And the staffs all splinter'd and broken.



<P>&nbsp;I saw battle-corpses, myriads of them,

<BR>And the white skeletons of young men, I saw them,

<BR>I saw the debris and debris of all the slain soldiers of the war,

<BR>But I saw they were not as was thought,

<BR>They themselves were fully at rest, they suffer'd not,

<BR>The living remain'd and suffer'd, the mother suffer'd,

<BR>And the wife and the child and the musing comrade suffer'd,

<BR>And the armies that remain'd suffer'd.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>16</CENTER>

Passing the visions, passing the night,

<BR>Passing, unloosing the hold of my comrades' hands,

<BR>Passing the song of the hermit bird and the tallying song of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my soul,

<BR>Victorious song, death's outlet song, yet varying ever-altering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; song,

<BR>As low and wailing, yet clear the notes, rising and falling,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flooding the night,

<BR>Sadly sinking and fainting, as warning and warning, and yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; again bursting with joy,

<BR>Covering the earth and filling the spread of the heaven,

<BR>As that powerful psalm in the night I heard from recesses,



<P>&nbsp;Passing, I leave thee lilac with heart-shaped leaves,

<BR>I leave thee there in the door-yard, blooming, returning with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spring.



<P>&nbsp;I cease from my song for thee,

<BR>From my gaze on thee in the west, fronting the west,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; communing with thee,

<BR>O comrade lustrous with silver face in the night.



<P>&nbsp;Yet each to keep and all, retrievements out of the night,

<BR>The song, the wondrous chant of the gray-brown bird,

<BR>And the tallying chant, the echo arous'd in my soul,

<BR>With the lustrous and drooping star with the countenance

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; full of woe,

<BR>With the holders holding my hand nearing the call of the bird,

<BR>Comrades mine and I in the midst, and their memory ever to keep,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for the dead I loved so well,

<BR>For the sweetest, wisest soul of all my days and lands&amp;emdash;and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this for his dear sake,

<BR>Lilac and star and bird twined with the chant of my soul,

<BR>There in the fragrant pines and the cedars dusk and dim.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1865-6&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

O CAPTAIN! MY CAPTAIN!</H2></CENTER>

O C<FONT SIZE=-1>aptain</FONT>! my Captain! our fearful trip is done,

<BR>The ship has weather'd every rack, the prize we sought is won,

<BR>The port is near, the bells I hear, the people all exulting,

<BR>While follow eyes the steady keel, the vessel grim and daring;



<P>&nbsp;But O heart! heart! heart!

<BR>O the bleeding drops of red,

<BR>Where on the deck my Captain lies,

<BR>Fallen cold and dead.



<P>&nbsp;O Captain! my Captain! rise up and hear the bells;

<BR>Rise up&amp;emdash;for you the flag is flung&amp;emdash;for you the

bugle trills,

<BR>For you bouquets and ribbon'd wreaths&amp;emdash;for you the shores

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a-crowding,

<BR>For you they call, the swaying mass, their eager faces

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; turning;

<BR>Here Captain! dear father!

<BR>The arm beneath your head!

<BR>It is some dream that on the deck,

<BR>You've fallen cold and dead.



<P>&nbsp;My Captain does not answer, his lips are pale and still,

<BR>My father does not feel my arm, he has no pulse nor will,

<BR>The ship is anchor'd safe and sound, its voyage closed and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; done,

<BR>From fearful trip the victor ship comes in with object won:

<BR>Exult O shores, and ring O bells!

<BR>But I with mournful tread,

<BR>Walk the deck my Captain lies,

<BR>Fallen cold and dead.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

HUSH'D BE THE CAMPS TO-DAY</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>May</I> 4, 1865)</CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>ush'd</FONT> be the camps to-day,

<BR>And soldiers let us drape our war-worn weapons,

<BR>And each with musing soul retire to celebrate,

<BR>Our dear commander's death.



<P>&nbsp;No more for him life's stormy conflicts,

<BR>Nor victory, nor defeat&amp;emdash;no more time's dark events,

<BR>Charging like ceaseless clouds across the sky.



<P>&nbsp;But sing poet in our name,

<BR>Sing of the love we bore him&amp;emdash;because you&amp;emdash;dweller

in camps,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know it truly.



<P>&nbsp;As they invault the coffin there,

<BR>Sing&amp;emdash;as they close the doors of earth upon him&amp;emdash;one

verse,

<BR>For the heavy hearts of soldiers.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THIS DUST WAS ONCE THE MAN</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>his</FONT> dust was once the man,

<BR>Gentle, plain, just and resolute, under whose cautious hand,

<BR>Against the foulest crime in history known in any land or age,

<BR>Was saved the Union of these States.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : A Song for Occupations</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>A Song for Occupations</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>A <FONT SIZE=-1>SONG</FONT> for occupations!

<BR>In the labor of engines and trades and the labor of fields

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I find the developments,

<BR>And find the eternal meanings.



<P>&nbsp;Workmen and Workwomen!

<BR>Were all educations practical and ornamental well display'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; out of me, what would it amount to?

<BR>Were I as the head teacher, charitable proprietor, wise

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; statesman, what would it amount to?

<BR>Were I to you as the boss employing and paying you, would

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that satisfy you?



<P>&nbsp;The learn'd, virtuous, benevolent, and the usual terms,

<BR>A man like me and never the usual terms.



<P>&nbsp;Neither a servant nor a master I,

<BR>I take no sooner a large price than a small price, I will

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; have my own whoever enjoys me,

<BR>I will be even with you and you shall be even with me.



<P>&nbsp;If you stand at work in a shop I stand as nigh as the nighest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the same shop,

<BR>If you bestow gifts on your brother or dearest friend I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; demand as good as your brother or dearest

friend,

<BR>If your lover, husband, wife, is welcome by day or night, I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; must be personally as welcome,

<BR>If you become degraded, criminal, ill, then I become so for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your sake,

<BR>If you remember your foolish and outlaw'd deeds, do you think

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I cannot remember my own foolish and outlaw'd

deeds?

<BR>If you carouse at the table I carouse at the opposite side of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the table,

<BR>If you meet some stranger in the streets and love him or her,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; why I often meet strangers in the street and

love them.



<P>&nbsp;Why what have you thought of yourself?

<BR>Is it you then that thought yourself less?

<BR>Is it you that thought the President greater than you?

<BR>Or the rich better off than you? or the educated wiser than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you?



<P>&nbsp;(Because you are greasy or pimpled, or were once drunk,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or a thief,

<BR>Or that you are diseas'd, or rheumatic, or a prostitute,

<BR>Or from frivolity or impotence, or that you are no scholar

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and never saw your name in print,

<BR>Do you give in that you are any less immortal?)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Souls of men and women! it is not you I call unseen, unheard,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untouchable and untouching,

<BR>It is not you I go argue pro and con about, and to settle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whether you are alive or no,

<BR>I own publicly who you are, if nobody else owns.



<P>&nbsp;Grown, half-grown and babe, of this country and every

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; country, indoors and out-doors, one just as

much as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the other, I see,

<BR>And all else behind or through them.



<P>&nbsp;The wife, and she is not one jot less than the husband,

<BR>The daughter, and she is just as good as the son,

<BR>The mother, and she is every bit as much as the father.



<P>&nbsp;Offspring of ignorant and poor, boys apprenticed to trades,

<BR>Young fellows working on farms and old fellows working on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; farms,

<BR>Sailor-men, merchant-men, coasters, immigrants,

<BR>All these I see, but nigher and farther the same I see,

<BR>None shall escape me and none shall wish to escape me.



<P>&nbsp;I bring what you much need yet always have,

<BR>Not money, amours, dress, eating, erudition, but as good,

<BR>I send no agent or medium, offer no representative of value,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but offer the value itself.



<P>&nbsp;There is something that comes to one now and perpetually,

<BR>It is not what is printed, preach'd, discussed, it eludes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; discussion and print,

<BR>It is not to be put in a book, it is not in this book,

<BR>It is for you whoever you are, it is no farther from you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than your hearing and sight are from you,

<BR>It is hinted by nearest, commonest, readiest, it is ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; provoked by them.



<P>&nbsp;You may read in many languages, yet read nothing about it,

<BR>You may read the President's message and read nothing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; about it there,

<BR>Nothing in the reports from the State department or Treasury

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; department, or in the daily papers or weekly

papers,

<BR>Or in the census or revenue returns, prices current, or any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accounts of stock.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>The sun and stars that float in the open air,

<BR>The apple-shaped earth and we upon it, surely the drift of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them is something grand,



<P>&nbsp;I do not know what it is except that it is grand, and that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it is happiness,

<BR>And that the enclosing purport of us here is not a speculation

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or bon-mot or reconnoissance,

<BR>And that it is not something which by luck may turn out well

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for us, and without luck must be a failure

for us,

<BR>And not something which may yet be retracted in a certain

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contingency.



<P>&nbsp;The light and shade, the curious sense of body and identity, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; greed that with perfect complaisance devours

all things,

<BR>The endless pride and outstretching of man, unspeakable joys

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sorrows,

<BR>The wonder every one sees in every one else he sees, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wonders that fill each minute of time forever,

<BR>What have you reckon'd them for, camerado?

<BR>Have you reckon'd them for your trade or farm-work? or for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the profits of your store?

<BR>Or to achieve yourself a position? or to fill a gentleman's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leisure, or a lady's leisure?



<P>&nbsp;Have you reckon'd that the landscape took substance and form

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that it might be painted in a picture?

<BR>Or men and women that they might be written of, and songs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sung?

<BR>Or the attraction of gravity, and the great laws and harmonious

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; combinations and the fluids of the air, as

subjects for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; savans?

<BR>Or the brown land and the blue sea for maps and charts?

<BR>Or the stars to be put in constellations and named fancy names?

<BR>Or that the growth of seeds is for agricultural tables, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; agriculture itself?



<P>&nbsp;Old institutions, these arts, libraries, legends, collections,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the practice handed along in manufactures,

will we rate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them so high?

<BR>Will we rate our cash and business high? I have no objection,

<BR>I rate them as high as the highest &amp;emdash; then a child born

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of a woman and man I rate beyond all rate.



<P>&nbsp;We thought our Union grand, and our Constitution grand,

<BR>I do not say they are not grand and good, for they are,

<BR>I am this day just as much in love with them as you,

<BR>Then I am in love with You, and with all my fellows upon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the earth.



<P>&nbsp;We consider bibles and religions divine &amp;emdash; I do not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; say they are not divine,

<BR>I say they have all grown out of you, and may grow out of you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; still,

<BR>It is not they who give the life, it is you who give the life,

<BR>Leaves are not more shed from the trees, or trees from the earth,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than they are shed out of you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>The sum of all known reverence I add up in you whoever you are,

<BR>The President is there in the White House for you, it is not you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; who are here for him,

<BR>The Secretaries act in their bureaus for you, not you here for them,

<BR>The Congress convenes every Twelfth-month for you,

<BR>Laws, courts, the forming of States, the charters of cities, the going

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and coming of commerce and mails, are all

for you.



<P>&nbsp;List close my scholars dear,

<BR>Doctrines, politics and civilization exurge from you,

<BR>Sculpture and monuments and any thing inscribed anywhere are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tallied in you,

<BR>The gist of histories and statistics as far back as the records

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reach is in you this hour, and myths and tales

the same,

<BR>If you were not breathing and walking here, where would they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all be?

<BR>The most renown'd poems would be ashes, orations and plays

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; would be vacuums.



<P>&nbsp;All architecture is what you do to it when you look upon it,

<BR>(Did you think it was in the white or gray stone? or the lines

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the arches and cornices?)



<P>&nbsp;All music is what awakes from you when you are reminded

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by the instruments,

<BR>It is not the violins and the cornets, it is not the oboe nor

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the beating drums, nor the score of the baritone

singer

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; singing his sweet romanza, nor that of the

men's chorus,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nor that of the women's chorus,

<BR>It is nearer and farther than they.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>Will the whole come back then?

<BR>Can each see signs of the best by a look in the looking-glass?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is there nothing greater or more?

<BR>Does all sit there with you, with the mystic unseen soul?



<P>&nbsp;Strange and hard that paradox true I give,

<BR>Objects gross and the unseen soul are one.



<P>&nbsp;House-building, measuring, sawing the boards,

<BR>Blacksmithing, glass-blowing, nail-making, coopering,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tin-roofing, shingle-dressing,

<BR>Ship-joining, dock-building, fish-curing, flagging of sidewalks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by flaggers,

<BR>The pump, the pile-driver, the great derrick, the coal-kiln

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and brick-kiln,

<BR>Coal-mines and all that is down there, the lamps in the darkness,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; echoes, songs, what meditations, what vast

native thoughts

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; looking through smutch'd faces,

<BR>Iron-works, forge-fires in the mountains or by river-banks, men

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; around feeling the melt with huge crowbars,

lumps of ore,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the due combining of ore, limestone, coal,

<BR>The blast-furnace and the puddling-furnace, the loup-lump at the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bottom of the melt at last, the rolling-mill,

the stumpy bars

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of pig-iron, the strong, clean-shaped T-rail

for railroads,

<BR>Oil-works, silk-works, white-lead-works, the sugar-house,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steam-saws, the great mills and factories,

<BR>Stone-cutting, shapely trimmings for fa&ccedil;ades or window or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; door-lintels, the mallet, the tooth-chisel,

the jib to protect

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the thumb,

<BR>The calking-iron, the kettle of boiling vault-cement, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fire under the kettle,



<P>&nbsp;The cotton-bale, the stevedore's hook, the saw and buck of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sawyer, the mould of the moulder, the working-knife

of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; butcher, the ice-saw, and all the work with

ice,

<BR>The work and tools of the rigger, grappler, sail-maker, block-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; maker,

<BR>Goods of gutta-percha, papier-mach&eacute;, colors, brushes, brush-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; making, glazier's implements,

<BR>The veneer and glue-pot, the confectioner's ornaments, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; decanter and glasses, the shears and flat-iron,

<BR>The awl and knee-strap, the pint measure and quart measure,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the counter and stool, the writing-pen of

quill or metal, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; making of all sorts of edged tools,

<BR>The brewery, brewing, the malt, the vats, everything that is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; done by brewers, wine-makers, vinegar-makers,

<BR>Leather-dressing, coach-making, boiler-making, rope-twisting,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; distilling, sign-painting, lime-burning, cotton-picking,

electro-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; plating, electrotyping, stereotyping,

<BR>Stave-machines, planing-machines, reaping-machines,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ploughing-machines, thrashing-machines, steam

wagons,

<BR>The cart of the carman, the omnibus, the ponderous dray,

<BR>Pyrotechny, letting off color'd fireworks at night, fancy figures

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and jets;

<BR>Beef on the butcher's stall, the slaughter-house of the butcher,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the butcher in his killing-clothes,

<BR>The pens of live pork, the killing-hammer, the hog-hook, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; scalder's tub, gutting, the cutter's cleaver,

the packer's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; maul, and the plenteous winterwork of pork-packing,

<BR>Flour-works, grinding of wheat, rye, maize, rice, the barrels

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the half and quarter barrels, the loaded

barges, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; high piles on wharves and levees,

<BR>The men and the work of the men on ferries, railroad,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; coasters, fish-boats, canals;

<BR>The hourly routine of your own or any man's life, the shop,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yard, store, or factory,

<BR>These shows all near you by day and night&amp;emdash;workman!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whoever you are, your daily life!

<BR>In that and them the heft of the heaviest&amp;emdash;in that and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them far more than you estimated, (and far

less also,)

<BR>In them realities for you and me, in them poems for you and me,



<P>&nbsp;In them, not yourself&amp;emdash;you and your soul enclose all

things,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; regardless of estimation,

<BR>In them the development good&amp;emdash;in them all themes, hints,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; possibilities.

<BR>I do not affirm that what you see beyond is futile, I do not advise

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you to stop,

<BR>I do not say leadings you thought great are not great,

<BR>But I say that none lead to greater than these lead to.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>Will you seek afar off? you surely come back at last,

<BR>In things best known to you finding the best, or as good as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the best,

<BR>In folks nearest to you finding the sweetest, strongest,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lovingest,

<BR>Happiness, knowledge, not in another place but this place,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not for another hour but this hour,

<BR>Man in the first you see or touch, always in friend, brother,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nighest neighbor&amp;emdash;woman in mother,

sister, wife,

<BR>The popular tastes and employments taking precedence in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poems or anywhere,

<BR>You workwomen and workmen of these States having your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; own divine and strong life,

<BR>And all else giving place to men and women like you.



<P>&nbsp;When the psalm sings instead of the singer,

<BR>When the script preaches instead of the preacher,

<BR>When the pulpit descends and goes instead of the carver that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; carved the supporting desk,

<BR>When I can touch the body of books by night or by day, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; when they touch my body back again,

<BR>When a university course convinces like a slumbering woman

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and child convince,

<BR>When the minted gold in the vault smiles like the night-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; watchman's daughter,

<BR>When warrantee deeds loafe in chairs opposite and are my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; friendly companions,

<BR>I intend to reach them my hand, and make as much of them as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I do of men and women like you.

<PRE>1855&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Song of the Open Road</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Song of the Open Road</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>A<FONT SIZE=-1>FOOT</FONT> and light-hearted I take to the open road,

<BR>Healthy, free, the world before me,

<BR>The long brown path before me leading wherever I choose.



<P>&nbsp;Henceforth I ask not good-fortune, I myself am good-fortune,

<BR>Henceforth I whimper no more, postpone no more, need

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nothing,

<BR>Done with indoor complaints, libraries, querulous criticisms,

<BR>Strong and content I travel the open road.



<P>&nbsp;The earth, that is sufficient,

<BR>I do not want the constellations any nearer,

<BR>I know they are very well where they are,

<BR>I know they suffice for those who belong to them.



<P>&nbsp;(Still here I carry my old delicious burdens,

<BR>I carry them, men and women, I carry them with me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wherever I go,



<P>&nbsp;I swear it is impossible for me to get rid of them,

<BR>I am fill'd with them; and I will fill them in return.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>You road I enter upon and look around, I believe you are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not all that is here,

<BR>I believe that much unseen is also here.



<P>&nbsp;Here the profound lesson of reception, nor preference nor

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; denial,

<BR>The black with his woolly head, the felon, the diseas'd, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; illiterate person, are not denied;

<BR>The birth, the hasting after the physician, the beggar's tramp,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the drunkard's stagger, the laughing party

of mechanics,

<BR>The escaped youth, the rich person's carriage, the fop, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eloping couple,

<BR>The early market-man, the hearse, the moving of furniture

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; into the town, the return back from the town,

<BR>They pass, I also pass, any thing passes, none can be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; interdicted,

<BR>None but are accepted, none but shall be dear to me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>You air that serves me with breath to speak!

<BR>You objects that call from diffusion my meanings and give

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them shape!

<BR>You light that wraps me and all things in delicate equable

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; showers!

<BR>You paths worn in the irregular hollows by the roadsides!

<BR>I believe you are latent with unseen existences, you are so

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dear to me.



<P>&nbsp;You flagg'd walks of the cities! you strong curbs at the edges!

<BR>You ferries! you planks and posts of wharves! you timberlined

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sides! you distant ships!

<BR>You rows of houses! you window-pierc'd fa&ccedil;ades! you roofs!

<BR>You porches and entrances! you copings and iron guards!

<BR>You windows whose transparent shells might expose so much!



<P>&nbsp;You doors and ascending steps! you arches!

<BR>You gray stones of interminable pavements! you trodden

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crossings!

<BR>From all that has touch'd you I believe you have imparted to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yourselves, and now would impart the same

secretly to me,

<BR>From the living and the dead you have peopled your impassive

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; surfaces, and the spirits thereof would be

evident and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amicable with me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>The earth expanding right hand and left hand,

<BR>The picture alive, every part in its best light,

<BR>The music falling in where it is wanted, and stopping where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it is not wanted,

<BR>The cheerful voice of the public road, the gay fresh sentiment

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the road.



<P>&nbsp;O highway I travel, do you say to me <I>Do not leave me?</I>

<BR>Do you say <I>Venture not&amp;emdash;if you leave me you are lost?</I>

<BR>Do you say <I>I am already prepared, I am well-beaten and</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; undenied, adhere to me?</I>



<P>&nbsp;O public road, I say back I am not afraid to leave you, yet I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; love you,

<BR>You express me better than I can express myself,

<BR>You shall be more to me than my poem.



<P>&nbsp;I think heroic deeds were all conceiv'd in the open air, and all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; free poems also,

<BR>I think I could stop here myself and do miracles,

<BR>I think whatever I shall meet on the road I shall like, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whoever beholds me shall like me,

<BR>I think whoever I see must be happy.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>From this hour I ordain myself loos'd of limits and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; imaginary lines,

<BR>Going where I list, my own master total and absolute,

<BR>Listening to others, considering well what they say,



<P>&nbsp;Pausing, searching, receiving, contemplating,

<BR>Gently, but with undeniable will, divesting myself of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; holds that would hold me.



<P>&nbsp;I inhale great draughts of space,

<BR>The east and the west are mine, and the north and the south

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are mine.



<P>&nbsp;I am larger, better than I thought,

<BR>I did not know I held so much goodness.



<P>&nbsp;All seems beautiful to me,

<BR>I can repeat over to men and women You have done such

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; good to me I would do the same to you,

<BR>I will recruit for myself and you as I go,

<BR>I will scatter myself among men and women as I go,

<BR>I will toss a new gladness and roughness among them,

<BR>Whoever denies me it shall not trouble me,

<BR>Whoever accepts me he or she shall be blessed and shall bless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>Now if a thousand perfect men were to appear it would not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amaze me,

<BR>Now if a thousand beautiful forms of women appear'd it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; would not astonish me.



<P>&nbsp;Now I see the secret of the making of the best persons,

<BR>It is to grow in the open air and to eat and sleep with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth.



<P>&nbsp;Here a great personal deed has room,

<BR>(Such a deed seizes upon the hearts of the whole race of men,

<BR>Its effusion of strength and will overwhelms law and mocks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all authority and all argument against it.)



<P>&nbsp;Here is the test of wisdom,

<BR>Wisdom is not finally tested in schools,

<BR>Wisdom cannot be pass'd from one having it to another not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; having it,



<P>&nbsp;Wisdom is of the soul, is not susceptible of proof, is its own

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; proof,

<BR>Applies to all stages and objects and qualities and is content,

<BR>Is the certainty of the reality and immortality of things, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the excellence of things;

<BR>Something there is in the float of the sight of things that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; provokes it out of the soul.



<P>&nbsp;Now I re-examine philosophies and religions,

<BR>They may prove well in lecture-rooms, yet not prove at all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; under the spacious clouds and along the landscape

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flowing currents.



<P>&nbsp;Here is realization,

<BR>Here is a man tallied&amp;emdash;he realizes here what he has in him,

<BR>The past, the future, majesty, love&amp;emdash;if they are vacant of

you,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you are vacant of them.



<P>&nbsp;Only the kernel of every object nourishes;

<BR>Where is he who tears off the husks for you and me?

<BR>Where is he that undoes stratagems and envelopes for you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and me?



<P>&nbsp;Here is adhesiveness, it is not previously fashion'd, it is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; apropos;

<BR>Do you know what it is as you pass to be loved by strangers?

<BR>Do you know the talk of those turning eye-balls?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>Here is the efflux of the soul,

<BR>The efflux of the soul comes from within through embower'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gates, ever provoking questions,

<BR>These yearnings why are they? these thoughts in the darkness

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; why are they?

<BR>Why are there men and women that while they are nigh me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sunlight expands my blood?

<BR>Why when they leave me do my pennants of joy sink flat and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lank?

<BR>Why are there trees I never walk under but large and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; melodious thoughts descend upon me?



<P>&nbsp;(I think they hang there winter and summer on those trees

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and always drop fruit as I pass;)

<BR>What is it I interchange so suddenly with strangers?

<BR>What with some driver as I ride on the seat by his side?

<BR>What with some fisherman drawing his seine by the shore as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I walk by and pause?

<BR>What gives me to be free to a woman's and man's good-will?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what gives them to be free to mine?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>The efflux of the soul is happiness, here is happiness,

<BR>I think it pervades the open air, waiting at all times,

<BR>Now it flows unto us, we are rightly charged.



<P>&nbsp;Here rises the fluid and attaching character,

<BR>The fluid and attaching character is the freshness and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sweetness of man and woman,

<BR>(The herbs of the morning sprout no fresher and sweeter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every day out of the roots of themselves,

than it sprouts

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fresh and sweet continually out of itself.)

<BR>Toward the fluid and attaching character exudes the sweat of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the love of young and old,

<BR>From it falls distill'd the charm that mocks beauty and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; attainments,

<BR>Toward it heaves the shuddering longing ache of contact.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>9</CENTER>





<P>Allons! whoever you are come travel with me!

<BR>Travelling with me you find what never tires.



<P>&nbsp;The earth never tires,

<BR>The earth is rude, silent, incomprehensible at first, Nature is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rude and incomprehensible at first,

<BR>Be not discouraged, keep on, there are divine things well

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; envelop'd,

<BR>I swear to you there are divine things more beautiful than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; words can tell.



<P>&nbsp;Allons! we must not stop here,

<BR>However sweet these laid-up stores, however convenient this

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dwelling we cannot remain here,

<BR>However shelter'd this port and however calm these waters

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; we must not anchor here,

<BR>However welcome the hospitality that surrounds us we are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; permitted to receive it but a little while.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>10</CENTER>





<P>Allons! the inducements shall be greater,

<BR>We will sail pathless and wild seas,

<BR>We will go where winds blow, waves dash, and the Yankee

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clipper speeds by under full sail.



<P>&nbsp;Allons! with power, liberty, the earth, the elements,

<BR>Health, defiance, gayety, self-esteem, curiosity;

<BR>Allons! from all formules!

<BR>From your formules, O bat-eyed and materialistic priests.



<P>&nbsp;The stale cadaver blocks up the passage&amp;emdash;the burial

waits no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; longer.



<P>&nbsp;Allons! yet take warning!

<BR>He traveling with me needs the best blood, thews, endurance,

<BR>None may come to the trial till he or she bring courage and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; health,

<BR>Come not here if you have already spent the best of yourself,

<BR>Only those may come who come in sweet and determin'd bodies,

<BR>No diseas'd person, no rum-drinker or venereal taint is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; permitted here.



<P>&nbsp;(I and mine do not convince by arguments, similes, rhymes,

<BR>We convince by our presence.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>11</CENTER>





<P>Listen! I will be honest with you,

<BR>I do not offer the old smooth prizes, but offer rough new prizes,

<BR>These are the days that must happen to you:



<P>&nbsp;You shall not heap up what is call'd riches,

<BR>You shall scatter with lavish hand all that you earn or achieve,

<BR>You but arrive at the city to which you were destin'd, you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hardly settle yourself to satisfaction before

you are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; call'd by an irresistible call to depart,

<BR>You shall be treated to the ironical smiles and mockings of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those who remain behind you,

<BR>What beckonings of love you receive you shall only answer

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with passionate kisses of parting,

<BR>You shall not allow the hold of those who spread their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reach'd hands toward you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>12</CENTER>





<P>Allons! after the great Companions, and to belong to them!

<BR>They too are on the road&amp;emdash;they are the swift and majestic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men&amp;emdash;they are the greatest women,

<BR>Enjoyers of calms of seas and storms of seas,

<BR>Sailors of many a ship, walkers of many a mile of land,

<BR>Habitu&egrave;s of many distant countries, habitu&egrave;s of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; far-distant dwellings,

<BR>Trusters of men and women, observers of cities, solitary

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; toilers,

<BR>Pausers and contemplators of tufts, blossoms, shells of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shore,

<BR>Dancers at wedding-dances, kissers of brides, tender helpers of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; children, bearers of children,

<BR>Soldiers of revolts, standers by gaping graves, lowerers-down

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of coffins,

<BR>Journeyers over consecutive seasons, over the years, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; curious years each emerging from that which

proceded it,

<BR>Journeyers as with companions, namely their own diverse

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; phases,

<BR>Forth-steppers from the latent unrealized baby-days,

<BR>Journeyers gayly with their own youth, journeyers with their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bearded and well-grain'd manhood,

<BR>Journeyers with their womanhood, ample, unsurpass'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; content,

<BR>Journeyers with their own sublime old age of manhood or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; womanhood,



<P>&nbsp;Old age, calm, expanded, broad with the haughty breadth of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the universe,

<BR>Old age, flowing free with the delicious near-by freedom of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>13</CENTER>





<P>Allons! to that which is endless as it was beginningless,

<BR>To undergo much, tramps of days, rests of nights,

<BR>To merge all in the travel they tend to, and the days and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nights they tend to,

<BR>Again to merge them in the start of superior journeys,

<BR>To see nothing anywhere but what you may reach it and pass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it,

<BR>To conceive no time, however distant, but what you may

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reach it and pass it,

<BR>To look up or down no road but it stretches and waits for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you, however long but it stretches and waits

for you,

<BR>To see no being, not God's or any, but you also go thither,

<BR>To see no possession but you may possess it, enjoying all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; without labor or purchase, abstracting the

feast yet not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; abstracting one particle of it,

<BR>To take the best of the farmer's farm and the rich man's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; elegant villa, and the chaste blessings of

the well-married

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; couple, and the fruits of orchards and flowers

of gardens,

<BR>To take to your use out of the compact cities as you pass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through,

<BR>To carry buildings and streets with you afterward wherever you go,

<BR>To gather the minds of men out of their brains as you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; encounter them, to gather the love out of

their hearts,

<BR>To take your lovers on the road with you, for all that you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leave them behind you,

<BR>To know the universe itself as a road, as many roads, as roads

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for traveling souls.



<P>&nbsp;All parts away for the progress of souls,

<BR>All religion, all solid things, arts, governments&amp;emdash;all that

was

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or is apparent upon this globe or any globe,

falls into

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; niches and corners before the procession of

souls along

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the grand roads of the universe.



<P>&nbsp;Of the progress of the souls of men and women along the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grand roads of the universe, all other progress

is the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; needed emblem and sustenance.



<P>&nbsp;Forever alive, forever forward,

<BR>Stately, solemn, sad, withdrawn, baffled, mad, turbulent,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feeble, dissatisfied,

<BR>Desperate, proud, fond, sick, accepted by men, rejected by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men,

<BR>They go! they go! I know that they go, but I know not where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they go,

<BR>But I know that they go toward the best&amp;emdash;toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; something great.



<P>&nbsp;Whoever you are, come forth! or man or woman come forth!

<BR>You must not stay sleeping and dallying there in the house,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; though you built it, or though it has been

built for you.



<P>&nbsp;Out of the dark confinement! out from behind the screen!

<BR>It is useless to protest, I know all and expose it.



<P>&nbsp;Behold through you as bad as the rest,

<BR>Through the laughter, dancing, dining, supping, of people,

<BR>Inside of dresses and ornaments, inside of those wash'd and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trimm'd faces,

<BR>Behold a secret silent loathing and despair.



<P>&nbsp;No husband, no wife, no friend, trusted to hear the confession,

<BR>Another self, a duplicate of every one, skulking and hiding it goes,

<BR>Formless and wordless through the streets of the cities, polite

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and bland in the parlors,

<BR>In the cars of railroads, in steamboats, in the public assembly,

<BR>Home to the houses of men and women, at the table, in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bedroom, everywhere,

<BR>Smartly attired, countenance smiling, form upright, death

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; under the breast-bones, hell under the skull-bones,

<BR>Under the broadcloth and gloves, under the ribbons and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; artificial flowers,



<P>&nbsp;Keeping fair with the customs, speaking not a syllable of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself,

<BR>Speaking of any thing else but never of itself.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>14</CENTER>





<P>Allons! through struggles and wars!

<BR>The goal that was named cannot be countermanded.



<P>&nbsp;Have the past struggles succeeded?

<BR>What has succeeded? yourself? your nation? Nature?

<BR>Now understand me well&amp;emdash;it is provided in the essence of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; things that from any fruition of success,

no matter what,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall come forth something to make a greater

struggle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; necessary.



<P>&nbsp;My call is the call of battle, I nourish active rebellion,

<BR>He going with me must go well arm'd,

<BR>He going with me goes often with spare diet, poverty, angry

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; enemies, desertions.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>15</CENTER>





<P>Allons! the road is before us!

<BR>It is safe&amp;emdash;I have tried it&amp;emdash;my own feet have tried

it well&amp;emdash;be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not detain'd!

<BR>Let the paper remain on the desk unwritten, and the book on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the shelf unopen'd!



<P>&nbsp;Let the tools remain in the workshop! let the money remain

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unearn'd!

<BR>Let the school stand! mind not the cry of the teacher!

<BR>Let the preacher preach in his pulpit! let the lawyer plead in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the court, and the judge expound the law.



<P>&nbsp;Camerado, I give you my hand!

<BR>I give you my love more precise than money,

<BR>I give you myself before preaching or law;

<BR>Will you give me yourself? will you come travel with me?

<BR>Shall we stick by each other as long as we live?

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : By the Roadside</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B><I><FONT SIZE=+3>By the Roadside</FONT></I></B></CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>A BOSTON BALLAD</CENTER>



<CENTER>(1854)</CENTER>



<CENTER>&nbsp;</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>

To get betimes in Boston town I rose this morning early,

<BR>Here's a good place at the corner, I must stand and see the show.



<P>&nbsp;Clear the way there Jonathan!

<BR>Way for the President's marshal&amp;emdash;way for the government cannon!

<BR>Way for the Federal foot and dragoons, (and the apparitions copiously

tumbling.)



<P>&nbsp;I love to look on the Stars and Stripes, I hope the fifes will

play Yankee Doodle.



<P>&nbsp;How bright shine the cutlasses of the foremost troops!

<BR>Every man holds his revolver, marching stiff through Boston town.



<P>&nbsp;A fog follows, antiques of the same come limping,

<BR>Some appear wooden-legged, and some appear bandaged and bloodless.



<P>&nbsp;Why this is indeed a show&amp;emdash;it has called the dead out

of the earth!

<BR>The old graveyards of the hills have hurried to see!

<BR>Phantoms! phantoms countless by flank and rear!

<BR>Cock'd hats of mothy mould&amp;emdash;crutches made of mist!

<BR>Arms in slings&amp;emdash;old men leaning on young men's shoulders.



<P>&nbsp;What troubles you Yankee phantoms? what is all this chattering

of bare gums?



<P>&nbsp;Does the ague convulse your limbs? do you mistake your crutches

for firelocks and level them?



<P>&nbsp;If you blind your eyes with tears you will not see the President's

marshal,

<BR>If you groan such groans you might balk the government cannon.



<P>&nbsp;For shame old maniacs&amp;emdash;bring down those toss'd arms,

and let your white hair be,

<BR>Here gape your great-grandsons, their wives gaze at them from the windows,

<BR>See how well dress'd, see how orderly they conduct themselves.



<P>&nbsp;Worse and worse&amp;emdash;can't you stand it? are you retreating?

<BR>Is this hour with the living too dead for you?



<P>&nbsp;Retreat then&amp;emdash;pell-mell!

<BR>To your graves&amp;emdash;back&amp;emdash;back to the hills old limpers!

<BR>I do not think you belong here anyhow.



<P>&nbsp;But there is one thing that belongs here&amp;emdash;shall I tell

you what it is, gentlemen of Boston?



<P>&nbsp;I will whisper it to the Mayor, he shall send a committee to England,

<BR>They shall get a grant from the Parliament, go with a cart to the royal

vault,

<BR>Dig out King George's coffin, unwrap him quick from the grave-clothes,

box up his bones for a journey,

<BR>Find a swift Yankee clipper&amp;emdash;here is freight for you, blackbellied

clipper,

<BR>Up with your anchor&amp;emdash;shake out your sails&amp;emdash;steer

straight toward Boston bay.



<P>&nbsp;Now call for the President's marshal again, bring out the government

cannon,

<BR>Fetch home the roarers from Congress, make another procession, guard

it with foot and dragoons.



<P>&nbsp;This centre-piece for them;

<BR>Look, all orderly citizens&amp;emdash;look from the windows, women!



<P>&nbsp;The committee open the box, set up the regal ribs, glue those

that will not stay,

<BR>Clap the skull on top of the ribs, and clap a crown on top of the skull.



<P>&nbsp;You have got your revenge, old buster&amp;emdash;the crown is

come to its own, and more than its own.



<P>&nbsp;Stick your hands in your pockets, Jonathan&amp;emdash;you are

a made man from this day,

<BR>You are mighty cute&amp;emdash;and here is one of your bargains.

<PRE>(1854?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>EUROPE</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>The 72d and 73d Years of These States</I></CENTER>

S<c>uddenly</c> out of its stale and drowsy lair, the lair of slaves,

<BR>Like lightning it le'pt forth half startled at itself,

<BR>Its feet upon the ashes and the rags, its hand tight to the throats

of kings.



<P>&nbsp;O hope and faith!

<BR>O aching close of exiled patriots' lives!

<BR>O many a sicken'd heart!

<BR>Turn back unto this day and make yourselves afresh.



<P>&nbsp;And you, paid to defile the People&amp;emdash;you liars, mark!

<BR>Not for numberless agonies, murders, lusts,

<BR>For court thieving in its manifold mean forms, worming from his simplicity

the poor man's wages,

<BR>For many a promise sworn by royal lips and broken and laugh'd at in

the breaking,

<BR>Then in their power not for all these did the blows strike revenge,

or the heads of the nobles fall;

<BR>The People scorn'd the ferocity of kings.



<P>&nbsp;But the sweetness of mercy brew'd bitter destruction, and the

frighten'd monarchs come back,

<BR>Each comes in state with his train, hangman, priest, taxgatherer,

<BR>Soldier, lawyer, lord, jailer, and sycophant.



<P>&nbsp;Yet behind all lowering stealing, lo, a shape,

<BR>Vague as the night, draped interminably, head, front and form, in scarlet

folds,

<BR>Whose face and eyes none may see,

<BR>Out of its robes only this, the red robes lifted by the arm,

<BR>One finger crook'd pointed high over the top, like the head of a snake

appears.



<P>&nbsp;Meanwhile corpses lie in new-made graves, bloody corpses of young

men,

<BR>The rope of the gibbet hangs heavily, the bullets of princes are flying,

the creatures of power laugh aloud,

<BR>And all these things bear fruits, and they are good.



<P>&nbsp;Those corpses of young men,

<BR>Those martyrs that hang from the gibbets, those hearts pierc'd by the

gray lead,

<BR>Cold and motionless as they seem live elsewhere with unslaughter'd

vitality.



<P>&nbsp;They live in other young men O kings!

<BR>They live in brothers again ready to defy you,

<BR>They were purified by death, they were taught and exalted.



<P>&nbsp;Not a grave of the murder'd for freedom but grows seed for freedom,

in its turn to bear seed,

<BR>Which the winds carry afar and re-sow, and the rains and the snows

nourish.



<P>&nbsp;Not a disembodied spirit can the weapons of tyrants let loose,

<BR>But it stalks invisibly over the earth, whispering, counseling, cautioning.



<P>&nbsp;Liberty, let others despair of you&amp;emdash;I never despair

of you.



<P>&nbsp;Is the house shut? is the master away?

<BR>Nevertheless, be ready, be not weary of watching,

<BR>He will soon return, his messengers come anon.

<PRE>1850&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>A HAND-MIRROR</CENTER>

H<c>old</c> it up sternly&amp;emdash;see this it sends back, (who is it?

is it you?)

<BR>Outside fair costume, within ashes and filth,

<BR>No more a flashing eye, no more a sonorous voice or springy step,

<BR>Now some slave's eye, voice, hands, step,

<BR>A drunkard's breath, unwholesome eater's face, venerealee's flesh,

<BR>Lungs rotting away piecemeal, stomach sour and cankerous,

<BR>Joints rheumatic, bowels clogged with abomination,

<BR>Blood circulating dark and poisonous streams,

<BR>Words babble, hearing and touch callous,

<BR>No brain, no heart left, no magnetism of sex;

<BR>Such from one look in this looking-glass ere you go hence,

<BR>Such a result so soon&amp;emdash;and from such a beginning!

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>GODS</CENTER>

L<c>over</c> divine and perfect Comrade,

<BR>Waiting content, invisible yet, but certain,

<BR>Be thou my God.



<P>&nbsp;Thou, thou, the Ideal Man,

<BR>Fair, able, beautiful, content, and loving,

<BR>Complete in body and dilate in spirit,

<BR>Be thou my God.



<P>&nbsp;O Death, (for Life has served its turn,)

<BR>Opener and usher to the heavenly mansion,

<BR>Be thou my God.



<P>&nbsp;Aught, aught of mightiest, best I see, conceive, or know,

<BR>(To break the stagnant tie&amp;emdash;thee, thee to free, O soul,)

<BR>Be thou my God.



<P>&nbsp;All great ideas, the races' aspirations,

<BR>All heroisms, deeds of rapt enthusiasts,

<BR>Be ye my Gods.



<P>&nbsp;Or Time and Space,

<BR>Or shape of Earth divine and wondrous,

<BR>Or some fair shape I viewing, worship,

<BR>Or lustrous orb of sun or star by night,

<BR>Be ye my Gods.

<PRE>1870&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>GERMS</CENTER>

F<c>orms</c>, qualities, lives, humanity, language, thoughts,

<BR>The ones known, and the ones unknown, the ones on the stars,

<BR>The stars themselves, some shaped, others unshaped,

<BR>Wonders as of those countries, the soil, trees, cities, inhabitants,

whatever they may be,

<BR>Splendid suns, the moons and rings, the countless combinations and

effects,

<BR>Such-like, and as good as such-like, visible here or anywhere, stand

provided for in a handful of space, which I extend my arm and half enclose

with my hand,

<BR>That containing the start of each and all, the virtue, the germs of

all.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>THOUGHTS</CENTER>

O<c>f</c> ownership&amp;emdash;as if one fit to own things could not at

pleasure enter upon all, and incorporate them into himself or herself;

<BR>Of vista&amp;emdash;suppose some sight in arriere through the formative

chaos, presuming the growth, fulness, life, now attain'd on the journey,

<BR>(But I see the road continued, and the journey ever continued;)

<BR>Of what was once lacking on earth, and in due time has become supplied&amp;emdash;and

of what will yet be supplied,

<BR>Because all I see and know I believe to have its main purport in what

will yet be supplied.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>WHEN I HEARD THE LEARN'D ASTRONOMER</CENTER>

W<c>hen</c> I heard the learn'd astronomer,

<BR>When the proofs, the figures, were ranged in columns before me,

<BR>When I was shown the charts and diagrams, to add, divide, and measure

them,

<BR>When I sitting heard the astronomer where he lectured with much applause

in the lecture-room,

<BR>How soon unaccountable I became tired and sick,

<BR>Till rising and gliding out I wander'd off by myself,

<BR>In the mystical moist night-air, and from time to time,

<BR>Look'd up in perfect silence at the stars.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>PERFECTIONS</CENTER>

O<c>nly</c> themselves understand themselves and the like of themselves,

<BR>As souls only understand souls.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>O ME! O LIFE!</CENTER>

O&nbsp;<c>me</c>! O life! of the questions of these recurring,

<BR>Of the endless trains of the faithless, of cities fill'd with the foolish,

<BR>Of myself forever reproaching myself, (for who more foolish than I,

and who more faithless?)

<BR>Of eyes that vainly crave the light, of the objects mean, of the struggle

ever renew'd,

<BR>Of the poor results of all, of the plodding and sordid crowds I see

around me,

<BR>Of the empty and useless years of the rest, with the rest me intertwined,

<BR>The question, O me! so sad, recurring&amp;emdash;What good amid these,

O me, O life?

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Answer</I></CENTER>

That you are here&amp;emdash;that life exists and identity,

<BR>That the powerful play goes on, and you may contribute a verse.

<PRE>1865-6&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>TO A PRESIDENT</CENTER>

A<c>ll</c> you are doing and saying is to America dangled mirages,

<BR>You have not learn'd of Nature&amp;emdash;of the politics of Nature

you have not learn'd the great amplitude, rectitude, impartiality,

<BR>You have not seen that only such as they are for these States,

<BR>And that what is less than they must sooner or later lift off from

these States.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>I SIT AND LOOK OUT</CENTER>

I&nbsp;<c>sit</c> and look out upon all the sorrows of the world, and upon

all oppression and shame,

<BR>I hear secret convulsive sobs from young men at anguish with themselves,

remorseful after deeds done,

<BR>I see in low life the mother misused by her children, dying, neglected,

gaunt, desperate,

<BR>I see the wife misused by her husband, I see the treacherous seducer

of young women,

<BR>I mark the ranklings of jealousy and unrequited love attempted to be

hid, I see these sights on the earth,

<BR>I see the workings of battle, pestilence, tyranny, I see martyrs and

prisoners,

<BR>I observe a famine at sea, I observe the sailors casting lots who shall

be kill'd to preserve the lives of the rest,

<BR>I observe the slights and degradations cast by arrogant persons upon

laborers, the poor, and upon negroes, and the like;

<BR>All these&amp;emdash;all the meanness and agony without end I sitting

look out upon,

<BR>See, hear, and am silent.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>TO RICH GIVERS</CENTER>

W<c>hat</c> you give me I cheerfully accept,

<BR>A little sustenance, a hut and garden, a little money, as I rendezvous

with my poems,



<P>&nbsp;A traveler's lodging and breakfast as I journey through the States,&amp;emdash;why

should I be ashamed to own such gifts? why to advertise for them?

<BR>For I myself am not one who bestows nothing upon man and woman,

<BR>For I bestow upon any man or woman the entrance to all the gifts of

the universe.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>THE DALLIANCE OF THE EAGLES</CENTER>

S<c>kirting</c> the river road, (my forenoon walk, my rest,)

<BR>Skyward in air a sudden muffled sound, the dalliance of the eagles,

<BR>The rushing amorous contact high in space together,

<BR>The clinching interlocking claws, a living, fierce, gyrating wheel,

<BR>Four beating wings, two beaks, a swirling mass tight grappling,

<BR>In tumbling turning clustering loops, straight downward falling,

<BR>Till o'er the river pois'd, the twain yet one, a moment's lull,

<BR>A motionless still balance in the air, then parting, talons loosing,

<BR>Upward again on slow-firm pinions slanting, their separate diverse

flight,

<BR>She hers, he his, pursuing.

<PRE>1880&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>ROAMING IN THOUGHT</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>After reading</I> H<c>egel</c>)</CENTER>

R<c>oaming</c> in thought over the Universe, I saw the little that is Good

steadily hastening towards immortality,

<BR>And the vast all that is call'd Evil I saw hastening to merge itself

and become lost and dead.

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>A FARM PICTURE</CENTER>

T<c>hrough</c> the ample open door of the peaceful country barn,

<BR>A sunlit pasture field with cattle and horses feeding,

<BR>And haze and vista, and the far horizon fading away.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>A CHILD'S AMAZE</CENTER>

S<c>ilent</c> and amazed even when a little boy,

<BR>I remember I heard the preacher every Sunday put God in his statements,

<BR>As contending against some being or influence.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>THE RUNNER</CENTER>

O<c>n</c> a flat road runs the well-train'd runner,

<BR>He is lean and sinewy with muscular legs,

<BR>He is thinly clothed, he leans forward as he runs,

<BR>With lightly closed fists and arms partially rais'd.

<PRE>1867&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>BEAUTIFUL WOMEN</CENTER>

W<c>omen</c> sit or move to and fro, some old, some young,

<BR>The young are beautiful&amp;emdash;but the old are more beautiful than

the young.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>MOTHER AND BABE</CENTER>

I&nbsp;<c>see</c> the sleeping babe nestling the breast of its mother,

<BR>The sleeping mother and babe&amp;emdash;hush'd, I study them long and

long.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>THOUGHT</CENTER>

O<c>f</c> obedience, faith, adhesiveness;

<BR>As I stand aloof and look there is to me something profoundly affecting

in large masses of men following the lead of those who do not believe in

men.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>VISOR'D</CENTER>

A&nbsp;<c>mask</c>, a perpetual natural disguiser of herself,

<BR>Concealing her face, concealing her form,

<BR>Changes and transformations every hour, every moment,

<BR>Falling upon her even when she sleeps.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>THOUGHT</CENTER>

O<c>f</c> Justice&amp;emdash;as if Justice could be any thing but the same

ample law, expounded by natural judges and saviors,

<BR>As if it might be this thing or that thing, according to decisions.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>GLIDING O'ER ALL</CENTER>

G<c>liding</c> o'er all, through all,

<BR>Through Nature, Time, and Space,

<BR>As a ship on the waters advancing,

<BR>The voyage of the soul&amp;emdash;not life alone,

<BR>Death, many deaths I'll sing.
