<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>HAST NEVER COME TO THEE AN HOUR</CENTER>

H<c>ast</c> never come to thee an hour,

<BR>A sudden gleam divine, precipitating, bursting all these bubbles, fashions,

wealth?

<BR>These eager business aims&amp;emdash;books, politics, art, amours,

<BR>To utter nothingness?

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>THOUGHT</CENTER>

O<c>f</c> Equality&amp;emdash;as if it harm'd me, giving others the same

chances and rights as myself&amp;emdash;as if it were not indispensable

to my own rights that others possess the same.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>TO OLD AGE</CENTER>

I&nbsp;<c>see</c> in you the estuary that enlarges and spreads itself grandly

as it pours in the great sea.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<CENTER>LOCATIONS AND TIMES</CENTER>

L<c>ocations</c> and times&amp;emdash;what is it in me that meets them

all, whenever and wherever, and makes me at home?

<BR>Forms, colors, densities, odors&amp;emdash;what is it in me that corresponds

with them?

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>OFFERINGS</CENTER>

A&nbsp;<c>thousand</c> perfect men and women appear,

<BR>Around each gathers a cluster of friends, and gay children and youths,

with offerings.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>TO THE STATES</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>To Identify the 16th, 17th, or 18th Presidentiad</I></CENTER>

W<c>hy</c> reclining, interrogating? why myself and all drowsing?

<BR>What deepening twilight&amp;emdash;scum floating atop of the waters,

<BR>Who are they as bats and night-dogs askant in the capitol?

<BR>What a filthy Presidentiad! (O South, your torrid suns! O North, your

arctic freezings!)

<BR>Are those really Congressmen? are those the great Judges? is that the

President?

<BR>Then I will sleep awhile yet, for I see that these States sleep, for

reasons;

<BR>(With gathering murk, with muttering thunder and lambent shoots we

all duly awake,

<BR>South, North, East, West, inland and seaboard, we will surely awake.)

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1860</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : A Broadway Pageant</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER><B><I><FONT SIZE=+3>A Broadway Pageant</FONT></I></B></CENTER>



<CENTER><B><I><FONT SIZE=+3></FONT></I></B></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

Over the Western sea hither from Niphon come,

<BR>Courteous, the swart-cheek'd two-sworded envoys,

<BR>Leaning back in their open barouches, bare-headed, impassive,

<BR>Ride to-day through Manhattan.

<BR>Libertad! I do not know whether others behold what I behold,

<BR>In the procession along with the nobles of Niphon, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; errand-bearers,

<BR>Bringing up the rear, hovering above, around, or in the ranks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; marching,

<BR>But I will sing you a song of what I behold Libertad.

<BR>When million-footed Manhattan unpent descends to her

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pavements,

<BR>When the thunder-cracking guns arouse me with the proud

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; roar I love,

<BR>When the round-mouth'd guns out of the smoke and smell I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; love spit their salutes,

<BR>When the fire-flashing guns have fully alerted me, and heaven

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clouds canopy my city with a delicate thin

haze,

<BR>When gorgeous the countless straight stems, the forests at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the wharves, thicken with colors,

<BR>When every ship richly drest carries her flag at the peak,

<BR>When pennants trail and street-festoons hang from the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; windows,

<BR>When Broadway is entirely given up to foot-passengers and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; foot-standers, when the mass is densest,

<BR>When the facades of the houses are alive with people, when

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eyes gaze riveted tens of thousands at a time,

<BR>When the guests from the islands advance, when the pageant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; moves forward visible,

<BR>When the summons is made, when the answer that waited

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thousands of years answers,

<BR>I too arising, answering, descend to the pavements, merge

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the crowd, and gaze with them.

<CENTER>2</CENTER>

Superb-faced Manhattan!

<BR>Comrade Americanos! to us, then at last the Orient comes.

<BR>To us, my city,

<BR>Where our tall-topt marble and iron beauties range on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; opposite sides, to walk in the space between,

<BR>To-day our Antipodes comes.

<BR>The Originatress comes,

<BR>The nest of languages, the bequeather of poems, the race of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eld,

<BR>Florid with blood, pensive, rapt with musings, hot with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; passion,

<BR>Sultry with perfume, with ample and flowing garments,

<BR>With sunburnt visage, with intense soul and glittering eyes,

<BR>The race of Brahma comes.

<BR>See my cantabile! these and more are flashing to us from the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; procession,

<BR>As it moves changing, a kaleidoscope divine it moves changing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before us.

<BR>For not the envoys nor the tann'd Japanee from his island

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; only,

<BR>Lithe and silent the Hindoo appears, the Asiatic continent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself appears, the past, the dead,

<BR>The murky night-morning of wonder and fable inscrutable,

<BR>The envelop'd mysteries, the old and unknown hive-bees,

<BR>The north, the sweltering south, eastern Assyria, the Hebrews,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the ancient of ancients,

<BR>Vast desolated cities, the gliding present, all of these and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more are in the pageant-procession.

<BR>Geography, the world, is in it,

<BR>The Great Sea, the brood of islands, Polynesia, the coast

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beyond,

<BR>The coast you henceforth are facing &amp;emdash; you, Libertad! from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your Western golden shores,

<BR>The countries there with their populations, the millions enmasse

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are curiously here,

<BR>The swarming market-places, the temples with idols ranged

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; along the sides or at the end, bonze, brahmin,

and llama,

<BR>Mandarin, farmer, merchant, mechanic, and fisherman,

<BR>The singing-girl and the dancing-girl, the ecstatic persons,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the secluded emperors,

<BR>Confucius himself, the great poets and heroes, the warriors,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the castes, all,

<BR>Trooping up, crowding from all directions, from the Altay

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mountains,

<BR>From Thibet, from the four winding and far-flowing rivers of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; China,

<BR>From the southern peninsulas and the demi-continental

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; islands, from Malaysia,

<BR>These and whatever belongs to them palpable show forth to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me, and are seiz'd by me,

<BR>And I am seiz'd by them, and friendlily held by them,

<BR>Till as here them all I chant, Libertad! for themselves and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for you.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>For I too raising my voice join the ranks of this pageant,

<BR>I am the chanter, I chant aloud over the pageant,

<BR>I chant the world on my Western sea,

<BR>I chant copious the islands beyond, thick as stars in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sky,

<BR>I chant the new empire grander than any before, as in a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; vision it comes to me,

<BR>I chant America the mistress, I chant a greater supremacy,

<BR>I chant projected a thousand blooming cities yet in time on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those groups of sea-islands,

<BR>My sail-ships and steam-ships threading the archipelagoes,

<BR>My stars and stripes fluttering in the wind,

<BR>Commerce opening, the sleep of ages having done its work,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; races reborn, refresh'd,

<BR>Lives, works resumed &amp;emdash; the object I know not &amp;emdash;

but the old,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Asiatic renew'd as it must be,

<BR>Commencing from this day surrounded by the world.

<CENTER>3</CENTER>

And you Libertad of the world!

<BR>You shall sit in the middle well-pois'd thousands and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thousands of years,

<BR>As to-day from one side the nobles of Asia come to you,

<BR>As to-morrow from the other side the queen of England sends

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her eldest son to you.

<BR>The sign is reversing, the orb is enclosed,

<BR>The ring is circled, the journey is done,

<BR>The box-lid is but perceptibly open'd, nevertheless the perfume

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pours copiously out of the whole box.

<BR>Young Libertad! with the venerable Asia, the all-mother,

<BR>Be considerate with her now and ever hot Libertad, for you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are all,

<BR>Bend your proud neck to the long-off mother now sending

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; messages over the archipelagoes to you,

<BR>Bend your proud neck low for once, young Libertad.

<BR>Were the children straying westward so long? so wide the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tramping?

<BR>Were the precedent dim ages debouching westward from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Paradise so long?

<BR>Were the centuries steadily footing it that way, all the while

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unknown, for you, for reasons?

<BR>They are justified, they are accomplish'd, they shall now be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; turn'd the other way also, to travel toward

you thence,

<BR>They shall now also march obediently eastward for your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sake Libertad.

<PRE>(1860?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Songs of Parting</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Songs of Parting</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AS THE TIME DRAWS NIGH</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>S</FONT> the time draws nigh glooming a cloud,

<BR>A dread beyond of I know not what darkens me.



<P>&nbsp;I shall go forth,

<BR>I shall traverse the States awhile, but I cannot tell whither or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; how long,

<BR>Perhaps soon some day or night while I am singing my voice

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; will suddenly cease.



<P>&nbsp;O book, O chants! must all then amount to but this?

<BR>Must we barely arrive at this beginning of us?&amp;emdash;and yet it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is enough, O soul;

<BR>O soul, we have positively appear'd&amp;emdash;that is enough.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

YEARS OF THE MODERN</H2></CENTER>

Y<FONT SIZE=-1>EARS</FONT> of the modern! years of the unperform'd!

<BR>Your horizon rises, I see it parting away for more august

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dramas,

<BR>I see not America only, not only Liberty's nation but other

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nations preparing,

<BR>I see tremendous entrances and exits, new combinations, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; solidarity of races,

<BR>I see that force advancing with irresistible power on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; world's stage,

<BR>(Have the old forces, the old wars, played their parts? are the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; acts suitable to them closed?)

<BR>I see Freedom, completely arm'd and victorious and very

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; haughty, with Law on one side and Peace on

the other,

<BR>A stupendous trio all issuing forth against the idea of caste;



<P>&nbsp;What historic denouements are these we so rapidly approach?

<BR>I see men marching and countermarching by swift millions,

<BR>I see the frontiers and boundaries of the old aristocracies

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; broken,

<BR>I see the landmarks of European kings removed,

<BR>I see this day the People beginning their landmarks, (all others

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; give way;)

<BR>Never were such sharp questions ask'd as this day,

<BR>Never was average man, his soul, more energetic, more like a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; God,

<BR>Lo, how he urges and urges, leaving the masses no rest!

<BR>His daring foot is on land and sea everywhere, he colonizes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Pacific, the archipelagoes,

<BR>With the steamship, the electric telegraph, the newspaper,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the wholesale engines of war,

<BR>With these and the world-spreading factories he interlinks all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; geography, all lands;

<BR>What whispers are these O lands, running ahead of you,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; passing under the seas?

<BR>Are all nations communing? is there going to be but one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heart to the globe?

<BR>Is humanity forming en-masse? for lo, tyrants tremble,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crowns grow dim,

<BR>The earth, restive, confronts a new era, perhaps a general

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; divine war,

<BR>No one knows what will happen next, such portents fill the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; days and nights;

<BR>Years prophetical! the space ahead as I walk, as I vainly try

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to pierce it, is full of phantoms,

<BR>Unborn deeds, things soon to be, project their shapes around

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>This incredible rush and heat, this strange ecstatic fever of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dreams O years!

<BR>Your dreams O years, how they penetrate through me! (I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know not whether I sleep or wake;)

<BR>The perform'd America and Europe grow dim, retiring in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shadow behind me,

<BR>The unperform'd, more gigantic than ever, advance, advance

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon me.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ASHES OF SOLDIERS</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>SHES</FONT> of soldiers South or North,

<BR>As I muse retrospective murmuring a chant in thought,

<BR>The war resumes, again to my sense your shapes,

<BR>And again the advance of the armies.



<P>&nbsp;Noiseless as mists and vapors,

<BR>From their graves in the trenches ascending,

<BR>From cemeteries all through Virginia and Tennessee,

<BR>From every point of the compass out of the countless graves,

<BR>In wafted clouds, in myriads large, or squads of twos or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; threes or single ones they come,

<BR>And silently gather round me.



<P>&nbsp;Now sound no note O trumpeters,

<BR>Not at the head of my cavalry parading on spirited horses,

<BR>With sabres drawn and glistening, and carbines by their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thighs, (ah my brave horsemen!

<BR>My handsome tan-faced horsemen! what life, what joy and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pride,

<BR>With all the perils were yours.)



<P>&nbsp;Nor you drummers, neither at reveill&eacute; at dawn,

<BR>Nor the long roll alarming the camp, nor even the muffled

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beat for a burial,

<BR>Nothing from you this time O drummers bearing my warlil

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drums.



<P>&nbsp;But aside from these and the marts of wealth and the crowded

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; promenade,

<BR>Admitting around me comrades close unseen by the rest and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; voiceless,

<BR>The slain elate and alive again, the dust and debris alive,

<BR>I chant this chant of my silent soul in the name of all dead

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soldiers.



<P>&nbsp;Faces so pale with wondrous eyes, very dear, gather closer

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet,

<BR>Draw close, but speak not.



<P>&nbsp;Phantoms of countless lost,

<BR>Invisible to the rest henceforth become my companions,

<BR>Follow me ever &amp;emdash; desert me not while I live.



<P>&nbsp;Sweet are the blooming cheeks of the living &amp;emdash; sweet

are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the musical voices sounding,

<BR>But sweet, ah sweet, are the dead with their silent eyes.



<P>&nbsp;Dearest comrades, all is over and long gone,

<BR>But love is not over &amp;emdash; and what love, O comrades

<BR>Perfume from battle-fields rising, up from the foetor arising.



<P>&nbsp;Perfume therefore my chant, O love, immortal love,

<BR>Give me to bathe the memories of all dead soldiers,

<BR>Shroud them, embalm them, cover them all over with tender

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pride.



<P>&nbsp;Perfume all &amp;emdash; make all wholesome,

<BR>Make these ashes to nourish and blossom,

<BR>O love, solve all, fructify all with the last chemistry.



<P>&nbsp;Give me exhaustless, make me a fountain,

<BR>That I exhale love from me wherever I go like a moist

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; perennial dew,

<BR>For the ashes of all dead soldiers South or North.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THOUGHTS</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>O<FONT SIZE=-1>F</FONT> these years I sing,

<BR>How they pass and have pass'd through convuls'd pains, as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through parturitions,

<BR>How America illustrates birth, muscular youth, the promise,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sure fulfilment, the absolute success,

despite of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; people &amp;emdash; illustrates evil as well

as good,

<BR>The vehement struggle so fierce for unity in one's -self;

<BR>How many hold despairingly yet to the models departed, caste,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myths, obedience, compulsion, and to infidelity,

<BR>How few see the arrived models, the athletes, the Western

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; States, or see freedom or spirituality, or

hold any faith

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in results,



<P>&nbsp;(But I see the athletes, and I see the results of the war glorious

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and inevitable, and they again leading to

other results.)



<P>&nbsp;How the great cities appear &amp;emdash; how the Democratic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; masses, turbulent, wilful, as I love them,

<BR>How the whirl, the contest, the wrestle of evil with good, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sounding and resounding, keep on and on,

<BR>How society waits unform'd, and is for a while between things

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ended and things begun,

<BR>How America is the continent of glories, and of the triumph

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of freedom and of the Democracies, and of

the fruits of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; society, and of all that is begun,

<BR>And how the States are complete in themselves &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and how all triumphs and glories are complete

in themselves,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to lead onward,

<BR>And how these of mine and of the States will in their turn be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; convuls'd, and serve other parturitions and

transitions,

<BR>And how all people, sights, combinations, the democratic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; masses too, serve &amp;emdash; and how every

fact, and war

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself, with all its horrors, serves,

<BR>And how now or at any time each serves the exquisite

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; transition of death.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Of seeds dropping into the ground, of births,

<BR>Of the steady concentration of America, inland, upward, to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; impregnable and swarming places,

<BR>Of what Indiana, Kentucky, Arkansas, and the rest, are to be,

<BR>Of what a few years will show there in Nebraska, Colorado,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Nevada, and the rest,

<BR>(Or afar, mounting the Northern Pacific to Sitka or Aliaska,)

<BR>Of what the feuillage of America is the preparation for &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and of what all sights, North, South, East

and West, are,

<BR>Of this Union welded in blood, of the solemn price paid, of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the unnamed lost ever present in my mind;

<BR>Of the temporary use of materials for identity's sake,

<BR>Of the present, passing, departing &amp;emdash; of the growth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of completer men than any yet,

<BR>Of all sloping down there where the fresh free giver the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mother, the Mississippi flows,



<P>&nbsp;Of mighty inland cities yet unsurvey'd and unsuspected,

<BR>Of the new and good names, of the modern developments,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of inalienable homesteads,

<BR>Of a free and original life there, of simple diet and clean

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sweet blood,

<BR>Of litheness, majestic faces, clear eyes, and perfect physique

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there,

<BR>Of immense spiritual results future years far West, each side

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the Anahuacs,

<BR>Of these songs, well understood there, (being made for that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; area,)

<BR>Of the native scorn of grossness and gain there,

<BR>(O it lurks in me night and day &amp;emdash; what is gain after

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all to savageness and freedom?)

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SONG AT SUNSET</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>PLENDOR</FONT> of ended day floating and filling me,

<BR>Hour prophetic, hour resuming the past,

<BR>Inflating my throat, you divine average,

<BR>You earth and life till the last ray gleams I sing.



<P>&nbsp;Open mouth of my soul uttering gladness,

<BR>Eyes of my soul seeing perfection,

<BR>Natural life of me faithfully praising things,

<BR>Corroborating forever the triumph of things.



<P>&nbsp;Illustrious every one!

<BR>Illustrious what we name space, sphere of unnumber'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spirits,

<BR>Illustrious the mystery of motion in all beings, even the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tiniest insect,

<BR>Illustrious the attribute of speech, the senses, the body,

<BR>Illustrious the passing light &amp;emdash; illustrious the pale

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reflection on the new moon in the western

sky,

<BR>Illustrious whatever I see or hear or touch, to the last.



<P>&nbsp;Good in all,

<BR>In the satisfaction and aplomb of animals,

<BR>In the annual return of the seasons,



<P>&nbsp;In the hilarity of youth,

<BR>In the strength and flush of manhood,

<BR>In the grandeur and exquisiteness of old age,

<BR>In the superb vistas of death.



<P>&nbsp;Wonderful to depart!

<BR>Wonderful to be here!

<BR>The heart, to jet the all-alike and innocent blood!

<BR>To breathe the air, how delicious!

<BR>To speak &amp;emdash; to walk &amp;emdash; to seize something

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by the hand!

<BR>To prepare for sleep, for bed, to look on my rose-color'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flesh!

<BR>To be conscious of my body, so satisfied, so large!

<BR>To be this incredible God I am!

<BR>To have gone forth among other Gods, these men and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; women I love.



<P>&nbsp;Wonderful how I celebrate you and myself!

<BR>How my thoughts play subtly at the spectacles around!

<BR>How the clouds pass silently overhead!

<BR>How the earth darts on and on! and how the sun, moon,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stars, dart on and on!

<BR>How the water sports and sings! (surely it is alive!)

<BR>How the trees rise and stand up, with strong trunks,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with branches and leaves!

<BR>(Surely there is something more in each of the trees, some

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; living soul.)



<P>&nbsp;O amazement of things &amp;emdash; even the least particle!

<BR>O spirituality of things!

<BR>O strain musical flowing through ages and continents, now

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reaching me and America!

<BR>I take your strong chords, intersperse them, and cheerfully

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pass them forward.



<P>&nbsp;I too carol the sun, usher'd or at noon, or as now, setting,

<BR>I too throb to the brain and beauty of the earth and of all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the growths of the earth,

<BR>I too have felt the resistless call of myself.



<P>&nbsp;As I steam'd down the Mississippi,

<BR>As I wander'd over the prairies,

<BR>As I have lived, as I have look'd through my windows my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eyes,

<BR>As I went forth in the morning, as I beheld the light breaking

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the east,

<BR>As I bathed on the beach of the Eastern Sea, and again on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the beach of Western Sea,

<BR>As I roam'd the streets of inland Chicago, whatever streets

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I have roam'd,

<BR>Or cities or silent woods, or even amid the sights of war,

<BR>Wherever I have been I have charged myself with content-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ment and triumph.



<P>&nbsp;I sing to the last the equalities modern or old,

<BR>I sing the endless final&eacute;s of things,

<BR>I say Nature continues, glory continues,

<BR>I praise with electric voice,

<BR>For I do not see one imperfection in the universe,

<BR>And I do not see one cause or result lamentable at last

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the universe.



<P>&nbsp;O setting sun! though the time has come,

<BR>I still warble under you, if none else does, unmitigated

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; adoration.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AS AT THY PORTALS ALSO DEATH</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>S</FONT> at thy portals also death,

<BR>Entering thy sovereign, dim, illimitable grounds,

<BR>To memories of my mother, to the divine blending, maternity,

<BR>To her, buried and gone, yet buried not, gone not from me,

<BR>(I see again the calm benignant face fresh and beautiful still,

<BR>I sit by the form in the coffin,

<BR>I kiss and kiss convulsively again the sweet old lips, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cheeks, the closed eyes in the coffin;)

<BR>To her, the ideal woman, practical, spiritual, of all of earth,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life, love, to me the best,

<BR>I grave a monumental line, before I go, amid these songs,

<BR>And set a tombstone here.

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MY LEGACY</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> business man the acquirer vast,

<BR>After assiduous years surveying results, preparing for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; departure,

<BR>Devises houses and lands to his children, bequeaths

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stocks, goods, funds for a school or hospital,

<BR>Leaves money to certain companions to buy tokens,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; souvenirs of gems and gold.



<P>&nbsp;But I, my life surveying, closing,

<BR>With nothing to show to devise from its idle years,

<BR>Nor houses nor lands, nor tokens of gems or gold for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my friends,

<BR>Yet certain remembrances of the war for you, and after

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you,

<BR>And little souvenirs of camps and soldiers, with my love,

<BR>I bind together and bequeath in this bundle of songs.

<PRE>1872&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

PENSIVE ON HER DEAD GAZING</H2></CENTER>

P<FONT SIZE=-1>ENSIVE</FONT> on her dead gazing I heard the Mother of All,

<BR>Desperate on the torn bodies, on the forms covering the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; battle-fields gazing,

<BR>(As the last gun ceased, but the scent of the powder-smoke

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; linger'd,)

<BR>As she call'd to her earth with mournful voice while she

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stalk'd,

<BR>Absorb them well O my earth, she cried, I charge you lose

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not my sons, lose not an atom,

<BR>And you streams absorb them well, taking their dear blood,

<BR>And you local spots, and you airs that swim above lightly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; impalpable,

<BR>And all you essences of soil and growth, and you my rivers'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; depths,

<BR>And you mountain sides, and the woods where my dear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; children's blood trickling redden'd,

<BR>And you trees down in your roots to bequeath to all future

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trees,

<BR>My dead absorb or South or North &amp;emdash; my young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men's bodies absorb, and their precious precious

blood,



<P>&nbsp;Which holding in trust for me faithfully back again give me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; many a year hence,

<BR>In unseen essence and odor of surface and grass, centuries

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hence,

<BR>In blowing airs from the fields back again give me my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; darlings, give my immortal heroes,

<BR>Exhale me them centuries hence, breathe me their breath, let

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not an atom be lost,

<BR>O years and graves! O air and soil! O my dead, an aroma

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sweet!

<BR>Exhale them perennial sweet death, years, centuries hence.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

CAMPS OF GREEN</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>OT</FONT> alone those camps of white, old comrades of the

wars,

<BR>When as order'd forward, after a long march,

<BR>Footsore and weary, soon as the light lessens we halt for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; night,

<BR>Some of us so fatigued carrying the gun and knapsack, drop-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ping asleep in our tracks,

<BR>Others pitching the little tents, and the fires lit up begin to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sparkle,

<BR>Outposts of pickets posted surrounding alert through the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dark,

<BR>And a word provided for countersign, careful for safety,

<BR>Till to the call of the drummers at daybreak loudly beating

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the drums,

<BR>We rise up refresh'd, the night and sleep pass'd over, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; resume our journey,

<BR>Or proceed to battle.



<P>&nbsp;Lo, the camps of the tents of green,

<BR>Which the days of peace keep filling, and the days of war

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; keep filling,

<BR>With a mystic army, (is it too order'd forward? is it too

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; only halting awhile,

<BR>Till night and sleep pass over?)



<P>&nbsp;Now in those camps of green, in their tents dotting the world,

<BR>In the parents, children, husbands, wives, in them, in the old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and young,



<P>&nbsp;Sleeping under the sunlight, sleeping under the moonlight,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; content and silent there at last,

<BR>Behold the mighty bivouac-field and waiting-camp of all,

<BR>Of the corps and generals all, and the President over the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; corps and generals all,

<BR>And of each of us O soldiers, and of each and all in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ranks we fought,

<BR>(There without hatred we all, all meet.)



<P>&nbsp;For presently O soldiers, we too camp in our place in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the bivouac-camps of green,

<BR>But we need not provide for outposts, nor word for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the counter-sign,

<BR>Nor drummer to beat the morning drum.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE SOBBING OF THE BELLS</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>Midnight, Sept</I>. 19-20, 1881)</CENTER>





<P>T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> sobbing of the bells, the sudden death-news

everywhere,

<BR>The slumberers rouse, the rapport of the People,

<BR>(Full well they know that message in the darkness,

<BR>Full well return, respond within their breasts, their brains,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sad reverberations,)

<BR>The passionate toll and clang &amp;emdash; city to city, joining,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sounding, passing,

<BR>Those heart-beats of a Nation in the night.

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AS THEY DRAW TO A CLOSE</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>S</FONT> they draw to a close,

<BR>Of what underlies the precedent songs &amp;emdash; of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my aims in them,

<BR>Of the seed I have sought to plant in them,

<BR>Of joy, sweet joy, through many a year, in them,

<BR>(For them, for them have I lived, in them my work is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; done,)

<BR>Of many an aspiration fond, of many a dream and plan;

<BR>Through Space and Time fused in a chant, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flowing eternal identity,

<BR>To Nature encompassing these, encompassing God

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; to the joyous, electric all,

<BR>To the sense of Death, and accepting exulting in Death

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in its turn the same as life,

<BR>The entrance of man to sing;

<BR>To compact you, ye parted, diverse lives,

<BR>To put rapport the mountains and rocks and streams,

<BR>And the winds of the north, and the forests of oak and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pine,

<BR>With you O soul.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

JOY, SHIPMATE, JOY!</H2></CENTER>



<BLOCKQUOTE>J<FONT SIZE=-1>OY</FONT>, shipmate, joy!

<BR>(Pleas'd to my soul at death I cry,)

<BR>Our life is closed, our life begins,

<BR>The long, long anchorage we leave,

<BR>The ship is clear at last, she leaps!

<BR>She swiftly courses from the shore,

<BR>Joy, shipmate, joy!</BLOCKQUOTE>



<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE UNTOLD WANT</H2></CENTER>



<BLOCKQUOTE>T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> untold want by life and land ne'er

granted,

<BR>Now voyager sail thou forth to seek and find.</BLOCKQUOTE>



<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

PORTALS</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HAT</FONT> are those of the known but to ascend and enter

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Unknown?

<BR>And what are those of life but for Death?

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THESE CAROLS</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HESE</FONT> carols sung to cheer my passage through the

world I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; see,

<BR>For completion I dedicate to the Invisible World.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

NOW FINAL&Egrave; TO THE SHORE</H2></CENTER>

Now final&egrave; to the shore,

<BR>Now land and life final&egrave; and farewell,

<BR>Now Voyager depart, (much, much for thee is yet in store,)



<P>&nbsp;Often enough hast thou adventur'd o'er the seas,

<BR>Cautiously cruising, studying the charts,

<BR>Duly again to port and hawser's tie returning;

<BR>But now obey thy cherish'd secret wish,

<BR>Embrace thy friends, leave all in order,

<BR>To port and hawser's tie no more returning,

<BR>Depart upon thy endless cruise old Sailor.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SO LONG!</H2></CENTER>

To conclude, I announce what comes after me.



<P>&nbsp;I remember I said before my leaves sprang at all,

<BR>I would raise my voice jocund and strong with reference to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consummations.



<P>&nbsp;When America does what was promis'd,

<BR>When through these States walk a hundred millions of superb

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; persons,

<BR>When the rest part away for superb persons and contribute

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to them,

<BR>When breeds of the most perfect mothers denote America,

<BR>Then to me and mine our due fruition.



<P>&nbsp;I have press'd through in my own right,

<BR>I have sung the body and the soul, war and peace have I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sung, and the songs of life and death,

<BR>And the songs of birth, and shown that there are many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; births.



<P>&nbsp;I have offer'd my style to every one, I have journey'd with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; confident step;

<BR>While my pleasure is yet at the full I whisper <I>So long</I>!

<BR>And take the young woman's hand and the young man's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hand for the last time.



<P>&nbsp;I announce natural persons to arise,

<BR>I announce justice triumphant,

<BR>I announce uncompromising liberty and equality,

<BR>I announce the justification of candor and the justification

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of pride.



<P>&nbsp;I announce that the identity of these States is a single identity

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; only,

<BR>I announce the Union more and more compact, indissoluble,

<BR>I announce splendors and majesties to make all the previous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; politics of the earth insignificant.



<P>&nbsp;I announce adhesiveness, I say it shall be limitless, un-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; loosen'd,

<BR>I say you shall yet find the friend you were looking for.



<P>&nbsp;I announce a man or woman coming, perhaps you are the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one, (<I>So long</I>!)

<BR>I announce the great individual, fluid as Nature, chaste,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; affectionate, compassionate, fully arm'd.



<P>&nbsp;I announce a life that shall be copious, vehement, spiritual,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bold,

<BR>I announce an end that shall lightly and joyfully meet its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; translation.



<P>&nbsp;I announce myriads of youths, beautiful, gigantic, sweet-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blooded,

<BR>I announce a race of splendid and savage old men.



<P>&nbsp;O thicker and faster &amp;emdash; (<I>So long</I>!)

<BR>O crowding too close upon me,

<BR>I foresee too much, it means more than I thought,

<BR>It appears to me I am dying.



<P>&nbsp;Hasten throat and sound your last,

<BR>Salute me &amp;emdash; salute the days once more. Peal the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; old cry once more.



<P>&nbsp;Screaming electric, the atmosphere using,

<BR>At random glancing, each as I notice absorbing,

<BR>Swiftly on, but a little while alighting,

<BR>Curious envelop'd messages delivering,

<BR>Sparkles hot, seed ethereal down in the dirt dropping,

<BR>Myself unknowing, my commission obeying, to question

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it never daring,

<BR>To ages and ages yet the growth of the seed leaving,



<P>&nbsp;To troops out of the war arising, they the tasks I have set

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; promulging,

<BR>To women certain whispers of myself bequeathing, their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; affection me more clearly explaining,

<BR>To young men my problems offering &amp;emdash; no dallier

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I &amp;emdash; I the muscle of their brains

trying,

<BR>So I pass, a little time vocal, visible, contrary,

<BR>Afterward a melodious echo, passionately bent for, (death

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; making me really undying,)

<BR>The best of me then when no longer visible, for toward that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I have been incessantly preparing.



<P>&nbsp;What is there more, that I lag and pause and crouch extended

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with unshut mouth?

<BR>Is there a single final farewell?



<P>&nbsp;My songs cease, I abandon them,

<BR>From behind the screen where I hid I advance personally

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; solely to you.



<P>&nbsp;Camerado, this is no book,

<BR>Who touches this touches a man,

<BR>(Is it night? are we here together alone?)

<BR>It is I you hold and who holds you,

<BR>I spring from the pages into your arms &amp;emdash; decease

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; calls me forth.



<P>&nbsp;O how your fingers drowse me,

<BR>Your breath falls around me like dew, your pulse lulls the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tympans of my ears,

<BR>I feel immerged from head to foot,

<BR>Delicious, enough.



<P>&nbsp;Enough O deed impromptu and secret,

<BR>Enough O gliding present &amp;emdash; enough O summ'd-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; up past.



<P>&nbsp;Dear friend whoever you are take this kiss,

<BR>I give it especially to you, do not forget me,

<BR>I feel like one who has done work for the day to retire

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; awhile,

<BR>I receive now again of my many translations, from my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; avataras ascending, while others doubtless

await me,



<P>&nbsp;An unknown sphere more real than I dream'd, more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; direct, darts awakening rays about me, <I>So

long</I>!

<BR>Remember my words, I may again return,

<BR>I love you, I depart from materials,

<BR>I am as one disembodied, triumphant, dead.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Starting from Paumanok</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Starting from Paumanok</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>S<FONT SIZE=-1>TARTING</FONT> from fish-shape Paumanok where I was born,

<BR>Well-begotten, and rais'd by a perfect mother,

<BR>After roaming many lands, lover of populous pavements,

<BR>Dweller in Mannahatta my city, or on southern savannas,

<BR>Or a soldier camp'd or carrying my knapsack and gun, or a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; miner in California,

<BR>Or rude in my home in Dakota's woods, my diet meat, my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drink from the spring,

<BR>Or withdrawn to muse and meditate in some deep recess,

<BR>Far from the clank of crowds intervals passing rapt and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; happy,

<BR>Aware of the fresh free giver the flowing Missouri, aware of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mighty Niagara,

<BR>Aware of the buffalo herds grazing the plains, the hirsute and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strong-breasted bull,

<BR>Of earth, rocks, Fifth-month flowers experienced, stars, rain,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; snow, my amaze,

<BR>Having studied the mocking-bird's tones and the flight of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mountain-hawk,

<BR>And heard at dawn the unrivall'd one, the hermit thrush

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from the swamp-cedars,

<BR>Solitary, singing in the West, I strike up for a New World.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Victory, union, faith, identity, time,

<BR>The indissoluble compacts, riches, mystery,

<BR>Eternal progress, the kosmos, and the modern reports.



<P>&nbsp;This then is life,

<BR>Here is what has come to the surface after so many throes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and convulsions.

<BR>How curious! how real!

<BR>Underfoot the divine soil, overhead the sun.



<P>&nbsp;See revolving the globe,

<BR>The ancestor-continents away group'd together,

<BR>The present and future continents north and south, with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; isthmus between.



<P>&nbsp;See, vast trackless spaces,

<BR>As in a dream they change, they swiftly fill,

<BR>Countless masses debouch upon them,

<BR>They are now cover'd with the foremost people, arts,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; institutions, known.



<P>&nbsp;See, projected through time,

<BR>For me an audience interminable.



<P>&nbsp;With firm and regular step they wend, they never stop,

<BR>Successions of men, Americanos, a hundred millions,

<BR>One generation playing its part and passing on,

<BR>Another generation playing its part and passing on in its turn,

<BR>With faces turn'd sideways or backward towards me to listen,

<BR>With eyes retrospective towards me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>Americanos! conquerors! marches humanitarian!

<BR>Foremost! century marches! Libertad! masses!

<BR>For you a programme of chants.



<P>&nbsp;Chants of the prairies,

<BR>Chants of the long-running Mississippi, and down to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mexican sea,

<BR>Chants of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Iowa, Wisconsin and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Minnesota,

<BR>Chants going forth from the centre from Kansas, and thence

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; equidistant,

<BR>Shooting in pulses of fire ceaseless to vivify all.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>Take my leaves America, take them South and take them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; North,

<BR>Make welcome for them everywhere, for they are your own

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; offspring,

<BR>Surround them East and West, for they would surround you,

<BR>And you precedents, connect lovingly with them, for they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; connect lovingly with you.



<P>&nbsp;I conn'd old times,

<BR>I sat studying at the feet of the great masters,

<BR>Now if eligible O that the great masters might return and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; study me.



<P>&nbsp;In the name of these States shall I scorn the antique?

<BR>Why these are the children of the antique to justify it.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>Dead poets, philosophs, priests,

<BR>Martyrs, artists, inventors, governments long since,

<BR>Language-shapers on other shores,

<BR>Nations once powerful, now reduced, withdrawn, or desolate,

<BR>I dare not proceed till I respectfully credit what you have left

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wafted hither,

<BR>I have perused it, own it is admirable, (moving awhile among

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it,)

<BR>Think nothing can ever be greater, nothing can ever deserve

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more than it deserves,

<BR>Regarding it all intently a long while, then dismissing it,

<BR>I stand in my place with my own day here.



<P>&nbsp;Here lands female and male,

<BR>Here the heir-ship and heiress-ship of the world, here the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flame of materials,

<BR>Here spirituality the translatress, the openly-avow'd,

<BR>The ever-tending, the final&egrave; of visible forms,

<BR>The satisfier, after due long-waiting now advancing,

<BR>Yes here comes my mistress the soul.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>The soul,

<BR>Forever and forever&amp;emdash;longer than soil is brown and solid&amp;emdash;

<BR>longer than water ebbs and flows.

<BR>I will make the poems of materials, for I think they are to be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the most spiritual poems,

<BR>And I will make the poems of my body and of mortality,

<BR>For I think I shall then supply myself with the poems of my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soul and of immortality.



<P>&nbsp;I will make a song for these States that no one State may

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; under any circumstances be subjected to another

State,

<BR>And I will make a song that there shall be comity by day and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by night between all the States, and between any

two of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>And I will make a song for the ears of the President, full of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; weapons with menacing points,

<BR>And behind the weapons countless dissatisfied faces;

<BR>And a song make I of the One form'd out of all,

<BR>The fang'd and glittering One including and over all,

<BR>(However high the head of any else that head is over all.)



<P>&nbsp;I will acknowledge contemporary lands,

<BR>I will trail the whole geography of the globe and salute

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; courteously every city large and small,

<BR>And employments! I will put in my poems that with you is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heroism upon land and sea,

<BR>And I will report all heroism from an American point of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; view.



<P>&nbsp;I will sing the song of companionship,

<BR>I will show what alone must finally compact these,

<BR>I believe these are to found their own ideal of manly love,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indicating it in me,

<BR>I will therefore let flame from me the burning fires that were

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; threatening to consume me,

<BR>I will lift what has too long kept down those smouldering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fires,

<BR>I will give them complete abandonment,

<BR>I will write the evangel-poem of comrades and of love,

<BR>For who but I should understand love with all its sorrow and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joy?

<BR>And who but I should be the poet of comrades?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>I am the credulous man of qualities, ages, races,

<BR>I advance from the people in their own spirit,

<BR>Here is what sings unrestricted faith.



<P>&nbsp;Omnes! omnes! let others ignore what they may,

<BR>I make the poem of evil also, I commemorate that part also,

<BR>I am myself just as much evil as good, and my nation is&amp;emdash;and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I say there is in fact no evil,

<BR>(Or if there is I say it is just as important to you, to the land

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or to me, as any thing else.)



<P>&nbsp;I too, following many and follow'd by many, inaugurate a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; religion, I descend into the arena,

<BR>(It may be I am destin'd to utter the loudest cries there, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; winner's pealing shouts,

<BR>Who knows? they may rise from me yet, and soar above

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every thing.)



<P>&nbsp;Each is not for its own sake,

<BR>I say the whole earth and all the stars in the sky are for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; religion's sake.



<P>&nbsp;I say no man has ever yet been half devout enough,

<BR>None has ever yet adored or worship'd half enough,

<BR>None has begun to think how divine he himself is, and how

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; certain the future is.



<P>&nbsp;I say that the real and permanent grandeur of these States

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; must be their religion,

<BR>Otherwise there is no real and permanent grandeur;

<BR>(Nor character nor life worthy the name without religion,

<BR>Nor land nor man or woman without religion.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>What are you doing young man?

<BR>Are you so earnest, so given up to literature, science, art,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amours?

<BR>These ostensible realities, politics, points?

<BR>Your ambition or business whatever it may be?



<P>&nbsp;It is well&amp;emdash;against such I say not a word, I am their

poet also,

<BR>But behold! such swiftly subside, burnt up for religion's sake,

<BR>For not all matter is fuel to heat, impalpable flame, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; essential life of the earth,

<BR>Any more than such are to religion.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>9</CENTER>





<P>What do you seek so pensive and silent?

<BR>What do you need camerado?

<BR>Dear son do you think it is love?



<P>&nbsp;Listen dear son&amp;emdash;listen America, daughter or son,

<BR>It is a painful thing to love a man or woman to excess, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet it satisfies, it is great,

<BR>But there is something else very great, it makes the whole

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; coincide,

<BR>It, magnificent, beyond materials, with continuous hands

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sweeps and provides for all.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>10</CENTER>





<P>Know you, solely to drop in the earth the germs of a greater

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; religion,

<BR>The following chants each for its kind I sing.



<P>&nbsp;My comrade!

<BR>For you to share with me two greatnesses, and a third one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rising inclusive and more resplendent,

<BR>The greatness of Love and Democracy, and the greatness of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Religion.



<P>&nbsp;Melange mine own, the unseen and the seen,

<BR>Mysterious ocean where the streams empty,

<BR>Prophetic spirit of material shifting and flickering around

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>Living beings, identities now doubtless near us in the air that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; we know not of,

<BR>Contact daily and hourly that will not release me,

<BR>These selecting, these in hints demanded of me.



<P>&nbsp;Not he with a daily kiss onward from childhood kissing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>Has winded and twisted around me that which holds me to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him,

<BR>Any more than I am held to the heavens and all the spiritual

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; world,

<BR>After what they have done to me, suggesting themes.



<P>&nbsp;O such themes&amp;emdash;equalities! O divine average!

<BR>Warblings under the sun, usher'd as now, or at noon, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; setting,

<BR>Strains musical flowing through ages, now reaching hither,

<BR>I take to your reckless and composite chords, add to them,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and cheerfully pass them forward.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>11</CENTER>





<P>As I have walk'd in Alabama my morning walk,

<BR>I have seen where the she-bird the mocking-bird sat on her

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nest in the briers hatching her brood.



<P>&nbsp;I have seen the he-bird also,

<BR>I have paus'd to hear him near at hand inflating his throat

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and joyfully singing.



<P>&nbsp;And while I paus'd it came to me that what he really sang for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; was not there only,

<BR>Nor for his mate nor himself only, nor all sent back by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; echoes,

<BR>But subtle, clandestine, away beyond,

<BR>A charge transmitted and gift occult for those being born.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>12</CENTER>





<P>Democracy! near at hand to you a throat is now inflating

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself and joyfully singing.



<P>&nbsp;Ma femme! for the brood beyond us and of us,

<BR>For those who belong here and those to come,

<BR>I exultant to be ready for them will now shake out carols

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stronger and haughtier than have ever yet

been heard

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon earth.

<BR>I will make the songs of passion to give them their way,

<BR>And your songs outlaw'd offenders, for I scan you with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; kindred eyes, and carry you with me the same

as any.



<P>&nbsp;I will make the true poem of riches,

<BR>To earn for the body and the mind whatever adheres and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; goes forward and is not dropt by death;

<BR>I will effuse egotism and show it underlying all, and I will be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the bard of personality,

<BR>And I will show of male and female that either is but the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; equal of the other,

<BR>And sexual organs and acts! do you concentrate in me, for I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; am determin'd to tell you with courageous

clear voice to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prove you illustrious,

<BR>And I will show that there is no imperfection in the present,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and can be none in the future,

<BR>And I will show that whatever happens to anybody it may be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; turn'd to beautiful results,

<BR>And I will show that nothing can happen more beautiful than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death,

<BR>And I will thread a thread through my poems that time and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; events are compact,

<BR>And that all the things of the universe are perfect miracles,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; each as profound as any.



<P>&nbsp;I will not make poems with reference to parts,

<BR>But I will make poems, songs, thoughts, with reference to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ensemble,

<BR>And I will not sing with reference to a day, but with reference

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to all days,

<BR>And I will not make a poem nor the least part of a poem but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; has reference to the soul,

<BR>Because having look'd at the objects of the universe, I find

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there is no one nor any particle of one but

has reference

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to the soul.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>13</CENTER>





<P>Was somebody asking to see the soul?

<BR>See, your own shape and countenance, persons, substances,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beasts, the trees, the running rivers, the

rocks and sands.



<P>&nbsp;All hold spiritual joys and afterwards loosen them;

<BR>How can the real body ever die and be buried?



<P>&nbsp;Of your real body and any man's or woman's real body,

<BR>Item for item it will elude the hands of the corpse-cleaners

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and pass to fitting spheres,

<BR>Carrying what has accrued to it from the moment of birth to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the moment of death.



<P>&nbsp;Not the types set up by the printer return their impression,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the meaning, the main concern,

<BR>Any more than a man's substance and life or a woman's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; substance and life return in the body and

the soul,

<BR>Indifferently before death and after death.



<P>&nbsp;Behold, the body includes and is the meaning, the main

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; concern, and includes and is the soul;

<BR>Whoever you are, how superb and how divine is your body,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or any part of it!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>14</CENTER>





<P>Whoever you are, to you endless announcements!



<P>&nbsp;Daughter of the lands did you wait for your poet?

<BR>Did you wait for one with a flowing mouth and indicative

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hand?

<BR>Toward the male of the States, and toward the female of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; States,

<BR>Exulting words, words to Democracy's lands.



<P>&nbsp;Interlink'd, food-yielding lands!

<BR>Land of coal and iron! land of gold! land of cotton, sugar,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rice!

<BR>Land of wheat, beef, pork! land of wool and hemp! land of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the apple and the grape!

<BR>Land of the pastoral plains, the grass-fields of the world! land

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of those sweet-air'd interminable plateaus!

<BR>Land of the herd, the garden, the healthy house of adobie!

<BR>Lands where the north-west Columbia winds, and where the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; south-west Colorado winds!

<BR>Land of the eastern Chesapeake! land of the Delaware!

<BR>Land of Ontario, Erie, Huron, Michigan!

<BR>Land of the Old Thirteen! Massachusetts land! land of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Vermont and Connecticut!



<P>&nbsp;Land of the ocean shores! land of sierras and peaks!

<BR>Land of boatmen and sailors! fishermen's land!

<BR>Inextricable lands! the clutch'd together! the passionate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ones!

<BR>The side by side! the elder and younger brothers! the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bony-limb'd!

<BR>The great women's land! the feminine! the experienced sisters

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the inexperienced sisters!

<BR>Far breath'd land! Arctic braced! Mexican breez'd! the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; diverse! the compact!

<BR>The Pennsylvanian! the Virginian! the double Carolinian!

<BR>O all and each well-loved by me! my intrepid nations! O I at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; any rate include you all with perfect love!

<BR>I cannot be discharged from you! not from one any sooner

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than another!

<BR>O death! O for all that, I am yet of you unseen this hour with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; irrepressible love,

<BR>Walking New England, a friend, a traveler,

<BR>Splashing my bare feet in the edge of the summer ripples on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Paumanok's sands,

<BR>Crossing the prairies, dwelling again in Chicago, dwelling in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every town,

<BR>Observing shows, births, improvements, structures, arts,

<BR>Listening to orators and oratresses in public halls,

<BR>Of and through the States as during life, each man and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; woman my neighbor,

<BR>The Louisianian, the Georgian, as near to me, and I as near

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to him and her,

<BR>The Mississippian and Arkansian yet with me, and I yet with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; any of them,

<BR>Yet upon the plains west of the spinal river, yet in my house

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of adobie,

<BR>Yet returning eastward, yet in the Seaside State or in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Maryland,

<BR>Yet Kanadian cheerily braving the winter, the snow and ice

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; welcome to me,

<BR>Yet a true son either of Maine or of the Granite State, or the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Narragansett Bay State, or the Empire State,

<BR>Yet sailing to other shores to annex the same, yet welcoming

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every new brother,



<P>&nbsp;Hereby applying these leaves to the new ones from the hour

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they unite with the old ones,

<BR>Coming among the new ones myself to be their companion

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and equal, coming personally to you now,

<BR>Enjoining you to acts, characters, spectacles, with me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>15</CENTER>





<P>With me with firm holding, yet haste, haste on.



<P>&nbsp;For your life adhere to me,

<BR>(I may have to be persuaded many times before I consent to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; give myself really to you, but what of that?

<BR>Must not Nature be persuaded many times?)



<P>&nbsp;No dainty dolce affettuoso I,

<BR>Bearded, sun-burnt, gray-neck'd, forbidding, I have arrived,

<BR>To be wrestled with as I pass for the solid prizes of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; universe,

<BR>For such I afford whoever can persevere to win them.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>16</CENTER>





<P>On my way a moment I pause,

<BR>Here for you! and here for America!

<BR>Still the present I raise aloft, still the future of the States I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; harbinge glad and sublime,

<BR>And for the past I pronounce what the air holds of the red

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; aborigines.



<P>&nbsp;The red aborigines,

<BR>Leaving natural breaths, sounds of rain and winds, calls as of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; birds and animals in the woods, syllabled,

to us for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; names,

<BR>Okonee, Koosa, Ottawa, Monongahela, Sauk, Natchez,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Chattahoochee, Kaqueta, Oronoco,

<BR>Wabash, Miami, Saginaw, Chippewa, Oshkosh,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WallaWalla,

<BR>Leaving such to the States they melt, they depart, charging

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the water and the land with names.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>17</CENTER>





<P>Expanding and swift, henceforth,

<BR>Elements, breeds, adjustments, turbulent, quick and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; audacious,

<BR>A world primal again, vistas of glory incessant and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; branching,

<BR>A new race dominating previous ones and grander far, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; new contests,

<BR>New politics, new literatures and religions, new inventions

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and arts.



<P>&nbsp;These, my voice announcing &amp;emdash; I will sleep no more but

arise,

<BR>You oceans that have been calm within me! how I feel you,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fathomless, stirring, preparing unprecedented waves

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; storms.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>18</CENTER>





<P>See, steamers steaming through my poems,

<BR>See, in my poems immigrants continually coming and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; landing,

<BR>See, in arriere, the wigwam, the trail, the hunter's hut, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flatboat, the maize-leaf, the claim, the rude

fence, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the backwoods village,

<BR>See, on the one side the Western Sea and on the other the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Eastern Sea, how they advance and retreat

upon my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poems as upon their own shores,

<BR>See, pastures and forests in my poems &amp;emdash; see, animals wild

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tame &amp;emdash; see, beyond the Kaw, countless

herds of buffalo

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feeding on short curly grass,

<BR>See, in my poems, cities, solid, vast, inland, with paved

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; streets, with iron and stone edifices, ceaseless

vehicles,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and commerce,

<BR>See, the many-cylinder'd steam printing-press &amp;emdash; see, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; electric telegraph stretching across the continent,

<BR>See, through Atlantica's depths pulses American Europe

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reaching, pulses of Europe duly return'd,

<BR>See, the strong and quick locomotive as it departs, panting,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blowing the steam-whistle,

<BR>See, ploughmen ploughing farms &amp;emdash; see, miners digging mines

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; see, the numberless factories,



<P>&nbsp;See, mechanics busy at their benches with tools &amp;emdash; see

from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; among them superior judges, philosophs, Presidents,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; emerge, drest in working dresses,

<BR>See, lounging through the shops and fields of the States, me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; well-belov'd, close-held by day and night,

<BR>Hear the loud echoes of my songs there &amp;emdash; read the hints

come

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at last.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>19</CENTER>





<P>O camerado close! O you and me at last, and us two only.

<BR>O a word to clear one's path ahead endlessly!

<BR>O something ecstatic and undemonstrable! O music wild!

<BR>O now I triumph &amp;emdash; and you shall also;

<BR>O hand in hand &amp;emdash; O wholesome pleasure &amp;emdash; O one

more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; desirer and lover!

<BR>O to haste firm holding &amp;emdash; to haste, haste on with me.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Crossing Brooklyn Ferry</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Crossing Brooklyn Ferry</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>F<FONT SIZE=-1>LOOD-TIDE</FONT> below me! I see you face to face!

<BR>Clouds of the west&amp;emdash;sun there half an hour high

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;I see you also face to face.



<P>&nbsp;Crowds of men and women attired in the usual costumes,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; how curious you are to me!

<BR>On the ferry-boats the hundreds and hundreds that cross,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; returning home, are more curious to me than

you suppose,

<BR>And you that shall cross from shore to shore years hence are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more to me, and more in my meditations, than

you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; might suppose.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>The impalpable sustenance of me from all things at all hours

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the day,

<BR>The simple, compact, well-join'd scheme, myself disinte-grated,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every one disintegrated yet part of the scheme,

<BR>The similitudes of the past and those of the future,

<BR>The glories strung like beads on my smallest sights and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hearings, on the walk in the street and the

passage over

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the river,

<BR>The current rushing so swiftly and swimming with me far away,

<BR>The others that are to follow me, the ties between me and them,

<BR>The certainty of others, the life, love, sight, hearing of others.



<P>&nbsp;Others will enter the gates of the ferry and cross from shore

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to shore,

<BR>Others will watch the run of the flood-tide,

<BR>Others will see the shipping of Manhattan north and west,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the heights of Brooklyn to the south and

east,

<BR>Others will see the islands large and small;



<P>&nbsp;Fifty years hence, others will see them as they cross, the sun

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; half an hour high,

<BR>A hundred years hence, or ever so many hundred years hence,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; others will see them,

<BR>Will enjoy the sunset, the pouring-in of the flood-tide, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; falling-back to the sea of the ebb-tide.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>It avails not, time nor place&amp;emdash;distance avails not,

<BR>I am with you, you men and women of a generation, or ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; so many generations hence,

<BR>Just as you feel when you look on the river and sky, so I felt,

<BR>Just as any of you is one of a living crowd, I was one of a crowd,

<BR>Just as you are refresh'd by the gladness of the river and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bright flow, I was refresh'd,

<BR>Just as you stand and lean on the rail, yet hurry with the swift

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; current, I stood yet was hurried,

<BR>Just as you look on the numberless masts of ships and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thick-stemm'd pipes of steamboats, I look'd.



<P>&nbsp;I too many and many a time cross'd the river of old,

<BR>Watched the Twelfth-month sea-gulls, saw them high in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; air floating with motionless wings, oscillating

their bodies,

<BR>Saw how the glistening yellow lit up parts of their bodies and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; left the rest in strong shadow,

<BR>Saw the slow-wheeling circles and the gradual edging toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the south,

<BR>Saw the reflection of the summer sky in the water,

<BR>Had my eyes dazzled by the shimmering track of beams,

<BR>Look'd at the fine centrifugal spokes of light round the shape

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of my head in the sunlit water,

<BR>Look'd on the haze on the hills southward and south-west-ward,

<BR>Look'd on the vapor as it flew in fleeces tinged with violet,

<BR>Look'd toward the lower bay to notice the vessels arriving,

<BR>Saw their approach, saw aboard those that were near me,

<BR>Saw the white sails of schooners and sloops, saw the ships

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at anchor,



<P>&nbsp;The sailors at work in the rigging or out astride the spars,

<BR>The round masts, the swinging motion of the hulls, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slender serpentine pennants,

<BR>The large and small steamers in motion, the pilots in their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pilot-houses,

<BR>The white wake left by the passage, the quick tremulous whirl

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the wheels,

<BR>The flags of all nations, the falling of them at sunset,

<BR>The scallop-edged waves in the twilight, the ladled cups, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; frolicsome crests and glistening,

<BR>The stretch afar growing dimmer and dimmer, the gray walls

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the granite storehouses by the docks,

<BR>On the river the shadowy group, the big steam-tug closely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flank'd on each side by the barges, the hay-boat,

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; belated lighter,

<BR>On the neighboring shore the fires from the foundry
