<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chimneys burning high and glaringly into the

night,

<BR>Casting their flicker of black contrasted with wild red and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yellow light over the tops of houses, and

down into the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clefts of streets.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>These and all else were to me the same as they are to you,

<BR>I loved well those cities, loved well the stately and rapid river,

<BR>The men and women I saw were all near to me,

<BR>Others the same&amp;emdash;others who look back on me because I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; look'd forward to them,

<BR>(The time will come, though I stop here to-day, and to-night.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>What is it then between us?

<BR>What is the count of the scores or hundreds of years between us?



<P>&nbsp;Whatever it is, it avails not&amp;emdash;distance avails not,

and place

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; avails not,

<BR>I too lived, Brooklyn of ample hills was mine,

<BR>I too walk'd the streets of Manhattan island, and bathed in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the waters around it,

<BR>I too felt the curious abrupt questionings stir within me.



<P>&nbsp;In the day among crowds of people sometimes they came upon me,

<BR>In my walks home late at night or as I lay in my bed they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; came upon me,

<BR>I too had been struck from the float forever held in solution,

<BR>I too had receiv'd identity by my body,

<BR>That I was I knew was of my body, and what I should be I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; knew I should be of my body.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>It is not upon you alone the dark patches fall,

<BR>The dark threw its patches down upon me also,

<BR>The best I had done seem'd to me blank and suspicious,

<BR>My great thoughts as I supposed them, were they not in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reality meagre?

<BR>Nor is it you alone who know what it is to be evil,

<BR>I am he who knew what it was to be evil,

<BR>I too knitted the old knot of contrariety,

<BR>Blabb'd, blush'd, resented, lied, stole, grudg'd,

<BR>Had guile, anger, lust, hot wishes I dared not speak,

<BR>Was wayward, vain, greedy, shallow, sly, cowardly, malignant,

<BR>The wolf, the snake, the hog, not wanting in me,

<BR>The cheating look, the frivolous word, the adulterous wish,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not wanting,

<BR>Refusals, hates, postponements, meanness, laziness, none of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; these wanting,

<BR>Was one with the rest, the days and haps of the rest,

<BR>Was call'd by my nighest name by clear loud voices of young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men as they saw me approaching or passing,

<BR>Felt their arms on my neck as I stood, or the negligent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leaning of their flesh against me as I sat,

<BR>Saw many I loved in the street or ferry-boat or public

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; assembly, yet never told them a word,

<BR>Lived the same life with the rest, the same old laughing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gnawing, sleeping,

<BR>Play'd the part that still looks back on the actor or actress,

<BR>The same old role, the role that is what we make it, as great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as we like,

<BR>Or as small as we like, or both great and small.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>Closer yet I approach you,

<BR>What thought you have of me now, I had as much of you&amp;emdash;I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; laid in my stores in advance,

<BR>I consider'd long and seriously of you before you were born.



<P>&nbsp;Who was to know what should come home to me?

<BR>Who knows but I am enjoying this?

<BR>Who knows, for all the distance, but I am as good as looking

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at you now, for all you cannot see me?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>Ah, what can ever be more stately and admirable to me than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mast-hemm'd Manhattan?

<BR>River and sunset and scallop-edg'd waves of flood-tide?

<BR>The sea-gulls oscillating their bodies, the hay-boat in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; twilight, and the belated lighter?



<P>&nbsp;What gods can exceed these that clasp me by the hand, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with voices I love call me promptly and loudly

by my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nighest name as I approach?



<P>&nbsp;What is more subtle than this which ties me to the woman or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; man that looks in my face?

<BR>Which fuses me into you now, and pours my meaning into you?



<P>&nbsp;We understand then do we not?

<BR>What I promis'd without mentioning it, have you not accepted?

<BR>What the study could not teach&amp;emdash;what the preaching could

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not accomplish is accomplish'd, is it not?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>9</CENTER>





<P>Flow on, river! flow with the flood-tide, and ebb with the ebb-tide!

<BR>Frolic on, created and scallop-edg'd waves!

<BR>Gorgeous clouds of the sunset! drench with your splendor me, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the men and women generations after me!



<P>&nbsp;Cross from shore to shore, countless crowds of passengers!

<BR>Stand up, tall masts of Mannahatta! stand up, beautiful hills

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of Brooklyn!

<BR>Throb, baffled and curious brain! throw out questions and answers!

<BR>Suspend here and everywhere, eternal float of solution!

<BR>Gaze, loving and thirsting eyes, in the house or street or public

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; assembly!

<BR>Sound out, voices of young men! loudly and musically call

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me by my nighest name!

<BR>Live, old life! play the part that looks back on the actor or actress!

<BR>Play the old role, the role that is great or small according as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one makes it!

<BR>Consider, you who peruse me, whether I may not in unknown

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ways be looking upon you;

<BR>Be firm, rail over the river, to support those who lean idly,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet haste with the hasting current;

<BR>Fly on, sea-birds! fly sideways, or wheel in large circles high

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the air;

<BR>Receive the summer sky, you water, and faithfully hold it till

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all downcast eyes have time to take it from

you!

<BR>Diverge, fine spokes of light, from the shape of my head, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; any one's head, in the sunlit water!

<BR>Come on, ships from the lower bay! pass up or down,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; white-sail'd schooners, sloops, lighters!

<BR>Flaunt away, flags of all nations! be duly lower'd at sunset!

<BR>Burn high your fires, foundry chimneys! cast black shadows

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at nightfall! cast red and yellow light over

the tops

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the houses!

<BR>Appearances, now or henceforth, indicate what you are,

<BR>You necessary film, continue to envelop the soul,

<BR>About my body for me, and your body for you, be hung our

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; divinest aromas,

<BR>Thrive, cities&amp;emdash;bring your freight, bring your shows,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ample and sufficient rivers,

<BR>Expand, being than which none else is perhaps more spiritual,

<BR>Keep your places, objects than which none else is more lasting.



<P>&nbsp;You have waited, you always wait, you dumb, beautiful ministers,

<BR>We receive you with free sense at last, and are insatiate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hence-forward,

<BR>Not you any more shall be able to foil us, or withhold

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yourselves from us,

<BR>We use you, and do not cast you aside&amp;emdash;we plant you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; permanently within us,

<BR>We fathom you not&amp;emdash;we love you&amp;emdash;there is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; perfection in you also,

<BR>You furnish your parts toward eternity,

<BR>Great or small, you furnish your parts toward the soul.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : To Think of Time</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>To Think of Time</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

To think of time&amp;emdash;of all that retrospection,

<BR>To think of to-day, and the ages continued henceforward.



<P>&nbsp;Have you guess'd you yourself would not continue?

<BR>Have you dreaded these earth-beetles?

<BR>Have you fear'd the future would be nothing to you?



<P>&nbsp;Is to-day nothing? is the beginningless past nothing?

<BR>If the future is nothing they are just as surely nothing.



<P>&nbsp;To think that the sun rose in the east&amp;emdash;that men and

women

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; were flexible, real, alive&amp;emdash;that

every thing was alive,

<BR>To think that you and I did not see, feel, think, nor bear our

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; part,

<BR>To think that we are now here and bear our part.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

Not a day passes, not a minute or second without an

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accouchement,

<BR>Not a day passes, not a minute or second without a corpse.



<P>&nbsp;The dull nights go over and the dull days also,

<BR>The soreness of lying so much in bed goes over,

<BR>The physician after long putting off gives the silent and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; terrible look for an answer,

<BR>The children come hurried and weeping, and the brothers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sisters are sent for,

<BR>Medicines stand unused on the shelf, (the camphor-smell has

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long pervaded the rooms,)

<BR>The faithful hand of the living does not desert the hand of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dying,

<BR>The twitching lips press lightly on the forehead of the dying,

<BR>The breath ceases and the pulse of the heart ceases,

<BR>The corpse stretches on the bed and the living look upon it,

<BR>It is palpable as the living are palpable.



<P>&nbsp;The living look upon the corpse with their eyesight,

<BR>But without eyesight lingers a different living and looks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; curiously on the corpse.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

To think the thought of death merged in the thought of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; materials,

<BR>To think of all these wonders of city and country, and others

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; taking great interest in them, and we taking no

interest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in them.



<P>&nbsp;To think how eager we are in building our houses,

<BR>To think others shall be just as eager, and we quite

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indifferent.



<P>&nbsp;(I see one building the house that serves him a few years, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seventy or eighty years at most,

<BR>I see one building the house that serves him longer than that.)



<P>&nbsp;Slow-moving and black lines creep over the whole earth&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they never cease&amp;emdash;they are the burial

lines,

<BR>He that was President was buried, and he that is now President

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall surely be buried.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

A reminiscence of the vulgar fate,

<BR>A frequent sample of the life and death of workmen,

<BR>Each after his kind.



<P>&nbsp;Cold dash of waves at the ferry-wharf, posh and ice in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; river, half-frozen mud in the streets,

<BR>A gray discouraged sky overhead, the short last daylight of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; December,

<BR>A hearse and stages, the funeral of an old Broadway stagedriver,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the cortege mostly drivers.



<P>&nbsp;Steady the trot to the cemetery, duly rattles the death-bell,

<BR>The gate is pass'd, the new-dug grave is halted at, the living

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; alight, the hearse uncloses,

<BR>The coffin is pass'd out, lower'd and settled, the whip is laid

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on the coffin, the earth is swiftly shovel'd in,

<BR>The mound above is flatted with the spades&amp;emdash;silence,

<BR>A minute&amp;emdash;no one moves or speaks&amp;emdash;it is done,

<BR>He is decently put away&amp;emdash;is there any thing more?



<P>&nbsp;He was a good fellow, free-mouth'd, quick-temper'd, not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bad-looking,

<BR>Ready with life or death for a friend, fond of women, gambled,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ate hearty, drank hearty,

<BR>Had known what it was to be flush, grew low-spirited toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the last, sicken'd, was help'd by a contribution,

<BR>Died, aged forty-one years&amp;emdash;and that was his funeral.



<P>&nbsp;Thumb extended, finger uplifted, apron, cape, gloves, strap,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wet-weather clothes, whip carefully chosen,

<BR>Boss, spotter, starter, hostler, somebody loafing on you, you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; loafing on somebody, headway, man before and man

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; behind,

<BR>Good day's work, bad day's work, pet stock, mean stock,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; first out, last out, turning-in at night,

<BR>To think that these are so much and so nigh to other drivers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and he there takes no interest in them.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>5</CENTER>

The markets, the government, the working-man's wages, to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; think what account they are through our nights and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; days,

<BR>To think that other working-men will make just as great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; account of them, yet we make little or no account.



<P>&nbsp;The vulgar and the refined, what you call sin and what

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you call goodness, to think how wide a difference,

<BR>To think the difference will still continue to others, yet we lie

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beyond the difference.



<P>&nbsp;To think how much pleasure there is,

<BR>Do you enjoy yourself in the city? or engaged in business? or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; planning a nomination and election? or with your

wife

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and family?

<BR>Or with your mother and sisters? or in womanly housework?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or the beautiful maternal cares?

<BR>These also flow onward to others, you and I flow onward,

<BR>But in due time you and I shall take less interest in them.



<P>&nbsp;Your farm, profits, crops&amp;emdash;to think how engross'd you

are,

<BR>To think there will still be farms, profits, crops, yet for you of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what avail?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>6</CENTER>

What will be will be well, for what is is well,

<BR>To take interest is well, and not to take interest shall be well.



<P>&nbsp;The domestic joys, the daily housework or business, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; building of houses, are not phantasms, they have

weight,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; form, location,

<BR>Farms, profits, crops, markets, wages, government, are none

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of them phantasms,

<BR>The difference between sin and goodness is no delusion,

<BR>The earth is not an echo, man and his life and all the things of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his life are well-consider'd.



<P>&nbsp;You are not thrown to the winds, you gather certainly and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; safely around yourself,

<BR>Yourself! yourself! yourself, for ever and ever!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>7</CENTER>

It is not to diffuse you that you were born of your mother

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and father, it is to identify you,

<BR>It is not that you should be undecided, but that you should

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be decided,

<BR>Something long preparing and formless is arrived and form'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in you,

<BR>You are henceforth secure, whatever comes or goes.



<P>&nbsp;The threads that were spun are gather'd, the weft crosses the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; warp, the pattern is systematic.



<P>The preparations have every one been justified,

<BR>The orchestra have sufficiently tuned their instruments,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the baton has given the signal.



<P>&nbsp;The guest that was coming, he waited long, he is now housed,

<BR>He is one of those who are beautiful and happy, he is one of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those that to look upon and be with is enough.



<P>&nbsp;The law of the past cannot be eluded,

<BR>The law of the present and future cannot be eluded,

<BR>The law of the living cannot be eluded, it is eternal,

<BR>The law of promotion and transformation cannot be eluded,

<BR>The law of heroes and good-doers cannot be eluded,

<BR>The law of drunkards, informers, mean persons, not one iota

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thereof can be eluded.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>8</CENTER>

Slow moving and black lines go ceaselessly over the earth,

<BR>Northerner goes carried and Southerner goes carried, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they on the Atlantic side and they on the Pacific,

<BR>And they between, and all through the Mississippi country,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and all over the earth.



<P>&nbsp;The great masters and kosmos are well as they go, the heroes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and good-doers are well,

<BR>The known leaders and inventors and the rich owners and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pious and distinguish'd may be well,

<BR>But there is more account than that, there is strict account of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all.



<P>&nbsp;The interminable hordes of the ignorant and wicked are not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nothing,

<BR>The barbarians of Africa and Asia are not nothing,

<BR>The perpetual successions of shallow people are not nothing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as they go.



<P>&nbsp;Of and in all these things,

<BR>I have dream'd that we are not to be changed so much, nor

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the law of us changed,

<BR>I have dream'd that heroes and good-doers shall be under the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; present and past law,

<BR>And that murderers, drunkards, liars, shall be under the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; present and past law,

<BR>For I have dream'd that the law they are under now is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; enough.



<P>&nbsp;And I have dream'd that the purpose and essence of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; known life, the transient,

<BR>Is to form and decide identity for the unknown life, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; permanent.



<P>&nbsp;If all came but to ashes of dung,

<BR>If maggots and rats ended us, then Alarum! for we are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; betray'd,

<BR>Then indeed suspicion of death.



<P>&nbsp;Do you suspect death? if I were to suspect death I should die

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; now,

<BR>Do you think I could walk pleasantly and well-suited toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; annihilation?



<P>&nbsp;Pleasantly and well-suited I walk,

<BR>Whither I walk I cannot define, but I know it is good,

<BR>The whole universe indicates that it is good,

<BR>The past and the present indicate that it is good.



<P>&nbsp;How beautiful and perfect are the animals!

<BR>How perfect the earth, and the minutest thing upon it!

<BR>What is called good is perfect, and what is called bad is just

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as perfect,

<BR>The vegetables and minerals are all perfect, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; imponderable fluids perfect;

<BR>Slowly and surely they have pass'd on to this, and slowly and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; surely they yet pass on.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>9</CENTER>

I swear I think now that every thing without exception has an

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eternal soul!

<BR>The trees have, rooted in the ground! the weeds of the sea

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; have! the animals!



<P>&nbsp;I swear I think there is nothing but immortality!

<BR>That the exquisite scheme is for it, and the nebulous float is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for it, and the cohering is for it!

<BR>And all preparation is for it&amp;emdash;and identity is for it&amp;emdash;and

life

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and materials are altogether for it!



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1855&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Salut Au Monde!</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Salut Au Monde!</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>O <FONT SIZE=-1>TAKE</FONT> my hand Walt Whitman!

<BR>Such gliding wonders! such sights and sounds!

<BR>Such join'd unended links, each hook'd to the next,

<BR>Each answering all, each sharing the earth with all.



<P>&nbsp;What widens within you Walt Whitman?

<BR>What waves and soils exuding?

<BR>What climes? what persons and cities are here?

<BR>Who are the infants, some playing, some slumbering?

<BR>Who are the girls? who are the married women?

<BR>Who are the groups of old men going slowly with their arms

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; about each other's necks?

<BR>What rivers are these? what forests and fruits are these?

<BR>What are the mountains call'd that rise so high in the mists?

<BR>What myriads of dwellings are they fill'd with dwellers?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Within me latitude widens, longitude lengthens,

<BR>Asia, Africa, Europe, are to the east&amp;emdash;America is provided

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for in the west,

<BR>Banding the bulge of the earth winds the hot equator,

<BR>Curiously north and south turn the axis-ends,

<BR>Within me is the longest day, the sun wheels in slanting rings,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it does not set for months,

<BR>Stretch'd in due time within me the midnight sun just rises

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; above the horizon and sinks again,

<BR>Within me zones, seas, cataracts, forests, volcanoes, groups,

<BR>Malaysia, Polynesia, and the great West Indian islands.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>What do you hear Walt Whitman?



<P>&nbsp;I hear the workman singing and the farmer's wife singing,

<BR>I hear in the distance the sounds of children and of animals

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; early in the day,

<BR>I hear emulous shouts of Australians pursuing the wild horse,

<BR>I hear the Spanish dance with castanets in the chestnut shade,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to the rebeck and guitar,

<BR>I hear continual echoes from the Thames,

<BR>I hear fierce French liberty songs,

<BR>I hear of the Italian boat-sculler the musical recitative of old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poems,

<BR>I hear the locusts in Syria as they strike the grain and grass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the showers of their terrible clouds,

<BR>I hear the Coptic refrain toward sundown, pensively falling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on the breast of the black venerable vast

mother the Nile,

<BR>I hear the chirp of the Mexican muleteer, and the bells of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mule,

<BR>I hear the Arab muezzin calling from the top of the mosque,

<BR>I hear the Christian priests at the altars of their churches, I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hear the responsive base and soprano,

<BR>I hear the cry of the Cossack, and the sailor's voice putting to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea at Okotsk,

<BR>I hear the wheeze of the slave-coffle as the slaves march on, as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the husky gangs pass on by twos and threes,

fasten'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; together with wrist-chains and ankle-chains,

<BR>I hear the Hebrew reading his records and psalms,

<BR>I hear the rhythmic myths of the Greeks, and the strong

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; legends of the Romans,

<BR>I hear the tale of the divine life and bloody death of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beautiful God the Christ,

<BR>I hear the Hindoo teaching his favorite pupil the loves, wars,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; adages, transmitted safely to this day from

poets who

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wrote three thousand years ago.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>What do you see Walt Whitman?

<BR>Who are they you salute, and that one after another salute you?



<P>&nbsp;I see a great round wonder rolling through space,

<BR>I see diminute farms, hamlets, ruins, graveyards, jails, factories,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; palaces, hovels, huts of barbarians, tents

of nomads

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon the surface,

<BR>I see the shaded part on one side where the sleepers are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sleeping, and the sunlit part on the other

side,

<BR>I see the curious rapid change of the light and shade,

<BR>I see distant lands, as real and near to the inhabitants of them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as my land is to me.



<P>&nbsp;I see plenteous waters,

<BR>I see mountain peaks, I see the sierras of Andes where they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; range,

<BR>I see plainly the Himalayas, Chian Shahs, Altays, Ghauts,

<BR>I see the giant pinnacles of Elbruz, Kazbek, Bazardjusi,

<BR>I see the Styrian Alps, and the Karnac Alps,

<BR>I see the Pyrenees, Balks, Carpathians, and to the north the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Dofrafields, and off at sea mount Hecla,

<BR>I see Vesuvius and Etna, the mountains of the Moon, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Red mountains of Madagascar,

<BR>I see the Lybian, Arabian, and Asiatic deserts,

<BR>I see huge dreadful Arctic and Antarctic icebergs,

<BR>I see the superior oceans and the interior ones, the Atlantic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and Pacific, the sea of Mexico, the Brazilian

sea, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea of Peru,

<BR>The waters of Hindustan, the China sea, and the gulf of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Guinea,

<BR>The Japan waters, the beautiful bay of Nagasaki land-lock'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in its mountains,

<BR>The spread of the Baltic, Caspian, Bothnia, the British shores,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the bay of Biscay,

<BR>The clear-sunn'd Mediterranean, and from one to another of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; its islands,

<BR>The White sea, and the sea around Greenland.



<P>&nbsp;I behold the mariners of the world,

<BR>Some are in storms, some in the night with the watch on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lookout,

<BR>Some drifting helplessly, some with contagious diseases.



<P>&nbsp;I behold the sail and steamships of the world, some in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clusters in port, some on their voyages,

<BR>Some double the cape of Storms, some cape Verde, others

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; capes Guardafui, Bon, or Bajadore,

<BR>Others Dondra head, others pass the straits of Sunda, others

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cape Lopatka, others Behring's straits,

<BR>Others cape Horn, others sail the gulf of Mexico or along

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Cuba or Hayti, others Hudson's bay or Baffin's

bay,

<BR>Others pass the straits of Dover, others enter the Wash,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; others the firth of Solway, others round cape

Clear,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; others the Land's End,

<BR>Others traverse the Zuyder Zee or the Scheld,

<BR>Others as comers and goers at Gibraltar or the Dardanelles,

<BR>Others sternly push their way through the northern winterpacks,

<BR>Others descend or ascend the Obi or the Lena,

<BR>Others the Niger or the Congo, others the Indus, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Burampooter and Cambodia,

<BR>Others wait steam'd up ready to start in the ports of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Australia,

<BR>Wait at Liverpool, Glasgow, Dublin, Marseilles, Lisbon,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Naples, Hamburg, Bremen, Bordeaux, the Hague,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Copenhagen,

<BR>Wait at Valparaiso, Rio Janeiro, Panama.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>I see the tracks of the railroads of the earth,

<BR>I see them in Great Britain, I see them in Europe,

<BR>I see them in Asia and in Africa.



<P>&nbsp;I see the electric telegraphs of the earth,

<BR>I see the filaments of the news of the wars, deaths, losses,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gains, passions, of my race.



<P>&nbsp;I see the long river-stripes of the earth,

<BR>I see the Amazon and the Paraguay,

<BR>I see the four great rivers of China, the Amour, the Yellow

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; River, the Yiang-tse, and the Pearl,

<BR>I see where the Seine flows, and where the Danube, the Loire,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Rhone, and the Guadalquiver flow,



<P>&nbsp;I see the windings of the Volga, the Dnieper, the Oder,

<BR>I see the Tuscan going down the Arno, and the Venetian

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; along the Po,

<BR>I see the Greek seaman sailing out of Egina bay.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>I see the sight of the old empire of Assyria, and that of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Persia, and that of India,

<BR>I see the falling of the Ganges over the high rim of Saukara.



<P>&nbsp;I see the place of the idea of the Deity incarnated by avatars

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in human forms,

<BR>I see the spots of the successions of priests on the earth,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; oracles, sacrificers, brahmins, sabians, Ilamas,

monks,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; muftis, exhorters,

<BR>I see where druids walk'd the groves of Mona, I see the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mistletoe and vervain,

<BR>I see the temples of the deaths of the bodies of Gods, I see the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; old signifiers.



<P>&nbsp;I see Christ eating the bread of his last supper in the midst

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; youths and old persons,

<BR>I see where the strong divine young man the Hercules toil'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; faithfully and long and then died,

<BR>I see the place of the innocent rich life and hapless fate of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beautiful nocturnal son, the full-limb'd Bacchus,

<BR>I see Kneph, blooming, drest in blue, with the crown of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feathers on his head,

<BR>I see Hermes, unsuspected, dying, well-belov'd, saying to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; people <I>Do not weep for me,</I>

<BR><I>This is not my true country, I have lived banish'd from my true</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; country, I now go back there,</I>

<BR><I>I return to the celestial sphere where every one goes in his turn.</I>



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>I see the battle-fields of the earth, grass grows upon them and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blossoms and corn,

<BR>I see the tracks of ancient and modern expeditions.



<P>&nbsp;I see the nameless masonries, venerable messages of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unknown events, heroes, records of the earth.



<P>&nbsp;I see the places of the sagas,

<BR>I see pine-trees and fir-trees torn by northern blasts,

<BR>I see granite bowlders and cliffs, I see green meadows and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lakes,

<BR>I see the burial-cairns of Scandinavian warriors,

<BR>I see them raised high with stones by the marge of restless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; oceans, that the dead men's spirits when they

wearied of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their quiet graves might rise up through the

mounds and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gaze on the tossing billows, and be refresh'd

by storms,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; immensity, liberty, action.



<P>&nbsp;I see the steppes of Asia,

<BR>I see the tumuli of Mongolia, I see the tents of Kalmucks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and Baskirs,

<BR>I see the nomadic tribes with herds of oxen and cows,

<BR>I see the table-lands notch'd with ravines, I see the jungles

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and deserts,

<BR>I see the camel, the wild steed, the bustard, the fat-tail'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sheep, the antelope, and the burrowing wolf.



<P>&nbsp;I see the highlands of Abyssinia,

<BR>I see flocks of goats feeding, and see the fig-tree, tamarind,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; date,

<BR>And see fields of teff-wheat and places of verdure and gold.



<P>&nbsp;I see the Brazilian vaquero,

<BR>I see the Bolivian ascending mount Sorata,

<BR>I see the Wacho crossing the plains, I see the incomparable

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rider of horses with his lasso on his arm,

<BR>I see over the pampas the pursuit of wild cattle for their hides.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8, [9]</CENTER>





<P>I see the regions of snow and ice,

<BR>I see the sharp-eyed Samoiede and the Finn,

<BR>I see the seal-seeker in his boat poising his lance,

<BR>I see the Siberian on his slight-built sledge drawn by dogs,



<P>&nbsp;I see the porpoise-hunters, I see the whale-crews of the south

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Pacific and the north Atlantic,

<BR>I see the cliffs, glaciers, torrents, valleys, of Switzerland&amp;emdash;I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mark the long winters and the isolation.



<P>&nbsp;I see the cities of the earth and make myself at random a part

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of them,

<BR>I am a real Parisian,

<BR>I am a habitan of Vienna, St. Petersburg, Berlin, Constantinople,

<BR>I am of Adelaide, Sidney, Melbourne,

<BR>I am of London, Manchester, Bristol, Edinburgh, Limerick,

<BR>I am of Madrid, Cadiz, Barcelona, Oporto, Lyons, Brussels,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Berne, Frankfort, Stuttgart, Turin, Florence,

<BR>I belong in Moscow, Cracow, Warsaw, or northward in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Christiania or Stockholm, or in Siberian Irkutsk,

or in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; some street in Iceland,

<BR>I descend upon all those cities, and rise from them again.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>10</CENTER>





<P>I see vapors exhaling from unexplored countries,

<BR>I see the savage types, the bow and arrow, the poison'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; splint, the fetich, and the obi.



<P>&nbsp;I see African and Asiatic towns,

<BR>I see Algiers, Tripoli, Derne, Mogadore, Timbuctoo,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Monrovia,

<BR>I see the swarms of Pekin, Canton, Benares, Delhi, Calcutta,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Tokio,

<BR>I see the Kruman in his hut, and the Dahoman and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ashanteeman in their huts,

<BR>I see the Turk smoking opium in Aleppo,

<BR>I see the picturesque crowds at the fairs of Khiva and those of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Herat,

<BR>I see Teheran, I see Muscat and Medina and the intervening

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sands, I see the caravans toiling onward,

<BR>I see Egypt and the Egyptians, I see the pyramids and obelisks,

<BR>I look on chisell'd histories, records of conquering kings,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dynasties, cut in slabs of sand-stone, or

on graniteblocks.



<P>&nbsp;I see at Memphis mummy-pits containing mummies embalm'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swathed in linen-cloth, lying there many centuries,

<BR>I look on the fall'n Theban, the large-ball'd eyes, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; side-drooping neck, the hands folded across

the breast.



<P>&nbsp;I see all the menials of the earth, laboring,

<BR>I see all the prisoners in the prisons,

<BR>I see the defective human bodies of the earth,

<BR>The blind, the deaf and dumb, idiots, hunchbacks, lunatics,

<BR>The pirates, thieves, betrayers, murderers, slave-makers of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the earth,

<BR>The helpless infants, and the helpless old men and women.



<P>&nbsp;I see male and female everywhere,

<BR>I see the serene brotherhood of philosophs,

<BR>I see the constructiveness of my race,

<BR>I see the results of the perseverance and industry of my race,

<BR>I see ranks, colors, barbarisms, civilizations, I go among

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them, I mix indiscriminately,

<BR>And I salute all the inhabitants of the earth.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>11</CENTER>





<P>You whoever you are!

<BR>You daughter or son of England!

<BR>You of the mighty Slavic tribes and empires! you Russ in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Russia!

<BR>You dim-descended, black, divine-soul'd African, large,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fine-headed, nobly-form'd, superbly destin'd,

on equal terms

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with me!

<BR>You Norwegian! Swede! Dane! Icelander! you Prussian!

<BR>You Spaniard of Spain! you Portuguese!

<BR>You Frenchwoman and Frenchman of France!

<BR>You Belge! you liberty-lover of the Netherlands! (you stock

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whence I myself have descended;)

<BR>You sturdy Austrian! you Lombard! Hun! Bohemian!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; farmer of Styria!

<BR>You neighbor of the Danube!

<BR>You working-man of the Rhine, the Elbe, or the Weser! you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; working-woman too!



<P>&nbsp;You Sardinian! you Bavarian! Swabian! Saxon! Wallachian!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Bulgarian!

<BR>You Roman! Neapolitan! you Greek!

<BR>You lithe matador in the arena at Seville!

<BR>You mountaineer living lawlessly on the Taurus or Caucasus!

<BR>You Bokh horse-herd watching your mares and stallions

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feeding!

<BR>You beautiful-bodied Persian at full speed in the saddle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shooting arrows to the mark!

<BR>You Chinaman and Chinawoman of China! you Tartar of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Tartary!

<BR>You women of the earth subordinated at your tasks!

<BR>You Jew journeying in your old age through every risk to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stand once on Syrian ground!

<BR>You other Jews waiting in all lands for your Messiah!

<BR>You thoughtful Armenian pondering by some stream of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Euphrates! you peering amid the ruins of Nineveh!

you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ascending mount Ararat!

<BR>You foot-worn pilgrim welcoming the far-away sparkle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the minarets of Mecca!

<BR>You sheiks along the stretch from Suez to Bab-el-mandeb

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ruling your families and tribes!

<BR>You olive-grower tending your fruit on fields of Nazareth,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Damascus, or lake Tiberias!

<BR>You Thibet trader on the wide inland or bargaining in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shops of Lassa!

<BR>You Japanese man or woman! you liver in Madagascar,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ceylon, Sumatra, Borneo!

<BR>All you continentals of Asia, Africa, Europe, Australia,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indifferent of place!

<BR>All you on the numberless islands of the archipelagoes of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea!

<BR>And you of centuries hence when you listen to me!

<BR>And you each and everywhere whom I specify not, but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; include just the same!

<BR>Health to you! good will to you all, from me and America sent!



<P>&nbsp;Each of us inevitable,

<BR>Each of us limitless&amp;emdash;each of us with his or her right upon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the earth,



<P>&nbsp;Each of us allow'd the eternal purports of the earth,

<BR>Each of us here as divinely as any is here.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>12</CENTER>





<P>You Hottentot with clicking palate! you woolly-hair'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hordes!

<BR>You own'd persons dropping sweat-drops or blood-drops!

<BR>You human forms with the fathomless ever-impressive

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; countenances of brutes!

<BR>You poor koboo whom the meanest of the rest look down

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon for all your glimmering language and

spirituality!

<BR>You dwarf'd Kamtschatkan, Greenlander, Lapp!

<BR>You Austral negro, naked, red, sooty, with protrusive lip,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; groveling, seeking your food!

<BR>You Caffre, Berber, Soudanese!

<BR>You haggard, uncouth, untutor'd Bedowee!

<BR>You plague-swarms in Madras, Nankin, Kaubul, Cairo!

<BR>You benighted roamer of Amazonia! you Patagonian! you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Feejee-man!

<BR>I do not prefer others so very much before you either,

<BR>I do not say one word against you, away back there where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you stand,

<BR>(You will come forward in due time to my side.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>13</CENTER>





<P>My spirit has pass'd in compassion and determination around

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the whole earth,

<BR>I have look'd for equals and lovers and found them ready for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me in all lands,

<BR>I think some divine rapport has equalized me with them.



<P>&nbsp;You vapors, I think I have risen with you, moved away

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to distant continents, and fallen down there,

for reasons,

<BR>I think I have blown with you you winds;

<BR>You waters I have finger'd every shore with you,

<BR>I have run through what any river or strait of the globe has

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; run through,



<P>&nbsp;I have taken my stand on the bases of peninsulas and on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; high embedded rocks, to cry thence:



<P>&nbsp;<I>Salut au monde!</I>

<BR>What cities the light or warmth penetrates I penetrate those

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cities myself,

<BR>All islands to which birds wing their way I wing my way

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself.



<P>&nbsp;Toward you all, in America's name,

<BR>I raise high the perpendicular hand, I make the signal,

<BR>To remain after me in sight forever,

<BR>For all the haunts and homes of men.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : A Song of Joys</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>A Song of Joys</I></H1></CENTER>

O <FONT SIZE=-1>TO</FONT> make the most jubilant song!

<BR>Full of music&amp;emdash;full of manhood, womanhood, infancy!

<BR>Full of common employments&amp;emdash;full of grain and trees.



<P>&nbsp;O for the voices of animals&amp;emdash;O for the swiftness and

balance

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of fishes!

<BR>O for the dropping of raindrops in a song!

<BR>O for the sunshine and motion of waves in a song!



<P>&nbsp;O the joy of my spirit&amp;emdash;it is uncaged&amp;emdash;it

darts like

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lightning!

<BR>It is not enough to have this globe or a certain time,

<BR>I will have thousands of globes and all time.



<P>&nbsp;O the engineer's joys! to go with a locomotive!

<BR>To hear the hiss of steam, the merry shriek, the steam-whistle,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the laughing locomotive!

<BR>To push with resistless way and speed off in the distance.



<P>&nbsp;O the gleesome saunter over fields and hillsides!

<BR>The leaves and flowers of the commonest weeds, the moist fresh

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stillness of the woods,

<BR>The exquisite smell of the earth at daybreak, and all through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the forenoon.



<P>&nbsp;O the horseman's and horsewoman's joys!

<BR>The saddle, the gallop, the pressure upon the seat, the cool

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gurgling by the ears and hair.



<P>&nbsp;O the fireman's joys!

<BR>I hear the alarm at dead of night,

<BR>I hear bells, shouts! I pass the crowd, I run!

<BR>The sight of the flames maddens me with pleasure.



<P>&nbsp;O the joy of the strong-brawn'd fighter, towering in the arena

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in perfect condition, conscious of power,

thirsting to meet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his opponent.



<P>&nbsp;O the joy of that vast elemental sympathy which only the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; human soul is capable of generating and emitting

in steady

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and limitless floods.



<P>&nbsp;O the mother's joys!

<BR>The watching, the endurance, the precious love, the anguish,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the patiently yielded life.



<P>&nbsp;O the joy of increase, growth, recuperation,

<BR>The joy of soothing and pacifying, the joy of concord and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; harmony.



<P>&nbsp;O to go back to the place where I was born,

<BR>To hear the birds sing once more,

<BR>To ramble about the house and barn and over the fields

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; once more,

<BR>And through the orchard and along the old lanes once more.



<P>&nbsp;O to have been brought up on bays, lagoons, creeks, or along

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the coast,

<BR>To continue and be employ'd there all my life,

<BR>The briny and damp smell, the shore, the salt weeds exposed at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; low water,

<BR>The work of fishermen, the work of the eel-fisher and clam-fisher;

<BR>I come with my clam-rake and spade, I come with my eel-spear,

<BR>Is the tide out? I join the group of clam-diggers on the flats,

<BR>I laugh and work with them, I joke at my work like a mettle-some

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; young man;

<BR>In winter I take my eel-basket and eel-spear and travel out on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; foot on the ice&amp;emdash;I have a small

axe to cut holes in the ice,



<P>&nbsp;Behold me well-clothed going gayly or returning in the afternoon,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my brood of tough boys accompanying me,

<BR>My brood of grown and part-grown boys, who love to be with no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one else so well as they love to be with me,

<BR>By day to work with me, and by night to sleep with me.



<P>&nbsp;Another time in warm weather out in a boat, to lift the lobster-pots

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; where they are sunk with heavy stones, (I

know the buoys,)

<BR>O the sweetness of the Fifth-month morning upon the water as I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; row just before sunrise toward the buoys,

<BR>I pull the wicker pots up slantingly, the dark green lobsters are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; desperate with their claws as I take them

out, I insert wooden

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pegs in the joints of their pincers,

<BR>I go to all the places one after another, and then row back

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to the shore,

<BR>There in a huge kettle of boiling water the lobsters shall be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; boil'd till their color becomes scarlet.



<P>&nbsp;Another time mackerel-taking,

<BR>Voracious, mad for the hook, near the surface, they seem to fill

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the water for miles;

<BR>Another time fishing for rock-fish in Chesapeake Bay, I one of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the brown-faced crew;

<BR>Another time trailing for blue-fish off Paumanok, I stand with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; braced body,

<BR>My left foot is on the gunwale, my right arm throws far out the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; coils of slender rope,

<BR>In sight around me the quick veering and darting of fifty skiffs,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my companions.



<P>&nbsp;O boating on the rivers,

<BR>The voyage down the St. Lawrence, the superb scenery, the steamers,

<BR>The ships sailing, the Thousand Islands, the occasional timber-raft

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the raftsmen with long-reaching sweepoars,

<BR>The little huts on the rafts, and the stream of smoke when they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cook supper at evening.



<P>&nbsp;(O something pernicious and dread!

<BR>Something far away from a puny and pious life!

<BR>Something unproved! something in a trance!

<BR>Something escaped from the anchorage and driving free.)



<P>&nbsp;O to work in mines, or forging iron,

<BR>Foundry casting, the foundry itself, the rude high roof, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ample and shadow'd space,

<BR>The furnace, the hot liquid pour'd out and running.



<P>&nbsp;O to resume the joys of the soldier!

<BR>To feel the presence of a brave commanding officer&amp;emdash;to feel

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his sympathy!

<BR>To behold his calmness&amp;emdash;to be warm'd in the rays of his smile!

<BR>To go to battle&amp;emdash;to hear the bugles play and the drums beat!

<BR>To hear the crash of artillery&amp;emdash;to see the glittering of

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bayonets and musket-barrels in the sun!

<BR>To see men fall and die and not complain!

<BR>To taste the savage taste of blood&amp;emdash;to be so devilish!

<BR>To gloat so over the wounds and deaths of the enemy.



<P>&nbsp;O the whaleman's joys! O I cruise my old cruise again!

<BR>I feel the ship's motion under me, I feel the Atlantic breezes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fanning me,

<BR>I hear the cry again sent down from the mast-head, <I>There</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;she blows!</I>

<BR>Again I spring up the rigging to look with the rest&amp;emdash;we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; descend, wild with excitement,

<BR>I leap in the lower'd boat, we row toward our prey where he lies,

<BR>We approach stealthy and silent, I see the mountainous mass,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lethargic, basking,

<BR>I see the harpooner standing up, I see the weapon dart from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his vigorous arm;

<BR>O swift again far out in the ocean the wounded whale, settling,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; running to windward, tows me,

<BR>Again I see him rise to breathe, we row close again,

<BR>I see a lance driven through his side, press'd deep, turn'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the wound,



<P>&nbsp;Again we back off, I see him settle again, the life is leaving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him fast,

<BR>As he rises he spouts blood, I see him swim in circles narrower and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; narrower, swiftly cutting the water&amp;emdash;I

see him die,

<BR>He gives one convulsive leap in the centre of the circle, and then

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; falls flat and still in the bloody foam.



<P>&nbsp;O the old manhood of me, my noblest joy of all!

<BR>My children and grand-children, my white hair and beard,

<BR>My largeness, calmness, majesty, out of the long stretch of my life.



<P>&nbsp;O ripen'd joy of womanhood! O happiness at last!

<BR>I am more than eighty years of age, I am the most venerable mother,

<BR>How clear is my mind&amp;emdash;how all people draw night to me!

<BR>What attractions are these beyond any before? what bloom more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than the bloom of youth?

<BR>What beauty is this that descends upon me and rises out of me?



<P>&nbsp;O the orator's joys!

<BR>To inflate the chest, to roll the thunder of the voice out from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the ribs and throat,

<BR>To make the people rage, weep, hate, desire, with yourself,

<BR>To lead America&amp;emdash;to quell America with a great tongue.



<P>&nbsp;O the joy of my soul leaning pois'd on itself, receiving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; identity through materials and loving them,

observing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; characters and absorbing them,

<BR>My soul vibrated back to me from them, from sight, hearing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; touch, reason, articulation, comparison, memory,

and the like,

<BR>The real life of my senses and flesh transcending my senses and flesh,

<BR>My body done with materials, my sight done with my material eyes,

<BR>Proved to me this day beyond cavil that it is not my material eyes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; which finally see,

<BR>Nor my material body which finally loves, walks, laughs, shouts,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; embraces, procreates.



<P>&nbsp;O the farmer's joys!

<BR>Ohioan's, Illinoisian's, Wisconsinese', Kanadian's, Iowan's,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Kansian's, Missourian's, Oregonese' joys!

<BR>To rise at peep of day and pass forth nimbly to work,

<BR>To plough land in the fall for winter-sown crops,

<BR>To plough land in the spring for maize,

<BR>To train orchards, to graft the trees, to gather apples in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the fall.



<P>&nbsp;O to bathe in the swimming-bath, or in a good place along

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shore,

<BR>To splash the water! to walk ankle-deep, or race naked along

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the shore.



<P>&nbsp;O to realize space!

<BR>The plenteousness of all, that there are no bounds,

<BR>To emerge and be of the sky, of the sun and moon and flying

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clouds, as one with them.



<P>&nbsp;O the joy of a manly self-hood!

<BR>To be servile to none, to defer to none, not to any tyrant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; known or unknown,

<BR>To walk with erect carriage, a step springy and elastic,

<BR>To look with calm gaze or with a flashing eye,

<BR>To speak with a full and sonorous voice out of a broad chest,

<BR>To confront with your personality all the other personalities of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the earth.



<P>&nbsp;Know'st thou the excellent joys of youth?

<BR>Joys of the dear companions and of the merry word and laughing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; face?

<BR>Joy of the glad light-beaming day, joy of the wide-breath'd games?

<BR>Joy of sweet music, joy of the lighted ball-room and the dancers?

<BR>Joy of the plenteous dinner, strong carouse and drinking?



<P>&nbsp;Yet O my soul supreme!

<BR>Know'st thou the joys of pensive thought?

<BR>Joys of the free and lonesome heart, the tender, gloomy heart?



<P>&nbsp;Joys of the solitary walk, the spirit bow'd yet proud, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; suffering and the struggle?

<BR>The agonistic throes, the ecstasies, joys of the solemn musings

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day or night?

<BR>Joys of the thought of Death, the great spheres Time and Space?

<BR>Prophetic joys of better, loftier love's ideals, the divine wife,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sweet, eternal, perfect comrade?

<BR>Joys all thine own undying one, joys worthy thee O soul.



<P>&nbsp;O while I live to be the ruler of life, not a slave,

<BR>To meet life as a powerful conqueror,

<BR>No fumes, no ennui, no more complaints or scornful criticisms,

<BR>To these proud laws of the air, the water and the ground,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; proving my interior soul impregnable,

<BR>And nothing exterior shall ever take command of me.



<P>&nbsp;For not life's joys alone I sing, repeating&amp;emdash;the joy

of death!

<BR>The beautiful touch of Death, soothing and benumbing a few

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; moments, for reasons,

<BR>Myself discharging my excrementitious body to be burn'd, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; render'd to powder, or buried,

<BR>My real body doubtless left to me for other spheres,

<BR>My voided body nothing more to me, returning to the purifications,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; further offices, eternal uses of the earth.



<P>&nbsp;O to attract by more than attraction!

<BR>How it is I know not&amp;emdash;yet behold! the something which

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; obeys none of the rest,

<BR>It is offensive, never defensive&amp;emdash;yet how magnetic it draws.



<P>&nbsp;O to struggle against great odds, to meet enemies undaunted!

<BR>To be entirely alone with them, to find how much one can stand!

<BR>To look strife, torture, prison, popular odium, face to face!

<BR>To mount the scaffold, to advance to the muzzles of guns

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with perfect nonchalance!

<BR>To be indeed a God!



<P>&nbsp;O to sail to sea in a ship!

<BR>To leave this steady unendurable land,

<BR>To leave the tiresome sameness of the streets, the sidewalks and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the houses,

<BR>To leave you O you solid motionless land, and entering a ship,

<BR>To sail and sail and sail!



<P>&nbsp;O to have life henceforth a poem of new joys!

<BR>To dance, clap hands, exult, shout, skip, leap, roll on, float on!

<BR>To be a sailor of the world bound for all ports,

<BR>A ship itself, (see indeed these sails I spread to the sun and air,)

<BR>A swift and swelling ship full of rich words, full of joys.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Thou Mother with Thy Equal Brood</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B><I><FONT SIZE=+3>Thou Mother with Thy Equal Brood</FONT></I></B></CENTER>



<CENTER><B><I><FONT SIZE=+3></FONT></I></B>&nbsp;</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>hou</FONT> Mother with thy equal brood,

<BR>Thou varied chain of different States, yet one identity only,

<BR>A special song before I go I'd sing o'er all the rest,

<BR>For thee, the future.



<P>&nbsp;I'd sow a seed for thee of endless Nationality,

<BR>I'd fashion thy ensemble including body and soul,

<BR>I'd show away ahead thy real Union, and how it may be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accomplish'd.



<P>&nbsp;The paths to the house I seek to make,

<BR>But leave to those to come the house itself.



<P>&nbsp;Belief I sing, and preparation;

<BR>As Life and Nature are not great with reference to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; present only,

<BR>But greater still from what is yet to come,

<BR>Out of that formula for thee I sing.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

As a strong bird on pinions free,

<BR>Joyous, the amplest spaces heavenward cleaving,

<BR>Such be the thought I'd think of thee America,

<BR>Such be the recitative I'd bring for thee.



<P>&nbsp;The conceits of the poets of other lands I'd bring thee not,

<BR>Nor the compliments that have served their turn so long,

<BR>Nor rhyme, nor the classics, nor perfume of foreign court or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indoor library;

<BR>But an odor I'd bring as from forests of pine in Maine, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breath of an Illinois prairie,

<BR>With open airs of Virginia or Georgia or Tennessee, or from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Texas uplands, or Florida's glades,

<BR>Or the Saguenay's black stream, or the wide blue spread of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Huron,

<BR>With presentment of Yellowstone's scenes, or Yosemite,

<BR>And murmuring under, pervading all, I'd bring the rustling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea-sound,

<BR>That endlessly sounds from the two Great Seas of the world.



<P>&nbsp;And for thy subtler sense subtler refrains dread Mother,

<BR>Preludes of intellect tallying these and thee, mind-formulas

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fitted for thee, real and sane and large as these

and thee,

<BR>Thou! mounting higher, diving deeper than we knew, thou

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; transcendental Union!

<BR>By thee fact to be justified, blended with thought,

<BR>Thought of man justified, blended with God,

<BR>Through thy idea, lo, the immortal reality!

<BR>Through thy reality, lo, the immortal ideal!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

Brain of the New World, what a task is thine,

<BR>To formulate the Modern&amp;emdash;out of the peerless grandeur of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the modern,

<BR>Out of thyself, comprising science, to recast poems, churches,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; art,

<BR>(Recast, maybe discard them, end them&amp;emdash;maybe their work

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is done, who knows?)

<BR>By vision, hand, conception, on the background of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mighty past, the dead,

<BR>To limn with absolute faith the mighty living present.



<P>&nbsp;And yet thou living present brain, heir of the dead, the Old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; World brain,

<BR>Thou that lay folded like an unborn babe within its fold so

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long,

<BR>Thou carefully prepared by it so long&amp;emdash;haply thou but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unfoldest it, only maturest it,



<P>&nbsp;It to eventuate in thee&amp;emdash;the essence of the by-gone

time

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contain'd in thee,

<BR>Its poems, churches, arts, unwitting to themselves, destined

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with reference to thee;

<BR>Thou but the apples, long, long, long a-growing,

<BR>The fruit of all the Old ripening to-day in thee.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

Sail, sail thy best, ship of Democracy,

<BR>Of value is thy freight, 'tis not the Present only,

<BR>The Past is also stored in thee,

<BR>Thou holdest not the venture of thyself alone, not of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Western continent alone,

<BR>Earth's <I>r&egrave;esum&egrave;e</I> entire floats on thy keel O ship,

is steadied by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy spars,

<BR>With thee Time voyages in trust, the antecedent nations sink

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or swim with thee,

<BR>With all their ancient struggles, martyrs, heroes, epics, wars,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thou bear'st the other continents,

<BR>Theirs, theirs as much as thine, the destination-port

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; triumphant;

<BR>Steer then with good strong hand and wary eye O helmsman,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thou carriest great companions,

<BR>Venerable priestly Asia sails this day with thee,

<BR>And royal feudal Europe sails with thee.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>5</CENTER>

Beautiful world of new superber birth that rises to my eyes,

<BR>Like a limitless golden cloud filling the western sky,

<BR>Emblem of general maternity lifted above all,

<BR>Sacred shape of the bearer of daughters and sons,

<BR>Out of thy teeming womb thy giant babes in ceaseless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; procession issuing,

<BR>Acceding from such gestation, taking and giving continual

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strength and life,

<BR>World of the real&amp;emdash;world of the twain in one,

<BR>World of the soul, born by the world of the real alone, led to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; identity, body, by it alone,



<P>&nbsp;Yet in beginning only, incalculable masses of composite

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; precious materials,

<BR>By history's cycles forwarded, by every nation, language,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hither sent,

<BR>Ready, collected here, a freer, vast, electric world, to be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; constructed here,

<BR>(The true New World, the world of orbic science, morals,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; literatures to come,)

<BR>Thou wonder world yet undefined, unform'd, neither do I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; define thee,

<BR>How can I pierce the impenetrable blank of the future?

<BR>I feel thy ominous greatness evil as well as good,

<BR>I watch thee advancing, absorbing the present, transcending

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the past,

<BR>I see thy light lighting, and thy shadow shadowing, as if the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; entire globe,

<BR>But I do not undertake to define thee, hardly to comprehend

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thee,

<BR>I but thee name, thee prophesy, as now,

<BR>I merely thee ejaculate!

<BR>Thee in thy future,

<BR>Thee in thy only permanent life, career, thy own unloosen'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mind, thy soaring spirit,

<BR>Thee as another equally needed sun, radiant, ablaze, swift-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; moving, fructifying all,

<BR>Thee risen in potent cheerfulness and joy, in endless great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hilarity,

<BR>Scattering for good the cloud that hung so long, that weigh'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; so long upon the mind of man,

<BR>The doubt, suspicion, dread, of gradual, certain decadence of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; man;

<BR>Thee in thy larger, saner brood of female, male&amp;emdash;thee in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy athletes, moral, spiritual, South, North, West,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; East,

<BR>(To thy immortal breasts, Mother of All, thy every daughter,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; son, endear'd alike, forever equal,)

<BR>Thee in thy own musicians, singers, artists, unborn yet, but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; certain,

<BR>Thee in thy moral wealth and civilization, (until which thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; proudest material civilization must remain in vain,)

<BR>Thee in thy all-supplying, all-enclosing worship&amp;emdash;thee in

no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; single bible, saviour, merely,

<BR>Thy saviours countless, latent within thyself, thy bibles

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; incessant within thyself, equal to any, divine as

any,

<BR>(Thy soaring course thee formulating, not in thy two great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wars, nor in thy century's visible growth,

<BR>But far more in these leaves and chants, thy chants, great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mother!)

<BR>Thee in an education grown of thee, in teachers, studies,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; students, born of thee,

<BR>Thee in thy democratic f&ccedil;etes en-masse, thy high original

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; festivals, operas, lecturers, preachers,

<BR>Thee in thy ultimata, (the preparations only now completed,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the edifice on sure foundations tied,)

<BR>Thee in thy pinnacles, intellect, thought, thy topmost rational

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joys, thy love and godlike aspiration,

<BR>In thy resplendent coming literati, thy full-lung'd orators,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy sacerdotal bards, kosmic savans,

<BR>These! these in thee, (certain to come,) to-day I prophesy.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>6</CENTER>

Land tolerating all, accepting all, not for the good alone, all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; good for thee,

<BR>Land in the realms of God to be a realm unto thyself,

<BR>Under the rule of God to be a rule unto thyself.



<P>&nbsp;(Lo, where arise three peerless stars,

<BR>To be thy natal stars my country, Ensemble, Evolution,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Freedom,

<BR>Set in the sky of Law.)



<P>&nbsp;Land of unprecedented faith, God's faith,

<BR>Thy soil, thy very subsoil, all upheav'd,

<BR>The general inner earth so long so sedulously draped over,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; now hence for what it is boldly laid bare,

<BR>Open'd by thee to heaven's light for benefit or bale.



<P>&nbsp;Not for success alone,

<BR>Not to fair-sail unintermitted always,

<BR>The storm shall dash thy face, the murk of war and worse

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than war shall cover thee all over,

<BR>(Wert capable of war, its tug and trials? be capable of peace,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; its trials,

<BR>For the tug and mortal strain of nations come at last in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prosperous peace, not war;)

<BR>In many a smiling mask death shall approach beguiling thee,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thou in disease shalt swelter,

<BR>The livid cancer spread its hideous claws, clinging upon thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breasts, seeking to strike thee deep within,

<BR>Consumption of the worst, moral consumption, shall rouge

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy face with hectic,

<BR>But thou shalt face thy fortunes, thy diseases, and surmount

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them all,

<BR>Whatever they are to-day and whatever through time they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; may be,

<BR>They each and all shall lift and pass away and cease from thee,

<BR>While thou, Time's spirals rounding, out of thyself, thyself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; still extricating, fusing,

<BR>Equable, natural, mystical Union thou, (the mortal with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; immortal blent,)

<BR>Shalt soar toward the fulfilment of the future, the spirit of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the body and the mind,

<BR>The soul, its destinies.



<P>&nbsp;The soul, its destinies, the real real,

<BR>(Purport of all these apparitions of the real;)

<BR>In thee America, the soul, its destinies,

<BR>Thou globe of globes! thou wonder nebulous!

<BR>By many a throe of heat and cold convuls'd, (by these thyself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; solidifying,)

<BR>Thou mental, moral orb&amp;emdash;thou New, indeed new, Spiritual

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; World!

<BR>The Present holds thee not&amp;emdash;for such vast growth as thine,

<BR>For such unparallel'd flight as thine, such brood as thine,

<BR>The F<FONT SIZE=-1>uture</FONT> only holds thee and can hold thee.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1872&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>A PAUMANOK PICTURE</CENTER>

Two boats with nets lying off the sea-beach, quite still,

<BR>Ten fishermen waiting&amp;emdash;they discover a thick school of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mossbonkers&amp;emdash;they drop the join'd seine-ends

in the water,

<BR>The boats separate and row off, each on its rounding course

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to the beach, enclosing the mossbonkers,

<BR>The net is drawn in by a windlass by those who stop ashore,

<BR>Some of the fishermen lounge in their boats, others stand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ankle-deep in the water, pois'd on strong legs,

<BR>The boats partly drawn up, the water slapping against them,

<BR>Strew'd on the sand in heaps and windrows, well out from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the water, the green-back'd spotted mossbonkers.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1881 1881

<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Drum-Taps</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B><I><FONT SIZE=+3>Drum-Taps</FONT></I></B></CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>FIRST O SONGS FOR A PRELUDE</CENTER>



<CENTER>&nbsp;</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>irst</FONT> O songs for a prelude,

<BR>Lightly strike on the stretch'd tympanum pride and joy in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my city,

<BR>How she led the rest to arms, how she gave the cue,

<BR>How at once with lithe limbs unwaiting a moment she sprang,

<BR>(O superb! O Manhattan, my own, my peerless!

<BR>O strongest you in the hour of danger, in crisis! O truer

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than steel!)

<BR>How you sprang&amp;emdash;how you threw off the costumes of peace

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with indifferent hand,

<BR>How your soft opera-music changed, and the drum and fife

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; were heard in their stead,

<BR>How you led to the war, (that shall serve for our prelude,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; songs of soldiers,)

<BR>How Manhattan drum-taps led.



<P>&nbsp;Forty years had I in my city seen soldiers parading,

<BR>Forty years as a pageant, till unawares the lady of this

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; teeming and turbulent city,

<BR>Sleepless amid her ships, her houses, her incalculable wealth,

<BR>With her million children around her, suddenly,

<BR>At dead of night, at news from the south,

<BR>Incens'd struck with clinch'd hand the pavement.



<P>&nbsp;A shock electric, the night sustain'd it,

<BR>Till with ominous hum our hive at daybreak pour'd out its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myriads.



<P>&nbsp;From the houses then and the workshops, and through all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the doorways,

<BR>Leapt they tumultuous, and lo! Manhattan arming.



<P>&nbsp;To the drum-taps prompt,

<BR>The young men falling in and arming,

<BR>The mechanics arming, (the trowel, the jack-plane, the blacksmith's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hammer, tost aside with precipitation,)

<BR>The lawyer leaving his office and arming, the judge leaving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the court,

<BR>The driver deserting his wagon in the street, jumping down,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; throwing the reins abruptly down on the horses'

backs,

<BR>The salesman leaving the store, the boss, book-keeper,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; porter, all leaving;

<BR>Squads gather everywhere by common consent and arm,

<BR>The new recruits, even boys, the old men show them how to wear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their accoutrements, they buckle the straps

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; carefully,

<BR>Outdoors, arming, indoors arming, the flash of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; musketbarrels,

<BR>The white tents cluster in camps, the arm'd sentries around,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sunrise cannon and again at sunset,

<BR>Arm'd regiments arrive every day, pass through the city,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and embark from the wharves,

<BR>(How good they look as they tramp down to the river, sweaty,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with their guns on their shoulders!

<BR>How I love them! how I could hug them, with their brown

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; faces and their clothes and knapsacks cover'd

with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dust!)

<BR>The blood of the city up&amp;emdash;arm'd! arm'd! the cry everywhere,

<BR>The flags flung out from the steeples of churches and from all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the public buildings and stores,

<BR>The tearful parting, the mother kisses her son, the son kisses

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his mother,

<BR>(Loth is the mother to part, yet not a word does she speak to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; detain him,)

<BR>The tumultuous escort, the ranks of policemen preceding,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clearing the way,

<BR>The unpent enthusiasm, the wild cheers of the crowd for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their favorites,

<BR>The artillery, the silent cannons bright as gold, drawn along,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rumble lightly over the stones,

<BR>(Silent cannons, soon to cease your silence,

<BR>Soon unlimber'd to begin the red business;)



<P>&nbsp;All the mutter of preparation, all the determin'd arming,

<BR>The hospital service, the lint, bandages and medicines,

<BR>The women volunteering for nurses, the work begun for in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earnest, no mere parade now;

<BR>War! an arm'd race is advancing! the welcome for battle, no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; turning away;

<BR>War! be it weeks, months, or years, an arm'd race is advancing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to welcome it.



<P>&nbsp;Mannahatta a-march&amp;emdash;and it's O to sing it well!

<BR>It's O for a manly life in the camp.



<P>&nbsp;And the sturdy artillery,

<BR>The guns bright as gold, the work for giants, to serve well the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; guns,

<BR>Unlimber them! (no more as the past forty years for salute or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; courtesies merely,

<BR>Put in something now besides powder and wadding.)



<P>&nbsp;And you lady of ships, you Mannahatta,

<BR>Old matron of this proud, friendly, turbulent city,

<BR>Often in peace and wealth you were pensive or covertly frown'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amid all your children,

<BR>But now you smile with joy exulting old Mannahatta.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>EIGHTEEN SIXTY-ONE</CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>rm'd</FONT> year&amp;emdash;year of the struggle,

<BR>No dainty rhymes or sentimental love verses for you terrible

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; year,

<BR>Not you as some pale poetling seated at a desk lisping

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cadenzas piano,

<BR>But as a strong man erect, clothed in blue clothes, advancing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; carrying a rifle on your shoulder,

<BR>With well-gristled body and sunburnt face and hands, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a knife in the belt at your side,

<BR>As I heard you shouting loud, your sonorous voice ringing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; across the continent,

<BR>Your masculine voice O year, as rising amid the great cities,



<P>&nbsp;Amid the men of Manhattan I saw you as one of the workmen,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the dwellers in Manhattan,

<BR>Or with large steps crossing the prairies out of Illinois and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Indiana,

<BR>Rapidly crossing the West with springy gait and descending

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Alleghanies,

<BR>Or down from the great lakes or in Pennsylvania, or on deck

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; along the Ohio river,

<BR>Or southward along the Tennessee or Cumberland rivers, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at Chattanooga on the mountain top,

<BR>Saw I your gait and saw I your sinewy limbs clothed in blue,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bearing weapons, robust year,

<BR>Heard your determin'd voice launch'd forth again and again,

<BR>Year that suddenly sang by the mouths of the round-lipp'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cannon,

<BR>I repeat you, hurrying, crashing, sad, distracted year.

<PRE>(1861?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>BEAT! BEAT! DRUMS!</CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>eat</FONT>! beat! drums!&amp;emdash;blow! bugles! blow!

<BR>Through the windows&amp;emdash;through doors&amp;emdash;burst like

a ruthless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; force,

<BR>Into the solemn church, and scatter the congregation,

<BR>Into the school where the scholar is studying;

<BR>Leave not the bridegroom quiet&amp;emdash;no happiness must he have

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; now with his bride,

<BR>Nor the peaceful farmer any peace, ploughing his field or gathering

his grain,

<BR>So fierce you whirr and pound you drums&amp;emdash;so shrill you bugles

blow.



<P>&nbsp;Beat! beat! drums!&amp;emdash;blow! bugles! blow!

<BR>Over the traffic of cities&amp;emdash;over the rumble of wheels in

the streets;

<BR>Are beds prepared for sleepers at night in the houses? no sleepers

must sleep in those beds,

<BR>No bargainers' bargains by day&amp;emdash;no brokers or speculators

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;would they continue?

<BR>Would the talkers be talking? would the singer attempt to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sing?



<P>&nbsp;Would the lawyer rise in the court to state his case before the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; judge?

<BR>Then rattle quicker, heavier drums&amp;emdash;you bugles wilder blow.



<P>&nbsp;Beat! beat! drums!&amp;emdash;blow! bugles! blow!

<BR>Make no parley&amp;emdash;stop for no expostulation,
