<BR>Mind not the timid&amp;emdash;mind not the weeper or prayer,

<BR>Mind not the old man beseeching the young man,

<BR>Let not the child's voice be heard, nor the mother's entreaties,

<BR>Make even the trestles to shake the dead where they lie

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; awaiting the hearses,

<BR>So strong you thump O terrible drums&amp;emdash;so loud you bugles

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blow.

<PRE>1861&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>FROM PAUMANOK STARTING I FLY LIKE A BIRD</CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>rom</FONT> Paumanok starting I fly like a bird,

<BR>Around and around to soar to sing the idea of all,

<BR>To the north betaking myself to sing there arctic songs,

<BR>To Kanada till I absorb Kanada in myself, to Michigan then,

<BR>To Wisconsin, Iowa, Minnesota, to sing their songs, (they are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inimitable;)

<BR>Then to Ohio and Indiana to sing theirs, to Missouri and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Kansas and Arkansas to sing theirs,

<BR>To Tennessee and Kentucky, to the Carolinas and Georgia

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to sing theirs,

<BR>To Texas and so along up toward California, to roam

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accepted everywhere;

<BR>To sing first, (to the tap of the war-drum if need be,)

<BR>The idea of all, of the Western world one and inseparable,

<BR>And then the song of each member of these States.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>SONG OF THE BANNER AT DAYBREAK</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Poet</I></CENTER>

O A new song, a free song,

<BR>Flapping, flapping, flapping, flapping, by sounds, by voices

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clearer,

<BR>By the wind's voice and that of the drum,

<BR>By the banner's voice and child's voice and sea's voice and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; father's voice,

<BR>Low on the ground and high in the air,

<BR>On the ground where father and child stand,

<BR>In the upward air where their eyes turn,

<BR>Where the banner at daybreak is flapping.



<P>&nbsp;Words! book-words! what are you?

<BR>Words no more, for hearken and see,

<BR>My song is there in the open air, and I must sing,

<BR>With the banner and pennant a-flapping.



<P>&nbsp;I'll weave the chord and twine in,

<BR>Man's desire and babe's desire, I'll twine them in, I'll put in

<BR>life,

<BR>I'll put the bayonet's flashing point, I'll let bullets and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slugs whizz,

<BR>(As one carrying a symbol and menace far into the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; future,

<BR>Crying with trumpet voice, <I>Arouse and beware! Beware and</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arouse</I>!)

<BR>I'll pour the verse with streams of blood, full of volition, full

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of joy,

<BR>Then loosen, launch forth, to go and compete,

<BR>With the banner and pennant a-flapping.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Pennant</I></CENTER>

Come up here, bard, bard,

<BR>Come up here, soul, soul,

<BR>Come up here, dear little child,

<BR>To fly in the clouds and winds with me, and play with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; measureless light.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Child</I></CENTER>

Father what is that in the sky beckoning to me with long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; finger?

<BR>And what does it say to me all the while?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Father</I></CENTER>

Nothing my babe you see in the sky,

<BR>And nothing at all to you it says&amp;emdash;but look you my babe,

<BR>Look at these dazzling things in the houses, and see you the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; money-shops opening,

<BR>And see you the vehicles preparing to crawl along the streets

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with goods;

<BR>These, ah these, how valued and toil'd for these!

<BR>How envied by all the earth!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Poet</I></CENTER>

Fresh and rosy red the sun is mounting high,

<BR>On floats the sea in distant blue careering through its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; channels,

<BR>On floats the wind over the breast of the sea setting in toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land,

<BR>The great steady wind from west or west-by-south,

<BR>Floating so buoyant with milk-white foam on the waters.



<P>&nbsp;But I am not the sea nor the red sun,

<BR>I am not the wind with girlish laughter,

<BR>Not the immense wind which strengthens, not the wind

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; which lashes,

<BR>Not the spirit that ever lashes its own body to terror and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death,

<BR>But I am that which unseen comes and sings, sings, sings,

<BR>Which babbles in brooks and scoots in showers on the land,

<BR>Which the birds know in the woods mornings and evenings,

<BR>And the shore-sands know and the hissing wave, and that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; banner and pennant,

<BR>Aloft there flapping and flapping.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Child</I></CENTER>

O father it is alive&amp;emdash;it is full of people&amp;emdash;it has

children,

<BR>O now it seems to me it is talking to its children,

<BR>I hear it&amp;emdash;it talks to me&amp;emdash;O it is wonderful!

<BR>O it stretches&amp;emdash;it spreads and runs so fast&amp;emdash;O

my father,

<BR>It is so broad it covers the whole sky.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Father</I></CENTER>

Cease, cease, my foolish babe,

<BR>What you are saying is sorrowful to me, much it displeases

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me;

<BR>Behold with the rest again I say, behold not banners and pennants aloft,

<BR>But the well-prepared pavements behold, and mark the solid-wall'd houses.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Banner and Pennant</I></CENTER>

Speak to the child O bard out of Manhattan,

<BR>To our children all, or north or south of Manhattan,

<BR>Point this day, leaving all the rest, to us over all&amp;emdash;and

yet we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know not why,

<BR>For what are we, mere strips of cloth profiting nothing,

<BR>Only flapping in the wind?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Poet</I></CENTER>

I hear and see not strips of cloth alone,

<BR>I hear the tramp of armies, I hear the challenging sentry,

<BR>I hear the jubilant shouts of millions of men, I hear Liberty!

<BR>I hear the drums beat and the trumpets blowing,

<BR>I myself move abroad swift-rising flying then,

<BR>I use the wings of the land-bird and use the wings of the sea-bird,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and look down as from a height,

<BR>I do not deny the precious results of peace, I see populous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cities with wealth incalculable,

<BR>I see numberless farms, I see the farmers working in their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fields or barns,

<BR>I see mechanics working, I see buildings everywhere founded,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; going up, or finish'd,

<BR>I see trains of cars swiftly speeding along railroad tracks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drawn by the locomotives,

<BR>I see the stores, depots, of Boston, Baltimore, Charleston,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; New Orleans,

<BR>I see far in the West the immense area of grain, I dwell awhile

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hovering,



<P>&nbsp;I pass to the lumber forests of the North, and again to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Southern plantation, and again to California;

<BR>Sweeping the whole I see the countless profit, the busy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gatherings, earn'd wages,

<BR>See the Identity formed out of thirty-eight spacious and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; haughty States, (and many more to come,)

<BR>See forts on the shores of harbors, see ships sailing in and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; out;

<BR>Then over all, (aye! aye!) my little and lengthen'd pennant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shaped like a sword,

<BR>Runs swiftly up indicating war and defiance&amp;emdash;and now the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; halyards have rais'd it,

<BR>Side of my banner broad and blue, side of my starry

<BR>banner,

<BR>Discarding peace over all the sea and land.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Banner and Pennant</I></CENTER>

Yet louder, higher, stronger, bard! yet farther, wider cleave!

<BR>No longer let our children deem us riches and peace alone,

<BR>We may be terror and carnage, and are so now,

<BR>Not now are we any one of these spacious and haughty

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; States, (nor any five, nor ten,)

<BR>Nor market nor depot we, nor money-bank in the city,

<BR>But these and all, and the brown and spreading land, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mines below, are ours,

<BR>And the shores of the sea are ours, and the rivers great and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; small,

<BR>And the fields they moisten, and the crops and the fruits are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ours,

<BR>Bays and channels and ships sailing in and out are ours&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; while we over all,

<BR>Over the area spread below, the three or four millions of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; square miles, the capitals,

<BR>The forty millions of people,&amp;emdash;O bard! in life and death

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; supreme,

<BR>We, even we, henceforth flaunt out masterful, high up above,

<BR>Not for the present alone, for a thousand years chanting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through you,

<BR>This song to the soul of one poor little child.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Child</I></CENTER>

O my father I like not the houses,

<BR>They will never to me be anything, nor do I like money,

<BR>But to mount up there I would like, O father dear, that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; banner I like,

<BR>That pennant I would be and must be.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Father</I></CENTER>

Child of mine you fill me with anguish,

<BR>To be that pennant would be too fearful,

<BR>Little you know what it is this day, and after this day, forever,

<BR>It is to gain nothing, but risk and defy everything,

<BR>Forward to stand in front of wars&amp;emdash;and O, such wars!&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what have you to do with them?

<BR>With passions of demons, slaughter, premature death?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Banner</I></CENTER>

Demons and death then I sing,

<BR>Put in all, aye all will I, sword-shaped pennant for war,

<BR>And a pleasure new and ecstatic, and the prattled yearning of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; children,

<BR>Blent with the sounds of the peaceful land and the liquid

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wash of the sea,

<BR>And the black ships fighting on the sea envelop'd in smoke,

<BR>And the icy cool of the far, far north, with rustling cedars

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and pines,

<BR>And the whirr of drums and the sound of soldiers marching,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the hot sun shining south,

<BR>And the beach-waves combing over the beach on my Eastern shore,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and my Western shore the same,

<BR>And all between those shores, and my ever running Mississippi

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with bends and chutes,

<BR>And my Illinois fields, and my Kansas fields, and my fields of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Missouri,

<BR>The Continent, devoting the whole identity without reserving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; an atom,

<BR>Pour in! whelm that which asks, which sings, with all and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yield of all,



<P>&nbsp;Fusing and holding, claiming, devouring the whole,

<BR>No more with tender lip, nor musical labial sound,

<BR>But out of the night emerging for good, our voice persuasive

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; no more,

<BR>Croaking like crows here in the wind.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Poet</I></CENTER>

My limbs, my veins dilate, my theme is clear at last,

<BR>Banner so broad advancing out of the night, I sing you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; haughty and resolute,

<BR>I burst through where I waited long, too long, deafen'd and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blinded,

<BR>My hearing and tongue are come to me, (a little child taught

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,)

<BR>I hear from above O pennant of war your ironical call and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; demand,

<BR>Insensate! insensate (yet I at any rate chant you,) O banner!

<BR>Not houses of peace indeed are you, nor any nor all their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prosperity, (if need be, you shall again have

every one of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those houses to destroy them,

<BR>You thought not to destroy those valuable houses, standing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fast, full of comfort, built with money,

<BR>May they stand fast, then? not an hour except you above

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them and all stand fast;)

<BR>O banner, not money so precious are you, not farm produce you,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nor the material good nutriment,

<BR>Nor excellent stores, nor landed on wharves from the ships,

<BR>Not the superb ships with sail-power or steam-power, fetching and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; carrying cargoes,

<BR>Nor machinery, vehicles, trade, nor revenues&amp;emdash;but you as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; henceforth I see you,

<BR>Running up out of the night, bringing your cluster of stars,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (ever-enlarging stars,)

<BR>Divider of daybreak you, cutting the air, touch'd by the sun,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; measuring the sky,

<BR>(Passionately seen and yearn'd for by one poor little child,

<BR>While others remain busy or smartly talking, forever teaching

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thrift, thrift;)



<P>&nbsp;O you up there! O pennant! where you undulate like a snake

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hissing so curious,

<BR>Out of reach, an idea only, yet furiously fought for, risking

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bloody death, loved by me,

<BR>So loved&amp;emdash;O you banner leading the day with stars brought

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from the night!

<BR>Valueless, object of eyes, over all and demanding all&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (absolute owner of all)&amp;emdash;O banner and

pennant!

<BR>I too leave the rest&amp;emdash;great as it is, it is nothing&amp;emdash;houses,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; machines are nothing&amp;emdash;I see them

not,

<BR>I see but you, O warlike pennant! O banner so broad, with stripes,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I sing you only,

<BR>Flapping up there in the wind.

<PRE>(1861-2?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>RISE O DAYS FROM YOUR FATHOMLESS DEEPS</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

R<FONT SIZE=-1>ise</FONT> O days from your fathomless deeps, till you loftier,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fiercer sweep,

<BR>Long for my soul hungering gymnastic I devour'd what the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth gave me,

<BR>Long I roam'd the woods of the north, long I watch'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Niagara pouring,

<BR>I travel'd the prairies over and slept on their breast, I cross'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Nevadas, I cross'd the plateaus,

<BR>I ascended the towering rocks along the Pacific, I sail'd out

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to sea,

<BR>I sail'd through the storm, I was refresh'd by the storm,

<BR>I watch'd with joy the threatening maws of the waves,

<BR>I mark'd the white combs where they career'd so high, curling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; over,

<BR>I heard the wind piping, I saw the black clouds,

<BR>Saw from below what arose and mounted, (O superb! O

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wild as my heart, and powerful!)

<BR>Heard the continuous thunder as it bellow'd after the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lightning,

<BR>Noted the slender and jagged threads of lightning as sudden

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and fast amid the din they chased each other

across the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sky;

<BR>These, and such as these, I, elate, saw&amp;emdash;saw with wonder,

yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pensive and masterful,

<BR>All the menacing might of the globe uprisen around me,

<BR>Yet there with my soul I fed, I fed content, supercilious.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>

'Twas well, O soul&amp;emdash;'twas a good preparation you gave me,

<BR>Now we advance our latent and ampler hunger to fill,

<BR>Now we go forth to receive what the earth and the sea never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gave us,

<BR>Not through the mighty woods we go, but through the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mightier cities,

<BR>Something for us is pouring now more than Niagara pouring,

<BR>Torrents of men, (sources and rills of the Northwest are you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indeed inexhaustible?)

<BR>What, to pavements and homesteads here, what were those

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; storms of the mountains and sea?

<BR>What, to passions I witness around me to-day? was the sea

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; risen?

<BR>Was the wind piping the pipe of death under the black clouds?

<BR>Lo! from deeps more unfathomable, something more deadly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and savage,

<BR>Manhattan rising, advancing with menacing front&amp;emdash;Cincinnati,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Chicago, unchain'd;

<BR>What was that swell I saw on the ocean? behold what comes here,

<BR>How it climbs with daring feet and hands&amp;emdash;how it dashes!

<BR>How the true thunder bellows after the lightning&amp;emdash;how

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bright the flashes of lightning!

<BR>How Democracy with desperate vengeful port strides on,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shown through the dark by those flashes of

lightning!

<BR>(Yet a mournful wail and low sob I fancied I heard through

<BR>the dark,

<BR>In a lull of the deafening confusion.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>

Thunder on! stride on, Democracy! strike with vengeful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stroke!

<BR>And do you rise higher than ever yet O days, O cities!

<BR>Crash heavier, heavier yet O storms! you have done me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; good,

<BR>My soul prepared in the mountains absorbs your immortal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strong nutriment,

<BR>Long had I walk'd my cities, my country roads through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; farms, only half satisfied,

<BR>One doubt nauseous undulating like a snake, crawl'd on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ground before me,

<BR>Continually preceding my steps, turning upon me oft, ironically

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hissing low;

<BR>The cities I love so well I abandon'd and left, I sped to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; certainties suitable to me,

<BR>Hungering, hungering, hungering, for primal energies and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Nature's dauntlessness,

<BR>I refresh'd myself with it only, I could relish it only,

<BR>I waited the bursting forth of the pent fire&amp;emdash;on the water

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; air I waited long;

<BR>But now I no longer wait, I am fully satisfied, I am glutted,

<BR>I have witness'd the true lightning, I have witness'd my cities

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; electric,

<BR>I have lived to behold man burst forth and warlike America

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rise,

<BR>Hence I will seek no more the food of the northern solitary

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wilds,

<BR>No more the mountains roam or sail the stormy sea.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>VIRGINIA&amp;emdash;THE WEST</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>he</FONT> noble sire fallen on evil days,

<BR>I saw with hand uplifted, menacing, brandishing,

<BR>(Memories of old in abeyance, love and faith in abeyance,)

<BR>The insane knife toward the Mother of All.



<P>&nbsp;The noble son on sinewy feet advancing,

<BR>I saw, out of the land of prairies, land of Ohio's waters and of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Indiana,

<BR>To the rescue the stalwart giant hurry his plenteous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; offspring,

<BR>Drest in blue, bearing their trusty rifles on their shoulders.

<BR>Then the Mother of All with calm voice speaking,

<BR>As to you Rebellious, (I seemed to hear her say,) why strive

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; against me, and why seek my life?

<BR>When you yourself forever provide to defend me?

<BR>For you provided me Washington&amp;emdash;and now these also.

<PRE>1872&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>CITY OF SHIPS</CENTER>

C<FONT SIZE=-1>ity</FONT> of Ships!

<BR>(O the black ships! O the fierce ships!

<BR>O the beautiful sharp-bow'd steam-ships and sail-ships!)

<BR>City of the world! (for all races are here,

<BR>All the lands of the earth make contributions here;)

<BR>City of the sea! city of hurried and glittering tides!

<BR>City whose gleeful tides continually rush or recede, whirling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in and out with eddies and foam!

<BR>City of wharves and stores&amp;emdash;city of tall fa&ccedil;cades

of marble and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; iron!

<BR>Proud and passionate city&amp;emdash;mettlesome, mad, extravagant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; city!

<BR>Spring up O city&amp;emdash;not for peace alone, but be indeed yourself,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; warlike!

<BR>Fear not&amp;emdash;submit to no models but your own O city!

<BR>Behold me&amp;emdash;incarnate me as I have incarnated you!

<BR>I have rejected nothing you offer'd me&amp;emdash;whom you adopted

I have adopted,

<BR>Good or bad I never question you&amp;emdash;I love all&amp;emdash;I

do not condemn anything,

<BR>I chant and celebrate all that is yours&amp;emdash;yet peace no more,

<BR>In peace I chanted peace, but now the drum of war is mine,

<BR>War, red war is my song through your streets, O city!

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>THE CENTENARIAN'S STORY</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Volunteer of</I> 1861-2, (<I>at Washington Park, Brooklyn, assisting

the Centenarian</I>)</CENTER>

G<FONT SIZE=-1>ive</FONT> me your hand old Revolutionary,

<BR>The hill-top is nigh, but a few steps, (make room

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gentlemen,)

<BR>Up the path you have follow'd me well, spite of your hundred and extra

years,

<BR>You can walk old man, though your eyes are almost done,

<BR>Your faculties serve you, and presently I must have them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; serve me.



<P>&nbsp;Rest, while I tell what the crowd around us means,

<BR>On the plain below recruits are drilling and exercising,

<BR>There is the camp, one regiment departs to-morrow,

<BR>Do you hear the officers giving their orders?

<BR>Do you hear the clank of the muskets?



<P>&nbsp;Why what comes over you now old man?

<BR>Why do you tremble and clutch my hand so convulsively?

<BR>The troops are but drilling, they are yet surrounded with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; smiles,

<BR>Around them at hand the well-drest friends and the women,

<BR>While splendid and warm the afternoon sun shines down,

<BR>Green the midsummer verdure and fresh blows the dallying

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breeze,

<BR>O'er proud and peaceful cities and arm of the sea between.



<P>&nbsp;But drill and parade are over, they march back to quarters,

<BR>Only hear that approval of hands! hear what a clapping!



<P>&nbsp;As wending the crowds now part and disperse&amp;emdash;but we

old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; man,

<BR>Not for nothing have I brought you hither&amp;emdash;we must remain,

<BR>You to speak in your turn, and I to listen and tell.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>The Centenarian</I></CENTER>

When I clutch'd your hand it was not with terror,

<BR>But suddenly pouring about me here on every side,

<BR>And below there where the boys were drilling, and up the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slopes they ran,

<BR>And where tents are pitch'd, and wherever you see south and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; south-east and south-west,

<BR>Over hills, across lowlands and in the skirts of woods,

<BR>And along the shores in mire (now fill'd over) came again

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and suddenly raged,



<P>&nbsp;As eighty-five years a-gone no mere parade receiv'd with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; applause of friends,

<BR>But a battle which I took part in myself&amp;emdash;aye, long ago as

it is,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I took part in it,

<BR>Walking then this hilltop, this same ground.



<P>&nbsp;Aye, this is the ground,

<BR>My blind eyes even as I speak behold it re-peopled from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; graves,

<BR>The years recede, pavements and stately houses disappear,

<BR>Rude forts appear again, the old hoop'd guns are mounted,

<BR>I see the lines of rais'd earth stretching from river to bay,

<BR>I mark the vista of waters, I mark the uplands and slopes;

<BR>Here we lay encamp'd, it was this time in summer also.



<P>&nbsp;As I talk I remember all, I remember the Declaration,

<BR>It was read here, the whole army paraded, it was read to us

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; here,

<BR>By his staff surrounded the General stood in the middle,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; he held up his unsheath'd sword,

<BR>It glitter'd in the sun in full sight of the army.



<P>&nbsp;'Twas a bold act then&amp;emdash;the English war-ships had just

arrived,

<BR>We could watch down the lower bay where they lay at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; anchor,

<BR>And the transports swarming with soldiers.



<P>&nbsp;A few days more and they landed and then the battle.



<P>&nbsp;Twenty thousand were brought against us,

<BR>A veteran force furnish'd with good artillery.



<P>&nbsp;I tell not now the whole of the battle,

<BR>But one brigade early in the forenoon order'd forward to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; engage the red-coats,

<BR>Of that brigade I tell, and how steadily it march'd,

<BR>And how long and well it stood confronting death.



<P>&nbsp;Who do you think that was marching steadily sternly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; confronting death?

<BR>It was the brigade of the youngest men, two thousand strong,

<BR>Rais'd in Virginia and Maryland, and most of them known

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; personally to the General.



<P>&nbsp;Jauntily forward they went with quick step toward Gowanus'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waters,

<BR>Till of a sudden unlook'd for by defiles through the woods,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gain'd at night,

<BR>The British advancing, rounding in from the east, fiercely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; playing their guns,

<BR>That brigade of the youngest was cut off and at the enemy's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mercy.



<P>&nbsp;The General watch'd them from this hill,

<BR>They made repeated desperate attempts to burst their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; environment,

<BR>Then drew close together, very compact, their flag flying in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the middle,

<BR>But O from the hills how the cannon were thinning and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thinning them!



<P>&nbsp;It sickens me yet, that slaughter!

<BR>I saw the moisture gather in drops on the face of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; General.

<BR>I saw how he wrung his hands in anguish.



<P>&nbsp;Meanwhile the British manoeuvr'd to draw us out for a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pitch'd battle,

<BR>But we dared not trust the chances of a pitch'd battle.



<P>&nbsp;We fought the fight in detachments,

<BR>Sallying forth we fought at several points, but in each the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; luck was against us,

<BR>Our foe advancing, steadily getting the best of it, push'd us

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; back to the works on this hill,

<BR>Till we turn'd menacing here, and then he left us.



<P>&nbsp;That was the going out of the brigade of the youngest men,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; two thousand strong,

<BR>Few return'd, nearly all remain in Brooklyn.



<P>&nbsp;That and here my General's first battle,

<BR>No women looking on nor sunshine to bask in, it did not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; conclude with applause,

<BR>Nobody clapp'd hands here then.



<P>&nbsp;But in darkness in mist on the ground under a chill rain,

<BR>Wearied that night we lay foil'd and sullen,

<BR>While scornfully laugh'd many an arrogant lord off against

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; us encamp'd,

<BR>Quite within hearing, feasting, clinking wineglasses together

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; over their victory.



<P>&nbsp;So dull and damp and another day,

<BR>But the night of that, mist lifting, rain ceasing,

<BR>Silent as a ghost while they thought they were sure of him,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my General retreated.



<P>&nbsp;I saw him at the river-side,

<BR>Down by the ferry lit by torches, hastening the embarcation;

<BR>My General waited till the soldiers and wounded were all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pass'd over,

<BR>And then, (it was just ere sunrise,) these eyes rested on him

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for the last time.



<P>&nbsp;Every one else seem'd fill'd with gloom,

<BR>Many no doubt thought of capitulation.



<P>&nbsp;But when my General pass'd me,

<BR>As he stood in his boat and look'd toward the coming sun,

<BR>I saw something different from capitulation.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Terminus</I></CENTER>

Enough, the Centenarian's story ends,

<BR>The two, the past and present, have interchanged,

<BR>I myself as connecter, a chansonnier of a great future, am

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; now speaking.



<P>&nbsp;And is this the ground Washington trod?

<BR>And these waters I listlessly daily cross, are these the waters

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; he cross'd,



<P>&nbsp;As resolute in defeat as other generals in their proudest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; triumphs?



<P>&nbsp;I must copy the story, and send it eastward and westward,

<BR>I must preserve that look as it beam'd on you rivers of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Brooklyn.



<P>&nbsp;See&amp;emdash;as the annual round returns the phantoms return,

<BR>It is the 27th of August and the British have landed,

<BR>The battle begins and goes against us, behold through the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; smoke Washington's face,

<BR>The brigade of Virginia and Maryland have march'd forth to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; intercept the enemy,

<BR>They are cut off, murderous artillery from the hills plays

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon them,

<BR>Rank after rank falls, while over them silently droops the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flag,

<BR>Baptized that day in many a young man's bloody wounds,

<BR>In death, defeat, and sisters', mothers' tears.



<P>&nbsp;Ah, hills and slopes of Brooklyn! I perceive you are more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; valuable than your owners supposed;

<BR>In the midst of you stands an encampment very old,

<BR>Stands forever the camp of that dead brigade.

<PRE>(1861-2?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>CAVALRY CROSSING A FORD</CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>line</FONT> in long array where they wind betwixt green

islands,

<BR>They take a serpentine course, their arms flash in the sun&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hark to the musical clank,

<BR>Behold the silvery river, in it the splashing horses loitering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stop to drink,

<BR>Behold the brown-faced men, each group, each person a picture,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the negligent rest on the saddles,

<BR>Some emerge on the opposite bank, others are just entering the ford&amp;emdash;while,

<BR>Scarlet and blue and snowy white,

<BR>The guidon flags flutter gayly in the wind.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>BIVOUAC ON A MOUNTAIN SIDE</CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>see</FONT> before me now a traveling army halting,

<BR>Below a fertile valley spread, with barns and the orchards of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; summer,

<BR>Behind, the terraced sides of a mountain, abrupt, in places

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rising high,

<BR>Broken, with rocks, with clinging cedars, with tall shapes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dingily seen,

<BR>The numerous camp-fires scatter'd near and far, some away

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; up on the mountain,

<BR>The shadowy forms of men and horses, looming, large-sized,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flickering,

<BR>And over all the sky&amp;emdash;the sky! far, far out of reach, studded,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breaking out, the eternal stars.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>AN ARMY CORPS ON THE MARCH</CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>ith</FONT> its cloud of skirmishers in advance,

<BR>With now the sound of a single shot snapping like a whip,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and now an irregular volley,

<BR>The swarming ranks press on and on, the dense brigades

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; press on,

<BR>Glittering dimly, toiling under the sun&amp;emdash;the dust-cover'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men,

<BR>In columns rise and fall to the undulations of the ground,

<BR>With artillery interspers'd&amp;emdash;the wheels rumble, the horses

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sweat,

<BR>As the army corps advances.

<PRE>1865-6&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>BY THE BIVOUAC'S FITFUL FLAME</CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>y</FONT> the bivouac's fitful flame,

<BR>A procession winding around me, solemn and sweet and slow&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but first I note,

<BR>The tents of the sleeping army, the fields' and woods' dim

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; outline,

<BR>The darkness lit by spots of kindled fire, the silence,

<BR>Like a phantom far or near an occasional figure moving,



<P>&nbsp;The shrubs and trees, (as I lift my eyes they seem to be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stealthily watching me,)

<BR>While wind in procession thoughts, O tender and wondrous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thoughts,

<BR>Of life and death, of home and the past and loved, and of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those that are far away;

<BR>A solemn and slow procession there as I sit on the ground,

<BR>By the bivouac's fitful flame.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>COME UP FROM THE FIELDS FATHER</CENTER>

C<FONT SIZE=-1>ome</FONT> up from the fields father, here's a letter from

our Pete,

<BR>And come to the front door mother, here's a letter from thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dear son.



<P>&nbsp;Lo, 'tis autumn,

<BR>Lo, where the trees, deeper green, yellower and redder,

<BR>Cool and sweeten Ohio's villages with leaves fluttering in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; moderate wind,

<BR>Where apples ripe in the orchards hang and grapes on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trellis'd vines,

<BR>(Smell you the smell of the grapes on the vines?

<BR>Smell you the buckwheat where the bees were lately buzzing?)



<P>&nbsp;Above all, lo, the sky so calm, so transparent after the rain,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and with wondrous clouds,

<BR>Below too, all calm, all vital and beautiful, and the farm

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prospers well.



<P>&nbsp;Down in the fields all prospers well,

<BR>But now from the fields come father, come at the daughter's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; call,

<BR>And come to the entry mother, to the front door come right

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; away.



<P>&nbsp;Fast as she can she hurries, something ominous, her steps

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trembling,

<BR>She does not tarry to smooth her hair nor adjust her cap.



<P>&nbsp;Open the envelope quickly,

<BR>O this is not our son's writing, yet his name is sign'd,



<P>&nbsp;O a strange hand writes for our dear son, O stricken mother's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soul!

<BR>All swims before her eyes, flashes with black, she catches the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; main words only,

<BR>Sentences broken, <I>gunshot wound in the breast, cavalry</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; skirmish, taken to hospital</I>,

<BR><I>At present low, but will soon be better</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Ah now the single figure to me,

<BR>Amid all teeming and wealthy Ohio with all its cities and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; farms,

<BR>Sickly white in the face and dull in the head, very faint,

<BR>By the jamb of a door leans.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Grieve not so, dear mother</I>, (the just-grown daughter speaks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through her sobs,

<BR>The little sisters huddle around speechless and dismay'd,)

<BR><I>See, dearest mother, the letter says Pete will soon be better</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Alas poor boy, he will never be better, (nor may-be needs to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be better, that brave and simple soul,)

<BR>While they stand at home at the door he is dead already,

<BR>The only son is dead.



<P>&nbsp;But the mother needs to be better,

<BR>She with thin form presently drest in black,

<BR>By day her meals untouch'd, then at night fitfully sleeping,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; often walking,

<BR>In the midnight waking, weeping, longing with one deep

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; longing,

<BR>O that she might withdraw unnoticed, silent from life escape

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and withdraw,

<BR>To follow, to seek, to be with her dear dead son.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>VIGIL STRANGE I KEPT ON THE FIELD ONE NIGHT</CENTER>

V<FONT SIZE=-1>igil</FONT> strange I kept on the field one night;

<BR>When you my son and my comrade dropt at my side that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day,

<BR>One look I but gave which your dear eyes return'd with a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; look I shall never forget,

<BR>One touch of your hand to mine O boy, reach'd up as you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lay on the ground,

<BR>Then onward I sped in the battle, the even-contested battle,

<BR>Till late in the night reliev'd to the place at last again I made

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my way,

<BR>Found you in death so cold dear comrade, found your body

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; son of responding kisses, (never again on earth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; responding,)

<BR>Bared your face in the stralight, curious the scene, cool blew

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the moderate night-wind,

<BR>Long there and then in vigil I stood, dimly around me the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; battlefield spreading,

<BR>Vigil wondrous and vigil sweet there in the fragrant silent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; night,

<BR>But not a tear fell, not even a long-drawn sigh, long, long I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gazed,

<BR>Then on the earth partially reclining sat by your side leaning

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my chin in my hands,

<BR>Passing sweet hours, immortal and mystic hours with you dearest comrade&amp;emdash;

<BR>not a tear, not a word, Vigil of silence, love and death, vigil for

you my son and my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soldier,

<BR>As onward silently stars aloft, eastward new ones upward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stole,

<BR>Vigil final for you brave boy, (I could not save you, swift was

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your death,

<BR>I faithfully loved you and cared for you living, I think we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall surely meet again,)

<BR>Till at latest lingering of the night, indeed just as the dawn

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; appear'd,

<BR>My comrade I wrapt in his blanket, envelop'd well his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; form,

<BR>Folded the blanket well, tucking it carefully over head and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; carefully under feet,

<BR>And there and then and bathed by the rising sun, my son in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his grave, in his rude-dug grave I deposited,

<BR>Ending my vigil strange with that, vigil of night and battle-field

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dim,



<P>&nbsp;Vigil for boy of responding kisses, (never again on earth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; responding,)

<BR>Vigil for comrade swiftly slain, vigil I never forget, how as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day brighten'd,

<BR>I rose from the chill ground and folded my soldier well in his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blanket,

<BR>And buried him where he fell.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>A MARCH IN THE RANKS HARD-PREST, AND THE ROAD UNKNOWN</CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>march</FONT> in the ranks hard-prest, and the road unknown,

<BR>A route through a heavy wood with muffled steps in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; darkness,

<BR>Our army foil'd with loss severe, and the sullen remnant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; retreating,

<BR>Till after midnight glimmer upon us the lights of a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dimlighted building,

<BR>We come to an open space in the woods, and halt by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dim-lighted building,

<BR>'Tis a large old church at the crossing roads, now an

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; impromptu hospital,

<BR>Entering but for a minute I see a sight beyond all the pictures

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and poems ever made,

<BR>Shadows of deepest, deepest black, just lit by moving candles

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and lamps,

<BR>And by one great pitchy torch stationary with wild red flame

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and clouds of smoke,

<BR>By these, crowds, groups of forms vaguely I see on the floor,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; some in the pews laid down,

<BR>At my feet more distinctly a soldier, a mere lad, in danger of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bleeding to death, (he is shot in the abdomen,)

<BR>I stanch the blood temporarily, (the youngster's face is white

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as a lily,)

<BR>Then before I depart I sweep my eyes o'er the scene fain to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; absorb it all,

<BR>Faces, varieties, postures beyond description, most in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; obscurity, some of them dead,

<BR>Surgeons operating, attendants holding lights, the smell of ether,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the odor of blood,

<BR>The crowd, O the crowd of the bloody forms, the yard

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; outside also fill'd,

<BR>Some on the bare ground, some on planks or stretchers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; some in the death-spasm sweating,

<BR>An occasional scream or cry, the doctor's shouted orders or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; calls,

<BR>The glisten of the little steel instruments catching the glint

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the torches,

<BR>These I resume as I chant, I see again the forms, I smell the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; odor,

<BR>Then hear outside the orders given, <I>Fall in, my men, fall in</I>;

<BR>But first I bend to the dying lad, his eyes open, a half-smile

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gives he me,

<BR>Then the eyes close, calmly close, and I speed forth to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; darkness,

<BR>Resuming, marching, ever in darkness marching, on in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ranks,

<BR>The unknown road still marching.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>A SIGHT IN CAMP IN THE DAYBREAK GRAY AND DIM</B></CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>sight</FONT> in camp in the daybreak gray and dim,

<BR>As from my tent I emerge so early sleepless,

<BR>As slow I walk in the cool fresh air the path near by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hospital tent,

<BR>Three forms I see on stretchers lying, brought out there

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untended lying,

<BR>Over each the blanket spread, ample brownish woolen blanket,

<BR>Gray and heavy blanket, folding, covering all.



<P>&nbsp;Curious I halt and silent stand,

<BR>Then with light fingers I from the face of the nearest the first

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; just lift the blanket;

<BR>Who are you elderly man so gaunt and grim, with well-gray'd hair,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and flesh all sunken about the eyes?

<BR>Who are you my dear comrade?



<P>&nbsp;Then to the second I step&amp;emdash;and who are you my child

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; darling?

<BR>Who are you sweet boy with cheeks yet blooming?



<P>&nbsp;Then to the third&amp;emdash;a face nor child nor old, very calm,

as of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beautiful yellow-white ivory;

<BR>Young man I think I know you&amp;emdash;I think this face is the face

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the Christ himself,

<BR>Dead and divine and brother of all, and here again he lies.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>AS TOILSOME I WANDER'D VIRGINIA'S WOODS</B></CENTER>

As toilsome I wander'd Virginia's woods,

<BR>To the music of rustling leaves kick'd by my feet, (for 'twas

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; autumn,)

<BR>I mark'd at the foot of a tree the grave of a soldier;

<BR>Mortally wounded he and buried on the retreat, (easily all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; could I understand,)

<BR>The halt of a mid-day hour, when up! no time to lose&amp;emdash;yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this sign left,

<BR>On a tablet scrawl'd and nail'd on the tree by the grave,

<BR><I>Bold, cautious, true, and my loving comrade</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Long, long I muse, then on my way go wandering,

<BR>Many a changeful season to follow, and many a scene of life,

<BR>Yet at times through changeful season and scene, abrupt,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; alone, or in the crowded street,

<BR>Comes before me the unknown soldier's grave, comes the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inscription rude in Virginia's woods,

<BR><I>Bold, cautious, true, and my loving comrade</I>.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>NOT THE PILOT</B></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>to</FONT> the pilot has charged himself to bring his ship

into port,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; though beaten back and many times baffled;

<BR>Not the pathfinder penetrating inland weary and long,

<BR>By deserts parch'd, snows chill'd, rivers wet, perseveres till he

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reaches his destination,

<BR>More than I have charged myself, heeded or unheeded, to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; compose a march for these States,

<BR>For a battle-call, rousing to arms if need be, years, centuries

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hence.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1860 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>YEAR THAT TREMBLED AND REEL'D BENEATH ME</B></CENTER>

Y<FONT SIZE=-1>ear</FONT> that trembled and reel'd beneath me!

<BR>Your summer wind was warm enough, yet the air I breathed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; froze me,

<BR>A thick gloom fell through the sunshine and darken'd me,

<BR>Must I change my triumphant songs? said I to myself,

<BR>Must I indeed learn to chant the cold dirges of the baffled?

<BR>And sullen hymns of defeat?



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>THE WOUND-DRESSER</B></CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>n</FONT> old man bending I come among new faces,

<BR>Years looking backward resuming in answer to children,

<BR>Come tell us old man, as from young men and maidens that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; love me,

<BR>(Arous'd and angry, I'd thought to beat the alarum, and urge

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; relentless war,

<BR>But soon my fingers fail'd me, my face droop'd and I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; resign'd myself,

<BR>To sit by the wounded and soothe them, or silently watch the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dead;)

<BR>Years hence of these scenes, of these furious passions, these

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chances,

<BR>Of unsurpass'd heroes, (was one side so brave? the other was

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; equally brave;)

<BR>Now be witness again, paint the mightiest armies of earth,

<BR>Of those armies so rapid so wondrous what saw you to tell us?

<BR>What stays with you latest and deepest? of curious panics,

<BR>Of hard-fought engagements or sieges tremendous what

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; deepest remains?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

O maidens and young men I love and that love me,

<BR>What you ask of my days those the strangest and sudden

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your talking recalls,

<BR>Soldier alert I arrive after a long march cover'd with sweat

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and dust,

<BR>In the nick of time I come, plunge in the fight, loudly shout

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the rush of successful charge,

<BR>Enter the captur'd works&amp;emdash;yet lo, like a swift running river

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they fade,

<BR>Pass and are gone they fade&amp;emdash;I dwell not on soldiers' perils

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or soldiers' joys,

<BR>(Both I remember well&amp;emdash;many of the hardships, few the joys,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet I was content.)



<P>&nbsp;But in silence, in dreams' projections,

<BR>While the world of gain and appearance and mirth goes on,

<BR>So soon what is over forgotten, and waves wash the imprints

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; off the sand,

<BR>With hinged knees returning I enter the doors, (while for you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; up there,

<BR>Whoever you are, follow without noise and be of strong

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heart.)



<P>&nbsp;Bearing the bandages, water and sponge,

<BR>Straight and swift to my wounded I go,

<BR>Where they lie on the ground after the battle brought in,

<BR>Where their priceless blood reddens the grass the ground,

<BR>Or to the rows of the hospital tent, or under the roof'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hospital,

<BR>To the long rows of cots up and down each side I return,

<BR>To each and all one after another I draw near, not one do I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; miss,

<BR>An attendant follows holding a tray, he carries a refuse pail,

<BR>Soon to be fill'd with clotted rags and blood, emptied, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fill'd again.



<P>&nbsp;I onward go, I stop,

<BR>With hinged knees and steady hand to dress wounds,

<BR>I am firm with each, the pangs are sharp yet unavoidable,

<BR>One turns to me his appealing eyes&amp;emdash;poor boy! I never knew

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you,

<BR>Yet I think I could not refuse this moment to die for you, if

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that would save you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

On, on I go, (open doors of time! open hospital doors!)

<BR>The crush'd head I dress, (poor crazed hand tear not the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bandage away,)

<BR>The neck of the cavalry-man with the bullet through and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through I examine,

<BR>Hard the breathing rattles, quite glazed already the eye, yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life struggles hard,

<BR>(Come sweet death! be persuaded O beautiful death!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In mercy come quickly.)



<P>&nbsp;From the stump of the arm, the amputated hand,

<BR>I undo the clotted lint, remove the slough, wash off the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; matter and blood,

<BR>Back on his pillow the soldier bends with curv'd neck and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; side falling head,

<BR>His eyes are closed, his face is pale, he dares not look on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bloody stump,

<BR>And has not yet look'd on it.



<P>&nbsp;I dress a wound in the side, deep, deep,

<BR>But a day or two more, for see the frame all wasted and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sinking,

<BR>And the yellow-blue countenance see.

<BR>I dress the perforated shoulder, the foot with the bullet-wound,

<BR>Cleanse the one with a gnawing and putrid gangrene, so

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sickening, so offensive,

<BR>While the attendant stands behind aside me holding the tray

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and pail.



<P>&nbsp;I am faithful, I do not give out,

<BR>The fractur'd thigh, the knee, the wound in the abdomen,

<BR>These and more I dress with impassive hand, (yet deep in my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breast a fire, a burning flame.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

Thus in silence in dreams' projections,

<BR>Returning, resuming, I thread my way through the hospitals,

<BR>The hurt and wounded I pacify with soothing hand,

<BR>I sit by the restless all the dark night, some are so young,

<BR>Some suffer so much, I recall the experience sweet and sad,

<BR>(Many a soldier's loving arms about this neck have cross'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and rested,

<BR>Many a soldier's kiss dwells on these bearded lips.)



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>LONG, TOO LONG AMERICA</B></CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>ong</FONT>, too long America,

<BR>Traveling roads all even and peaceful you learn'd from joys

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and prosperity only,

<BR>But now, ah now, to learn from crises of anguish, advancing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grappling with direst fate and recoiling not,

<BR>And now to conceive and show to the world what your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; children en-masse really are,

<BR>(For who except myself has yet conceiv'd what your children

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; en-masse really are?)



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>GIVE ME THE SPLENDID SILENT SUN</B></CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

G<FONT SIZE=-1>ive</FONT> me the splendid silent sun with all his beams

full-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dazzling,

<BR>Give me juicy autumnal fruit ripe and red from the orchard,

<BR>Give me a field where the unmow'd grass grows,

<BR>Give me an arbor, give me the trellis'd grape,

<BR>Give me fresh corn and wheat, give me serene-moving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; animals teaching content,

<BR>Give me nights perfectly quiet as on high plateaus west of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mississippi, and I looking up at the stars,

<BR>Give me odorous at sunrise a garden of beautiful flowers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; where I can walk undisturb'd,

<BR>Give me for marriage a sweet-breath'd woman of whom I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; should never tire,

<BR>Give me a perfect child, give me away aside from the noise of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the world a rural domestic life,

<BR>Give me to warble spontaneous songs recluse by myself, for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my own ears only,

<BR>Give me solitude, give me Nature, give me again O Nature

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your primal sanities!



<P>&nbsp;These demanding to have them, (tired with ceaseless excitement,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and rack'd by the war-strife,)

<BR>These to procure incessantly asking, rising in cries from my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heart,

<BR>While yet incessantly asking still I adhere to my city,

<BR>Day upon day and year upon year O city, walking your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; streets,

<BR>Where you hold me enchain'd a certain time refusing to give

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me up,

<BR>Yet giving to make me glutted, enrich'd of soul, you give me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forever faces;

<BR>(O I see what I sought to escape, confronting, reversing my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cries,

<BR>I see my own soul trampling down what it ask'd for.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

Keep your splendid silent sun,

<BR>Keep your woods O Nature, and the quiet places by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; woods,

<BR>Keep your fields of clover and timothy, and your corn-fields

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and orchards,

<BR>Keep the blossoming buckwheat fields where the Ninth-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; month bees hum;

<BR>Give me faces and streets&amp;emdash;give me these phantoms incessant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and endless along the trottoirs!

<BR>Give me interminable eyes&amp;emdash;give me women&amp;emdash;give

me comrades

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and lovers by the thousand!

<BR>Let me see new ones every day&amp;emdash;let me hold new ones by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hand every day!

<BR>Give me such shows&amp;emdash;give me the streets of Manhattan!

<BR>Give me Broadway, with the soldiers marching&amp;emdash;give me the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sound of the trumpets and drums!



<P>&nbsp;(The soldiers in companies or regiments&amp;emdash;some starting

away,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flush'd and reckless,

<BR>Some, their time up, returning with thinn'd ranks, young,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet very old, worn, marching, noticing nothing;)

<BR>Give me the shores and wharves heavy-fringed with black

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ships!

<BR>O such for me! O an intense life, full to repletion and varied!

<BR>The life of the theatre, bar-room, huge hotel, for me!

<BR>The saloon of the steamer! the crowded excursion for me!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the torchlight procession!

<BR>The dense brigade bound for the war, with high piled military

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wagons following;

<BR>People, endless, streaming, with strong voices, passions,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pageants,

<BR>Manhattan streets with their powerful throbs, with beating

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drums as now,

<BR>The endless and noisy chorus, the rustle and clank of muskets,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (even the sight of the wounded,)

<BR>Manhattan crowds, with their turbulent musical chorus!

<BR>Manhattan faces and eyes forever for me.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>DIRGE FOR TWO VETERANS</B></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>he</FONT> last sunbeam

<BR>Lightly falls from the finish'd Sabbath,

<BR>On the pavement here, and there beyond it is looking,

<BR>Down a new-made double grave.



<P>&nbsp;Lo, the moon ascending,

<BR>Up from the east the silvery round moon,

<BR>Beautiful over the house-tops, ghastly, phantom moon,

<BR>Immense and silent moon.



<P>&nbsp;I see a sad procession,

<BR>And I hear the sound of coming full-key'd bugles,

<BR>All the channels of the city streets they're flooding,

<BR>As with voices and with tears.



<P>&nbsp;I hear the great drums pounding,

<BR>And the small drums steady whirring,

<BR>And every blow of the great convulsive drums,

<BR>Strikes me through and through.



<P>&nbsp;For the son is brought with the father,

<BR>(In the foremost ranks of the fierce assault they fell,

<BR>Two veterans son and father dropt together,

<BR>And the double grave awaits them.)



<P>&nbsp;Now nearer blow the bugles,

<BR>And the drums strike more convulsive,

<BR>And the daylight o'er the pavement quite has faded,

<BR>And the strong dead-march enwraps me.



<P>&nbsp;In the eastern sky up-buoying,

<BR>The sorrowful vast phantom moves illumin'd,

<BR>('Tis some mother's large transparent face,

<BR>In heaven brighter growing.)



<P>&nbsp;O strong dead-march you please me!

<BR>O moon immense with your silvery face you soothe me!

<BR>O my soldiers twain! O my veterans passing to burial!

<BR>What I have I also give you.



<P>&nbsp;The moon gives you light,

<BR>And the bugles and the drums give you music,

<BR>And my heart, O my soldiers, my veterans,

<BR>My heart gives you love.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865-6 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>OVER THE CARNAGE ROSE PROPHETIC A VOICE</B></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>ver</FONT> the carnage rose prophetic a voice,

<BR>Be not dishearten'd, affection shall solve the problems of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; freedom yet,

<BR>Those who love each other shall become invincible,

<BR>They shall yet make Columbia victorious.



<P>&nbsp;Sons of the Mother of All, you shall yet be victorious,

<BR>You shall yet laugh to scorn the attacks of all the remainder

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the earth.

<BR>No danger shall balk Columbia's lovers,

<BR>If need be a thousand shall sternly immolate themselves for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one.



<P>&nbsp;One from Massachusetts shall be a Missourian's comrade,

<BR>From Maine and from hot Carolina, and another an Oregonese,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall be friends triune,

<BR>More precious to each other than all the riches of the earth.



<P>&nbsp;To Michigan, Florida perfumes shall tenderly come,

<BR>Not the perfumes of flowers, but sweeter, and wafted beyond

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death.



<P>&nbsp;It shall be customary in the houses and streets to see manly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; affection,

<BR>The most dauntless and rude shall touch face to face lightly,

<BR>The dependence of Liberty shall be lovers,

<BR>The continuance of Equality shall be comrades.



<P>&nbsp;These shall tie you and band you stronger than hoops of iron,

<BR>I, ecstatic, O partners! O lands, with the love of lovers tie

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you.



<P>&nbsp;(Were you looking to be held together by lawyers?

<BR>Or by an agreement on a paper? or by arms?

<BR>Nay, nor the world, nor any living thing, will so cohere.)



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1860 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>I SAW OLD GENERAL AT BAY</B></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>saw</FONT> old General at bay,

<BR>(Old as he was, his gray eyes yet shone out in battle like stars,)

<BR>His small force was now completely hemm'd in, in his works,

<BR>He call'd for volunteers to run the enemy's lines, a desperate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; emergency,

<BR>I saw a hundred and more step forth from the ranks, but two

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or three were selected,

<BR>I saw them receive their orders aside, they listen'd with care,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the adjutant was very grave,

<BR>I saw them depart with cheerfulness, freely risking their lives.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>THE ARTILLERYMAN'S VISION</B></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>hile</FONT> my wife at my side lies slumbering, and the

wars are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; over long,

<BR>And my head on the pillow rests at home, and the vacant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; midnight passes,

<BR>And through the stillness, through the dark, I hear, just hear,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the breath of my infant,

<BR>There in the room as I wake from sleep this vision presses

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon me;

<BR>The engagement opens there and then in fantasy unreal,

<BR>The skirmishers begin, they crawl cautiously ahead, I hear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the irregular snap! snap!

<BR>I hear the sounds of the different missiles, the short <I>t-h-t!</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; t-h-t!</I> of the rifle-balls,

<BR>I see the shells exploding leaving small white clouds, I hear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the great shells shrieking as they pass,

<BR>The grape like the hum and whirr of wind through the trees,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (tumultuous now the contest rages,)

<BR>All the scenes at the batteries rise in detail before me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; again,

<BR>The crashing and smoking, the pride of the men in their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pieces,

<BR>The chief-gunner ranges and sights his piece and selects a fuse

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the right time,

<BR>After firing I see him lean aside and look eagerly off to note

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the effect;

<BR>Elsewhere I hear the cry of a regiment charging, (the young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; colonel leads himself this time with brandish'd

sword,)

<BR>I see the gaps cut by the enemy's volleys, (quickly fill'd up, no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; delay,)

<BR>I breathe the suffocating smoke, then the flat clouds hover

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; low concealing all;

<BR>Now a strange lull for a few seconds, not a shot fired on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; either side,

<BR>Then resumed the chaos louder than ever, with eager calls

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and orders of officers,

<BR>While from some distant part of the field the wind wafts

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to my ears a shout of applause, (some special

success,)

<BR>And ever the sound of the cannon far or near, (rousing even

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in dreams a devilish exultation and all the

old mad joy in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the depths of my soul,)

<BR>And ever the hastening of infantry shifting positions,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; batteries, cavalry, moving hither and thither,

<BR>(The falling, dying, I heed not, the wounded dripping and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; red I heed not, some to the rear are hobbling,)

<BR>Grime, heat, rush, aides-de-camp galloping by or on a full

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; run,

<BR>With the patter of small arms, the warning <I>s-s-t</I> of the rifles,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (these in my vision I hear or see,)

<BR>And bombs bursting in air, and at night the vari-color'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rockets.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1865 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B>ETHIOPIA SALUTING THE COLORS</B></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>ho</FONT> are you dusky woman, so ancient hardly human,

<BR>With your woolly-white and turban'd head, and bare bony

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feet?

<BR>Why rising by the roadside here, do you the colors greet?



<P>&nbsp;('Tis while our army lines Carolina's sands and pines,

<BR>Forth from thy hovel door thou Ethiopia com'st to me,

<BR>As under doughty Sherman I march toward the sea.)



<P>&nbsp;<I>Me master years a hundred since from my parents sunder'd</I>,

<BR><I>A little child, they caught me as the savage beast is caught</I>,

<BR><I>Then hither me across the sea the cruel slaver brought</I>.



<P>&nbsp;No further does she say, but lingering all the day,

<BR>Her high-borne turban'd head she wags, and rolls her darkling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eye,

<BR>And courtesies to the regiments, the guidons moving by.



<P>&nbsp;What is it fateful woman, so blear, hardly human?

<BR>Why wag your head with turban bound, yellow, red and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; green?

<BR>Are the things so strange and marvelous you see or have

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seen?



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1871 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>NOT YOUTH PERTAINS TO ME</CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>to</FONT> youth pertains to me,

<BR>Nor delicatesse, I cannot beguile the time with talk,

<BR>Awkward in the parlor, neither a dancer nor elegant,

<BR>In the learn'd coterie sitting constrain'd and still, for learning

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; insures not to me,

<BR>Beauty, knowledge, inure not to me&amp;emdash;yet there are two or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; three things inure to me,

<BR>I have nourish'd the wounded and sooth'd many a dying

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soldier,

<BR>And at intervals waiting or in the midst of camp,

<BR>Composed these songs.



<P>1865 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>RACE OF VETERANS</CENTER>

R<FONT SIZE=-1>ace</FONT> of veterans&amp;emdash;race of victors!

<BR>Race of the soil, ready for conflict&amp;emdash;race of the conquering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; march!

<BR>(No more credulity's race, abiding-temper'd race,)

<BR>Race henceforth owning no law but the law of itself,

<BR>Race of passion and the storm.



<P>1865-6 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>WORLD TAKE GOOD NOTICE</CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>orld</FONT> take good notice, silver stars fading,

<BR>Milky hue ript, weft of white detaching,

<BR>Coals thirty-eight, baleful and burning,

<BR>Scarlet, significant, hands off warning,

<BR>Now and henceforth flaunt from these shores.



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>O TAN-FACED PRAIRIE-BOY</CENTER>

O <FONT SIZE=-1>tan-faced</FONT> prairie-boy,

<BR>Before you came to camp came many a welcome gift,

<BR>Praises and presents came and nourishing food, till at last

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; among the recruits,

<BR>You came, taciturn, with nothing to give&amp;emdash;we but look'd on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; each other,

<BR>When lo! more than all the gifts of the world you gave me.



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>LOOK DOWN FAIR MOON</CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>ook</FONT> down fair moon and bathe this scene,

<BR>Pour softly down night's nimbus floods on faces ghastly,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swollen, purple,

<BR>On the dead on their backs with arms toss'd wide,

<BR>Pour down your unstinted nimbus sacred moon.



<P>1865 1867

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>RECONCILIATION</CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>ord</FONT> over all, beautiful as the sky,

<BR>Beautiful that war and all its deeds of carnage must in time

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be utterly lost,

<BR>That the hands of the sisters Death and Night incessantly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; softly wash again, and ever again, this soil'd

world;

<BR>For my enemy is dead, a man divine as myself is dead,

<BR>I look where he lies white-faced and still in the coffin&amp;emdash;I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; draw near,

<BR>Bend down and touch lightly with my lips the white face in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the coffin.



<P>1865-6 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>HOW SOLEMN AS ONE BY ONE</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>(Washington City, 1865)</I></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>ow</FONT> solemn as one by one,

<BR>As the ranks returning worn and sweaty, as the men file by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; where I stand,

<BR>As the faces the masks appear, as I glance at the faces studying

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the masks,

<BR>(As I glance upward out of this page studying you, dear friend,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whoever you are,)

<BR>How solemn the thought of my whispering soul to each in the ranks,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and to you!

<BR>I see behind each mask that wonder a kindred soul,

<BR>O the bullet could never kill what you really are, dear friend,

<BR>Nor the bayonet stab what you really are;

<BR>The soul! yourself I see, great as any, good as the best,

<BR>Waiting secure and content, which the bullet could never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; kill,

<BR>Nor the bayonet stab O friend.



<P>(1865?) 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>AS I LAY WITH MY HEAD IN YOUR LAP CAMERADO</CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>s</FONT> I lay with my head in your lap camerado,

<BR>The confession I made I resume, what I said to you and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; open air I resume,

<BR>I know I am restless and make others so,

<BR>I know my words are weapons full of danger, full of death,

<BR>For I confront peace, security, and all the settled laws, to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unsettle them,

<BR>I am more resolute because all have denied me than I could

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ever have been had all accepted me,

<BR>I heed not and have never heeded either experience, cautions,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; majorities, nor ridicule,

<BR>And the threat of what is call'd hell is little or nothing to me,

<BR>And the lure of what is call'd heaven is little or nothing to me;

<BR>Dear camerado! I confess I have urged you onward with me,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and still urge you, without the least idea

what is our

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; destination,

<BR>Or whether we shall be victorious, or utterly quell'd and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; defeated.



<P>1865-6 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>DELICATE CLUSTER</CENTER>

D<FONT SIZE=-1>elicate</FONT> cluster! flag of teeming life!

<BR>Covering all my lands&amp;emdash;all my seashores lining!

<BR>Flag of death! (how I watch'd you through the smoke of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; battle pressing!

<BR>How I heard you flap and rustle, cloth defiant!)

<BR>Flag cerulean&amp;emdash;sunny flag, with the orbs of night dappled!

<BR>Ah my silvery beauty&amp;emdash;ah my woolly white and crimson!

<BR>Ah to sing the song of you, my matron mighty!

<BR>My sacred one, my mother!



<P>1871 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>TO A CERTAIN CIVILIAN</CENTER>

D<FONT SIZE=-1>id</FONT> you ask dulcet rhymes from me?

<BR>Did you seek the civilian's peaceful and languishing rhymes?

<BR>Did you find what I sang erewhile so hard to follow?

<BR>Why I was not singing erewhile for you to follow, to understand&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nor am I now;

<BR>(I have been born of the same as the war was born,

<BR>The drum-corps' rattle is ever to me sweet music, I love well

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the martial dirge,

<BR>With slow wail and convulsive throb leading the officer's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; funeral;)

<BR>What to such as you anyhow such a poet as I? therefore leave

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my works,

<BR>And go lull yourself with what you can understand, and with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; piano-tunes,

<BR>For I lull nobody, and you will never understand me.



<P>1865 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>LO, VICTRESS ON THE PEAKS</CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>o</FONT>, Victress on the peaks,

<BR>Where thou with mighty brow regarding the world,

<BR>(The world O Libertad, that vainly conspired against thee,)

<BR>Out of its countless beleaguering toils, after thwarting them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all,

<BR>Dominant, with the dazzling sun around thee,

<BR>Flauntest now unharm'd in immortal soundness and bloom&amp;emdash;lo,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in these hours supreme,

<BR>No poem proud, I chanting bring to thee, nor mastery's rapturous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; verse,

<BR>But a cluster containing night's darkness and blood-dripping

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wounds,

<BR>And psalms of the dead.



<P>1865-6 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>SPIRIT WHOSE WORK IS DONE</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>(Washington City,</I> 1865)</CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>pirit</FONT> whose work is done&amp;emdash;spirit of dreadful

hours!

<BR>Ere departing fade from my eyes your forests of bayonets;

<BR>Spirit of gloomiest fears and doubts, (yet onward ever unfaltering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pressing,)

<BR>Spirit of many a solemn day and many a savage scene&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; electric spirit,

<BR>That with muttering voice through the war now closed, like a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tireless phantom flitted,

<BR>Rousing the land with breath of flame, while you beat and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beat the drum,

<BR>Now as the sound of the drum, hollow and harsh to the last,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reverberates round me,

<BR>As your ranks, your immortal ranks, return, return from the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; battles,

<BR>As the muskets of the young men yet lean over their shoulders,

<BR>As I look on the bayonets bristling over their shoulders,

<BR>As those slanted bayonets, whole forests of them appearing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the distance, approach and pass on, returning

homeward,

<BR>Moving with steady motion, swaying to and fro to the right

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and left,

<BR>Evenly, lightly rising and falling while the steps keep time;

<BR>Spirit of hours I knew, all hectic red one day, but pale as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death next day,

<BR>Touch my mouth ere you depart, press my lips close,

<BR>Leave me your pulses of rage&amp;emdash;bequeath them to me&amp;emdash;fill

me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with currents convulsive,

<BR>Let them scorch and blister out of my chants when you are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gone,

<BR>Let them identify you to the future in these songs.



<P>1865-6 1881

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>ADIEU TO A SOLDIER</CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>dieu</FONT> O soldier,

<BR>You of the rude campaigning, (which we shared,)

<BR>The rapid march, the life of the camp,

<BR>The hot contention of opposing fronts, the long manoeuvre,

<BR>Red battles with their slaughter, the stimulus, the strong

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; terrific game,

<BR>Spell of all brave and manly hearts, the trains of time through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you and like of you all fill'd,

<BR>With war and war's expression.



<P>&nbsp;Adieu dear comrade,

<BR>Your mission is fulfill'd&amp;emdash;but I, more warlike,

<BR>Myself and this contentious soul of mine,

<BR>Still on our own campaigning bound,

<BR>Through untried roads with ambushes opponents lined,

<BR>Through many a sharp defeat and many a crisis, often

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; baffled,

<BR>Here marching, ever marching on, a war fight out&amp;emdash;aye

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; here,

<BR>To fiercer, weightier battles give expression.



<P>1871 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>TURN O LIBERTAD</CENTER>
