T<FONT SIZE=-1>urn</FONT> O Libertad, for the war is over,

<BR>From it and all henceforth expanding, doubting no more,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; resolute, sweeping the world,

<BR>Turn from lands retrospective recording proofs of the past,

<BR>From the singers that sing the trailing glories of the past,

<BR>From the chants of the feudal world, the triumphs of kings,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slavery, caste,

<BR>Turn to the world, the triumphs reserv'd and to come&amp;emdash;give

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; up that backward world,

<BR>Leave to the singers of hitherto, give them the trailing past,

<BR>But what remains remains for singers for you&amp;emdash;wars to come

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are for you,

<BR>(Lo, how the wars of the past have duly inured to you, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the wars of the present also inure;)

<BR>Then turn, and be not alarm'd O Libertad&amp;emdash;turn your undying

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; face,

<BR>To where the future, greater than all the past,

<BR>Is swiftly, surely preparing for you.



<P>1865 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>TO THE LEAVEN'D SOIL THEY TROD</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>o</FONT> the leaven'd soil they trod calling I sing for

the last,

<BR>(Forth from my tent emerging for good, loosing, untying the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tent-ropes,)

<BR>In the freshness the forenoon air, in the far-stretching circuits

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and vistas again to peace restored,

<BR>To the fiery fields emanative and the endless vistas beyond,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to the South and the North,

<BR>To the leaven'd soil of the general Western world to attest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my songs,

<BR>To the Alleghanian hills and the tireless Mississippi,

<BR>To the rocks I calling sing, and all the trees in the woods,

<BR>To the plains of the poems of heroes, to the prairies spreading

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wide,

<BR>To the far-off sea and the unseen winds, and the sane impalpable

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; air;

<BR>And responding they answer all, (but not in words,)

<BR>The average earth, the witness of war and peace, acknowledges

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mutely,

<BR>The prairie draws me close, as the father to bosom broad the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; son,

<BR>The Northern ice and rain that began me nourish me to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; end,

<BR>But the hot sun of the South is to fully ripen my songs.



<P>1865-6 1881

<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Children of Adam</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<B><I>Children of Adam</I></B></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO THE GARDEN THE WORLD</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>O</FONT> the garden the world anew ascending,

<BR>Potent mates, daughters, sons, preluding,

<BR>The love, the life of their bodies, meaning and being,

<BR>Curious here behold my resurrection after slumber,

<BR>The revolving cycles in their wide sweep having brought me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; again,

<BR>Amorous, mature, all beautiful to me, all wondrous,

<BR>My limbs and the quivering fire that ever plays through them,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for reasons, most wondrous,

<BR>Existing I peer and penetrate still,

<BR>Content with the present, content with the past,

<BR>By my side or back of me Eve following,

<BR>Or in front, and I following her just the same.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FROM PENT-UP ACHING RIVERS</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>ROM</FONT> pent-up aching rivers,

<BR>From that of myself without which I were nothing,

<BR>From what I am determin'd to make illustrious, even if I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stand sole among men,

<BR>From my own voice resonant, singing the phallus,

<BR>Singing the song of procreation,

<BR>Singing the need of superb children and therein superb grown

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; people,

<BR>Singing the muscular urge and the blending,

<BR>Singing the bedfellow's song, (O resistless yearning!

<BR>O for any and each the body correlative attracting!

<BR>O for you whoever you are your correlative body! O it,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more than all else, you delighting!)

<BR>From the hungry gnaw that eats me night and day,



<P>&nbsp;From native moments, from bashful pains, singing them,

<BR>Seeking something yet unfound though I have diligently

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sought it many a long year,

<BR>Singing the true song of the soul fitful at random,

<BR>Renascent with grossest Nature or among animals,

<BR>Of that, of them and what goes with them my poems

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; informing,

<BR>Of the smell of apples and lemons, of the pairing of birds,

<BR>Of the wet of woods, of the lapping of waves,

<BR>Of the mad pushes of waves upon the land, I them chanting,

<BR>The overture lightly sounding, the strain anticipating,

<BR>The welcome nearness, the sight of the perfect body,

<BR>The swimmer swimming naked in the bath, or motionless on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his back lying and floating,

<BR>The female form approaching, I pensive, love-flesh tremulous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; aching,

<BR>The divine list for myself or you or for any one making,

<BR>The face, the limbs, the index from head to foot, and what it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arouses,

<BR>The mystic deliria, the madness amorous, the utter abandonment,

<BR>(Hark close and still what I now whisper to you,

<BR>I love you, O you entirely possess me,

<BR>O that you and I escape from the rest and go utterly off, free

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and lawless,

<BR>Two hawks in the air, two fishes swimming in the sea not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more lawless than we;)

<BR>The furious storm through me careering, I passionately

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trembling,

<BR>The oath of the inseparableness of two together, of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; woman that loves me and whom I love more than

my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life, that oath swearing,

<BR>(O I willingly stake all for you,

<BR>O let me be lost if it must be so!

<BR>O you and I! what is it to us what the rest do or think?

<BR>What is all else to us? only that we enjoy each other and exhaust

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; each other if it must be so;)

<BR>From the master, the pilot I yield the vessel to,

<BR>The general commanding me, commanding all, from him

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; permission taking,



<P>&nbsp;From time the programme hastening, (I have loiter'd too

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long as it is,)

<BR>From sex, from the warp and from the woof,

<BR>From privacy, from frequent repinings alone,

<BR>From plenty of persons near and yet the right person not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; near,

<BR>From the soft sliding of hands over me and thrusting of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fingers through my hair and beard,

<BR>From the long sustain'd kiss upon the mouth or bosom,

<BR>From the close pressure that makes me or any man drunk,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fainting with excess,

<BR>From what the divine husband knows, from the work of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fatherhood,

<BR>From exultation, victory and relief from the bedfellow's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; embrace in the night,

<BR>From the act-poems of eyes, hands, hips and bosoms,

<BR>From the cling of the trembling arm,

<BR>From the bending curve and the clinch,

<BR>From side by side the pliant coverlet off-throwing,

<BR>From the one so unwilling to have me leave, and me just as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unwilling to leave,

<BR>(Yet a moment O tender waiter, and I return,)

<BR>From the hour of shining stars and dropping dews,

<BR>From the night a moment I emerging flitting out,

<BR>Celebrate you act divine and you children prepared for,

<BR>And you stalwart loins.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

I SING THE BODY ELECTRIC</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>SING</FONT> the body electric,

<BR>The armies of those I love engirth me and I engirth them,

<BR>They will not let me off till I go with them, respond to them,

<BR>And discorrupt them, and charge them full with the charge of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the soul.



<P>&nbsp;Was it doubted that those who corrupt their own bodies

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; conceal themselves?



<P>&nbsp;And if those who defile the living are as bad as they who defile

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the dead?

<BR>And if the body does not do fully as much as the soul?

<BR>And if the body were not the soul, what is the soul?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>The love of the body of man or woman balks account, the body

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself balks account,

<BR>That of the male is perfect, and that of the female is perfect.



<P>&nbsp;The expression of the face balks account,

<BR>But the expression of a well-made man appears not only in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his face,

<BR>It is in his limbs and joints also, it is curiously in the joints of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his hips and wrists,

<BR>It is in his walk, the carriage of his neck, the flex of his waist

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and knees, dress does not hide him,

<BR>The strong sweet quality he has strikes through the cotton

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and broad-cloth,

<BR>To see him pass conveys as much as the best poem, perhaps

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more,

<BR>You linger to see his back, and the back of his neck and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shoulder-side.



<P>&nbsp;The sprawl and fulness of babes, the bosoms and heads of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; women, the folds of their dress, their style

as we pass in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the street, the contour of their shape downwards,

<BR>The swimmer naked in the swimming-bath, seen as he swims

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through the transparent green-shine, or lies

with his face

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; up and rolls silently to and fro in the heave

of the water,

<BR>The bending forward and backward of rowers in row-boats,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the horseman in his saddle,

<BR>Girls, mothers, house-keepers, in all their performances,

<BR>The group of laborers seated at noon-time with their open

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dinner kettles, and their wives waiting,

<BR>The female soothing a child, the farmer's daughter in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; garden or cow-yard,

<BR>The young fellow hoeing corn, the sleigh-driver driving his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; six horses through the crowd,



<P>&nbsp;The wrestle of wrestlers, two apprentice-boys, quite grown,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lusty, good-natured, native-born, out on the

vacant lot

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at sundown after work,

<BR>The coats and caps thrown down, the embrace of love and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; resistance,

<BR>The upper-hold and under-hold, the hair rumpled over and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blinding the eyes;

<BR>The march of firemen in their own costumes, the play of masculine

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; muscle through clean-setting trowsers and

waist-straps,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>The slow return from the fire, the pause when the bell strikes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; suddenly again, and the listening on the alert,

<BR>The natural, perfect, varied attitudes, the bent head, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; curv'd neck and the counting;

<BR>Such-like I love &amp;emdash; I loosen myself, pass freely, am at the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mother's breast with the little child,

<BR>Swim with the swimmers, wrestle with wrestlers, march in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; line with the firemen, and pause, listen,

count.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>I knew a man, a common farmer, the father of five sons,

<BR>And in them the fathers of sons, and in them the fathers of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sons.



<P>&nbsp;This man was of wonderful vigor, calmness, beauty of person,

<BR>The shape of his head, the pale yellow and white of his hair

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and beard, the immeasurable meaning of his

black eyes,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the richness and breadth of his manners,

<BR>These I used to go and visit him to see, he was wise also,

<BR>He was six feet tall, he was over eighty years old, his sons

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; were massive, clean, bearded, tan-faced, handsome,

<BR>They and his daughters loved him, all who saw him loved him,

<BR>They did not love him by allowance, they loved him with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; personal love,

<BR>He drank water only, the blood show'd like scarlet through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the clear-brown skin of his face,

<BR>He was a frequent gunner and fisher, he sail'd his boat himself,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a fine one presented to him by a ship-joiner,

he had

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fowling-pieces presented to him by men that

loved him,



<P>&nbsp;When he went with his five sons and many grand-sons to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hunt or fish, you would pick him out as the

most beautiful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and vigorous of the gang,

<BR>You would wish long and long to be with him, you would wish to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sit by him in the boat that you and he might

touch each other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>I have perceiv'd that to be with those I like is enough,

<BR>To stop in company with the rest at evening is enough,

<BR>To be surrounded by beautiful, curious, breathing, laughing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flesh is enough,

<BR>To pass among them or touch any one, or rest my arm ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; so lightly round his or her neck for a moment,

what is this then?

<BR>I do not ask any more delight, I swim in it as in a sea.



<P>&nbsp;There is something in staying close to men and women and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; looking on them, and in the contact and odor

of them,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that pleases the soul well,

<BR>All things please the soul, but these please the soul well.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>This is the female form,

<BR>A divine nimbus exhales from it from head to foot,

<BR>It attracts with fierce undeniable attraction,

<BR>I am drawn by its breath as if I were no more than a helpless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; vapor, all falls aside but myself and it,

<BR>Books, art, religion, time, the visible and solid earth, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what was expected of heaven or fear'd of hell,

are now

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consumed,

<BR>Mad filaments, ungovernable shoots play out of it, the response

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; likewise ungovernable,

<BR>Hair, bosom, hips, bend of legs, negligent falling hands all diffused,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mine too diffused,

<BR>Ebb stung by the flow and flow stung by the ebb, love-flesh

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swelling and deliciously aching,

<BR>Limitless limpid jets of love hot and enormous, quivering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; jelly of love, white-blow and delirious juice,



<P>&nbsp;Bridegroom night of love working surely and softly into the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prostrate dawn,

<BR>Undulating into the willing and yielding day,

<BR>Lost in the cleave of the clasping and sweet-flesh'd day.



<P>&nbsp;This the nucleus&amp;emdash;after the child is born of woman,

man is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; born of woman,

<BR>This the bath of birth, this the merge of small and large, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the outlet again.



<P>&nbsp;Be not ashamed women, your privilege encloses the rest, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is the exit of the rest,

<BR>You are the gates of the body, and you are the gates of the soul.



<P>&nbsp;The female contains all qualities and tempers them,

<BR>She is in her place and moves with perfect balance,

<BR>She is all things duly veil'd, she is both passive and active,

<BR>She is to conceive daughters as well as sons, and sons as well

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as daughters.



<P>&nbsp;As I see my soul reflected in Nature,

<BR>As I see through a mist, One with inexpressible completeness,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sanity, beauty,

<BR>See the bent head and arms folded over the breast, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Female I see.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>The male is not less the soul nor more, he too is in his place,

<BR>He too is all qualities, he is action and power,

<BR>The flush of the known universe is in him,

<BR>Scorn becomes him well, and appetite and defiance become

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him well,

<BR>The wildest largest passions, bliss that is utmost, sorrow that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is utmost become him well, pride is for him,

<BR>The full-spread pride of man is calming and excellent to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soul,

<BR>Knowledge becomes him, he likes it always, he brings every

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thing to the test of himself,

<BR>Whatever the survey, whatever the sea and the sail he strikes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soundings at last only here,

<BR>(Where else does he strike soundings except here?)



<P>&nbsp;The man's body is sacred and the woman's body is sacred,

<BR>No matter who it is, it is sacred&amp;emdash;is it the meanest one

in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; laborer's gang?

<BR>Is it one of the dull-faced immigrants just landed on the wharf?

<BR>Each belongs here or anywhere just as much as the well-off,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; just as much as you,

<BR>Each has his or her place in the procession.



<P>&nbsp;(All is a procession,

<BR>The universe is a procession with measured and perfect motion.)



<P>&nbsp;Do you know so much yourself that you call the meanest ignorant?

<BR>Do you suppose you have a right to a good sight, and he or she has

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; no right to a sight?

<BR>Do you think matter has cohered together from its diffuse float, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the soil is on the surface, and water runs

and vegetation sprouts,

<BR>For you only, and not for him and her?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>A man's body at auction,

<BR>(For before the war I often go to the slave-mart and watch

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sale,)

<BR>I help the auctioneer, the sloven does not half know his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; business.



<P>&nbsp;Gentlemen look on this wonder,

<BR>Whatever the bids of the bidders they cannot be high enough

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for it,

<BR>For it the globe lay preparing quintillions of years without

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one animal or plant,

<BR>For it the revolving cycles truly and steadily roll'd.



<P>&nbsp;In this head the all-baffling brain,

<BR>In it and below it the makings of heroes.



<P>&nbsp;Examine these limbs, red, black, or white, they are cunning in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tendon and nerve,

<BR>They shall be stript that you may see them.



<P>&nbsp;Exquisite senses, life-lit eyes, pluck, volition,

<BR>Flakes of breast-muscle, pliant backbone and neck, flesh not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flabby, good-sized arms and legs,

<BR>And wonders within there yet.



<P>&nbsp;Within there runs blood,

<BR>The same old blood! the same red-running blood!

<BR>There swells and jets a heart, there all passions, desires,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reachings, aspirations,

<BR>(Do you think they are not there because they are not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; express'd in parlors and lecture-rooms?)



<P>&nbsp;This is not only one man, this the father of those who shall

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be fathers in their turns,

<BR>In him the start of populous states and rich republics,

<BR>Of him countless immortal lives with countless embodiments

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and enjoyments.



<P>&nbsp;How do you know who shall come from the offspring of his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; offspring through the centuries?

<BR>(Who might you find you have come from yourself, if you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; could trace back through the centuries?)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>A woman's body at auction,

<BR>She too is not only herself, she is the teeming mother of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mothers,

<BR>She is the bearer of them that shall grow and be mates to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mothers.



<P>&nbsp;Have you ever loved the body of a woman?

<BR>Have you ever loved the body of a man?

<BR>Do you not see that these are exactly the same to all in all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nations and times all over the earth?



<P>&nbsp;If any thing is sacred the human body is sacred,

<BR>And the glory and sweat of a man is the token of manhood

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untainted,

<BR>And in man or woman a clean, strong, firm-fibred body, is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more beautiful than the most beautiful face.



<P>&nbsp;Have you seen the fool that corrupted his own live body? or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the fool that corrupted her own live body?

<BR>For they do not conceal themselves, and cannot conceal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; themselves.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>9</CENTER>





<P>O my body! I dare not desert the likes of you in other men

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and women, nor the likes of the parts of you,

<BR>I believe the likes of you are to stand or fall with the likes of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the soul, (and that they are the soul,)

<BR>I believe the likes of you shall stand or fall with my poems,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and that they are my poems,

<BR>Man's, woman's, child's, youth's, wife's, husband's, mother's,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; father's, young man's, young woman's poems,

<BR>Head, neck, hair, ears, drop and tympan of the ears,

<BR>Eyes, eye-fringes, iris of the eye, eyebrows, and the waking or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sleeping of the lids,

<BR>Mouth, tongue, lips, teeth, roof of the mouth, jaws, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; jaw-hinges,

<BR>Nose, nostrils of the nose, and the partition,

<BR>Cheeks, temples, forehead, chin, throat, back of the neck,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; neck-slue,

<BR>Strong shoulders, manly beard, scapula, hind-shoulders, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the ample side-round of the chest,

<BR>Upper-arm, armpit, elbow-socket, lower-arm, arm-sinews,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arm-bones,

<BR>Wrist and wrist-joints, hand, palm, knuckles, thumb,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forefinger, finger-joints, finger-nails,

<BR>Broad breast-front, curling hair of the breast, breast-bone,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breast-side,

<BR>Ribs, belly, backbone, joints of the backbone,

<BR>Hips, hip-sockets, hip-strength, inward and outward round,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; man-balls, man-root,

<BR>Strong set of thighs, well carrying the trunk above,

<BR>Leg-fibres, knee, knee-pan, upper-leg, under-leg,

<BR>Ankles, instep, foot-ball, toes, toe-joints, the heel;

<BR>All attitudes, all the shapeliness, all the belongings of my or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your body or of any one's body, male or female,

<BR>The lung-sponges, the stomach-sac, the bowels sweet and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clean,



<P>&nbsp;The brain in its folds inside the skull-frame,

<BR>Sympathies, heart-valves, palate-valves, sexuality, maternity,

<BR>Womanhood and all that is a woman, and the man that comes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from woman,

<BR>The womb, the teats, nipples, breast-milk, tears, laughter,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; weeping, love-looks, love-perturbations and

risings,

<BR>The voice, articulation, language, whispering, shouting aloud,

<BR>Food, drink, pulse, digestion, sweat, sleep, walking, swimming,

<BR>Poise on the hips, leaping, reclining, embracing, arm-curving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and tightening,

<BR>The continual changes of the flex of the mouth, and around

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the eyes,

<BR>The skin, the sunburnt shade, freckles, hair,

<BR>The curious sympathy one feels when feeling with the hand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the naked meat of the body,

<BR>The circling rivers the breath, and breathing it in and out,

<BR>The beauty of the waist, and thence of the hips, and thence

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; downward toward the knees,

<BR>The thin red jellies within you or within me, the bones and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the marrow in the bones,

<BR>The exquisite realization of health;

<BR>O I say these are not the parts and poems of the body only,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but of the soul,

<BR>O I say now these are the soul!

<PRE>1855&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A WOMAN WAITS FOR ME</H2></CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>WOMEN</FONT> waits for me, she contains all, nothing is

lacking,

<BR>Yet all were lacking if sex were lacking, or if the moisture of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the right man were lacking.

<BR>Sex contains all, bodies, souls,

<BR>Meanings, proofs, purities, delicacies, results, promulgations,

<BR>Songs, commands, health, pride, the maternal mystery, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seminal milk,

<BR>All hopes, benefactions, bestowals, all the passions, loves,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beauties, delights of the earth,

<BR>All the governments, judges, gods, follow'd persons of the earth,



<P>&nbsp;These are contain'd in sex as parts of itself and justifications

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of itself.



<P>&nbsp;Without shame the man I like knows and avows the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; deliciousness of his sex,

<BR>Without shame the woman I like knows and avows hers.



<P>&nbsp;Now I will dismiss myself from impassive women,

<BR>I will go stay with her who waits for me, and with those

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; women that are warm-blooded and sufficient

for me,

<BR>I see that they understand me and do not deny me,

<BR>I see that they are worthy of me, I will be the robust husband

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of those women.



<P>&nbsp;They are not one jot less than I am,

<BR>They are tann'd in the face by shining suns and blowing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; winds,

<BR>Their flesh has the old divine suppleness and strength,

<BR>They know how to swim, row, ride, wrestle, shoot, run,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strike, retreat, advance, resist, defend themselves,

<BR>They are ultimate in their own right&amp;emdash;they are calm, clear,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; well-possess'd of themselves.



<P>&nbsp;I draw you close to me, you women,

<BR>I cannot let you go, I would do you good,

<BR>I am for you, and you are for me, not only for our own sake,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but for others' sakes,

<BR>Envelop'd in you sleep greater heroes and bards,

<BR>They refuse to awake at the touch of any man but me.



<P>&nbsp;It is I, you women, I make my way,

<BR>I am stern, acrid, large, undissuadable, but I love you,

<BR>I do not hurt you any more than is necessary for you,

<BR>I pour the stuff to start sons and daughters fit for these States,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I press with slow rude muscle,

<BR>I brace myself effectually, I listen to no entreaties,

<BR>I dare not withdraw till I deposit what has so long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accumulated within me.



<P>&nbsp;Through you I drain the pent-up rivers of myself,

<BR>In you I wrap a thousand onward years,



<P>&nbsp;On you I graft the grafts of the best-beloved of me and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; America,

<BR>The drops I distil upon you shall grow fierce and athletic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; girls, new artists, musicians, and singers,

<BR>The babes I beget upon you are to beget babes in their turn,

<BR>I shall demand perfect men and women out of my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; love-spendings,

<BR>I shall expect them to interpenetrate with others, as I and you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; interpenetrate now,

<BR>I shall count on the fruits of the gushing showers of them, as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I count on the fruits of the gushing showers

I give now,

<BR>I shall look for loving crops from the birth, life, death,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; immortality, I plant so lovingly now.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SPONTANEOUS ME</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>PONTANEOUS</FONT> me, Nature,

<BR>The loving day, the mounting sun, the friend I am happy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with,

<BR>The arm of my friend hanging idly over my shoulder,

<BR>The hillside whiten'd with blossoms of the mountain ash,

<BR>The same late in autumn, the hues of red, yellow, drab,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; purple, and light and dark green,

<BR>The rich coverlet of the grass, animals and birds, the private

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untrimm'd bank, the primitive apples, the

pebble-stones,

<BR>Beautiful dripping fragments, the negligent list of one after

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; another as I happen to call them to me or

think of them,

<BR>The real poems, (what we call poems being merely pictures,)

<BR>The poems of the privacy of the night, and of men like me,

<BR>This poem drooping shy and unseen that I always carry, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that all men carry,

<BR>(Know once for all, avow'd on purpose, wherever are men like

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me, are our lusty lurking masculine poems,)

<BR>Love-thoughts, love-juice, love-odor, love-yielding, love-climbers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the climbing sap,

<BR>Arms and hands of love, lips of love, phallic thumb of love,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breasts of love, bellies press'd and glued

together with love,

<BR>Earth of chaste love, life that is only life after love,



<P>&nbsp;The body of my love, the body of the woman I love, the body

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the man, the body of the earth,

<BR>Soft forenoon airs that blow from the south-west,

<BR>The hairy wild-bee that murmurs and hankers up and down,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that gripes the full-grown lady-flower, curves

upon her

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with amorous firm legs, takes his will of

her, and holds

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; himself tremulous and tight till he is satisfied;

<BR>The wet of woods through the early hours,

<BR>Two sleepers at night lying close together as they sleep, one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with an arm slanting down across and below

the waist of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the other,

<BR>The smell of apples, aromas from crush'd sage-plant, mint,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; birch-bark,

<BR>The boy's longings, the glow and pressure as he confides to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me what he was dreaming,

<BR>The dead leaf whirling its spiral whirl and falling still and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; content to the ground,

<BR>The no-form'd stings that sights, people, objects, sting me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with,

<BR>The hubb'd sting of myself, stinging me as much as it ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; can any one,

<BR>The sensitive, orbic, underlapp'd brothers, that only

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; privileged feelers may be intimate where they

are,

<BR>The curious roamer the hand roaming all over the body, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bashful withdrawing of flesh where the fingers

soothingly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pause and edge themselves,

<BR>The limpid liquid within the young man,

<BR>The vex'd corrosion so pensive and so painful,

<BR>The torment, the irritable tide that will not be at rest,

<BR>The like of the same I feel, the like of the same in others,

<BR>The young man that flushes and flushes, and the young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; woman that flushes and flushes,

<BR>The young man that wakes deep at night, the hot hand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seeking to repress what would master him,

<BR>The mystic amorous night, the strange half-welcome pangs,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; visions, sweats,

<BR>The pulse pounding through palms and trembling encircling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fingers, the young man all color'd, red, ashamed,

angry;

<BR>The souse upon me of my lover the sea, as I lie willing and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; naked,



<P>&nbsp;The merriment of the twin babies that crawl over the grass in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sun, the mother never turning her vigilant

eyes from them,

<BR>The walnut-trunk, the walnut-husks, and the ripening or ripen'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long-round walnuts,

<BR>The continence of vegetables, birds, animals,

<BR>The consequent meanness of me should I skulk or find myself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indecent, while birds and animals never once

skulk or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; find themselves indecent,

<BR>The great chastity of paternity, to match the great chastity of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; maternity,

<BR>The oath of procreation I have sworn, my Adamic and fresh

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; daughters,

<BR>The greed that eats me day and night with hungry gnaw, till

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I saturate what shall produce boys to fill

my place when

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I am through,

<BR>The wholesome relief, repose, content,

<BR>And this bunch pluck'd at random from myself,

<BR>It has done its work&amp;emdash;I toss it carelessly to fall where

it may.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ONE HOUR TO MADNESS AND JOY</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>NE</FONT> hour to madness and joy! O furious! O confine

me not!

<BR>(What is this that frees me so in storms?

<BR>What do my shouts amid lightnings and raging winds mean?)



<P>&nbsp;O to drink the mystic deliria deeper than any other man!

<BR>O savage and tender achings! (I bequeath them to you, my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; children,

<BR>I tell them to you, for reasons, O bridegroom and bride.)



<P>&nbsp;O to be yielded to you whoever you are, and you to be yielded

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me in defiance of the world!

<BR>O to return to Paradise! O bashful and feminine!

<BR>O to draw you to me, to plant on you for the first time the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lips of a determin'd man.



<P>&nbsp;O the puzzle, the thrice-tied knot, the deep and dark pool, all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untied and illumin'd!



<P>&nbsp;O to speed where there is space enough and air enough at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; last!

<BR>To be absolv'd from previous ties and conventions, I from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mine and you from yours!

<BR>To find a new unthought-of nonchalance with the best of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Nature!

<BR>To have the gag remov'd from one's mouth!

<BR>To have the feeling to-day or any day I am sufficient as I am.



<P>&nbsp;O something unprov'd! something in a trance!

<BR>To escape utterly from others' anchors and holds!

<BR>To drive free! to love free! to dash reckless and dangerous!

<BR>To court destruction with taunts, with invitations!

<BR>To ascend, to leap to the heavens of the love indicated to me!

<BR>To rise thither with my inebriate soul!

<BR>To be lost if it must be so!

<BR>To feed the remainder of life with one hour of fulness and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; freedom!

<BR>With one brief hour of madness and joy.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OUT OF THE ROLLING OCEAN THE CROWD</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>UT</FONT> of the rolling ocean the crowd came a drop gently

to me,

<BR>Whispering <I>I love you, before long I die,</I>

<BR><I>I have travel'd a long way merely to look on you to touch you,</I>

<BR><I>For I could not die till I once look'd on you,</I>

<BR><I>For I fear'd I might afterward lose you.</I>



<P>&nbsp;Now we have met, we have look'd, we are safe,

<BR>Return in peace to the ocean my love,

<BR>I too am part of that ocean my love, we are not so much

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; separated,

<BR>Behold the great rondure, the cohesion of all, how perfect!

<BR>But as for me, for you, the irresistible sea is to separate us,

<BR>As for an hour carrying us diverse, yet cannot carry us

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; diverse forever;

<BR>Be not impatient&amp;emdash;a little space&amp;emdash;know you I salute

the air,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the ocean and the land,

<BR>Every day at sundown for your dear sake my love.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AGES AND AGES RETURNING AT INTERVALS</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>GES</FONT> and ages returning at intervals,

<BR>Undestroy'd, wandering immortal,

<BR>Lusty, phallic, with the potent original loins, perfectly sweet,

<BR>I, chanter of Adamic songs,

<BR>Through the new garden the West, the great cities calling,

<BR>Deliriate, thus prelude what is generated, offering these,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; offering myself,

<BR>Bathing myself, bathing my songs in Sex,

<BR>Offspring of my loins.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WE TWO, HOW LONG WE WERE FOOL'D</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>E</FONT> two, how long we were fool'd,

<BR>Now transmuted, we swiftly escape as Nature escapes,

<BR>We are Nature, long have we been absent, but now we return,

<BR>We become plants, trunks, foliage, roots, bark,

<BR>We are bedded in the ground, we are rocks,

<BR>We are oaks, we grow in the openings side by side,

<BR>We browse, we are two among the wild herds spontaneous as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; any,

<BR>We are two fishes swimming in the sea together,

<BR>We are what locust blossoms are, we drop scent around lanes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mornings and evenings,

<BR>We are also the coarse smut of beasts, vegetables, minerals,

<BR>We are two predatory hawks, we soar above and look down,

<BR>We are two resplendent suns, we it is who balance ourselves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; orbic and stellar, we are as two comets,

<BR>We prowl fang'd and four-footed in the woods, we spring on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prey,

<BR>We are two clouds forenoons and afternoons driving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; over-head,

<BR>We are seas mingling, we are two of those cheerful waves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rolling over each other and interwetting each

other,

<BR>We are what the atmosphere is, transparent, receptive,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pervious, impervious,

<BR>We are snow, rain, cold, darkness, we are each product and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; influence of the globe,



<P>&nbsp;We have circled and circled till we have arrived home again,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; we two,

<BR>We have voided all but freedom and all but our own joy.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

O HYMEN! O HYMENEE!</H2></CENTER>

O H<FONT SIZE=-1>YMEN</FONT>! O hymenee! why do you tantalize me thus?

<BR>O why sting me for a swift moment only?

<BR>Why can you not continue? O why do you now cease?

<BR>Is it because if you continued beyond the swift moment you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; would soon certainly kill me?

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

I AM HE THAT ACHES WITH LOVE</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>AM</FONT> he that aches with amorous love;

<BR>Does the earth gravitate? does not all matter, aching, attract

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all matter?

<BR>So the body of me to all I meet or know.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

NATIVE MOMENTS</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>ATIVE</FONT> moments&amp;emdash;when you come upon me&amp;emdash;ah

you are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; here now,

<BR>Give me now libidinous joys only,

<BR>Give me the drench of my passions, give me life coarse and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rank,

<BR>To-day I go consort with Nature's darlings, to-night too,

<BR>I am for those who believe in loose delights, I share the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; midnight orgies of young men,

<BR>I dance with the dancers and drink with the drinkers,

<BR>The echoes ring with out indecent calls, I pick out some low

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; person for my dearest friend,

<BR>He shall be lawless, rude, illiterate, he shall be one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; condemned by others for deeds done,

<BR>I will play a part no longer, why should I exile myself from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my companions?

<BR>O you shunn'd persons, I at least do not shun you,

<BR>I come forthwith in your midst, I will be your poet,

<BR>I will be more to you than to any of the rest.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ONCE I PASS'D THROUGH A POPULOUS CITY</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>NCE</FONT> I pass'd through a populous city imprinting my

brain

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for future use with its shows, architecture,

customs, traditions,

<BR>Yet now of all that city I remember only a woman I casually

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; met there who detain'd me for love of me,

<BR>Day by day and night by night we were together&amp;emdash;all else

has

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long been forgotten by me,

<BR>I remember I say only that woman who passionately clung to me,

<BR>Again we wander, we love, we separate again,

<BR>Again she holds me by the hand, I must not go,

<BR>I see her close beside me with silent lips sad and tremulous.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

I HEARD YOU SOLEMN-SWEET PIPES OF THE ORGAN</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>HEARD</FONT> you solemn-sweet pipes of the organ as last

Sunday

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; morn I pass'd the church,

<BR>Winds of autumn, as I walk'd the woods at dusk I heard your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long-stretch'd sighs up above so mournful,

<BR>I heard the perfect Italian tenor singing at the opera, I heard

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the soprano in the midst of the quartet singing;

<BR>Heart of my love! you too I heard murmuring low through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one of the wrists around my head,

<BR>Heard the pulse of you when all was still ringing little bells

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; last night under my ear.

<PRE>1861&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FACING WEST FROM CALIFORNIA'S SHORES</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>ACING</FONT> west from California's shores,

<BR>Inquiring, tireless, seeking what is yet unfound,

<BR>I, a child, very old, over waves, towards the house of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; maternity, the land of migrations, look afar,

<BR>Look off the shores of my Western sea, the circle almost

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; circled;

<BR>For starting westward from Hindustan, from the vales of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Kashmere,



<P>&nbsp;From Asia, from the north, from the God, the sage, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hero,

<BR>From the south, from the flowery peninsulas and the spice

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; islands,

<BR>Long having wander'd since, round the earth having wander'd,

<BR>Now I face home again, very pleas'd and joyous,

<BR>(But where is what I started for so long ago?

<BR>And why is it yet unfound?)

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AS ADAM EARLY IN THE MORNING</H2></CENTER>

As Adam early in the morning,

<BR>Walking forth from the bower refresh'd with sleep,

<BR>Behold me where I pass, hear my voice, approach,

<BR>Touch me, touch the palm of your hand to my body as I pass,

<BR>Be not afraid of my body.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Proud Music of the Storm</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Proud Music of the Storm</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

P<FONT SIZE=-1>roud</FONT> music of the storm,

<BR>Blast that careers so free, whistling across the prairies,

<BR>Strong hum of forest tree-tops&amp;emdash;wind of the mountains,

<BR>Personified dim shapes&amp;emdash;you hidden orchestras,

<BR>You serenades of phantoms with instruments alert,

<BR>Bending with Nature's rhythmus all the tongues of nations;

<BR>You chords left as by vast composers&amp;emdash;you choruses,

<BR>You formless, free, religious dances&amp;emdash;you from the Orient,

<BR>You undertone of rivers, roar of pouring cataracts,

<BR>You sounds from distant guns with galloping cavalry,

<BR>Echoes of camps with all the different bugle-calls,

<BR>Trooping tumultuous, filling the midnight late, bending me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; powerless,

<BR>Entering my lonesome slumber-chamber, why have you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seiz'd me?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

Come forward O my soul, and let the rest retire,

<BR>Listen, lose not, it is toward thee they tend,

<BR>Parting the midnight, entering my slumber-chamber,

<BR>For thee they sing and dance O soul.



<P>&nbsp;A festival song,

<BR>The duet of the bridegroom and the bride, a marriage-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; march,

<BR>With lips of love, and hearts of lovers fill'd to the brim with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; love,

<BR>The red-flush'd cheeks and perfumes, the cortege swarming

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; full of friendly faces young and old,

<BR>To flutes' clear notes and sounding harps' cantabile.



<P>&nbsp;Now loud approaching drums,

<BR>Victoria! see'st thou in powder-smoke the banners torn but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flying? the rout of the baffled?

<BR>Hearest those shouts of a conquering army?

<BR>(Ah soul, the sobs of women, the wounded groaning in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; agony,

<BR>The hiss and crackle of flames, the blacken'd ruins, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; embers of cities,

<BR>The dirge and desolation of mankind.)



<P>&nbsp;Now airs antique and mediaeval fill me,

<BR>I see and hear old harpers with their harps at Welsh festivals,

<BR>I hear the minnesingers singing their lays of love,

<BR>I hear the minstrels, gleemen, troubadours, of the middle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ages.



<P>&nbsp;Now the great organ sounds,

<BR>Tremulous, while underneath, (as the hid footholds of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth,

<BR>On which arising rest, and leaping forth depend,

<BR>All shapes of beauty, grace and strength, all hues we know,

<BR>Green blades of grass and warbling birds, children that gambol

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and play, the clouds of heaven above,)

<BR>The strong base stands, and its pulsations intermits not,

<BR>Bathing, supporting, merging all the rest, maternity of all the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rest,

<BR>And with it every instrument in multitudes,

<BR>The players playing, all the world's musicians,

<BR>The solemn hymns and masses rousing adoration,

<BR>All passionate heart-chants, sorrowful appeals,

<BR>The measureless sweet vocalists of ages,

<BR>And for their solvent setting earth's own diapason,

<BR>Of winds and woods and mighty ocean waves,

<BR>A new composite orchestra, binder of years and climes,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tenfold renewer,

<BR>As of the far-back days the poets tell, the Paradiso,

<BR>The straying thence, the separation long, but now the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wandering done,

<BR>The journey done, the journeyman come home,

<BR>And man and art with Nature fused again.



<P>&nbsp;Tutti! for earth and heaven;

<BR>(The Almighty leader now for once has signal'd with his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wand.)



<P>&nbsp;The manly strophe of the husbands of the world,

<BR>And all the wives responding.



<P>&nbsp;The tongues of violins,

<BR>(I think O tongues ye tell this heart, that cannot tell itself,

<BR>This brooding yearning heart, that cannot tell itself.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

Ah from a little child,

<BR>Thou knowest soul how to me all sounds became music,

<BR>My mother's voice in lullaby or hymn,

<BR>(The voice, O tender voices, memory's loving voices,

<BR>Last miracle of all, O dearest mother's, sister's, voices;)

<BR>The rain, the growing corn, the breeze among the long-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leav'd corn,

<BR>The measur'd sea-surf beating on the sand,

<BR>The twittering bird, the hawk's sharp scream,

<BR>The wild-fowl's notes at night as flying low migrating north

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or south,

<BR>The psalm in the country church or mid the clustering trees,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the open air camp-meeting,

<BR>The fiddler in the tavern, the glee, the long-strung sailor-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; song,

<BR>The lowing cattle, bleating sheep, the crowing cock at dawn.



<P>&nbsp;All songs of current lands come sounding round me,

<BR>The German airs of friendship, wine and love,

<BR>Irish ballads, merry jigs and dances, English warbles,

<BR>Chansons of France, Scotch tunes, and o'er the rest,

<BR>Italia's peerless compositions.



<P>&nbsp;Across the stage with pallor on her face, yet lurid passion,

<BR>Stalks Norma brandishing the dagger in her hand.



<P>&nbsp;I see poor crazed Lucia's eyes' unnatural gleam,

<BR>Her hair down her back falls loose and dishevel'd.



<P>&nbsp;I see where Ernani walking the bridal garden,

<BR>Amid the scent of night-roses, radiant, holding his bride by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the hand,

<BR>Hears the infernal call, the death-pledge of the horn.



<P>&nbsp;To crossing swords and gray hairs bared to heaven,

<BR>The clear electric base and baritone of the world,

<BR>The trombone duo, Libertad forever!



<P>&nbsp;From Spanish chestnut trees' dense shade,

<BR>By old and heavy convent walls a wailing song,

<BR>Song of lost love, the torch of youth and life quench'd in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; despair,

<BR>Song of the dying swan, Fernando's heart is breaking.



<P>&nbsp;Awaking from her woes at last retriev'd Amina sings,

<BR>Copious as stars and glad as morning light the torrents of her

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joy.



<P>&nbsp;(The teeming lady comes,

<BR>The lustrous orb, Venus contralto, the blooming mother,

<BR>Sister of loftiest gods, Alboni's self I hear.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

I hear those odes, symphonies, operas,

<BR>I hear in the <I>William Tell</I> the music of an arous'd and angry

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; people,

<BR>I hear Meyerbeer's <I>Huguenots</I>, the <I>Prophet</I>, or <I>Robert</I>,

<BR>Gounod's <I>Faust</I>, or Mozart's <I>Don Juan</I>.



<P>&nbsp;I hear the dance-music of all nations,

<BR>The waltz, some delicious measure, lapsing, bathing me in bliss,

<BR>The bolero to tinkling guitars and clattering castanets.



<P>&nbsp;I see religious dances old and new,

<BR>I hear the sound of the Hebrew lyre,

<BR>I see the crusaders marching bearing the cross on high, to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; martial clang of cymbals,

<BR>I hear dervishes monotonously chanting, interspers'd with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; frantic shouts, as they spin around turning always

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; towards Mecca,



<P>&nbsp;I see the rapt religious dances of the Persians and the Arabs,

<BR>Again, at Eleusis, home of Ceres, I see the modern Greeks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dancing,

<BR>I hear them clapping their hands as they bend their bodies,

<BR>I hear the metrical shuffling of their feet.

<BR>I see again the wild old Corybantian dance, the performers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wounding each other,

<BR>I see the Roman youth to the shrill sound of flageolets throwing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and catching their weapons,

<BR>As they fall on their knees and rise again.

<BR>I hear from the Mussulman mosque the muezzin calling,

<BR>I see the worshippers within, nor form nor sermon, argument

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nor word,

<BR>But silent, strange, devout, rais'd glowing heads, ecstatic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; faces.

<BR>I hear the Egyptian harp of many strings,

<BR>The primitive chants of the Nile boatmen,

<BR>The sacred imperial hymns of China,

<BR>To the delicate sounds of the king, (the stricken wood and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stone,)

<BR>Or to Hindu flutes and the fretting twang of the vina,

<BR>A band of bayaderes.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>5</CENTER>

Now Asia, Africa leave me, Europe seizing inflates me,

<BR>To organs huge and bands I hear as from vast concourses of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; voices,

<BR>Luther's strong hymn <I>Eine feste Burg ist unser Gott</I>,

<BR>Rossini's <I>Stabat Mater dolorosa</I>,

<BR>Or floating in some high cathedral dim with gorgeous color'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; windows,

<BR>The passionate <I>Agnus Dei</I> or <I>Gloria in Excelsis</I>.

<BR>Composers! mighty maestros!

<BR>And you, sweet singers of old lands, soprani, tenori, bassi!

<BR>To you a new bard caroling in the West,

<BR>Obeisant sends his love.



<P>&nbsp;(Such led to thee O soul,

<BR>All senses, shows and objects, lead to thee,

<BR>But now it seems to me sound leads o'er all the rest.)

<BR>I hear the annual singing of the children in St. Paul's cathedral,

<BR>Or, under the high roof of some colossal hall, the symphonies,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; oratorios of Beethoven, Handel, or Haydn,

<BR>The <I>Creation</I> in billows of godhood laves me.

<BR>Give me to hold all sounds, (I madly struggling cry,)

<BR>Fill me with all the voices of the universe,

<BR>Endow me with their throbbings, Nature's also,

<BR>The tempests, waters, winds, operas and chants, marches and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dances,

<BR>Utter, pour in, for I would take them all!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>6</CENTER>

Then I woke softly,

<BR>And pausing, questioning awhile the music of my dream,

<BR>And questioning all those reminiscences, the tempest in its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fury,

<BR>And all the songs of sopranos and tenors,

<BR>And those rapt oriental dances of religious fervor,

<BR>And the sweet varied instruments, and the diapason of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; organs,

<BR>And all the artless plaints of love and grief and death,

<BR>I said to my silent curious soul out of the bed of the slumber-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chamber,

<BR>Come, for I have found the clew I sought so long,

<BR>Let us go forth refresh'd amid the day,

<BR>Cheerfully tallying life, walking the world, the real,

<BR>Nourish'd henceforth by our celestial dream.

<BR>And I said, moreover,

<BR>Haply what thou hast heard O soul was not the sound of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; winds,

<BR>Nor dream of raging storm, nor sea-hawk's flapping wings

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nor harsh scream,

<BR>Nor vocalism of sun-bright Italy,



<P>&nbsp;Nor German organ majestic, nor vast concourse of voices,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nor layers of harmonies,

<BR>Nor strophes of husbands and wives, nor sound of marching

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soldiers,

<BR>Nor flutes, nor harps, nor the bugle-calls of camps,

<BR>But to a new rhythmus fitted for thee,

<BR>Poems bridging the way from Life to Death, vaguely wafted

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in night air, uncaught, unwritten,

<BR>Which let us go forth in the bold day and write.

<BR>(1868) 1881

<BR>

<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Prayer of Columbus</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Prayer of Columbus</I></H1></CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>batter'd</FONT>, wreck'd old man,

<BR>Thrown on this savage shore, far, far from home,

<BR>Pent by the sea and dark rebellious brows, twelve dreary

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; months,

<BR>Sore, stiff with many toils, sicken'd and nigh to death,

<BR>I take my way along the island's edge,

<BR>Venting a heavy heart.



<P>&nbsp;I am too full of woe!

<BR>Haply I may not live another day;

<BR>I cannot rest O God, I cannot eat or drink or sleep,

<BR>Till I put forth myself, my prayer, once more to Thee,

<BR>Breathe, bathe myself once more in Thee, commune with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thee,

<BR>Report myself once more to Thee.



<P>&nbsp;Thou knowest my years entire, my life,

<BR>My long and crowded life of active work, not adoration

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; merely;

<BR>Thou knowest the prayers and vigils of my youth,



<P>&nbsp;Thou knowest my manhood's solemn and visionary

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; meditations,

<BR>Thou knowest how before I commenced I devoted all to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; come to Thee,

<BR>Thou knowest I have in age ratified all those vows and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strictly kept them,

<BR>Thou knowest I have not once lost nor faith nor ecstasy in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thee,

<BR>In shackles, prison'd, in disgrace, repining not,

<BR>Accepting all from Thee, as duly come from Thee.



<P>&nbsp;All my emprises have been fill'd with Thee,

<BR>My speculations, plans, begun and carried on in thought of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thee,

<BR>Sailing the deep or journeying the land for Thee;

<BR>Intentions, purports, aspirations mine, leaving results to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thee.



<P>&nbsp;O I am sure they really came from Thee,

<BR>The urge, the ardor, the unconquerable will,

<BR>The potent, felt, interior command, stronger than words,

<BR>A message from the Heavens whispering to me even in sleep,

<BR>These sped me on.



<P>&nbsp;By me and these the work so far accomplish'd,

<BR>By me earth's elder cloy'd and stifled lands uncloy'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unloos'd,

<BR>By me the hemispheres rounded and tied, the unknown to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; known.



<P>&nbsp;The end I know not, it is all in Thee,

<BR>Or small or great I know not&amp;emdash;haply what broad fields, what

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lands,

<BR>Haply the brutish measureless human undergrowth I know,

<BR>Transplanted there may rise to stature, knowledge worthy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thee,

<BR>Haply the swords I know may there indeed be turn'd to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reaping-tools,

<BR>Haply the lifeless cross I know, Europe's dead cross, may

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bud and blossom there.



<P>&nbsp;One effort more, my altar this bleak sand;

<BR>That Thou O God my life hast lighted,

<BR>With ray of light, steady, ineffable, vouchsafed of Thee,

<BR>Light rare untellable, lighting the very light,

<BR>Beyond all signs, descriptions, languages;

<BR>For that O God, be it my latest word, here on my knees,

<BR>Old, poor, and paralyzed, I thank Thee.



<P>&nbsp;My terminus near,

<BR>The clouds already closing in upon me,

<BR>The voyage balk'd, the course disputed, lost,

<BR>I yield my ships to Thee.



<P>&nbsp;My hands, my limbs grow nerveless,

<BR>My brain feels rack'd, bewilder'd,

<BR>Let the old timbers part, I will not part,

<BR>I will cling fast to Thee, O God, though the waves buffet me,

<BR>Thee, Thee at least I know.



<P>&nbsp;Is it the prophet's thought I speak, or am I raving?

<BR>What do I know of life? what of myself?

<BR>I know not even my own work past or present,

<BR>Dim ever-shifting guesses of it spread before me,

<BR>Of newer better worlds, their mighty parturition,

<BR>Mocking, perplexing me.



<P>&nbsp;And these things I see suddenly, what mean they?

<BR>As if some miracle, some hand divine unseal'd my eyes,

<BR>Shadowy vast shapes smile through the air and sky,

<BR>And on the distant waves sail countless ships,

<BR>And anthems in new tongues I hear saluting me.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1874&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : A Song of the Rolling Earth</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>A Song of the Rolling Earth</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>A <FONT SIZE=-1>SONG</FONT> of the rolling earth, and of words according,

<BR>Were you thinking that those were the words, those upright lines?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those curves, angles, dots?

<BR>No, those are not the words, the substantial words are in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ground and sea,

<BR>They are in the air, they are in you.



<P>&nbsp;Were you thinking that those were the words, those delicious

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sounds out of your friends' mouths?

<BR>No, the real words are more delicious than they.



<P>&nbsp;Human bodies are words, myriads of words,

<BR>(In the best poems re-appears the body, man's or woman's,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; well-shaped, natural, gay,

<BR>Every part able, active, receptive, without shame or the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; need of shame.)



<P>&nbsp;Air, soil, water, fire&amp;emdash;those are words,

<BR>I myself am a word with them&amp;emdash;my qualities interpenetrate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with theirs&amp;emdash;my name is nothing

to them,

<BR>Though it were told in the three thousand languages, what would

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; air, soil, water, fire, know of my name?



<P>&nbsp;A healthy presence, a friendly or commanding gesture, are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; words, sayings, meanings,

<BR>The charms that go with the mere looks of some men and women,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are sayings and meanings also.



<P>&nbsp;The workmanship of souls is by those inaudible words of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth,

<BR>The masters know the earth's words and use them more than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; audible words.



<P>&nbsp;Amelioration is one of the earth's words,

<BR>The earth neither lags nor hastens,



<P>&nbsp;It has all attributes, growths, effects, latent in itself from

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; jump,

<BR>It is not half beautiful only, defects and excrescences show

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; just as much as perfections show.



<P>&nbsp;The earth does not withhold, it is generous enough,

<BR>The truths of the earth continually wait, they are not so

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; conceal'd either,

<BR>They are calm, subtle, untransmissible by print,

<BR>They are imbued through all things conveying themselves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; willingly,

<BR>Conveying a sentiment and invitation, I utter and utter,

<BR>I speak not, yet if you hear me not of what avail am I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to you?

<BR>To bear, to better, lacking these of what avail am I?



<P>&nbsp;(Accouche! accouchez!

<BR>Will you rot your own fruit in yourself there?

<BR>Will you squat and stifle there?)



<P>&nbsp;The earth does not argue,

<BR>Is not pathetic, has no arrangements,

<BR>Does not scream, haste, persuade, threaten, promise,

<BR>Makes no discriminations, has no conceivable failures,

<BR>Closes nothing, refuses nothing, shuts none out,

<BR>Of all the powers, objects, states, it notifies, shuts

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; none out.



<P>&nbsp;The earth does not exhibit itself nor refuse to exhibit

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself, possesses still underneath,

<BR>Underneath the ostensible sounds, the august chorus of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heroes, the wail of slaves,

<BR>Persuasions of lovers, curses, gasps of the dying, laughter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of young people, accents of bargainers,

<BR>Underneath these possessing words that never fail.



<P>&nbsp;To her children the words of the eloquent dumb great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mother never fail,

<BR>The true words do not fail, for motion does not fail and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reflection does not fail,

<BR>Also the day and night do not fail, and the voyage we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pursue does not fail.



<P>&nbsp;Of the interminable sisters,

<BR>Of the ceaseless cotillions of sisters,

<BR>Of the centripetal and centrifugal sisters, the elder and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; younger sisters,

<BR>The beautiful sister we know dances on with the rest.



<P>&nbsp;With her ample back towards every beholder,

<BR>With the fascinations of youth and the equal fascinations

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of age,

<BR>Sits she whom I too love like the rest, sits undisturb'd,

<BR>Holding up in her hand what has the character of a mirror,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; while her eyes glance back from it,

<BR>Glance as she sits, inviting none, denying none,

<BR>Holding a mirror day and night tirelessly before her own

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; face.



<P>&nbsp;Seen at hand or seen at a distance,

<BR>Duly the twenty-four appear in public every day,

<BR>Duly approach and pass with their companions or a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; companion,

<BR>Looking from no countenances of their own, but from the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; countenances of those who are with them,

<BR>From the countenances of children or women or the manly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; countenance,

<BR>From the open countenances of animals or from inanimate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; things,

<BR>From the landscape or waters or from the exquisite apparition

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the sky,

<BR>From our countenances, mine and yours, faithfully returning

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>Every day in public appearing without fail, but never twice

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the same companions.



<P>&nbsp;Embracing man, embracing all, proceed the three hundred

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sixty-five resistlessly round the sun;

<BR>Embracing all, soothing, supporting, follow close three hundred

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sixty-five offsets of the first, sure

and necessary as they.



<P>&nbsp;Tumbling on steadily, nothing dreading,

<BR>Sunshine, storm, cold, heat, forever withstanding, passing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; carrying,



<P>&nbsp;The soul's realization and determination still inheriting,

<BR>The fluid vacuum around and ahead still entering and dividing,

<BR>No balk retarding, no anchor anchoring, on no rock striking,

<BR>Swift, glad, content, unbereav'd, nothing losing,

<BR>Of all able and ready at any time to give strict account,

<BR>The divine ship sails the divine sea.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Whoever you are! motion and reflection are especially for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you,

<BR>The divine ship sails the divine sea for you.



<P>&nbsp;Whoever you are! you are he or she for whom the earth is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; solid and liquid,

<BR>You are he or she for whom the sun and moon hang in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sky,

<BR>For none more than you are the present and the past,

<BR>For none more than you is immortality.



<P>&nbsp;Each man to himself and each woman to herself, is the word

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the past and present, and the true word

of immortality;

<BR>No one can acquire for another&amp;emdash;not one,

<BR>Not one can grow for another&amp;emdash;not one.



<P>&nbsp;The song is to the singer, and comes back most to him,

<BR>The teaching is to the teacher, and comes back most to him,

<BR>The murder is to the murderer, and comes back most to him,

<BR>The theft is to the thief, and comes back most to him,

<BR>The love is to the lover, and comes back most to him,

<BR>The gift is to the giver, and comes back most to him&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it cannot fail,

<BR>The oration is to the orator, the acting is to the actor and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; actress not to the audience,

<BR>And no man understands any greatness or goodness but his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; own, or the indication of his own.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>I swear the earth shall surely be complete to him or her who

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall be complete,

<BR>The earth remains jagged and broken only to him or her who

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; remains jagged and broken.



<P>&nbsp;I swear there is no greatness or power that does not emulate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those of the earth,

<BR>There can be no theory of any account unless it corroborate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the theory of the earth,

<BR>No politics, song, religion, behavior, or what not, is of account,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unless it compare with the amplitude of the

earth,

<BR>Unless it face the exactness, vitality, impartiality, rectitude

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the earth.



<P>&nbsp;I swear I begin to see love with sweeter spasms than that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; which responds love,

<BR>It is that which contains itself, which never invites and never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; refuses.



<P>&nbsp;I swear I begin to see little or nothing in audible words,

<BR>All merges toward the presentation of the unspoken meanings

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the earth,

<BR>Toward him who sings the songs of the body and of the truths

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the earth,

<BR>Toward him who makes the dictionaries of words that print

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cannot touch.



<P>&nbsp;I swear I see what is better than to tell the best,

<BR>It is always to leave the best untold.



<P>&nbsp;When I undertake to tell the best I find I cannot,

<BR>My tongue is ineffectual on its pivots,

<BR>My breath will not be obedient to its organs,

<BR>I become a dumb man.



<P>&nbsp;The best of the earth cannot be told anyhow, all or any is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; best,

<BR>It is not what you anticipated, it is cheaper, easier, nearer,

<BR>Things are not dismiss'd from the places they held before,

<BR>The earth is just as positive and direct as it was before,

<BR>Facts, religions, improvements, politics, trades, are as real

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as before,

<BR>But the soul is also real, it too is positive and direct,

<BR>No reasoning, no proof has establish'd it,

<BR>Undeniable growth has establish'd it.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>These to echo the tones of souls and the phrases of souls,

<BR>(If they did not echo the phrases of souls what were they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; then?

<BR>If they had not reference to you in especial what were they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; then?)

<BR>I swear I will never henceforth have to do with the faith that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tells the best,

<BR>I will have to do only with that faith that leaves the best

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untold.



<P>&nbsp;Say on, sayers! sing on, singers!

<BR>Delve! mould! pile the words of the earth!

<BR>Work on, age after age, nothing is to be lost,

<BR>It may have to wait long, but it will certainly come in use,

<BR>When the materials are all prepared and ready, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; architects shall appear.



<P>&nbsp;I swear to you the architects shall appear without fail,

<BR>I swear to you they will understand you and justify you,

<BR>The greatest among them shall be he who best knows you,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and encloses all and is faithful to all,

<BR>He and the rest shall not forget you, they shall perceive that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you are not an iota less than they,

<BR>You shall be fully glorified in them.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

YOUTH, DAY, OLD AGE AND NIGHT</H2></CENTER>

Y<FONT SIZE=-1>OUTH</FONT>, large, lusty, loving&amp;emdash;youth full

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of grace, force, fascination,

<BR>Do you know that Old Age may come after you with equal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grace, force, fascination?

<BR>Day full-blown and splendid&amp;emdash;day of the immense

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sun, action, ambition, laughter,

<BR>The Night follows close with millions of suns, and sleep and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; restoring darkness.

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Whispers of Heavenly Death</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Whispers of Heavenly Death</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

DAREST THOU NOW O SOUL</H2></CENTER>

D<FONT SIZE=-1>arest</FONT> thou now O soul,

<BR>Walk out with me toward the unknown region,

<BR>Where neither ground is for the feet nor any path to follow?



<P>&nbsp;No map there, nor guide,

<BR>Nor voice sounding, nor touch of human hand,

<BR>Nor face with blooming flesh, nor lips, nor eyes, are in that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land.



<P>&nbsp;I know it not O soul,
