<BR>Nor dost thou, all is a blank before us,

<BR>All waits undream'd of in that region, that inaccessible land.



<P>&nbsp;Till when the ties loosen,

<BR>All but the ties eternal, Time and Space,

<BR>Nor darkness, gravitation, sense, nor any bounds bounding

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; us.



<P>&nbsp;Then we burst forth, we float,

<BR>In Time and Space O soul, prepared for them,

<BR>Equal, equipt at last, (O joy! O fruit of all!) them to fulfil O

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soul.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1868&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHISPERS OF HEAVENLY DEATH</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>hispers</FONT> of heavenly death murmur'd I hear,

<BR>Labial gossip of night, sibilant chorals,

<BR>Footsteps gently ascending, mystical breezes wafted soft and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; low,



<P>&nbsp;Ripples of unseen rivers, tides of a current flowing, forever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flowing,

<BR>(Or is it the plashing of tears? the measureless waters of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; human tears?)



<P>&nbsp;I see, just see skyward, great cloud-masses,

<BR>Mournfully slowly they roll, silently swelling and mixing,

<BR>With at times a half-dimm'd sadden'd far-off star,

<BR>Appearing and disappearing.



<P>&nbsp;(Some parturition rather, some solemn immortal birth;

<BR>On the frontiers to eyes impenetrable,

<BR>Some soul is passing over.)



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1868&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

CHANTING THE SQUARE DEIFIC</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

C<FONT SIZE=-1>hanting</FONT> the square deific, out of the One advancing,

out of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sides,

<BR>Out of the old and new, out of the square entirely divine,

<BR>Solid, four-sided, (all the sides needed,) from this side Jehovah

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; am I,

<BR>Old Brahm I, and I Saturnius am;

<BR>Not Time affects me&amp;emdash;I am Time, old, modern as any,

<BR>Unpersuadable, relentless, executing righteous judgments,

<BR>As the Earth, the Father, the brown old Kronos, with laws,

<BR>Aged beyond computation, yet ever new, ever with those

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mighty laws rolling,

<BR>Relentless I forgive no man&amp;emdash;whoever sins dies&amp;emdash;I

will have

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that man's life;

<BR>Therefore let none expect mercy&amp;emdash;have the seasons, gravitation,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the appointed days, mercy? no more have I,

<BR>But as the seasons and gravitation, and as all the appointed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; days that forgive not,

<BR>I dispense from this side judgments inexorable without the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; least remorse.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

Consolator most mild, the promis'd one advancing,

<BR>With gentle hand extended, the mightier God am I,



<P>&nbsp;Foretold by prophets and poets in their most rapt prophecies

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and poems,

<BR>From this side, lo! the Lord Christ gazes&amp;emdash;lo! Hermes I&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lo! mine is Hercules' face,

<BR>All sorrow, labor, suffering, I, tallying it, absorb in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself,

<BR>Many times have I been rejected, taunted, put in prison, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crucified, and many times shall be again,

<BR>All the world have I given up for my dear brothers' and sisters'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sake, for the soul's sake,

<BR>Wending my way through the homes of men, rich or poor,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the kiss of affection,

<BR>For I am affection, I am the cheer-bringing God, with hope

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and all-enclosing charity,

<BR>With indulgent words as to children, with fresh and sane

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; words, mine only,

<BR>Young and strong I pass knowing well I am destin'd myself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to an early death;

<BR>But my charity has no death&amp;emdash;my wisdom dies not, neither

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; early nor late,

<BR>And my sweet love bequeath'd here and elsewhere never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dies.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

Aloof, dissatisfied, plotting revolt,

<BR>Comrade of criminals, brother of slaves,

<BR>Crafty, despised, a drudge, ignorant,

<BR>With sudra face and worn brow, black, but in the depths of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my heart, proud as any,

<BR>Lifted now and always against whoever scorning assumes to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rule me,

<BR>Morose, full of guile, full of reminiscences, brooding, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; many wiles,

<BR>(Though it was thought I was baffled and dispel'd, and my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wiles done, but that will never be,)

<BR>Defiant, I, Satan, still live, still utter words, in new lands duly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; appearing, (and old ones also,)

<BR>Permanent here from my side, warlike, equal with any, real

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as any,

<BR>Nor time nor change shall ever change me or my words.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

Santa Spirita, breather, life,

<BR>Beyond the light, lighter than light,

<BR>Beyond the flames of hell, joyous, leaping easily above hell,

<BR>Beyond Paradise, perfumed solely with mine own perfume,

<BR>Including all life on earth, touching, including God, including

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Saviour and Satan,

<BR>Ethereal, pervading all, (for without me what were all? what

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; were God?)

<BR>Essence of forms, life of the real identities, permanent, positive,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (namely the unseen,)

<BR>Life of the great round world, the sun and stars, and of man,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I, the general soul,

<BR>Here the square finishing, the solid, I the most solid,

<BR>Breathe my breath also through these songs.

<BR>1865-6



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>OF HIM I LOVE DAY AND NIGHT</CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>f</FONT> him I love day and night I dream'd I heard he was

dead,

<BR>And I dream'd I went where they had buried him I love, but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; he was not in that place,

<BR>And I dream'd I wander'd searching among burial-places to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; find him,

<BR>And I found that every place was a burial-place;

<BR>The houses full of life were equally full of death, (this house

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is now,)

<BR>The streets, the shipping, the places of amusement, the Chicago,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Boston, Philadelphia, the Mannahatta, were as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; full of the dead as of the living,

<BR>And fuller, O vastly fuller of the dead than of the living;

<BR>And what I dream'd I will henceforth tell to every person and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; age,

<BR>And I stand henceforth bound to what I dream'd,

<BR>And now I am willing to disregard burial-places and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dispense with them,

<BR>And if the memorials of the dead were put up indifferently

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; everywhere, even in the room where I eat or sleep,

I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; should be satisfied,



<P>&nbsp;And if the corpse of any one I love, or if my own corpse,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be duly render'd to powder and pour'd in the sea,

I shall be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; satisfied,

<BR>Or if it be distributed to the winds I shall be satisfied.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>YET, YET, YE DOWNCAST HOURS</CENTER>

Y<FONT SIZE=-1>et</FONT>, yet, ye downcast hours, I know ye also,

<BR>Weights of lead, how ye clog and cling at my ankles,

<BR>Earth to a chamber of mourning turns&amp;emdash;I hear the o'er

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; weening, mocking voice,

<BR><I>Matter is conqueror&amp;emdash;matter, triumphant only, continues</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; onward</I>.

<BR>Despairing cries float ceaselessly toward me,

<BR>The call of my nearest lover, putting forth, alarm'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; uncertain,

<BR><I>The sea I am quickly to sail, come tell me</I>,

<BR><I>Come tell me where I am speeding, tell me my destination</I>.

<BR>I understand your anguish, but I cannot help you,

<BR>I approach, hear, behold, the sad mouth, the look out of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eyes, your mute inquiry,

<BR><I>Whither I go from the bed I recline on, come tell me</I>;

<BR>Old age, alarm'd, uncertain&amp;emdash;a young woman's voice,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; appealing to me for comfort;

<BR>A young man's voice, <I>Shall I not escape</I>?

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>AS IF A PHANTOM CARESS'D ME</CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>s</FONT> if a phantom caress'd me,

<BR>I thought I was not alone walking here by the shore;

<BR>But the one I thought was with me as now I walk by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shore, the one I loved that caress'd me,

<BR>As I lean and look through the glimmering light, that one has

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; utterly disappear'd,

<BR>And those appear that are hateful to me and mock me.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>ASSURANCES</CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>need</FONT> no assurances, I am a man who is pre-occupied

of his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; own soul;

<BR>I do not doubt that from under the feet and beside the hands

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and face I am cognizant of, are now looking faces

I am

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not cognizant of, calm and actual faces,

<BR>I do not doubt but the majesty and beauty of the world are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; latent in any iota of the world,

<BR>I do not doubt I am limitless, and that the universes are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; limitless, in vain I try to think how limitless,

<BR>I do not doubt that the orbs and the systems of orbs play

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their swift sports through the air on purpose, and

that I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall one day be eligible to do as much as they,

and more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than they,

<BR>I do not doubt that temporary affairs keep on and on millions

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of years,

<BR>I do not doubt interiors have their interiors, and exteriors

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; have their exteriors, and that the eyesight has

another

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eyesight, and the hearing another hearing, and the

voice

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; another voice,

<BR>I do not doubt that the passionately-wept deaths of young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men are provided for, and that the deaths of young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; women and the deaths of little children are provided

for,

<BR>(Did you think Life was so well provided for, and Death, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; purport of all Life, is not well provided for?)

<BR>I do not doubt that wrecks at sea, no matter what the horrors

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of them, no matter whose wife, child, husband, father,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lover, has gone down, are provided for, to the minutest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; points,

<BR>I do not doubt that whatever can possibly happen anywhere

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at any time, is provided for in the inherences of

things,

<BR>I do not think Life provides for all and for Time and Space,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but I believe Heavenly Death provides for all.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>QUICKSAND YEARS</CENTER>

Q<FONT SIZE=-1>uicksand</FONT> years that whirl me I know not whither,

<BR>Your schemes, politics, fail, lines give way, substances mock

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and elude me,



<P>&nbsp;Only the theme I sing, the great and strong-possess'd soul,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eludes not,

<BR>One's-self must never give way&amp;emdash;that is the final substance&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that out of all is sure,

<BR>Out of politics, triumphs, battles, life, what at last finally

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; remains?

<BR>When shows break up what but One's-Self is sure?

<PRE>(1861-2)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>THAT MUSIC ALWAYS ROUND ME</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>hat</FONT> music always round me, unceasing, unbeginning,

yet long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untaught I did not hear,

<BR>But now the chorus I hear and am elated,

<BR>A tenor, strong, ascending with power and health, with glad

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; notes of daybreak I hear,

<BR>A soprano at intervals sailing buoyantly over the tops of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; immense waves,

<BR>A transparent base shuddering lusciously under and through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the universe,

<BR>The triumphant tutti, the funeral wailings with sweet flutes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and violins, all these I fill myself with,

<BR>I hear not the volumes of sound merely, I am moved by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; exquisite meanings,

<BR>I listen to the different voices winding in and out, striving,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contending with fiery vehemence to excel each other

in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; emotion;

<BR>I do not think the performers know themselves&amp;emdash;but now I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; think I begin to know them.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>WHAT SHIP PUZZLED AT SEA</CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>hat</FONT> ship puzzled at sea, cons for the true reckoning?

<BR>Or coming in, to avoid the bars and follow the channel a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; perfect pilot needs?

<BR>Here, sailor! here, ship! take aboard the most perfect pilot,

<BR>Whom, in a little boat, putting off and rowing, I hailing you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; offer.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>A NOISELESS PATIENT SPIDER</CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>noiseless</FONT> patient spider,

<BR>I mark'd where on a little promontory it stood isolated,

<BR>Mark'd how to explore the vacant vast surrounding,

<BR>It launched forth filament, filament, filament, out of itself,

<BR>Ever unreeling them, ever tirelessly speeding them.



<P>&nbsp;And you O my soul where you stand,

<BR>Surrounded, detached, in measureless oceans of space,

<BR>Ceaselessly musing, venturing, throwing, seeking the spheres

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to connect them,

<BR>Till the bridge you will need be form'd, till the ductile anchor

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hold,

<BR>Till the gossamer thread you fling catch somewhere, O my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soul.

<PRE>(1862-3)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>O LIVING ALWAYS, ALWAYS DYING</CENTER>

O <FONT SIZE=-1>living</FONT> always, always dying!

<BR>O the burials of me past and present,

<BR>O me while I stride ahead, material, visible, imperious as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ever;

<BR>O me, what I was for years, now dead, (I lament not, I am

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; content;)

<BR>O to disengage myself from those corpses of me, which I turn

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and look at where I cast them,

<BR>To pass on, (O living! always living!) and leave the corpses

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; behind.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>TO ONE SHORTLY TO DIE</CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>rom</FONT> all the rest I single out you, having a message

for you,

<BR>You are to die&amp;emdash;let others tell you what they please, I cannot

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prevaricate,

<BR>I am exact and merciless, but I love you&amp;emdash;there is no escape

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>HEAVENLY DEATH</I></CENTER>

Softly I lay my right hand upon you, you just feel it,

<BR>I do not argue, I bend my head close and half envelop it,

<BR>I sit quietly by, I remain faithful,

<BR>I am more than nurse, more than parent or neighbor,

<BR>I absolve you from all except yourself spiritual bodily, that is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eternal, you yourself will surely escape,

<BR>The corpse you will leave will be but excrementitious.



<P>&nbsp;The sun bursts through in unlooked-for directions,

<BR>Strong thoughts fill you and confidence, you smile,

<BR>You forget you are sick, as I forget you are sick,

<BR>You do not see the medicines, you do not mind the weeping

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; friends, I am with you,

<BR>I exclude others from you, there is nothing to be commiserated,

<BR>I do not commiserate, I congratulate you.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1860 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>NIGHT ON THE PRAIRIES</CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>ight</FONT> on the prairies,

<BR>The supper is over, the fire on the ground burns low,

<BR>The wearied emigrants sleep, wrapt in their blankets;

<BR>I walk by myself&amp;emdash;I stand and look at the stars, which I

think

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; now I never realized before.



<P>&nbsp;Now I absorb immortality and peace,

<BR>I admire death and test propositions.



<P>&nbsp;How plenteous! how spiritual! how resume!

<BR>The same old man and soul&amp;emdash;the same old aspirations, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the same content.



<P>&nbsp;I was thinking the day most splendid till I saw what the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; notday exhibited,

<BR>I was thinking this globe enough till there sprang out so

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; noiseless around me myriads of other globes.



<P>&nbsp;Now while the great thoughts of space and eternity fill me I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; will measure myself by them,

<BR>And now touch'd with the lives of other globes arrived as far

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; along as those of the earth,



<P>&nbsp;Or waiting to arrive, or pass'd on farther than those of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth,

<BR>I henceforth no more ignore them than I ignore my own life,

<BR>Or the lives of the earth arrived as far as mine, or waiting to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arrive.



<P>&nbsp;O I see now that life cannot exhibit all to me, as the day

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cannot,

<BR>I see that I am to wait for what will be exhibited by death.



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1860 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>THOUGHT</CENTER>

As I sit with others at a great feast, suddenly while the music

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is playing,

<BR>To my mind, (whence it comes I know not,) spectral in mist

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of a wreck at sea,

<BR>Of certain ships, how they sail from port with flying streamers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and wafted kisses, and that is the last of them,

<BR>Of the solemn and murky mystery about the fate of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; President,

<BR>Of the flower of the marine science of fifty generations

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; founder'd off the Northeast coast and going down&amp;emdash;of

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steamship Arctic going down,

<BR>Of the veil'd tableau&amp;emdash;women gather'd together on deck,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pale, heroic, waiting the moment that draws so close&amp;emdash;O

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the moment!

<BR>A huge sob&amp;emdash;a few bubbles&amp;emdash;the white foam spirting

up&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and then the women gone,

<BR>Sinking there while the passionless wet flows on&amp;emdash;and I now

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pondering, Are those women gone?

<BR>Are souls drown'd and destroy'd so?

<BR>Is only matter triumphants?



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1860 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>THE LAST INVOCATION</CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>t</FONT> the last, tenderly,

<BR>From the walls of the powerful fortress'd house,

<BR>From the clasp of the knitted locks, from the keep of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; well-closed doors,

<BR>Let me be wafted.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>HEAVENLY DEATH</I></CENTER>

Let me glide noiselessly forth;

<BR>With the key of softness unlock the locks&amp;emdash;with a whisper,

<BR>Set ope the doors O soul.



<P>&nbsp;Tenderly&amp;emdash;be not impatient,

<BR>(Strong is your hold O mortal flesh,

<BR>Strong is your hold O love.)



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1868 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>AS I WATCH'D THE PLOUGHMAN PLOUGHING</CENTER>

As I watch'd the ploughman ploughing,

<BR>Or the sower sowing in the fields, or the harvester harvesting,

<BR>I saw there too, O life and death, your analogies;

<BR>(Life, life is the tillage, Death is the harvest according.)



<P>&nbsp;



<P>1871 1871

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>PENSIVE AND FALTERING</CENTER>



<BLOCKQUOTE>P<FONT SIZE=-1>ensive</FONT> and faltering,

<BR>The words <I>the Dead</I> I write,

<BR>For living are the Dead,

<BR>(Haply the only living, only real,

<BR>And I the apparition, I the spectre.)



<P>&nbsp;</BLOCKQUOTE>

1868 1871



<P>

<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Good-bye My Fancy</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Good-bye My Fancy</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>Second Annex</I>)</CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SAIL OUT FOR GOOD, EID&Oacute;LON YACHT!</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>EAVE</FONT> the anchor short!

<BR>Raise main-sail and jib&amp;emdash;steer forth,

<BR>O little white-hull'd sloop, now speed on really deep

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waters,

<BR>(I will not call it our concluding voyage,

<BR>But outset and sure entrance to the truest, best,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; maturest;)

<BR>Depart, depart from solid earth&amp;emdash;no more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; returning to these shores,

<BR>Now on for aye our infinite free venture wending,

<BR>Spurning all yet tried ports, seas, hawsers, densities,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gravitation,

<BR>Sail out for good, eid&oacute;lon yacht of me!

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

LINGERING LAST DROPS</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>ND</FONT> whence and why come you?



<P>&nbsp;We know not whence, (was the answer,)

<BR>We only know that we drift here with the rest,

<BR>That we linger'd and lagg'd&amp;emdash;but were wafted

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at last, and are now here,

<BR>To make the passing shower's concluding drops,

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

GOOD-BYE MY FANCY</H2></CENTER>

G<FONT SIZE=-1>OOD-BYE</FONT><SUP><FONT SIZE=-2><A HREF="fan.html#ftn1">*</A></FONT></SUP>

my fancy&amp;emdash;(I had a word to say,

<BR>But 'tis not quite the time&amp;emdash;The best of any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; man's word or say,

<BR>Is when its proper place arrives&amp;emdash;and for its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; meaning,

<BR>I keep mine till the last.)

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ON, ON THE SAME, YE JOCUND TWAIN!</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>N</FONT>, on the same, ye jocund twain!

<BR>My life and recitative, containing birth, youth, mid-age

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; years,

<BR>Fitful as motley-tongues of flame, inseparably twined

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and merged in one&amp;emdash;combining all,

<BR>My single soul&amp;emdash;aims, confirmations, failures,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joys&amp;emdash;Nor single soul alone,

<BR>I chant my nation's crucial stage, (America's, haply

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; humanity's) &amp;emdash;the trial great, the

victory great,

<BR>A strange <I>eclaircissement</I> of all the masses past, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eastern world, the ancient, medieval,

<BR>Here, here from wanderings, strayings, lessons, wars,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; defeats &amp;emdash;here at the west a voice

triumphant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;justifying all,

<BR>A gladsome pealing cry&amp;emdash;a song for once of utmost

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pride and satisfaction;

<BR>I chant from it the common bulk, the general average horde,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (the best no sooner than the worst)&amp;emdash;And

now

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I chant old age,

<BR>(My verses, written first for forenoon life, and for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; summer's, autumn's spread,

<BR>I pass to snow-white hairs the same, and give to pulses

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; winter-cool'd the same;)

<BR>As here in careless trill, I and my recitatives, with faith

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and love,



<P>&nbsp;Wafting to other work, to unknown songs, conditions,

<BR>On, on, ye jocund twain! continue on the same!

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MY 71<FONT SIZE=-1>ST</FONT> YEAR</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>FTER</FONT> surmounting three-score and ten,

<BR>With all their chances, changes, losses, sorrows,

<BR>My parents' deaths, the vagaries of my life, the many tearing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; passions of me, the war of '63 and '4,

<BR>As some old broken soldier, after a long, hot, wearying

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; march, or haply after battle,

<BR>To-day at twilight, hobbling, answering company roll-call,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <I>Here</I>, with vital voice,

<BR>Reporting yet, saluting yet the Officer over all.

<PRE>1889&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

APPARITIONS</H2></CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>VAGUE</FONT> mist hanging 'round half the pages:

<BR>(Sometimes how strange and clear to the soul,

<BR>That all these solid things are indeed but apparitions, concepts,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; non-realities.)

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE PALLID WREATH</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>OMEHOW</FONT> I cannot let it go yet, funeral though it

is,

<BR>Let it remain back there on its nail suspended,

<BR>With pink, blue, yellow, all blanch'd, and the white now gray

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and ashy,

<BR>One wither'd rose put years ago for thee, dear friend;

<BR>But I do not forget thee. Hast thou then faded?

<BR>Is the odor exhaled? Are the colors, vitalities, dead?

<BR>No, while memories subtly play &amp;emdash; the past vivid as ever;

<BR>For but last night I woke, and in that spectral ring saw

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thee,

<BR>Thy smile, eyes, face, calm, silent, loving as ever;

<BR>So let the wreath hang still awhile within my eye-reach,

<BR>It is not yet dead to me, nor even pallid.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AN ENDED DAY</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> soothing sanity and blitheness of completion,

<BR>The pomp and hurried contest-glare and rush are done;

<BR>Now triumph! transformation! jubilate!<SUP><FONT SIZE=-2><A HREF="fan.html#ftn2">*</A></FONT></SUP>

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OLD AGE'S SHIP &amp; CRAFTY DEATH'S</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>ROM</FONT> cast and west across the horizon's edge,

<BR>Two mighty masterful vessels sailers steal upon us:

<BR>But we'll make race a-time upon the seas &amp;emdash; a battle-contest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet! bear lively there!

<BR>(Our joys of strife and derring-do to the last!)

<BR>Put on the old ship all her power to-day!

<BR>Crowd top-sail, top-gallant and royal studding-sails,

<BR>Out challenge and defiance &amp;emdash; flags and flaunting pennants

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; added,

<BR>As we take to the open! take to the deepest, freest waters.

<PRE>1890&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO THE PENDING YEAR</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>AVE</FONT> I no weapon-word for thee &amp;emdash; some message

brief and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fierce?

<BR>(Have I fought out and done indeed the battle?) Is there no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shot left,

<BR>For all thy affectations, lisps, scorns, manifold silliness?

<BR>Nor for myself &amp;emdash; my own rebellious self in thee?



<P>&nbsp;Down, down, proud gorge! &amp;emdash; though choking thee;

<BR>Thy bearded throat and high-borne forehead to the gutter;

<BR>Crouch low thy neck to eleemosynary gifts.

<PRE>(1889)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SHAKSPERE-BACON'S CIPHER</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>DOUBT</FONT> it not &amp;emdash; then more, far more;

<BR>In each old song bequeath'd &amp;emdash; in every noble page or text,

<BR>(Different &amp;emdash; something unreck'd before &amp;emdash; some

unsuspected

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; author,)

<BR>In every object , mountain, tree, and star &amp;emdash; in every birth

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life,

<BR>As part of each &amp;emdash; evolv'd from each &amp;emdash; meaning,

behind the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ostent,

<BR>A mystic cipher waits infolded.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

LONG, LONG HENCE</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>FTER</FONT> a long, long course, hundreds of years, denials,

<BR>Accumulations, rous'd love and joy and thought,

<BR>Hopes, wishes, aspirations, ponderings, victories, myriads of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; readers,

<BR>Coating, compassing, covering &amp;emdash; after ages' and ages'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; encrustations,

<BR>Then only may these songs reach fruition.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

BRAVO, PARIS EXPOSITION!</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>DD</FONT> to your show, before you close it, France,

<BR>With all the rest, visible, concrete, temples, towers, goods,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; machines and ores,

<BR>Our sentiment wafted from many million heart-throbs,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ethereal but solid,



<P>&nbsp;(We grand-sons and great-grand-sons do not forget your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grand-sires,)

<BR>From fifty Nations and nebulous Nations, compacted, sent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; oversea to-day,

<BR>America's applause, love, memories and good-will.

<PRE>1889&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

INTERPOLATION SOUNDS</H2></CENTER>

(<I>General Philip Sheridan was buried at the Cathedral, Washington, D.C.,

August, 1888, with all the pomp, music, and ceremonies of the Roman Catholic

service</I>.)



<P>&nbsp;O<FONT SIZE=-1>VER</FONT> and through the burial chant,

<BR>Organ and solemn service, sermon, bending priests,

<BR>To me come interpolation sounds not in the show &amp;emdash; plainly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me, crowding up the aisle and from the

window,

<BR>Of sudden battle's hurry and harsh noises &amp;emdash; war's grim game

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to sight and ear in earnest;

<BR>The scout call'd up and forward &amp;emdash; the general mounted and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his aids around him &amp;emdash; the new-brought

word &amp;emdash; the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; instantaneous order issued;

<BR>The rifle crack &amp;emdash; the cannon thud &amp;emdash; the rushing

forth of men

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from their tents;

<BR>The clank of cavalry &amp;emdash; the strange celerity of forming ranks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; the slender bugle note;

<BR>The sound of horses' hoofs departing &amp;emdash; saddles, arms,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accoutrements.<SUP>*</SUP>

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>

<SUP>*</SUP> <FONT SIZE=-1>NOTE. &amp;emdash; CAMDEN. N.J., August 7, 1888.

&amp;emdash; Walt Whitman asks the <I>New York Herald</I> "to add his tribute

to Sheridan":</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;



<P><FONT SIZE=-1>"In the grand constellation of five or six names. under

Lincoln's Presidency, that history will bear for ages in her firmament

as marking the last life-throbs of secession, and beaming on its dying

gasps, Sheridan's will be bright. One consideration rising out of the now

dead soldier's example as it passes my mind, is worth taking notice of.

If the war had continued any long time these States, in my opinion, would

have shown and proved the most conclusive military talents ever evinced

by any nation on earth. That they possess'd a rank and file ahead of all

other known in points of quality and limitlessness of number are easily

admitted. But we have, too, the eligibility of organizing, handling and

officering equal to the other. These two, with modern arms, transportation

and inventive American genius, would make the United States with earnestness,

not only able to stand the whole world, but conquer that world united against

us."</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

TO THE SUNSET BREEZE</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>H</FONT>, whispering, something again, unseen,

<BR>Where late this heated day thou enterest at my window, door,

<BR>Thou, laving, tempering all, cool-freshing, gently vitalizing

<BR>Me, old, alone, sick, weak-down, melted-worn with sweat;

<BR>Thou, nestling, folding close and firm yet soft, companion

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; better than talk, book, art,

<BR>(Thou hast, O Nature! elements! utterance to my heart beyond

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the rest &amp;emdash; and this is of them,)

<BR>So sweet thy primitive taste to breathe within &amp;emdash; thy soothing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fingers on my face and hands,

<BR>Thou, messenger-magical strange bringer to body and spirit

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of me,

<BR>(Distances balk'd &amp;emdash; occult medicines penetrating me from

head

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to foot,)

<BR>I feel the sky, the prairies vast &amp;emdash; I feel the mighty northern

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lakes,

<BR>I feel the ocean and the forest &amp;emdash; somehow I feel the globe

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself swift-swimming in space;

<BR>Thou blown from lips so loved, now gone &amp;emdash; haply from endless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; store, God-sent,

<BR>(For thou art spiritual, Godly, most of all known to my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sense,)

<BR>Minister to speak to me, here and now, what word has never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; told, and cannot tell,

<BR>Art thou not universal concrete's distillation? Law's, all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Astronomy's last refinement?

<BR>Hast thou no soul? Can I not know, identify thee?

<PRE>1890&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OLD CHANTS</H2></CENTER>

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; A<FONT SIZE=-1>N</FONT> ancient song, reciting, ending,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Once gazing toward thee, Mother of All,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Musing, seeking themes fitted for thee,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <I>Accept for me</I>, thou saidst, <I>the elder

ballads</I>,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <I>And name for me before thou goest each ancient

poet</I>.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (Of many debts incalculable,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Haply our New World's chiefest debt is to old poems.)



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ever so far back, preluding thee, America,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Old chants, Egyptian priests, and those of Ethiopia,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Hindu epics, the Grecian, Chinese, Persian,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Biblic books and prophets, and deep idyls of

the Nazarene,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Iliad, Odyssey, plots, doings, wanderings of

Eneas,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Hesiod, Eschylus, Sophocles, Merlin, Arthur,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Cid, Roland at Roncesvalles, the Nibelungen,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The troubadours, minstrels, minnesingers, skalds,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Chaucer, Dante, flocks of singing birds,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Border Minstrelsy, the bye-gone ballads, feudal

tales,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; essays, plays.

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Shakspere, Schiller, Walter Scott, Tennyson,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As some vast wondrous weird dream-presences,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The great shadowy groups gathering around,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Darting their mighty masterful eyes forward at thee,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thou! with as now thy bending neck and head, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; courteous hand and word,

ascending,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thou! pausing a moment, drooping thine eyes upon

them,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blent with their music,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Well pleased, accepting all, curiously prepared

for by them,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thou enterest at thy entrance porch.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A CHRISTMAS GREETING</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>From a Nothern Star-Group to a Southern</I>, 1889-90)</CENTER>





<P>W<FONT SIZE=-1>ELCOME</FONT>, Brazilian brother &amp;emdash; thy ample

place is ready;

<BR>A loving hand &amp;emdash; a smile from the north &amp;emdash; a sunny

instant hail!

<BR>(Let the future care for itself, where it reveals its troubles,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; impedimentas,

<BR>Ours, ours the present throe, the democratic aim, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; acceptance and the faith;)

<BR>To thee to-day our reaching arm, our turning neck &amp;emdash; to thee

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from us the expectant eye,

<BR>Thou cluster free! thou brilliant lustrous one! thou, learning

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; well,

<BR>The true lesson of a nation's light in the sky,

<BR>(More shining than the Cross, more than the Crown,)

<BR>The height to be superb humanity.

<PRE>(1889)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SOUNDS OF THE WINTER</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>OUNDS</FONT> of the winter too,

<BR>Sunshine upon the mountains &amp;emdash; many a distant strain

<BR>From cheery railroad train &amp;emdash; from nearer field, barn, house,

<BR>The whispering air &amp;emdash; even the mute crops, garner'd apples,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; corn,

<BR>Children's and women's tones &amp;emdash; rhythm of many a farmer

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and of flail,

<BR>An old man's garrulous lips among the rest, <I>Think not we</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; give out yet</I>,

<BR><I>Forth from these snowy hairs we keep up yet the lilt</I>.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A TWILIGHT SONG</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>S</FONT> I sit in twilight late alone by the flickering

oak-flame,

<BR>Musing on long-pass'd war-scenes &amp;emdash; of the countless buried

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unknown soldiers,

<BR>Of the vacant names, as unindented air's and sea's &amp;emdash; the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unreturn'd,

<BR>The brief truce after battle, with grim burial-squads, and the deep-fill'd

trenches

<BR>Of gather'd dead from all America, North, South, East, West,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whence they came up,

<BR>From wooded Maine, New-England's farms, from fertile

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Pennsylvania, Illinois, Ohio,

<BR>From the measureless West, Virginia, the South, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Carolinas, Texas,

<BR>(Even here in my room-shadows and half-lights in the noiseless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flickering flames,

<BR>Again I see the stalwart ranks on-filing, rising &amp;emdash; I hear

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rhythmic tramp of the armies;)

<BR>You million unwrit names all, all &amp;emdash; you dark bequest from

all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the war,

<BR>A special verse for you &amp;emdash; a flash of duty long neglected

&amp;emdash; your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mystic roll strangely gather'd here,

<BR>Each name recall'd by me from out the darkness and death's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ashes,

<BR>Henceforth to be, deep, deep within my heart recording, for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; many a future year,



<P>&nbsp;Your mystic roll entire of unknown names, or North or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; South,

<BR>Embalm'd with love in this twilight song.

<PRE>1890&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHEN THE FULL-GROWN POET CAME</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HEN</FONT> the full-grown poet came,

<BR>Out spake pleased Nature (the round impassive globe, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all its shows of day and night,) saying, <I>He

is mine</I>;

<BR>But out spake too the Soul of man, proud, jealous and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unreconciled, <I>Nay, he is mine alone</I>;

<BR>&amp;emdash; Then the full-grown poet stood between the two, and took

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; each by the hand;

<BR>And to-day and ever so stands, as blender, uniter, tightly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; holding hands,

<BR>Which he will never release until he reconciles the two,

<BR>And wholly and joyously blends them.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OSCEOLA</H2></CENTER>

(<I>When I was nearly grown to manhood in Brooklyn, New York (middle of

1838), I met one of the return'd U.S. Marines from Fort Moultrie, S. C.,

and had long talks with him &amp;emdash; learn'd the occurrence below described

&amp;emdash; death of Osceola. The latter was a young, brave, leading Seminole,

in the Florida war of that time &amp;emdash; was surrender'd to our troops,

imprison'd, and literally died of "a broken heart", at Fort Moultrie. He

sicken'd of his confinement &amp;emdash; the doctor and officers made every

allowance and kindness possible for him; then the close</I>.)



<P>&nbsp;W<FONT SIZE=-1>HEN</FONT> his hour for death had come,

<BR>He slowly rais'd himself from the bed on the floor,

<BR>Drew on his war-dress, shirt, leggings, and girdled the belt

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; around his waist,

<BR>Call'd for vermilion paint (his looking-glass was held before

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him,)

<BR>Painted half his face and neck, his wrists, and back-hands,

<BR>Put the scalp-knife carefully in his belt &amp;emdash; then lying down,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; resting a moment,



<P>&nbsp;Rose again, half sitting, smiled, gave in silence his extended

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hand to each and all,

<BR>Sank faintly low to the floor (tightly grasping the tomahawk

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; handle,)

<BR>Fix'd his look on wife and little children &amp;emdash; the last:

<BR>(And here a line in memory of his name and death.)

<PRE>1890&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A VOICE FROM DEATH</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>The Johnstown, Penn., cataclysm, May</I> 31, 1889)</CENTER>





<P>A <FONT SIZE=-1>VOICE</FONT> from Death, solemn and strange, in all

his sweep and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; power,

<BR>With sudden, indescribable blow &amp;emdash; towns drown'd &amp;emdash;

humanity

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by thousands slain,

<BR>The vaunted work of thrift, goods, dwellings, forge, street,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; iron bridge,

<BR>Dash'd pell-mell by the blow &amp;emdash; yet usher'd life continuing

on,

<BR>(Amid the rest, amid the rushing, whirling, wild debris,

<BR>A suffering woman saved &amp;emdash; a baby safely born!)

<BR>Although I come and unannounc'd, in horror and in pang,

<BR>In pouring flood and fire, and wholesale elemental crash,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (this voice so solemn, strange,)

<BR>I too a minister of Deity.



<P>&nbsp;Yea, Death, we bow our faces, veil our eyes to thee,

<BR>We mourn the old, the young untimely drawn to thee,

<BR>The fair, the strong, the good, the capable,

<BR>The household wreck'd, the husband and the wife, the engulf'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forger in his forge,

<BR>The corpses in the whelming waters and the mud,

<BR>The gather'd thousands to their funeral mounds, and thousands

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; never found or gather'd.



<P>&nbsp;Then after burying, mourning the dead,

<BR>(Faithful to them found or unfound, forgetting not, bearing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the past, here new musing,)

<BR>A day &amp;emdash; a passing moment or an hour &amp;emdash; America

itself bends

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; low,

<BR>Silent, resign'd, submissive.



<P>&nbsp;War, death, cataclysm like this, America,

<BR>Take deep to thy proud prosperous heart.



<P>&nbsp;E'en as I chant, Io! out of death, and out of ooze and slime,

<BR>The blossoms rapidly blooming, sympathy, help, love,

<BR>From West and East, from South and North and over sea,

<BR>Its hot-spurr'd hearts and hands humanity to human aid

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; moves on;

<BR>And from within a thought and lesson yet.



<P>&nbsp;Thou ever-darting Globe! through Space and Air!

<BR>Thou waters that encompass us!

<BR>Thou that in all the life and death of us, in action or in sleep!

<BR>Thou laws invisible that permeate them and all,

<BR>Thou that in all, and over all, and through and under all,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; incessant!

<BR>Thou! thou! the vital, universal, giant force resistless,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sleepless, calm,

<BR>Holding Humanity as in thy open hand, as some ephemeral

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; toy,

<BR>How ill to e'er forget thee!



<P>&nbsp;For I too have forgotten,

<BR>(Wrapt in these little potencies of progress, politics, culture,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wealth, inventions, civilization,)

<BR>Have lost my recognition of your silent ever-swaying power, ye

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mighty, elemental throes,

<BR>In which and upon which we float, and every one of us is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; buoy'd.

<PRE>1889&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A PERSIAN LESSON</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>OR</FONT> his o'erarching and last lesson the greybeard

sufi,

<BR>In the fresh scent of the morning in the open air,

<BR>On the slope of a teeming Persian rose-garden,

<BR>Under the ancient chestnut-tree wide spreading its branches,

<BR>Spoke to the young priests and students.



<P>&nbsp;Finally my children, to envelop each word, each part of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rest,

<BR>Allah is all, all, all &amp;emdash; is immanent in every life and object,



<P>&nbsp;May-be at many and many-a-more removes &amp;emdash; yet Allah,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Allah, Allah is there.



<P>&nbsp;"Has the estray wander'd far? Is the reason-why strangely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hidden?

<BR>Would you sound below the restless ocean of the entire world?

<BR>Would you know the dissatisfaction? the urge and spur of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every life;

<BR>The something never still'd &amp;emdash; never entirely gone? the invisible

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; need of every seed?



<P>&nbsp;"It is the central urge in every atom,

<BR>(Often unconscious, often evil, downfallen,)

<BR>To return to its divine source and origin, however distant,

<BR>Latent the same in subject and in object, without one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; exception."

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE COMMONPLACE</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> commonplace I sing;

<BR>How cheap is health! how cheap nobility!

<BR>Abstinence, no falsehood, no gluttony, lust;

<BR>The open air I sing, freedom, toleration,

<BR>(Take here the mainest lesson &amp;emdash; less from books &amp;emdash;

less from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the schools,)

<BR>The common day and night &amp;emdash; the common earth and waters,

<BR>Your farm &amp;emdash; your work, trade, occupation,

<BR>The democratic wisdom underneath, like solid ground for all.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>

"THE ROUNDED CATALOGUE DIVINE COMPLETE"



<P>(<I>Sunday_ _ _. _ Went this forenoon to church. A college professor,

Rev. Dr._, gave us a fine sermon, during which I caught the above words;

but the minister included in his "rounded catalogue" letter and spirit,

only the esthetic things, and entirely ignored what I name in the following</I>:)



<P>&nbsp;T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> devilish and the dark, the dying and

diseas'd,

<BR>The countless (nineteen-twentieths) low and evil, crude and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; savage,



<P>&nbsp;The crazed, prisoners in jail, the horrible, rank,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; malignant,

<BR>Venom and filth, serpents, the ravenous sharks, liars, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dissolute;

<BR>(What is the part the wicked and the loathsome bear within

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth's orbic scheme?)

<BR>Newts, crawling things in slime and mud, poisons,

<BR>The barren soil, the evil men, the slag and hideous rot.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MIRAGES</H2></CENTER>

(<I>Noted verbatim after a supper-talk out doors in Nevada with</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

two old miners</I>)



<P>&nbsp;M<FONT SIZE=-1>ORE</FONT> experiences and sights, stranger, than

you'd think

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for;

<BR>Times again, now mostly just after sunrise or before

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sunset,

<BR>Sometimes in spring, oftener in autumn, perfectly clear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; weather, in plain sight,

<BR>Camps far or near, the crowded streets of cities and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shop-fronts,

<BR>(Account for it or not &amp;emdash; credit or not &amp;emdash; it is

all true,

<BR>And my mate there could tell you the like &amp;emdash; we have often

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; confab'd about it,)

<BR>People and scenes, animals, trees, colors and lines, plain as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; could be,

<BR>Farms and dooryards of home, paths border'd with box,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lilacs in corners,

<BR>Weddings in churches, thanksgiving dinners, returns of long-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; absent sons,

<BR>Glum funerals, the crape-veil'd mother and the daughters,

<BR>Trials in courts, jury, and judge, the accused in the box,

<BR>Contestants, battles, crowds, bridges, wharves,

<BR>Now and then mark'd faces of sorrow or joy,

<BR>(I could pick them out this moment if I saw them again,)

<BR>Show'd to me just aloft to the right in the sky-edge,

<BR>Or plainly there to the left on the hill-tops.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

L. OF G.'S PURPORT</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>TO</FONT> to exclude or demarcate, or pick out evils from

their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; formidable masses (even to expose them,)

<BR>But add, fuse, complete, extend &amp;emdash; and celebrate the immortal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the good.



<P>&nbsp;Haughty this song, its words and scope,

<BR>To span vast realms of space and time,

<BR>Evolution &amp;emdash; the cumulative &amp;emdash; growths and generations.



<P>&nbsp;Begun in ripen'd youth and steadily pursued,

<BR>Wandering, peering, dallying with all &amp;emdash; war, peace, day

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; night absorbing,

<BR>Never even for one brief hour abandoning my task,

<BR>I end it here in sickness, poverty, and old age.



<P>&nbsp;I sing of life, yet mind me well of death:

<BR>To-day shadowy Death dogs my steps, my seated shape, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; has for years &amp;emdash;

<BR>Draws sometimes close to me, as face to face.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE UNEXPRESS'D</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>OW</FONT> dare one say it?

<BR>After the cycles, poems, singers, plays,

<BR>Vaunted Ionia's, India's &amp;emdash; Homer, Shakspere &amp;emdash;

the long, long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; times, thick dotted roads, areas,

<BR>The shining clusters and the Milky Ways of stars &amp;emdash; Nature's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pulses reap'd,

<BR>All retrospective passions, heroes, war, love, adoration,

<BR>All ages' plummets dropt to their utmost depths,

<BR>All human lives, throats, wishes, brains &amp;emdash; all experiences'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; utterance;

<BR>After the countless songs, or long or short, all tongues, all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lands,

<BR>Still something not yet told in poesy's voice or print &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; something lacking,

<BR>(Who knows? the best yet unexpress'd and lacking.)

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

GRAND IS THE SEEN</H2></CENTER>

G<FONT SIZE=-1>RAND</FONT> is the seen, the light, to me &amp;emdash; grand

are the sky and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stars,

<BR>Grand is the earth, and grand are lasting time and space,

<BR>And grand their laws, so multiform, puzzling, evolutionary;

<BR>But grander far the unseen soul of me, comprehending, endowing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all those,

<BR>Lighting the light, the sky and stars, delving the earth, sailing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sea,

<BR>(What were all those, indeed, without thee, unseen soul? of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what amount without thee?)

<BR>More evolutionary, vast, puzzling, O my soul!

<BR>More multiform far &amp;emdash; more lasting thou than they.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

UNSEEN BUDS</H2></CENTER>

U<FONT SIZE=-1>NSEEN</FONT> buds, infinite, hidden well,

<BR>Under the snow and ice, under the darkness, in every square

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or cubic inch,

<BR>Germinal, exquisite, in delicate lace, microscopic, unborn,

<BR>Like babes in wombs, latent, folded, compact, sleeping;

<BR>Billions of billions, and trillions of trillions of them waiting,

<BR>(On earth and in the sea &amp;emdash; the universe &amp;emdash; the

stars there in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heavens,)

<BR>Urging slowly, surely forward, forming endless,

<BR>And waiting ever more, forever more behind.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

GOOD-BYE MY FANCY!</H2></CENTER>

G<FONT SIZE=-1>OOD-BYE</FONT> my Fancy!

<BR>Farewell dear mate, dear love!

<BR>I'm going away, I know not where,

<BR>Or to what fortune, or whether I may ever see you again,

<BR>So Good-bye my Fancy.



<P>&nbsp;Now for my last &amp;emdash; let me look back a moment;

<BR>The slower fainter ticking of the clock is in me,

<BR>Exit, nightfall, and soon the heart-thud stopping.



<P>&nbsp;Long have we lived, joy'd, caress'd together;

<BR>Delightful! &amp;emdash; now separation &amp;emdash; Good-bye my Fancy.



<P>&nbsp;Yet let me not be too hasty,

<BR>Long indeed have we lived, slept, filter'd, become really

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blended into one;

<BR>Then if we die we die together, (yes, we'll remain one,)

<BR>If we go anywhere we'll go together to meet what happens,

<BR>May-be we'll be better off and blither, and learn something,

<BR>May-be it is yourself now really ushering me to the true songs,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (who knows?)

<BR>May-be it is you the mortal knob really undoing, turning &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; so now finally,

<BR>Good-bye &amp;emdash; and hail! my Fancy.

<PRE>1891&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1891-2</PRE>

<A NAME="ftn1"></A><SUP><FONT SIZE=-2>*</FONT></SUP><FONT SIZE=-1>Behind

a Good-bye there lurks much of the salutation of another beginning&amp;emdash;to

me, Development, Continuity, Immortality, Transformation, are the chiefest

life-meanings of Nature and Humanity, and are the <I>sine qua non</I> of

all facts, and each fact.</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;<FONT SIZE=-1>Why do folks dwell so fondly on the last words,

advice, appearance, of the departing? Those last words are not samples

of the best, which involve vitality at its full, and balance, and perfect

control and scope. But they are valuable beyond measure to confirm and

endorse the varied train, facts, theories and faith of the whole preceding

life.</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;<A NAME="ftn2"></A><SUP><FONT SIZE=-2>*</FONT></SUP><FONT SIZE=-1>NOTE.

&amp;emdash; <I>Summer country life</I>. &amp;emdash; <I>Several years</I>.

&amp;emdash; In my rambles and explorations I found a woody place near

the creek, where for some reason the birds in happy mood seem'd to resort

in unusual numbers. Especially at the beginning of the day, and again at

the ending, I was sure to get there the most copious bird-concerts. I repair'd

there frequently at sunrise &amp;emdash; and also at sunset, or just before.

. . . Once the question arose in me: Which is the best singing, the first

or the latter-most? The first always exhilarated, and perhaps seem'd more

joyous and stronger; but I always felt the sunset or late afternoon sounds

more penetrating and sweeter &amp;emdash; seem'd to touch the soul &amp;emdash;

often the evening thrushes, two or three of them, responding and perhaps

blending. Though I miss'd some of the mornings, I found myself getting

to be quite strictly punctual at the evening utterances.</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;<FONT SIZE=-1>ANOTHER NOTE. &amp;emdash;"He went out with the

tide and the sunset," was a phrase I heard from a surgeon describing an

old sailor's death under peculiarly gentle conditions.</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;<FONT SIZE=-1>During the Secession War, 1863 and '4, visiting

the Army Hospitals around Washington, I form'd the habit, and continued

it to the end, whenever the ebb or flood tide began the latter part of

the day, of punctually visiting those at that time populous wards of suffering

men. Somehow (or I thought so) the effect of the hour was palpable. The

badly wounded would get some ease, and would like to talk a little, or

be talk'd to. Intellectual and emotional natures would be at their best:

Deaths were always easier; medicines seem'd to have better effect when

given then, and a lulling atmosphere would pervade the wards.</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;<FONT SIZE=-1>Similar influences, similar circumstances and hours,

day-close, after great battles, even with all their horrors. I had more

than once the same experience on the fields cover'd with fallen or dead.</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;

<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Our Old Feuillage</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Our Old Feuillage</I></H1></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>LWAYS</FONT> our old feuillage!

<BR>Always Florida's green peninsula&amp;emdash;always the priceless delta

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of Louisiana&amp;emdash;always the cotton-fields

of Alabama and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Texas,

<BR>Always California's golden hills and hollows, and the silver

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mountains of New Mexico&amp;emdash;always

soft-breath'd Cuba,

<BR>Always the vast slope drain'd by the Southern sea, inseparable

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the slopes drain'd by the Eastern and

Western seas,

<BR>The area the eighty-third year of these States, the three and a half

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; millions of square miles,

<BR>The eighteen thousand miles of sea-coast and bay-coast on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; main, the thirty thousand miles of river navigation,

<BR>The seven millions of distinct families and the same number of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dwellings&amp;emdash;always these, and more,

branching forth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; into numberless branches,

<BR>Always the free range and diversity&amp;emdash;always the continent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of Democracy;

<BR>Always the prairies, pastures, forests, vast cities, travelers, Kanada,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the snows;

<BR>Always these compact lands tied at the hips with the belt stringing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the huge oval lakes;

<BR>Always the West with strong native persons, the increasing density

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there, the habitans, friendly, threatening,

ironical, scorning invaders;

<BR>All sights, South, North, East&amp;emdash;all deeds promiscuously done

at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all times,

<BR>All characters, movements, growths, a few noticed, myriads unnoticed,

<BR>Through Mannahatta's streets I walking, these things gathering,

<BR>On interior rivers by night in the glare of pine knots, steam-boats

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wooding up,

<BR>Sunlight by day on the valley of the Susquehanna, and on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; valleys of the Potomac and Rappahannock, and

the valleys of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Roanoke and Delaware,



<P>&nbsp;In their northerly wilds beasts of prey haunting the Adirondacks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the hills, or lapping the Saginaw waters to

drink,

<BR>In a lonesome inlet a sheldrake lost from the flock, sitting on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the water rocking silently,

<BR>In farmers' barns oxen in the stable, their harvest labor done,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they rest standing, they are too tired,

<BR>Afar on arctic ice the she-walrus lying drowsily while her cubs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; play around,

<BR>The hawk sailing where men have not yet sail'd, the farthest polar

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea, ripply, crystalline, open, beyond the

floes,

<BR>White drift spooning ahead where the ship in the tempest dashes,

<BR>On solid land what is done in cities as the bells strike midnight

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; together,

<BR>In primitive woods the sounds there also sounding, the howl of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wolf, the scream of the panther, and the hoarse

bellow of the elk,

<BR>In winter beneath the hard blue ice of Moosehead lake, in summer

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; visible through the clear waters, the great

trout swimming,

<BR>In lower latitudes in warmer air in the Carolinas the large black

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; buzzard floating slowly high beyond the tree

tops,

<BR>Below, the red cedar festoon'd with tylandria, the pines and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cypresses growing out of the white sand that

spreads far and flat,

<BR>Rude boats descending the big Pedee, climbing plants, parasites with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; color'd flowers and berries enveloping huge

trees,

<BR>The waving drapery on the live-oak trailing long and low, noiselessly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waved by the wind,

<BR>The camp of Georgia wagoners just after dark, the supperfires and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the cooking and eating by whites and negroes,

<BR>Thirty or forty great wagons, the mules, cattle, horses, feeding

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from troughs,

<BR>The shadows, gleams, up under the leaves of the old sycamore-trees,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the flames with the black smoke from the pitch-pine

curling and rising;

<BR>Southern fishermen fishing, the sounds and inlets of North Carolina's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; coast, the shad-fishery and the herring-fishery,

the large

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sweep-seines, the windlasses on shore work'd

by horses, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clearing, curing, and packing-houses;

<BR>Deep in the forest in piney woods turpentine dropping from the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; incisions in the trees, there are the turpentine

works,

<BR>There are the negroes at work in good health, the ground in all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; directions is cover'd with pine straw;

<BR>In Tennessee and Kentucky slaves busy in the coalings, at the forge,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by the furnace-blaze, or at the corn-shucking,

<BR>In Virginia, the planter's son returning after a long absence, joyfully

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; welcom'd and kiss'd by the aged mulatto nurse,

<BR>On rivers boatmen safely moor'd at nightfall in their boats under

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shelter of high banks,

<BR>Some of the younger men dance to the sound of the banjo or fiddle,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; others sit on the gunwale smoking and talking;

<BR>Late in the afternoon the mocking-bird, the American mimic, singing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the Great Dismal Swamp,

<BR>There are the greenish waters, the resinous odor, the plenteous moss,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the cypress-tree, and the juniper-tree;

<BR>Northward, young men of Mannahatta, the target company from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; an excursion returning home at evening, the

musket-muzzles

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all bear bunches of flowers presented by women;

<BR>Children at play, or on his father's lap a young boy fallen asleep,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (how his lips move! how he smiles in his sleep!)

<BR>The scout riding on horseback over the plains west of the Mississippi,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; he ascends a knoll and sweeps his eyes around;

<BR>California life, the miner, bearded, dress'd in his rude costume,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the stanch California friendship, the sweet

air, the graves one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in passing meets solitary just aside the horse-path;

<BR>Down in Texas the cotton-field, the negro-cabins, drivers driving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mules or oxen before rude carts, cotton bales

piled on banks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and wharves;

<BR>Encircling all, vast-darting up and wide, the American Soul,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with equal hemispheres, one Love, one Dilation

or Pride;

<BR>In arriere the peace-talk with the Iroquois the aborigines, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; calumet, the pipe of good-will, arbitration,

and indorsement,



<P>&nbsp;The sachem blowing the smoke first toward the sun and then

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; toward the earth,

<BR>The drama of the scalp-dance enacted with painted faces and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; guttural exclamations,

<BR>The setting out of the war-party, the long and stealthy march,

<BR>The single file, the swinging hatchets, the surprise and slaughter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of enemies;

<BR>All the acts, scenes, ways, persons, attitudes of these States,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reminiscences, institutions,

<BR>All these States compact, every square mile of these States

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; without excepting a particle;

<BR>Me pleas'd, rambling in lanes and country fields, Paumanok's fields,

<BR>Observing the spiral flight of two little yellow butterflies shuffling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; between each other, ascending high in the

air,

<BR>The darting swallow, the destroyer of insects, the fall traveler

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; southward but returning northward early in

the spring,

<BR>The country boy at the close of the day driving the herd of cows
