<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and shouting to them as they loiter to browse

by the roadside,

<BR>The city wharf, Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Charleston,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; New Orleans, San Francisco,

<BR>The departing ships when the sailors heave at the capstan;

<BR>Evening&amp;emdash;me in my room&amp;emdash;the setting sun,

<BR>The setting summer sun shining in my open window, showing the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swarm of flies, suspended, balancing in the

air in the centre of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the room, darting athwart, up and down, casting

swift shadows,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in specks on the opposite wall where the shine

is;

<BR>The athletic American matron speaking in public to crowds of listeners,

<BR>Males, females, immigrants, combinations, the copiousness, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; individuality of the States, each for itself&amp;emdash;the

money-makers,

<BR>Factories, machinery, the mechanical forces, the windlass, lever,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pulley, all certainties,

<BR>The certainty of space, increase, freedom, futurity,

<BR>In space the sporades, the scatter'd islands, the stars&amp;emdash;on

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; firm earth, the lands, my lands,



<P>&nbsp;O lands! all so dear to me&amp;emdash;what you are, (whatever

it is,) I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; putting it at random in these songs, become

a part of that,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whatever it is,

<BR>Southward there, I screaming, with wings slow flapping, with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myriads of gulls wintering along the coasts

of Florida,

<BR>Otherways there atwixt the banks of the Arkansas, the Rio Grande,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Nueces, the Brazos, the Tombigbee, the

Red River, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Saskatchewan or the Osage, I with the spring

waters laughing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and skipping and running,

<BR>Northward, on the sands, on some shallow bay of Paumanok, I with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; parties of snowy herons wading in the wet

to seek worms and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; aquatic plants,

<BR>Retreating, triumphantly twittering, the king-bird, from piercing the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crow with its bill, for amusement&amp;emdash;and

I triumphantly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; twittering,

<BR>The migrating flock of wild geese alighting in autumn to refresh

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; themselves, the body of the flock feed, the

sentinels outside

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; move around with erect heads watching, and

are from time to time

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reliev'd by other sentinels&amp;emdash;and

I feeding and taking turns

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the rest,

<BR>In Kanadian forests the moose, large as an ox, corner'd by hunters,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rising desperately on his hind-feet, and plunging

with his fore-feet,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the hoofs as sharp as knives&amp;emdash;and

I, plunging at the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hunters, corner'd and desperate,

<BR>In the Mannahatta, streets, piers, shipping, store-houses, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; countless workmen working in the shops,

<BR>And I too of the Mannahatta, singing thereof&amp;emdash;and no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; less in myself than the whole of the Mannahatta

in itself,

<BR>Singing the song of These, my ever-united lands&amp;emdash;my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; body no more inevitably united, part to part,

and made out

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of a thousand diverse contributions one identity,

any more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than my lands are inevitably united and made

O<FONT SIZE=-1>NE IDENTITY</FONT>;

<BR>Nativities, climates, the grass of the great pastoral Plains,

<BR>Cities, labors, death, animals, products, war, good and evil

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;these me,

<BR>These affording, in all their particulars, the old feuillage to me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and to America, how can I do less than pass

the clew of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; union of them, to afford the like to you?



<P>&nbsp;Whoever you are! how can I but offer you divine leaves, that you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; also be eligible as I am?

<BR>How can I but as here chanting, invite you for yourself to collect

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bouquets of the incomparable feuillage of

these States?

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : The Sleepers</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>The Sleepers</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>wander</FONT> all night in my vision,

<BR>Stepping with light feet, swiftly and noiselessly stepping and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stopping,



<P>&nbsp;Bending with open eyes over the shut eyes of sleepers,

<BR>Wandering and confused, lost to myself, ill-assorted,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contradictory,

<BR>Pausing, gazing, bending, and stopping.



<P>&nbsp;How solemn they look there, stretch'd and still,

<BR>How quiet they breathe, the little children in their cradles.



<P>&nbsp;The wretched features of ennuy&egrave;s, the white features of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; corpses, the livid faces of drunkards, the sick-gray

faces

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of onanists,

<BR>The gash'd bodies on battle-fields, the insane in their strong-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; door'd rooms, the sacred idiots, the new-born emerging

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from gates, and the dying emerging from gates,

<BR>The night pervades them and infolds them.



<P>&nbsp;The married couple sleep calmly in their bed, he with his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; palm on the hip of the wife, and she with her palm

on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hip of the husband,

<BR>The sisters sleep lovingly side by side in their bed,

<BR>The men sleep lovingly side by side in theirs,

<BR>And the mother sleeps with her little child carefully wrapt.



<P>&nbsp;The blind sleep, and the deaf and dumb sleep,

<BR>The prisoner sleeps well in the prison, the runaway son

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sleeps,

<BR>The murderer that is to be hung next day, how does he sleep?

<BR>And the murder'd person, how does he sleep?



<P>&nbsp;The female that loves unrequited sleeps,

<BR>And the male that loves unrequited sleeps,

<BR>The head of the money-maker that plotted all day sleeps,

<BR>And the enraged and treacherous dispositions, all, all sleep.



<P>&nbsp;I stand in the dark with drooping eyes by the worst-suffering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the most restless,

<BR>I pass my hands soothingly to and fro a few inches from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>The restless sink in their beds, they fitfully sleep.



<P>&nbsp;Now I pierce the darkness, new beings appear,

<BR>The earth recedes from me into the night,



<P>&nbsp;I saw that it was beautiful, and I see that what is not the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth is beautiful.



<P>&nbsp;I go from bedside to bedside, I sleep close with the other

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sleepers each in turn,

<BR>I dream in my dream all the dreams of the other dreamers,

<BR>And I become the other dreamers.



<P>&nbsp;I am a dance&amp;emdash;play up there! the fit is whirling me

fast!



<P>&nbsp;I am the ever-laughing&amp;emdash;it is new moon and twilight,

<BR>I see the hiding of douceurs, I see nimble ghosts whichever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; way I look,

<BR>Cache and cache again deep in the ground and sea, and where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it is neither ground nor sea.



<P>&nbsp;Well do they do their jobs those journeymen divine,

<BR>Only from me can they hide nothing, and would not if they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; could,

<BR>I reckon I am their boss and they make me a pet besides,

<BR>And surround me and lead me and run ahead when I walk,

<BR>To lift their cunning covers to signify me with stretch'd arms,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and resume the way;

<BR>Onward we move, a gay gang of blackguards! with mirth-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shouting music and wild-flapping pennants of joy!



<P>&nbsp;I am the actor, the actress, the voter, the politician,

<BR>The emigrant and the exile, the criminal that stood in the box,

<BR>He who has been famous and he who shall be famous after

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to-day,

<BR>The stammerer, the well-formed person, the wasted or feeble

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; person.



<P>&nbsp;I am she who adorn'd herself and folded her hair expectantly,

<BR>My truant lover has come, and it is dark.



<P>&nbsp;Double yourself and receive me darkness,

<BR>Receive me and my lover too, he will not let me go without

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him.



<P>&nbsp;I roll myself upon you as upon a bed, I resign myself to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dusk.



<P>&nbsp;He whom I call answers me and takes the place of my lover,

<BR>He rises with me silently from the bed.



<P>&nbsp;Darkness, you are gentler than my lover, his flesh was sweaty

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and panting,

<BR>I feel the hot moisture yet that he left me.



<P>&nbsp;My hands are spread forth, I pass them in all directions,

<BR>I would sound up the shadowy shore to which you are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; journeying.



<P>&nbsp;Be careful darkness! already what was it touch'd me?

<BR>I thought my lover had gone, else darkness and he are one,

<BR>I hear the heart-beat, I follow, I fade away.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

I descend my western course, my sinews are flaccid,

<BR>Perfume and youth course through me and I am their wake.



<P>&nbsp;It is my face yellow and wrinkled instead of the old woman's,

<BR>I sit low in a straw-bottom chair and carefully darn my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grandson's stockings.



<P>&nbsp;It is I too, the sleepless widow looking out on the winter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; midnight,

<BR>I see the sparkles of starshine on the icy and pallid earth.



<P>&nbsp;A shroud I see and I am the shroud, I wrap a body and lie in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the coffin,

<BR>It is dark here under ground, it is not evil or pain here, it is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blank here, for reasons.



<P>&nbsp;(It seems to me that every thing in the light and air ought to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be happy,

<BR>Whoever is not in his coffin and the dark grave let him know

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; he has enough.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

I see a beautiful gigantic swimmer swimming naked through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the eddies of the sea,



<P>&nbsp;His brown hair lies close and even to his head, he strikes out

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with courageous arms, he urges himself with his

legs,

<BR>I see his white body, I see his undaunted eyes,

<BR>I hate the swift-running eddies that would dash him head-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; foremost on the rocks.



<P>&nbsp;What are you doing you ruffianly red-trickled waves?

<BR>Will you kill the courageous giant? will you kill him in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prime of his middle age?



<P>&nbsp;Steady and long he struggles,

<BR>He is baffled, bang'd, bruis'd, he holds out while his strength

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; holds out,

<BR>The slapping eddies are spotted with his blood, they bear him away,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they roll him, swing him, turn him,

<BR>His beautiful body is borne in the circling eddies, it is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; continually bruis'd on rocks,

<BR>Swiftly and out of sight is borne the brave corpse.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

I turn but do not extricate myself,

<BR>Confused, a past-reading, another, but with darkness yet.



<P>&nbsp;The beach is cut by the razory ice-wind, the wreck-guns

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sound,

<BR>The tempest lulls, the moon comes floundering through the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drifts.



<P>&nbsp;I look where the ship helplessly heads end on, I hear the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; burst as she strikes, I hear the howls of dismay,

they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grow fainter and fainter.



<P>&nbsp;I cannot aid with my wringing fingers,

<BR>I can but rush to the surf and let it drench me and freeze upon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me.



<P>&nbsp;I search with the crowd, not one of the company is wash'd to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; us alive,

<BR>In the morning I help pick up the dead and lay them in rows

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in a barn.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>5</CENTER>

Now of the older war-days, the defeat at Brooklyn,

<BR>Washington stands inside the lines, he stands on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; intrench'd hills amid a crowd of officers,

<BR>His face is cold and damp, he cannot repress the weeping

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drops,

<BR>He lifts the glass perpetually to his eyes, the color is blanch'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from his cheeks,

<BR>He sees the slaughter of the southern braves confided to him

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by their parents.



<P>&nbsp;The same at last and at last when peace is declared,

<BR>He stands in the room of the old tavern, the well-belov'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soldiers all pass through,

<BR>The officers speechless and slow draw near in their turns,

<BR>The chief encircles their necks with his arm and kisses them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on the cheek,

<BR>He kisses lightly the wet cheeks one after another, he shakes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hands and bids good-by to the army.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>6</CENTER>

Now what my mother told me one day as we sat at dinner

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; together,

<BR>Of when she was a nearly grown girl living home with her

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; parents on the old homestead.



<P>&nbsp;A red squaw came one breakfast-time to the old homestead,

<BR>On her back she carried a bundle of rushes for rush-bottoming

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chairs,

<BR>Her hair, straight, shiny, coarse, black, profuse, half-envelop'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her face,

<BR>Her step was free and elastic, and her voice sounded

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; exquisitely as she spoke.



<P>&nbsp;My mother looked in delight and amazement at the stranger,

<BR>She look'd at the freshness of her tall-borne face and full and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pliant limbs,

<BR>The more she look'd upon her she loved her,

<BR>Never before had she seen such wonderful beauty and purity,



<P>&nbsp;She made her sit on a bench by the jamb of the fireplace, she

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cook'd food for her,

<BR>She had no work to give her, but she gave her remembrance

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and fondness.



<P>&nbsp;The red squaw staid all the forenoon, and toward the middle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the afternoon she went away,

<BR>O my mother was loth to have her go away,

<BR>All the week she thought of her, she watch'd for her many a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; month,

<BR>She remember'd her many a winter and many a summer,

<BR>But the red squaw never came nor was heard of there again.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>7</CENTER>

A show of the summer softness&amp;emdash;a contact of something unseen

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;an amour of the light and air,

<BR>I am jealous and overwhelm'd with friendliness,

<BR>And will go gallivant with the light and air myself.



<P>&nbsp;O love and summer, you are in the dreams and in me,

<BR>Autumn and winter are in the dreams, the farmer goes with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his thrift,

<BR>The droves and crops increase, the barns are well-fill'd.



<P>&nbsp;Elements merge in the night, ships make tacks in the dreams,

<BR>The sailor sails, the exile returns home,

<BR>The fugitive returns unharm'd, the immigrant is back beyond

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; months and years,

<BR>The poor Irishman lives in the simple house of his childhood

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the well-known neighbors and faces,

<BR>They warmly welcome him, he is barefoot again, he forgets

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; he is well off,

<BR>The Dutchman voyages home, and the Scotchman and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Welshman voyage home, and the native of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mediterranean voyages home,

<BR>To every port of England, France, Spain, enter well-fill'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ships,

<BR>The Swiss foots it toward his hills, the Prussian goes his way,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Hungarian his way, and the Pole his way,

<BR>The Swede returns, and the Dane and Norwegian return.



<P>&nbsp;The homeward bound and the outward bound,

<BR>The beautiful lost swimmer, the ennuy&egrave;e, the onanist, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; female that loves unrequited, the money-maker,

<BR>The actor and actress, those through with their parts and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those waiting to commence,

<BR>The affectionate boy, the husband and wife, the voter, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nominee that is chosen and the nominee that has

fail'd,

<BR>The great already known and the great any time after to-day,

<BR>The stammerer, the sick, the perfect-form'd, the homely,

<BR>The criminal that stood in the box, the judge that sat and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sentenced him, the fluent lawyers, the jury, the

audience,

<BR>The laugher and weeper, the dancer, the midnight widow, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; red squaw,

<BR>The consumptive, the erysipalite, the idiot, he that is wrong'd,

<BR>The antipodes, and every one between this and them in the dark,

<BR>I swear they are averaged now&amp;emdash;one is no better than the

other,

<BR>The night and sleep have liken'd them and restored them.



<P>&nbsp;I swear they are all beautiful,

<BR>Every one that sleeps is beautiful, every thing in the dim light

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is beautiful,

<BR>The wildest and bloodiest is over, and all is peace.



<P>&nbsp;Peace is always beautiful,

<BR>The myth of heaven indicates peace and night.



<P>&nbsp;The myth of heaven indicates the soul,

<BR>The soul is always beautiful, it appears more or it appears less,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it comes or it lags behind,

<BR>It comes from its embower'd garden and looks pleasantly on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself and encloses the world,

<BR>Perfect and clean the genitals previously jetting, and perfect

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and clean the womb cohering,

<BR>The head well-grown proportion'd and plumb, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bowels and joints proportion'd and plumb.



<P>&nbsp;The soul is always beautiful,

<BR>The universe is duly in order, every thing is in its place,

<BR>What has arrived is in its place and what waits shall be in its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; place,



<P>&nbsp;The twisted skull waits, the watery or rotten blood waits,

<BR>The child of the glutton or venerealee waits long, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; child of the drunkard waits long, and the drunkard

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; himself waits long,

<BR>The sleepers that lived and died wait, the far advanced are to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; go on in their turns, and the far behind are to

come on in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their turns,

<BR>The diverse shall be no less diverse, but they shall flow and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unite&amp;emdash;they unite now.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>8</CENTER>

The sleepers are very beautiful as they lie unclothed,

<BR>They flow hand in hand over the whole earth from east to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; west as they lie unclothed,

<BR>The Asiatic and African are hand in hand, the European and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; American are hand in hand,

<BR>Learn'd and unlearn'd are hand in hand, and male and female

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are hand in hand,

<BR>The bare arm of the girl crosses the bare breast of her lover,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they press close without lust, his lips press her

neck,

<BR>The father holds his grown or ungrown son in his arms

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with measureless love, and the son holds the father

in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his arms with measureless love,

<BR>The white hair of the mother shines on the white wrist of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; daughter,

<BR>The breath of the boy goes with the breath of the man, friend is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inarm'd by friend,

<BR>The scholar kisses the teacher and the teacher kisses the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; scholar, the wrong'd is made right,

<BR>The call of the slave is one with the master's call, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; master salutes the slave,

<BR>The felon steps forth from the prison, the insane becomes sane,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the suffering of sick persons is reliev'd,

<BR>The sweatings and fevers stop, the throat that was unsound is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sound, the lungs of the consumptive are resumed,

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poor distress'd head is free,

<BR>The joints of the rheumatic move as smoothly as ever, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; smoother than ever,

<BR>Stiflings and passages open, the paralyzed become supple,



<P>&nbsp;They swell'd and convuls'd and congested awake to themselves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in condition,

<BR>They pass the invigoration of the night and the chemistry of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the night, and awake.



<P>&nbsp;I too pass from the night,

<BR>I stay a while away O night, but I return to you again and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; love you.



<P>&nbsp;Why should I be afraid to trust myself to you?

<BR>I am not afraid, I have been well brought forward by you,

<BR>I love the rich running day, but I do not desert her in whom I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lay so long,

<BR>I know not how I came of you and I know not where I go

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with you, but I know I came well and shall go well.



<P>&nbsp;I will stop only a time with the night, and rise betimes,

<BR>I will duly pass the day O my mother, and duly return to you.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1855&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TRANSPOSITIONS</H2></CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>et</FONT> the reformers descend from the stands where they

are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forever bawling&amp;emdash;let an idiot or insane

person appear on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; each of the stands;

<BR>Let judges and criminals be transposed&amp;emdash;let the prison-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; keepers be put in prison&amp;emdash;let those that

were prisoners

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; take the keys;

<BR>Let them that distrust birth and death lead the rest.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Passage to India</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Passage to India</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>inging</FONT> my days,

<BR>Singing the great achievements of the present,

<BR>Singing the strong light works of engineers,

<BR>Our modern wonders, (the antique ponderous Seven outvied,)

<BR>In the Old World the east the Suez canal,

<BR>The New by its mighty railroad spann'd,

<BR>The seas inlaid with eloquent gentle wires;

<BR>Yet first to sound, and ever sound, the cry with thee O soul,

<BR>The Past! the Past! the Past!



<P>&nbsp;The Past&amp;emdash;the dark unfathom'd retrospect!

<BR>The teeming gulf&amp;emdash;the sleepers and the shadows!

<BR>The past&amp;emdash;the infinite greatness of the past!

<BR>For what is the present after all but a growth out of the past?

<BR>(As a projectile form'd, impell'd, passing a certain line, still

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; keeps on,

<BR>So the present, utterly form'd, impell'd by the past.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

Passage O soul to India!

<BR>Eclaircise the myths Asiatic, the primitive fables.

<BR>Not you alone proud truths of the world,

<BR>Nor you alone ye facts of modern science,

<BR>But myths and fables of eld, Asia's, Africa's fables,

<BR>The far-darting beams of the spirit, the unloos'd dreams,

<BR>The deep diving bibles and legends,

<BR>The daring plots of the poets, the elder religions;

<BR>O you temples fairer than lilies pour'd over by the rising

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sun!

<BR>O you fables spurning the known, eluding the hold of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; known, mounting to heaven!

<BR>You lofty and dazzling towers, pinnacled, red as roses,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; burnish'd with gold!

<BR>Towers of fables immortal fashion'd from mortal dreams!

<BR>You too I welcome and fully the same as the rest!

<BR>You too with joy I sing.



<P>&nbsp;Passage to India!

<BR>Lo, soul, seest thou not God's purpose from the first?

<BR>The earth to be spann'd, connected by network,

<BR>The races, neighbors, to marry and be given in marriage,

<BR>The oceans to be cross'd, the distant brought near,

<BR>The lands to be welded together.



<P>&nbsp;A worship new I sing,

<BR>You captains, voyagers, explorers, yours,

<BR>You engineers, you architects, machinists, yours,

<BR>You, not for trade or transportation only,

<BR>But in God's name, and for thy sake O soul.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

Passage to India!

<BR>Lo soul for thee of tableaus twain,

<BR>I see in one the Suez canal initiated, open'd,

<BR>I see the procession of steamships, the Empress Eugenie's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leading the van,

<BR>I mark from on deck the strange landscape, the pure sky, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; level sand in the distance,

<BR>I pass swiftly the picturesque groups, the workmen gather'd,

<BR>The gigantic dredging machines.



<P>&nbsp;In one again, different, (yet thine, all thine, O soul, the same,)

<BR>I see over my own continent the Pacific railroad surmounting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every barrier,

<BR>I see continual trains of cars winding along the Platte carrying

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; freight and passengers,

<BR>I hear the locomotives rushing and roaring, and the shrill

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steam-whistle,

<BR>I hear the echoes reverberate through the grandest scenery in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the world,

<BR>I cross the Laramie plains, I note the rocks in grotesque

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shapes, the buttes,

<BR>I see the plentiful larkspur and wild onions, the barren,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; colorless, sage-deserts,

<BR>I see in glimpses afar or towering immediately above me the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; great mountains, I see the Wind river and the Wahsatch

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mountains,

<BR>I see the Monument mountain and the Eagle's Nest, I pass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Promontory, I ascend the Nevadas,

<BR>I scan the noble Elk mountain and wind around its base,

<BR>I see the Humboldt range, I thread the valley and cross the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; river,

<BR>I see the clear waters of lake Tahoe, I see forests of majestic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pines,

<BR>Or crossing the great desert, the alkaline plains, I behold

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; enchanting mirages of waters and meadows,

<BR>Marking through these and after all, in duplicate slender

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lines,

<BR>Bridging the three or four thousand miles of land travel,

<BR>Tying the Eastern to the Western sea,

<BR>The road between Europe and Asia.

<BR>(Ah Genoese thy dream! thy dream!

<BR>Centuries after thou art laid in thy grave,

<BR>The shore thou foundest verifies thy dream.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

Passage to India!

<BR>Struggles of many a captain, tales of many a sailor dead,

<BR>Over my mood stealing and spreading they come,

<BR>Like clouds and cloudlets in the unreach'd sky.



<P>&nbsp;Along all history, down the slopes,

<BR>As a rivulet running, sinking now, and now again to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; surface rising,

<BR>A ceaseless thought, a varied train&amp;emdash;lo, soul, to thee, thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sight, they rise,

<BR>The plans, the voyages again, the expeditions;

<BR>Again Vasco de Gama sails forth,

<BR>Again the knowledge gain'd, the mariner's compass,

<BR>Lands found and nations born, thou born America,

<BR>For purpose vast, man's long probation fill'd,

<BR>Thou rondure of the world at last accomplish'd.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>5</CENTER>

O vast Rondure, swimming in space,

<BR>Cover'd all over with visible power and beauty,

<BR>Alternate light and day and the teeming spiritual darkness,

<BR>Unspeakable high processions of sun and moon and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; countless stars above,

<BR>Below, the manifold grass and waters, animals, mountains,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trees,

<BR>With inscrutable purpose, some hidden prophetic intention,

<BR>Now first it seems my thought begins to span thee.

<BR>Down from the gardens of Asia descending radiating,

<BR>Adam and Eve appear, then their myriad progeny after

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>Wandering, yearning, curious, with restless explorations,

<BR>With questionings, baffled, formless, feverish, with never-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; happy hearts,

<BR>With that sad incessant refrain, <I>Wherefore unsatisfied soul</I>?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and <I>Whither O mocking life</I>?

<BR>Ah who shall soothe these feverish children?

<BR>Who justify these restless explorations?

<BR>Who speak the secret of impassive earth?

<BR>Who bind it to us? what is this separate Nature so unnatural?

<BR>What is this earth to our affections? (unloving earth, without

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a throb to answer ours,

<BR>Cold earth, the place of graves.)



<P>&nbsp;Yet soul be sure the first intent remains, and shall be carried

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; out,

<BR>Perhaps even now the time has arrived.

<BR>After the seas are all cross'd, (as they seem already cross'd,)

<BR>After the great captains and engineers have accomplish'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their work,

<BR>After the noble inventors, after the scientists, the chemist, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; geologist, ethnologist,

<BR>Finally shall come the poet worthy that name,

<BR>The true son of God shall come singing his songs.

<BR>Then not your deeds only O voyagers, O scientists and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inventors, shall be justified,

<BR>All these hearts as of fretted children shall be sooth'd,

<BR>All affection shall be fully responded to, the secret shall be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; told,

<BR>All these separations and gaps shall be taken up and hook'd and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; link'd together,

<BR>The whole earth, this cold, impassive, voiceless earth, shall

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be completely justified,

<BR>Trinitas divine shall be gloriously accomplish'd and compacted

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by the true son of God, the poet,

<BR>(He shall indeed pass the straits and conquer the mountains,

<BR>He shall double the cape of Good Hope to some purpose,)

<BR>Nature and Man shall be disjoin'd and diffused no more,

<BR>The true son of God shall absolutely fuse them.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>6</CENTER>

Year at whose wide-flung door I sing!

<BR>Year of the purpose accomplish'd!

<BR>Year of the marriage of continents, climates and oceans!

<BR>(No mere doge of Venice now wedding the Adriatic,)

<BR>I see O year in you the vast terraqueous globe given and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; giving all,

<BR>Europe to Asia, Africa join'd, and they to the New World,

<BR>The lands, geographies, dancing before you, holding a festival

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; garland,

<BR>As brides and bridegrooms hand in hand.



<P>&nbsp;Passage to India!

<BR>Cooling airs from Caucasus, far, soothing cradle of man,

<BR>The river Euphrates flowing, the past lit up again.



<P>&nbsp;Lo soul, the retrospect brought forward,

<BR>The old, most populous, wealthiest of earth's lands,

<BR>The streams of the Indus and the Ganges and their many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; affluents,

<BR>(I my shores of America walking to-day behold, resuming all,)

<BR>The tale of Alexander on his warlike marches suddenly dying,

<BR>On one side China and on the other side Persia and Arabia,

<BR>To the south the great seas and the bay of Bengal,

<BR>The flowing literatures, tremendous epics, religions, castes,

<BR>Old occult Brahma interminably far back, the tender and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; junior Buddha,

<BR>Central and southern empires and all their belongings,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; possessors,

<BR>The wars of Tamerlane, the reign of Aurungzebe,

<BR>The traders, rulers, explorers, Moslems, Venetians, Byzantium,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Arabs, Portuguese,

<BR>The first travelers famous yet, Marco Polo, Batouta the Moor,

<BR>Doubts to be solv'd, the map incognita, blanks to be fill'd,

<BR>The foot of man unstay'd, the hands never at rest,

<BR>Thyself O soul that will not brook a challenge.



<P>&nbsp;The mediaeval navigators rise before me,

<BR>The world of 1492, with its awaken'd enterprise,

<BR>Something swelling in humanity now like the sap of the earth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in spring,

<BR>The sunset splendor of chivalry declining.

<BR>And who art thou sad shade?

<BR>Gigantic, visionary, thyself a visionary,

<BR>With majestic limbs and pious beaming eyes,

<BR>Spreading around with every look of thine a golden world,

<BR>Enhuing it with gorgeous hues.



<P>&nbsp;As the chief histrion,

<BR>Down to the footlights walks in some great scena,

<BR>Dominating the rest I see the Admiral himself,

<BR>(History's type of courage, action, faith,)



<P>&nbsp;Behold him sail from Palos leading his little fleet,

<BR>His voyage behold, his return, his great fame,

<BR>His misfortunes, calumniators, behold him a prisoner,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chain'd,

<BR>Behold his dejection, poverty, death.



<P>&nbsp;(Curious in time I stand, noting the efforts of heroes,

<BR>Is the deferment long? bitter the slander, poverty, death?

<BR>Lies the seed unreck'd for centuries in the ground? lo, to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; God's due occasion,

<BR>Uprising in the night, it sprouts, blooms,

<BR>And fills the earth with use and beauty.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>7</CENTER>

Passage indeed O soul to primal thought,

<BR>Not lands and seas alone, thy own clear freshness,

<BR>The young maturity of brood and bloom,

<BR>To realms of budding bibles.



<P>&nbsp;O soul, repressless, I with thee and thou with me,

<BR>Thy circumnavigation of the world begin,

<BR>Of man, the voyage of his mind's return,

<BR>To reason's early paradise,

<BR>Back, back to wisdom's birth, to innocent intuitions,

<BR>Again with fair creation.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>8</CENTER>

O we can wait no longer,

<BR>We too take ship O soul,

<BR>Joyous we too launch out on trackless seas,

<BR>Fearless for unknown shores on waves of ecstasy to sail,

<BR>Amid the wafting winds, (thou pressing me to thee, I thee to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me, O soul,)

<BR>Caroling free, singing our song of God,

<BR>Chanting our chant of pleasant exploration.

<BR>With laugh and many a kiss,

<BR>(Let others deprecate, let others weep for sin, remorse,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; humiliation,)

<BR>O soul thou pleasest me, I thee.

<BR>Ah more than any priest O soul we too believe in God,

<BR>But with the mystery of God we dare not dally.



<P>&nbsp;O soul thou pleasest me, I thee,

<BR>Sailing these seas or on the hills, or waking in the night,

<BR>Thoughts, silent thoughts, of Time and Space and Death, like

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waters flowing,

<BR>Bear me indeed as through the regions infinite,

<BR>Whose air I breathe, whose ripples hear, lave me all over,

<BR>Bathe me O God in thee, mounting to thee,

<BR>I and my soul to range in range of thee.



<P>&nbsp;O Thou transcendent,

<BR>Nameless, the fibre and the breath,

<BR>Light of the light, shedding forth universes, thou centre of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>Thou mightier centre of the true, the good, the loving,

<BR>Thou moral, spiritual fountain&amp;emdash;affection's source&amp;emdash;thou

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reservoir,

<BR>(O pensive soul of me&amp;emdash;O thirst unsatisfied&amp;emdash;waitest

not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there?

<BR>Waitest not haply for us somewhere there the Comrade perfect?)

<BR>Thou pulse&amp;emdash;thou motive of the stars, suns, systems,

<BR>That, circling, move in order, safe, harmonious,

<BR>Athwart the shapeless vastnesses of space,

<BR>How should I think, how breathe a single breath, how speak,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; if, out of myself,

<BR>I could not launch, to those, superior universes?



<P>&nbsp;Swiftly I shrivel at the thought of God,

<BR>At Nature and its wonders, Time and Space and Death,

<BR>But that I, turning, call to thee O soul, thou actual Me,

<BR>And lo, thou gently masterest the orbs,

<BR>Thou matest Time, smilest content at Death,

<BR>And fillest, swellest full the vastnesses of Space.



<P>&nbsp;Greater than stars or suns,

<BR>Bounding O soul thou journeyest forth;

<BR>What love than thine and ours could wider amplify?

<BR>What aspirations, wishes, outvie thine and ours O soul?



<P>&nbsp;What dreams of the ideal? what plans of purity, perfection,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strength,

<BR>What cheerful willingness for others' sake to give up all?

<BR>For others' sake to suffer all?



<P>&nbsp;Reckoning ahead O soul, when thou, the time achiev'd,

<BR>The seas all cross'd, weather'd the capes, the voyage done,

<BR>Surrounded, copest, frontest God, yieldest, the aim attain'd,

<BR>As fill'd with friendship, love complete, the Elder Brother

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; found,

<BR>The Younger melts in fondness in his arms.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>9</CENTER>

Passage to more than India!

<BR>Are thy wings plumed indeed for such far flights?

<BR>O soul, voyagest thou indeed on voyages like those?

<BR>Disportest thou on waters such as those?

<BR>Soundest below the Sanscrit and the Vedas?

<BR>Then have thy bent unleash'd.



<P>&nbsp;Passage to you, your shores, ye aged fierce enigmas!

<BR>Passage to you, to mastership of you, ye strangling problems!

<BR>You, strew'd with the wrecks of skeletons, that, living, never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reach'd you.



<P>&nbsp;Passage to more than India!

<BR>O secret of the earth and sky!

<BR>Of you O waters of the sea! O winding creeks and rivers!

<BR>Of you O woods and fields! of you strong mountains of my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land!

<BR>Of you O prairies! of you gray rocks!

<BR>O morning red! O clouds! O rain and snows!

<BR>O day and night, passage to you!

<BR>O sun and moon and all you stars! Sirius and Jupiter!

<BR>Passage to you!



<P>&nbsp;Passage, immediate passage! the blood burns in my veins!

<BR>Away O soul! hoist instantly the anchor!

<BR>Cut the hawsers&amp;emdash;haul out&amp;emdash;shake out every sail!

<BR>Have we not stood here like trees in the ground long enough?



<P>&nbsp;Have we not grovel'd here long enough, eating and drinking

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; like mere brutes?

<BR>Have we not darken'd and dazed ourselves with books long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; enough?



<P>&nbsp;Sail forth&amp;emdash;steer for the deep waters only,

<BR>Reckless O soul, exploring, I with thee, and thou with me,

<BR>For we are bound where mariner has not yet dared to go,

<BR>And we will risk the ship, ourselves and all.



<P>&nbsp;O my brave soul!

<BR>O farther farther sail!

<BR>O daring joy, but safe! are they not all the seas of God?

<BR>O farther, farther, farther sail!



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>(1868)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : From Noon to Starry Night</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>From Noon to Starry Night</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THOU ORB ALOFT FULL-DAZZLING</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HOU</FONT> orb full-dazzling! thou hot October noon!

<BR>Flooding with sheeny light the gray beach sand,

<BR>The sibilant near sea with vistas far and foam,

<BR>And tawny streaks and shades and spreading blue;

<BR>O sun of noon refulgent! my special word to thee.



<P>&nbsp;Hear me illustrious!

<BR>Thy lover me, for always I have loved thee,

<BR>Even as basking babe, then happy boy alone by some

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wood edge, thy touching-distant beams enough,

<BR>Or man matured, or young or old, as now to thee I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; launch my invocation.



<P>&nbsp;(Thou canst not with thy dumbness me deceive,

<BR>I know before the fitting man all Nature yields,

<BR>Though answering not in words, the skies, trees,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hear his voice&amp;emdash;and thou O sun,

<BR>As for thy throes, thy perturbations, sudden breaks

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and shafts of flame gigantic,

<BR>I understand them, I know those flames, those

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; perturbations well.)



<P>&nbsp;Thou that with fructifying heat and light,

<BR>O'er myriad farms, o'er lands and waters North

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and South,

<BR>O'er Mississippi's endless course, o'er Texas'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grassy plains, Kanada's woods,

<BR>O'er all the globe that turns its face to thee shining

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in space,

<BR>Thou that impartially infoldest all, not only continents,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seas,

<BR>Thou that to grapes and weeds and little wild

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flowers givest so liberally,



<P>&nbsp;Shed, shed thyself on mine and me, with but a fleeting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ray out of thy million millions,

<BR>Strike though these chants.



<P>&nbsp;Nor only launch thy subtle dazzle and thy strength

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for these,

<BR>Prepare the later afternoon of me myself&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prepare my lengthening shadows,

<BR>Prepare my starry nights.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FACES</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>S<FONT SIZE=-1>AUNTERING</FONT> the pavement or riding the country by-road,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lo, such faces!

<BR>Faces of friendship, precision, caution, sauvity, ideality,

<BR>The spiritual-prescient face, the always welcome common

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; benevolent face,

<BR>The face of the singing of music, the grand faces of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; natural lawyers and judges broad at the back-top,

<BR>The faces of hunters and fishers bulged at the brows,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the shaved blanch'd faces of orthodox citizens,

<BR>The pure, extravagant, yearning, questioning artist's face,

<BR>The ugly face of some beautiful soul, the handsome

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; detested or despised face,

<BR>The sacred faces of infants, the illuminated face of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mother of many children,

<BR>The face of an amour, the face of veneration,

<BR>The face as of a dream, the face of an immobile rock,

<BR>The face withdrawn of its good and bad, a castrated

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; face,

<BR>A wild hawk, his wings clipp'd by the clipper,

<BR>A stallion that yielded at last to the thongs and knife

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the gelder.



<P>&nbsp;Sauntering the pavement thus, or crossing the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ceaseless ferry, faces and faces and faces,

<BR>I see them and complain not, and am content with all.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Do you suppose I could be content with all if I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thought them their own final&egrave;?



<P>&nbsp;This now is too lamentable a face for a man,

<BR>Some abject louse asking leave to be, cringing for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it,

<BR>Some milk-nosed maggot blessing what lets it wrig

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to its hole.



<P>&nbsp;This face is a dog's snout sniffing for garbage,

<BR>Snakes nest in that mouth, I hear the sibilant threat.



<P>&nbsp;This face is a haze more chill than the arctic sea,

<BR>Its sleepy and wabbling icebergs crunch as they go.



<P>&nbsp;This is a face of bitter herbs, this an emetic, they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; need no label,

<BR>And more of the drug-shelf, laudanum, caoutchouc,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or hog'slard.



<P>&nbsp;This face is an epilepsy, its wordless tongue gives

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; out the earthly cry,

<BR>Its veins down the neck distend, its eyes roll till

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they show nothing but their whites,

<BR>Its teeth grit, the palms of the hands are cut by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; turn'd-in nails,

<BR>The man falls struggling and foaming to the ground,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; while he speculates well.



<P>&nbsp;This face is bitten by vermin and worms,

<BR>And this is some murderer's knife with a half-pull'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; scabbard.



<P>&nbsp;This face owes to the sexton his dismalest fee,

<BR>An unceasing death-bell tolls there.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>Features of my equals would you trick me with your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; creas'd and cadaverous march?

<BR>Well, you cannot trick me.



<P>&nbsp;I see your rounded never-erased flow,

<BR>I see 'neath the rims of your haggard and mean

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; disguises.



<P>&nbsp;Splay and twist as you like, poke with the tangling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fores of fishes or rats,

<BR>You'll be unmuzzled, you certainly will.



<P>&nbsp;I saw the face of the most smear'd and slobbering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; idiot they had at the asylum,

<BR>And I knew for my consolation what they knew not,

<BR>I knew of the agents that emptied and broke my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brother,

<BR>The same wait to clear the rubbish from the fallen

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tenement,

<BR>And I shall look again in a score or two of ages,

<BR>And I shall meet the real landlord perfect and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unharm'd, every inch as good as myself.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>The Lord advances, and yet advances,

<BR>Always the shadow in front, always the reach'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hand bringing up the laggards.



<P>&nbsp;Out of this face emerge banners and horses&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; O superb! I see what is coming,

<BR>I see the high pioneer-caps, see staves of runners

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clearing the way,

<BR>I hear victorious drums.



<P>&nbsp;This face is a life-boat,

<BR>This is the face commanding and bearded, it asks no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; odds of the rest,

<BR>This face is flavor'd fruit ready for eating,

<BR>This face of a healthy honest boy is the programme

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of all good.



<P>&nbsp;These faces bear testimony slumbering or awake,

<BR>They show their descent from the Master himself.



<P>&nbsp;Off the word I have spoken I except not one&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; red, white, black, are all deific,

<BR>In each house is the ovum, it comes forth after a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thousand years.



<P>&nbsp;Spots or cracks at the windows do not disturb me,

<BR>Tall and sufficient stand behind and make signs to me,

<BR>I read the promise and patiently wait.



<P>&nbsp;This is a full-grown lily's face,

<BR>She speaks to the limber-hipp'd man near the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; garden pickets,

<BR><I>Come here</I> she blushingly cries, <I>Come night</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me limberhipp'd man,</I>

<BR><I>Stand at my side till I lean as high as I can</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon you</I>,

<BR><I>Fill me with albescent honey, bend down to me</I>,

<BR><I>Rub to me with your chafing beard, rub to my</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breast and shoulders</I>.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>The old face of the mother of many children,

<BR>Whist! I am fully content.



<P>&nbsp;Lull'd and late is the smoke of the First-day morning,

<BR>It hangs low over the rows of trees by the fences,

<BR>It hangs thin by the sassafras and wild-cherry and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cat-brier under them.



<P>&nbsp;I saw the rich ladies in full dress at the soiree,

<BR>I heard what the singers were singing so long,

<BR>Heard who sprang in crimson youth from the white

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; froth and the water-blue.



<P>&nbsp;Behold a woman!

<BR>She looks out from her quaker cap, her face is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clearer and more beautiful than the sky.



<P>&nbsp;She sits in an armchair under the shaded porch

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the farmhouse,

<BR>The sun just shines on her old white head.



<P>&nbsp;Her ample gown is of cream-hued linen,

<BR>Her grandsons raised the flax, and her grand-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; daughters spin it with the distaff and the wheel.



<P>&nbsp;The melodious character of the earth,

<BR>The finish beyond which philosophy cannot go

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and does not wish to go,

<BR>The justified mother of men.

<PRE>1855&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE MYSTIC TRUMPETER</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>H<FONT SIZE=-1>ARK</FONT>, some wild trumpeter, some strange musician,

<BR>Hovering unseen in air, vibrates capricious tunes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to-night.



<P>&nbsp;I hear thee trumpeter, listening alert I catch thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; notes,

<BR>Now pouring, whirling like a tempest round me,

<BR>Now low, subdued, now in the distance lost.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Come nearer bodiless one, haply in thee resounds

<BR>Some dead composer, haply thy pensive life

<BR>Was fill'd with aspirations high, unform'd ideals,

<BR>Waves, oceans musical, chaotically surging,

<BR>That now ecstatic ghost, close to me bending,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy cornet echoing, pealing,

<BR>Gives out to no one's ears but mine, but freely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gives to mine,

<BR>That I may thee translate.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>Blow trumpeter free and clear, I follow thee,

<BR>While at thy liquid prelude, glad, serene,

<BR>The fretting world, the streets, the noisy hours of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day withdraw,

<BR>A holy calm descends like dew upon me,

<BR>I walk in cool refreshing night the walks of Paradise,

<BR>I scent the grass, the moist air and the roses;

<BR>Thy song expands my numb'd imbonded spirit,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thou freest, launchest me,

<BR>Floating and basking upon heaven's lake.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>Blow again trumpeter! and for my sensuous eyes,

<BR>Bring the old pageants, show the feudal world.



<P>&nbsp;What charm thy music works! thou makest pass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before me,

<BR>Ladies and cavaliers long dead, barons are in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their castle halls, the troubadours are singing,

<BR>Arm'd knights go forth to redress wrongs, some

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in quest of the holy Graal;

<BR>I see the tournament, I see the contestants incased

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in heavy armor seated on stately champing

horses,

<BR>I hear the shouts, the sounds of blows and smiting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steel;



<P>&nbsp;I see the Crusaders' tumultuous armies&amp;emdash;hark,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; how the cymbals clang,

<BR>Lo, where the monks walk in advance, bearing the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cross on high.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>Blow again trumpeter! and for thy theme,

<BR>Take now the enclosing theme of all, the solvent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the setting,

<BR>Love, that is pulse of all, the sustenance and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the pang,

<BR>The heart of man and woman all for love,

<BR>No other theme but love&amp;emdash;knitting,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; enclosing, all-diffusing love.



<P>&nbsp;O how the immortal phantoms crowd around me!

<BR>I see the vast alembic ever working, I see and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know the flames that heat the world,

<BR>The glow, the blush, the beating hearts of lovers,

<BR>So blissful happy some, and some so silent, dark,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and nigh to death;

<BR>Love, that is all the earth to lovers&amp;emdash;love,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that mocks time and space,

<BR>Love, that is day and night&amp;emdash;love, that is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sun and moon and stars,

<BR>Love, that is crimson, sumptuous, sick with perfume,

<BR>No other words but words of love, no other thought

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but love.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>Blow again trumpeter&amp;emdash;conjure war's alarums.



<P>&nbsp;Swift to thy spell a shuddering hum like distant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thunder rolls,

<BR>Lo, where the arm'd men hasten&amp;emdash;lo, mid the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clouds of dust the glint of bayonets,

<BR>I see the grime-faced cannoneers, I mark the rosy flash

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amid the smoke, I hear the cracking of the

guns;

<BR>Nor war alone&amp;emdash;thy fearful music-song, wild

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prayer, brings every sight of fear,

<BR>The deeds of ruthless brigands, rapine, murder&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I hear the cries for help!

<BR>I see ships foundering at sea, I behold on deck and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; below deck the terrible tableaus.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>O trumpeter, methinks I am myself the instrument

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thou playest,

<BR>Thou melt'st my heart, my brain&amp;emdash;thou movest,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drawest, changest them at will;

<BR>And now thy sullen notes send darkness through me,

<BR>Thou takest away all cheering light, all hope,

<BR>I see the enslaved, the overthrown, the hurt, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; opprest of the whole earth,

<BR>I feel the measureless shame and humiliation of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my race, it becomes all mine,

<BR>Mine too the revenges of humanity, the wrongs of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ages, baffled feuds and hatreds,

<BR>Utter defeat upon me weighs&amp;emdash;all lost&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the foe victorious,

<BR>(Yet 'mid the ruins Pride colossal stands unshaken to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the last,

<BR>Endurance, resolution to the last.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>Now trumpeter for thy close,

<BR>Vouchsafe a higher strain than any yet,

<BR>Sing to my soul, renew its languishing faith and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hope,

<BR>Rouse up my slow belief, give me some vision of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the future,

<BR>Give me for once its prophecy and joy.



<P>&nbsp;O glad, exulting, culminating song!

<BR>A vigor more than earth's is in thy notes,

<BR>Marches of victory&amp;emdash;man disenthral'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the conqueror at last,

<BR>Hymns to the universal God from universal man

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;all joy!

<BR>A reborn race appears&amp;emdash;a perfect world,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all joy!

<BR>Women and men in wisdom innocence and health

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;all joy!

<BR>Riotous laughing bacchanals fill'd with joy!

<BR>War, sorrow, suffering gone&amp;emdash;the rank earth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; purged&amp;emdash;nothing but joy left!

<BR>The ocean fill'd with joy&amp;emdash;the atmosphere

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all joy!

<BR>Joy! joy! in freedom, worship, love! joy in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ecstasy of life!

<BR>Enough to merely be! enough to breathe!

<BR>Joy! joy! all over joy!

<PRE>1872&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO A LOCOMOTIVE IN WINTER</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HEE</FONT> for my recitative,

<BR>Thee in the driving storm even as now, the snow,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the winterday declining,

<BR>Thee in thy panoply, thy measur'd dual throbbing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and thy beat convulsive,

<BR>Thy black cylindric body, golden brass and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; silvery steel,

<BR>Thy ponderous side-bars, parallel and connecting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rods, gyrating, shuttling at thy sides,

<BR>Thy metrical, now swelling pant and roar, now

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tapering in the distance,

<BR>Thy great protruding head-light fix'd in front,

<BR>Thy long, pale, floating vapor-pennants, tinged

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with delicate purple,

<BR>The dense and murky clouds out-belching from thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; smoke-stack,

<BR>Thy knitted frame, thy springs and valves, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tremulous twinkle of thy wheels,

<BR>Thy train of cars behind, obedient, merrily following,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>Through gale or calm, now swift, now slack, yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steadily careering;

<BR>Type of the modern&amp;emdash;emblem of motion and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; power&amp;emdash;pulse of the continent,

<BR>For once come serve the Muse and merge in verse,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; even as here I see thee,

<BR>With storm and buffeting gusts of wind and falling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; snow,

<BR>By day thy warning ringing bell to sound its notes,

<BR>By night thy silent signal lamps to swing.



<P>&nbsp;Fierce-throated beauty!

<BR>Roll through my chant with all thy lawless music, thy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swinging lamps at night,

<BR>Thy madly-whistled laughter, echoing, rumbling like

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; an earthquake, rousing all,

<BR>Law of thyself complete, thine own track firmly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; holding,

<BR>(No sweetness debonair of tearful harp or glib

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; piano thine,)

<BR>Thy trills of shrieks by rocks and hills return'd,

<BR>Launch'd o'er the prairies wide, across the lakes,

<BR>To the free skies unpent and glad and strong.

<PRE>1876&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

O MAGNET-SOUTH</H2></CENTER>

O M<FONT SIZE=-1>AGNET</FONT>-S<FONT SIZE=-1>OUTH</FONT>! O glistening

perfumed South!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my South!

<BR>O quick mettle, rich blood, impulse and love! good

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and evil! O all dear to me!

<BR>O dear to me my birth-things&amp;emdash;all moving

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; things and the trees where I was born&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the grains, plants, rivers,

<BR>Dear to me my own slow sluggish rivers where they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flow, distant, over flats of silvery sands

or through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swamps,

<BR>Dear to me the Roanoke, the Savannah, the Altamahaw,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Pedee, the Tombigbee, the Santee, the

Coosa,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the Sabine,

<BR>O pensive, far away wandering, I return with my soul

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to haunt their banks again,

<BR>Again in Florida I float on transparent lakes, I float

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on the Okeechobee, I cross the hummock-land

or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through pleasant openings or dense forests,

<BR>I see the parrots in the woods, I see the papaw-tree

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the blossoming titi;

<BR>Again, sailing in my coaster on deck, I coast off

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Georgia, I coast up the Carolinas,

<BR>I see where the live-oak is growing, I see where the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yellowpine, the scented bay-tree, the lemon

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; orange, the cypress, the graceful palmetto,

<BR>I pass rude sea-headlands and enter Pamlico sound

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through an inlet, and dart my vision inland;

<BR>O the cotton plant! the growing fields of rice, sugar,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hemp!

<BR>The cactus guarded with thorns, the laurel-tree with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; large white flowers,

<BR>The range afar, the richness and barrenness, the old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; woods charged with mistletoe and trailing

moss,

<BR>The piney odor and the gloom, the awful natural

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stillness, (here in these dense swamps the

free-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; booter carries his gun, and the fugitive has

his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; conceal'd hut;)

<BR>O the strange fascination of these half-known half-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; impassable swamps, infested by reptiles,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; resounding with the bellow of the alligator,

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sad noises of the night-owl and the wild-cat,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the whirr of the rattlesnake,

<BR>The mocking-bird, the American mimic, singing all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the forenoon, singing through the moon-lit

night,



<P>&nbsp;The humming-bird, the wild turkey, the raccoon, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; opossum;

<BR>A Kentucky corn-field, the tall, graceful, long-leav'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; corn, slender, flapping, bright green, with

tassels,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with beautiful ears each well-sheath'd in

its husk;

<BR>O my heart! O tender and fierce pangs, I can stand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them not, I will depart;

<BR>O to be a Virginian where I grew up! O to be a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Carolinian!

<BR>O longings irrepressible! O I will go back to old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Tennessee and never wander more.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MANNAHATTA</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>WAS</FONT> asking for something specific and perfect

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for my city,

<BR>Whereupon lo! upsprang the aboriginal name.



<P>&nbsp;Now I see what there is in a name, a word, liquid,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sane, unruly, musical, self-sufficient,

<BR>I see that the word of my city is that word from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of old,

<BR>Because I see that word nested in nests of water-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bays, superb,

<BR>Rich, hemm'd thick all around with sailships and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steamships, an island sixteen miles long,

solid-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; founded,

<BR>Numberless crowded streets, high growths of iron,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slender, strong, light, splendidly uprising

toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clear skies,

<BR>Tides swift and ample, well-loved by me, toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sundown,

<BR>The flowing sea-currents, the little islands, larger

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; adjoining islands, the heights, the villas,

<BR>The countless masts, the white shore-steamers, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lighters, the ferry-boats, the black sea-steamers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; well-model'd,

<BR>The down-town streets, the jobbers' houses of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; business, the houses of business of the ship-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; merchants and money-brokers, the river-streets,

<BR>Immigrants arriving, fifteen or twenty thousand in a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; week,

<BR>The carts hauling goods, the manly race of drivers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of horses, the brown-faced sailors,

<BR>The summer air, the bright sun shining, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sailing clouds aloft,

<BR>The winter snows, the sleigh-bells, the broken ice

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in the river, passing along up or down with

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flood-tide or ebb-tide,

<BR>The mechanics of the city, the masters, well-form'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beautiful-faced, looking you straight in the

eyes,



<P>&nbsp;Trottoirs throng'd, vehicles, Broadway, the women,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the shops and shows,

<BR>A million people&amp;emdash;manners free and superb

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;open voices&amp;emdash;hospitality

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the most courageous and friendly young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men,

<BR>City of hurried and sparkling waters! city of spires

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and masts!

<BR>City nested in bays! my city!

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ALL IS TRUTH</H2></CENTER>

O <FONT SIZE=-1>ME</FONT>, man of slack faith so long,

<BR>Standing aloof, denying portions so long,

<BR>Only aware to-day of compact all-diffused truth,

<BR>Discovering to-day there is no lie or form of lie,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and can be none, but grows as inevitably upon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself as the truth does upon itself,

<BR>Or as any law of the earth or any natural production

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the earth does.



<P>&nbsp;(This is curious and may not be realized immediately,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but it must be realized,

<BR>I feel in myself that I represent falsehoods equally

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with the rest,

<BR>And that the universe does.)



<P>&nbsp;Where has fail'd a perfect return indifferent of lies

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or the truth?

<BR>Is it upon the ground, or in water or fire? or in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spirit of man? or in the meat and blood?



<P>&nbsp;Meditating among liars and retreating sternly into

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself, I see that there are really no liars

or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lies after all,

<BR>And that nothing fails its perfect return, and that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what are called lies are perfect returns,

<BR>And that each thing exactly represents itself and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what has preceded it,

<BR>And that the truth includes all, and is compact just

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as much as space is compact,

<BR>And that there is no flaw or vacuum in the amount

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the truth&amp;emdash;but that all is truth

without

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; exception;

<BR>And henceforth I will go celebrate any thing I see

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or am,

<BR>And sing and laugh and deny nothing.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A RIDDLE SONG</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HAT</FONT> which eludes this verse and any verse,

<BR>Unheard by sharpest ear, unform'd in clearest eye

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or cunningest mind,

<BR>Nor lore nor fame, nor happiness nor wealth,

<BR>And yet the pulse of every heart and life throughout

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the world incessantly,

<BR>Which you and I and all pursuing ever ever miss,

<BR>Open but still a secret, the real of the real, an

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; illusion,

<BR>Costless, vouchsafed to each, yet never man the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; owner,

<BR>Which poets vainly seek to put in rhyme, historians

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in prose,

<BR>Which sculptor never chisel'd yet, not painter painted,

<BR>Which vocalist never sung, nor orator nor actor ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; utter'd,

<BR>Invoking here and how I challenge for my song.



<P>&nbsp;Indifferently, 'mid public, private haunts, in solitude,

<BR>Behind the mountain and the wood,

<BR>Companion of the city's busiest streets, through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the assemblage,

<BR>It and its radiations constantly glide.



<P>&nbsp;In looks of fair unconscious babes,

<BR>Or strangely in the coffin'd dead,

<BR>Or show of breaking dawn or stars by night,

<BR>As some dissolving delicate film of dreams,

<BR>Hiding yet lingering.



<P>&nbsp;Two little breaths of words comprising it,

<BR>Two words, yet all from first to last comprised

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in it.



<P>&nbsp;How ardently for it!

<BR>How many ships have sail'd and sunk for it!

<BR>How many travelers started from their homes and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ne'er return'd!

<BR>How much of genius boldly staked and lost for it!

<BR>What countless stores of beauty, love, ventur'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for it!

<BR>How all superbest deeds since Time began are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; traceable to it&amp;emdash;and shall be to

the end!

<BR>How all heroic martyrdoms to it!



<P>&nbsp;How, justified by it, the horrors, evils, battles of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the earth!

<BR>How the bright fascinating lambent flames of it, in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every age and land, have drawn men's eyes,

<BR>Rich as a sunset on the Norway coast, the sky, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; islands, and the cliffs,

<BR>Or midnight's silent glowing northern lights unreachable.



<P>&nbsp;Haply God's riddle it, so vague and yet so certain,

<BR>The soul for it, and all the visible universe for it,

<BR>And heaven at last for it.

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

EXCELSIOR</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HO</FONT> has gone farthest? for I would go farther,

<BR>And who has been just? for I would be the most just

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; person of the earth,

<BR>And who most cautious? for I would be more cautious,

<BR>And who has been happiest? O I think it is I&amp;emdash;I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; think no one was ever happier than I,

<BR>And who has lavish'd all? for I lavish constantly the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; best I have,

<BR>And who proudest? for I think I have reason to be the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; proudest son alive&amp;emdash;for I am the

son of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brawny and tall-topt city,

<BR>And who has been bold and true? for I would be the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; boldest and truest being of the universe,

<BR>And who benevolent? for I would show more benevolence

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than all the rest,

<BR>And who has receiv'd the love of the most friends? for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I know what it is to receive the passionate

love

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of many friends,

<BR>And who possesses a perfect and enamour'd body? for I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; do not believe any one possesses a more perfect

or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; enamour'd body than mine,

<BR>And who thinks the amplest thoughts? for I would

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; surround those thoughts,

<BR>And who has made hymns fit for the earth? for I am mad

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with devouring ecstasy to make joyous hymns

for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whole earth.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

AH POVERTIES, WINCINGS, AND SULKY RETREATS</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>H</FONT> poverties, wincings, and sulky retreats,

<BR>Ah you foes that in conflict have overcome me,

<BR>(For what is my life or any man's life but a conflict

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with foes, the old, the incessant war?)

<BR>You degradations, you tussle with passions and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; appetites,

<BR>You smarts from dissatisfied friendships, (ah wounds

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sharpest of all!)

<BR>You toil of painful and choked articulations, you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; meannesses,

<BR>You shallow tongue-talks at tables, (my tongue the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shallowest of any;)

<BR>You broken resolutions, you racking angers, you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; smother'd ennuis!

<BR>Ah think not you finally triumph, my real self has

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet to come forth,

<BR>It shall yet march forth o'ermastering, till all lies

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beneath me,

<BR>It shall yet stand up the soldier of ultimate victory.

<PRE>1865-6&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THOUGHTS</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>F</FONT> public opinion,

<BR>Of a calm and cool fiat sooner or later, (how

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; impassive! how certain and final!)

<BR>Of the President with pale face asking secretly to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; himself, <I>What will the people say at last?</I>

<BR>Of the frivolous Judge&amp;emdash;of the corrupt

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Congressman, Governor, Mayor&amp;emdash;of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; such as these standing helpless and exposed,

<BR>Of the mumbling and screaming priest, (soon, soon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; deserted,)

<BR>Of the lessening year by year of venerableness, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the dicta of officers, statutes, pulpits,

schools,

<BR>Of the rising forever taller and stronger and broader

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the intuitions of men and women, and of

Self-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; esteem and Personality;

<BR>Of the true New World&amp;emdash;of the Democracies

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; resplendent enmasse,

<BR>Of the conformity of politics, armies, navies, to them,



<P>&nbsp;Of the shining sun by them&amp;emdash;of the inherent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; light, greater than the rest,

<BR>Of the envelopment of all by them, and the effusion

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of all from them.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MEDIUMS</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HEY</FONT> shall arise in the States,

<BR>They shall report Nature, laws, physiology, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; happiness,

<BR>They shall illustrate Democracy and the kosmos,

<BR>They shall be alimentive, amative, perceptive,

<BR>They shall be complete women and men, their pose

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brawny and supple, their drink water, their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blood clean and clear,

<BR>They shall fully enjoy materialism and the sight of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; products, they shall enjoy the sight of the

beef,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lumber, breadstuffs, of Chicago the great

city,

<BR>They shall train themselves to go in public to become

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; orators and oratresses,

<BR>Strong and sweet shall their tongues be, poems and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; materials of poems shall come from their lives,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they shall be makers and finders,

<BR>Of them and of their works shall emerge divine

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; conveyers, to convey gospels,

<BR>Characters, events, retrospections, shall be convey'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in gospels, trees, animals, waters, shall

be convey'd,

<BR>Death, the future, the invisible faith, shall all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be convey'd.
