<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WEAVE IN, MY HARDY LIFE</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>EAVE</FONT> in, weave in, my hardy life,

<BR>Weave yet a soldier strong and full for great campaigns

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to come,

<BR>Weave in red blood, weave sinews in like ropes, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; senses, sight weave in,

<BR>Weave lasting sure, weave day and night the weft, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; warp, incessant weave, tire not,

<BR>(We know not what the use O life, nor know the aim,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the end, nor really aught we know,

<BR>But know the work, the need goes on and shall go on,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the death-envelop'd march of peace as well

as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; war goes on,)



<P>&nbsp;For great campaigns of peace the same the wiry

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; threads to weave,

<BR>We know not why or what, yet weave, forever weave.

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SPAIN, 1873-74</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>UT</FONT> of the murk of heaviest clouds,

<BR>Out of the feudal wrecks and heap'd-up skeletons

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of kings,

<BR>Out of that old entire European debris, the shatter'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mummeries,

<BR>Ruin'd cathedrals, crumble of palaces, tombs of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; priests,

<BR>Lo, Freedom's features fresh undimm'd look forth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the same immortal face looks forth;

<BR>(A glimpse as of thy Mother's face Columbia,

<BR>A flash significant as of a sword,

<BR>Beaming towards thee.)



<P>&nbsp;Nor think we forget thee maternal;

<BR>Lag'd'st thou so long? shall the clouds close

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; again upon thee?

<BR>Ah, but thou hast thyself now appear'd to us

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; we know thee,

<BR>Thou hast given us a sure proof, the glimpse of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thyself,

<BR>Thou waitest there as everywhere thy time.

<PRE>1873&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

BY BROAD POTOMAC'S SHORE</H2></CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>Y</FONT> broad Potomac's shore, again old tongue,

<BR>(Still uttering, still ejaculating, canst never cease

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this babble?)

<BR>Again old heart so gay, again to you, your sense,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the full flush spring returning,

<BR>Again the freshness and the odors, again Virginia's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; summer sky, pellucid blue and silver,

<BR>Again the forenoon purple of the hills,

<BR>Again the deathless grass, so noiseless soft and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; green,

<BR>Again the blood-red roses blooming.



<P>&nbsp;Perfume this book of mine O blood-red roses!

<BR>Lave subtly with your waters every line Potomac!

<BR>Give me of you O spring, before I close, to put

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; between its pages!

<BR>O forenoon purple of the hills, before I close,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of you!

<BR>O deathless grass, of you!

<PRE>1876&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FROM FAR DAKOTA'S CA&Ntilde;ONS</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>June</I> 25, 1876</CENTER>





<P>F<FONT SIZE=-1>ROM</FONT> far Dakota's ca&ntilde;ons,

<BR>Lands of the wild ravine, the dusky Sioux, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lonesome stretch, the silence,

<BR>Haply to-day a mournful wail, haply a trumpet-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; note for heroes.



<P>&nbsp;The battle-bulletin,

<BR>The Indian ambuscade, the craft, the fatal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; environment,

<BR>The cavalry companies fighting to the last in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sternest heroism,

<BR>In the midst of their little circle, with their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slaughter'd horses for breastworks,

<BR>The fall of Custer and all his officers and men.



<P>&nbsp;Continues yet the old, old legend of our race,

<BR>The loftiest of life upheld by death,

<BR>The ancient banner perfectly maintain'd,

<BR>O lesson opportune, O how I welcome thee!



<P>&nbsp;As sitting in dark days,

<BR>Lone, sulky, through the time's thick murk

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; looking in vain for light, for hope,

<BR>From unsuspected parts a fierce and momentary

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; proof,

<BR>(The sun there at the centre though conceal'd,

<BR>Electric life forever at the centre,)

<BR>Breaks forth a lightning flash.



<P>&nbsp;Thou of the tawny flowing hair in battle,

<BR>I erewhile saw, with erect head, pressing ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in front, bearing a birth sword in thy hand,

<BR>Now ending well in death the splendid fever of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy deeds,

<BR>(I bring no dirge for it or thee, I bring a glad

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; triumphal sonnet,)

<BR>Desperate and glorious, aye in defeat most

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; desperate, most glorious,

<BR>After thy many battles in which never yielding

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; up a gun or a color,



<P>&nbsp;Leaving behind thee a memory sweet to soldiers,

<BR>Thou yieldest up thyself.

<PRE>1876&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OLD WAR-DREAMS</H2></CENTER>

I<FONT SIZE=-1>N</FONT> midnight sleep of many a face of anguish,

<BR>Of the look at first of the mortally wounded, (of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that indescribable look,)

<BR>Of the dead on their backs with arms extended

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wide,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I dream, I dream,

I dream.



<P>&nbsp;Of scenes of Nature, fields and mountains,

<BR>Of skies so beauteous after a storm, and at night

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the moon so unearthly bright,

<BR>Shining sweetly, shining down, where we dig the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trenches and gather the heaps,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I dream, I dream,

I dream.



<P>&nbsp;Long have they pass'd, faces and trenches and fields,

<BR>Where through the carnage I moved with a callous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; composure, or away from the fallen,

<BR>Onward I sped at the time&amp;emdash;but now of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their forms at night, I dream, I dream, I

dream.

<PRE>1865-6&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THICK-SPRINKLED BUNTING</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HICK-SPRINKLED</FONT> bunting! flag of stars!

<BR>Long yet your road, fateful flag&amp;emdash;long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet your road, and lined with bloody death,

<BR>For the prize I see at issue at last is the world,

<BR>All its ships and shores I see interwoven with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your threads greedy banner;

<BR>Dream'd again the flags of kings, highest borne,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to flaunt unrival'd?

<BR>O hasten flag of man&amp;emdash;O with sure and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steady step, passing highest flags of kings,

<BR>Walk supreme to the heavens mighty symbol

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;run up above them all,

<BR>Flag of stars! thick-sprinkled bunting!



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1865&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHAT BEST I SEE IN THEE</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>To U. S. G. return'd from his World's Tour</I></CENTER>





<P>W<FONT SIZE=-1>HAT</FONT> best I see in thee,

<BR>Is not that where thou mov'st down history's great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; highways,

<BR>Ever undimm'd by time shoots warlike victory's dazzle,

<BR>Or that thou sat'st where Washington sat, ruling the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land in peace,

<BR>Or thou the man whom feudal Europe f&ecirc;ted,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; venerable Asia swarm'd upon,

<BR>Who walk'd with kings with even pace the round

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; world's promenade;

<BR>But that in foreign lands, in all thy walks with kings,

<BR>Those prairie sovereigns of the West, Kansas,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Missouri, Illinois,

<BR>Ohio's, Indiana's millions, comrades, farmers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soldiers, all to the front,

<BR>Invisibly with thee walking with kings with even

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pace the round world's promenade,

<BR>Were all so justified.

<PRE>(1879?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SPIRIT THAT FORM'D THIS SCENE</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Written in Platte Ca&ntilde;on, Colorado</I></CENTER>





<P>S<FONT SIZE=-1>PIRIT</FONT> that form'd this scene,

<BR>These tumbled rock-piles grim and red,

<BR>These reckless heaven-ambitious peaks,

<BR>These gorges, turbulent-clear streams, this naked

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; freshness,

<BR>These formless wild arrays, for reasons of their own,

<BR>I know thee, savage spirit&amp;emdash;we have

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; communed together,

<BR>Mine too such wild arrays, for reasons of their own;

<BR>Was't charged against my chants they had forgotten

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; art?

<BR>To fuse within themselves its rules precise and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; delicatesse?

<BR>The lyrist's measur'd beat, the wrought-out temple's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grace&amp;emdash;column and polish'd arch

forgot?

<BR>But thou that revelest here&amp;emdash;spirit that form'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this scene,

<BR>They have remember'd thee.

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AS I WALK THESE BROAD MAJESTIC DAYS</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>S</FONT> I walk these broad majestic days of peace,

<BR>(For the war, the struggle of blood finish'd, wherein,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; O terrific Ideal,

<BR>Against vast odds erewhile having gloriously won,

<BR>Now thou stridest on, yet perhaps in time toward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; denser wars,

<BR>Perhaps to engage in time in still more dreadful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contests, dangers,

<BR>Longer campaigns and crises, labors beyond all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; others,)

<BR>Around me I hear that eclat of the world, politics,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; produce,

<BR>The announcements of recognized things, science,

<BR>The approved growth of cities and the spread of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inventions.



<P>&nbsp;I see the ships, (they will last a few years,)

<BR>The vast factories with their foremen and workmen,

<BR>And hear the indorsement of all, and do not object

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to it.



<P>&nbsp;But I too announce solid things,

<BR>Science, ships, politics, cities, factories, are not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nothing,

<BR>Like a grand procession to music of distant bugles

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pouring, triumphantly moving, and grander

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heaving in sight,

<BR>They stand for realities&amp;emdash;all is as it should be.



<P>&nbsp;Then my realities;

<BR>What else is so real as mine?

<BR>Libertad and the divine average, freedom to every

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slave on the face of the earth,

<BR>The rapt promises and lumin&egrave; of seers, the spiritual

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; world, these centuries-lasting songs,

<BR>And our visions, the visions of poets, the most

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; solid announcements of any.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A CLEAR MIDNIGHT</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HIS</FONT> is thy hour O soul, thy free flight into the

wordless,

<BR>Away from books, away from art, the day erased, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lesson done,

<BR>Thee fully forth emerging, silent, gazing, pondering the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; themes thou lovest best,

<BR>Night, sleep, death and the stars.

<PRE>1881&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Old Age Echoes</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Old Age Echoes</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>Posthumous Additions</I>)</CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO SOAR IN FREEDOM AND IN FULLNESS OF POWER</H2></CENTER>

I H<FONT SIZE=-1>AVE</FONT> not so much emulated the birds that musically

sing,

<BR>I have abandon'd myself to flights, broad circles.

<BR>The hawk, the seagull, have far more possess'd me than the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; canary or mocking-bird,

<BR>I have not felt to warble and trill, however sweetly,

<BR>I have felt to soar in freedom and in the fullness of power,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joy, volition.

<PRE>1897&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THEN SHALL PERCEIVE</H2></CENTER>

I<FONT SIZE=-1>N</FONT> softness, languor, bloom, and growth,

<BR>Thine eyes, ears, all thy sense &amp;emdash; thy loftiest attribute

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; all that takes cognizance of

beauty,

<BR>Shall rouse and fill &amp;emdash; then shall perceive!

<PRE>1897&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE FEW DROPS KNOWN</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>F</FONT> heroes, history, grand events, premises, myths,

poems,

<BR>The few drops known must stand for oceans of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unknown,

<BR>On this beautiful and thick peopl'd earth, here and there a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; little specimen put on record,

<BR>A little of Greeks and Romans, a few Hebrew canticles, a few

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death odors as from graves, from Egypt &amp;emdash;

<BR>What are they to the long and copious retrospect of anti quity?

<PRE>1897&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ONE THOUGHT EVER AT THE FORE</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>NE</FONT> thought ever at the fore &amp;emdash;

<BR>That in the Divine Ship, the World, breasting Time and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Space,

<BR>All Peoples of the globe together sail, sail the same voyage,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are bound to the same destination.

<PRE>1897&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHILE BEHIND ALL FIRM AND ERECT</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HILE</FONT> behind all, firm and erect as ever,

<BR>Undismay'd amid the rapids &amp;emdash; amid the irresistible

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and deadly urge,

<BR>Stands a helmsman, with brow elate and strong hand.

<PRE>1897&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A KISS TO THE BRIDE</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Marriage of Nelly Grant, May</I> 21, 1874</CENTER>





<P>S<FONT SIZE=-1>ACRED</FONT>, blithesome, undenied,

<BR>With benisons from East and West,

<BR>And salutations North and South,

<BR>Through me indeed to-day a million hearts and hands,

<BR>Wafting a million loves, a million soulfelt prayers;

<BR>&amp;emdash; Tender and true remain the arm that shields thee!

<BR>Fair winds always fill the ship's sails that sail thee!

<BR>Clear sun by day, and light stars at night, beam on thee!

<BR>Dear girl &amp;emdash; through me the ancient privilege too,

<BR>For the New World, through me, the old, old wedding greeting,

<BR>O youth and health! O sweet Missouri rose! O bonny bride!

<BR>Yield thy red cheeks, thy lips, to-day,

<BR>Unto a Nation's loving kiss.

<PRE>1874&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

NAY, TELL ME NOT TO-DAY THE PUBLISH'D SHAME</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Winter of</I> 1873, <I>Congress in Session</I></CENTER>





<P>N<FONT SIZE=-1>AY</FONT>, tell me not to-day the publish'd shame,

<BR>Read not to-day the journal's crowded page,

<BR>The merciless reports still branding forehead after forehead,

<BR>The guilty column following guilty column.



<P>&nbsp;To-day to me the tale refusing,

<BR>Turning from it &amp;emdash; from the white capitol turning,

<BR>Far from these swelling domes, topt with statues,

<BR>More endless, jubilant, vital visions rise

<BR>Unpublish'd, unreported.



<P>&nbsp;Through all your quiet ways, or North or South, you Equal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; States, you honest farms,

<BR>Your million untold manly healthy lives, or East or West,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; city or country,

<BR>Your noiseless mothers, sisters, wives, unconscious of their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; good,

<BR>Your mass of homes nor poor nor rich, in visions rise

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; (even your excellent poverties,)

<BR>Your self-distilling, never-ceasing virtues, self-denials, graces,

<BR>Your endless base of deep integrities within, timid but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; certain,

<BR>Your blessings steadily bestow'd, sure as the light, and still,

<BR>(Plunging to these as a determin'd diver down the deep

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hidden waters,)

<BR>These, these to-day I brood upon &amp;emdash; all else refusing,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; these will I con,

<BR>To-day to these give audience.

<PRE>1873&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SUPPLEMENT HOURS</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>ANE</FONT>, random, negligent hours,

<BR>Sane, easy, culminating hours,

<BR>After the flush, the Indian summer, of my life,

<BR>Away from Books &amp;emdash; away from Art &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the lesson learn'd, pass'd o'er,

<BR>Soothing, bathing, merging all &amp;emdash; the sane, magnetic,

<BR>Now for the day and night themselves &amp;emdash; the open air,

<BR>Now for the fields, the seasons, insects, trees &amp;emdash; the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rain and snow,

<BR>Where wild bees flitting hum,

<BR>Or August mulleins grow, or winter's snowflakes fall,

<BR>Or stars in the skies roll round &amp;emdash;

<BR>The silent sun and stars.

<PRE>1897&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OF MANY A SMUTCH'D DEED REMINISCENT</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>ULL</FONT> of wickedness, I &amp;emdash; of many a smutch'd

deed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reminiscent &amp;emdash; of worse deeds capable,

<BR>Yet I look composedly upon nature, drink day and night the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joys of life, and await death with perfect

equanimity.

<BR>Because of my tender and boundless love for him I love and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; because of his boundless love for me.

<PRE>1897&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO BE AT ALL</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>Cf. Stanza</I> 27,&nbsp;<qq>Song of Myself,</qq> <I>p</I>.

53)</CENTER>





<P>T<FONT SIZE=-1>O</FONT> be at all &amp;emdash; what is better than that?

<BR>I think if there were nothing more developed, the clam

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in its callous shell in the sand were august enough.

<BR>I am not in any callous shell;

<BR>I am cased with supple conductors, all over,

<BR>They take every object by the hand, and lead it within me;

<BR>They are thousands, each one with his entry to himself;

<BR>They are always watching with their little eyes, from my head

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to my feet;

<BR>One no more than a point lets in and out of me such bliss and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; magnitude,

<BR>I think I could lift the girder of the house away if it lay

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; between me and whatever I wanted.

<PRE>1855&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

DEATH'S VALLEY</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>To accompany a picture; by request.&nbsp;<qq>The Valley of the</I></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Shadow of Death,</qq> from the painting by George Inness</I></CENTER>





<P>N<FONT SIZE=-1>AY</FONT>, do not dream, designer dark,

<BR>Thou hast portray'd or hit thy theme entire;

<BR>I, hoverer of late by this dark valley, by its confines,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; having glimpses of it,

<BR>Here enter lists with thee, claiming my right to make a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; symbol too.



<P>&nbsp;For I have seen many wounded soldiers die,

<BR>After dread suffering &amp;emdash; have seen their lives

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pass off with smiles;

<BR>And I have watch'd the death-hours of the old; and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seen the infant die;

<BR>The rich with all his nurses and his doctors;

<BR>And then the poor, in meagreness and poverty;

<BR>And I myself for long, O Death, have breath'd my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every breath

<BR>Amid the nearness and the silent thought of thee.

<BR>And out of these and thee,

<BR>I make a scene, a song (not fear of thee,

<BR>Nor gloom's ravines, nor bleak, nor dark &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for I do not fear thee,

<BR>Nor celebrate the struggle, or contortion, or hard-tied knot),

<BR>Of the broad blessed light and perfect air, with meadows,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rippling tides, and trees and flowers and

grass,

<BR>And the low hum of living breeze &amp;emdash; and in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; midst God's beautiful eternal right hand,

<BR>Thee, holiest minister of Heaven &amp;emdash; thee, envoy,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; usherer, guide at last of all,

<BR>Rich, florid, loosener of the stricture-knot call'd life,

<BR>Sweet, peaceful, welcome Death.

<PRE>1892&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ON THE SAME PICTURE</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>Intended for first stanza of&nbsp;<qq>Death's Valley</I></qq></CENTER>





<P>A<FONT SIZE=-1>YE</FONT>, well I know 'tis ghastly to descend that valley:

<BR>Preachers, musicians, poets, painters, always render it,

<BR>Philosophs exploit &amp;emdash; the battlefield, the ship at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea, the myriad beds, all lands,

<BR>All, all the past have enter'd, the ancientest humanity we

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know,

<BR>Syria's, India's, Egypt's, Greece's, Rome's;

<BR>Till now for us under our very eyes spreading the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; today,

<BR>Grim, ready, the same to-day, for entrance, yours and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mine,

<BR>Here, here 'tis limn'd.

<PRE>1892&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A THOUGHT OF COLUMBUS</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> mystery of mysteries, the crude and hurried ceaseless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flame, spontaneous, bearing on itself.

<BR>The bubble and the huge, round, concrete orb!

<BR>A breath of Deity, as thence the bulging universe unfolding!

<BR>The many issuing cycles from their precedent minute!

<BR>The eras of the soul incepting in an hour,

<BR>Haply the widest, farthest evolutions of the world and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; man.



<P>&nbsp;Thousands and thousands of miles hence, and now four

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; centuries back,

<BR>A mortal impulse thrilling its brain cell,

<BR>Reck'd or unreck'd, the birth can no longer be postpon'd:

<BR>A phantom of the moment, mystic, stalking, sudden,

<BR>Only a silent thought, yet toppling down of more than walls

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of brass or stone.

<BR>(A flutter at the darkness' edge as if old Time's and Space's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; secret near revealing.)

<BR>A thought! a definite thought works out in shape.

<BR>Four hundred years roll on.

<BR>The rapid cumulus &amp;emdash; trade, navigation, war, peace,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; democracy, roll on;

<BR>The restless armies and the fleets of time following their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leader &amp;emdash; the old camps of ages

pitch'd in newer,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; larger areas,

<BR>The tangl'd, long-deferr'd, &eacute;claircissement of human life and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hopes boldly begins untying,

<BR>As here to-day up-grows the Western World.



<P>&nbsp;(An added word yet to my song, far Discoverer, as ne'er

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before sent back to son of earth &amp;emdash;

<BR>If still thou hearest, hear me,

<BR>Voicing as now &amp;emdash; lands, races, arts, bravas to thee,

<BR>O'er the long backward path to thee &amp;emdash; one vast

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consensus north, south, east, west,

<BR>Soul plaudits! acclamation! reverent echoes!

<BR>One manifold, huge memory to thee! oceans and lands!

<BR>The modern world to thee and thought of thee!)

<PRE>(1891)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1897</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Calamus</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Calamus</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

IN PATHS UNTRODDEN</H2></CENTER>

I<FONT SIZE=-1>N</FONT> paths untrodden,

<BR>In the growths by margins of pond-waters,

<BR>Escaped from the life that exhibits itself,

<BR>From all the standards hitherto publish'd, from the pleasures,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; profits, conformities,

<BR>Which too long I was offering to feed my soul,

<BR>Clear to me now standards not yet publish'd, clear to me that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my soul,

<BR>That the soul of the man I speak for rejoices in comrades,

<BR>Here by myself away from the clank of the world,

<BR>Tallying and talk'd to here by tongues aromatic,

<BR>No longer abash'd, (for in this secluded spot I can respond as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I would not dare elsewhere,)

<BR>Strong upon me the life that does not exhibit itself, yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contains all the rest,

<BR>Resolv'd to sing no songs to-day but those of manly attachment,

<BR>Projecting them along that substantial life,

<BR>Bequeathing hence types of athletic love,

<BR>Afternoon this delicious Ninth-month in my forty-first year,

<BR>I proceed for all who are or have been young men,

<BR>To tell the secret of my nights and days,

<BR>To celebrate the need of comrades.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SCENTED HERBAGE OF MY BREAST</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>CENTED</FONT> herbage of my breast,

<BR>Leaves from you I glean, I write, to be perused best

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; afterwards,

<BR>Tomb-leaves, body-leaves growing up above me above death.



<P>&nbsp;Perennial roots, tall leaves, O the winter shall not freeze you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; delicate leaves,

<BR>Every year shall you bloom again, out from where you retired

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you shall emerge again;

<BR>O I do not know whether many passing by will discover you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or inhale your faint odor, but I believe a

few will;

<BR>O slender leaves! O blossoms of my blood! I permit you to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tell in your own way of the heart that is

under you,

<BR>O I do not know what you mean there underneath yourselves,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you are not happiness,

<BR>You are often more bitter than I can bear, you burn and sting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>Yet you are beautiful to me you faint-tinged roots, you make

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me think of death,

<BR>Death is beautiful from you, (what indeed is finally beautiful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; except death and love?)

<BR>O I think it is not for life I am chanting here my chant of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lovers, I think it must be for death,

<BR>For how calm, how solemn it grows to ascend to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; atmosphere of lovers,

<BR>Death or life I am then indifferent, my soul declines to prefer,

<BR>(I am not sure but the high soul of lovers welcomes death

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; most,)

<BR>Indeed O death, I think now these leaves mean precisely the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; same as you mean,

<BR>Grow up taller sweet leaves that I may see! grow up out of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my breast!

<BR>Spring away from the conceal'd heart there!

<BR>Do not fold yourself so in your pink-tinged roots timid leaves!

<BR>Do not remain down there so ashamed, herbage of my breast!

<BR>Come I am determin'd to unbare this broad breast of mine, I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; have long enough stifled and choked;

<BR>Emblematic and capricious blades I leave you, now you serve

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me not,

<BR>I will say what I have to say by itself,

<BR>I will sound myself and comrades only, I will never again

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; utter a call only their call,

<BR>I will raise with it immortal reverberations through the States,

<BR>I will give an example to lovers to take permanent shape and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; will through the States,



<P>&nbsp;Through me shall the words be said to make death

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; exhilarating.

<BR>Give me your tone therefore O death, that I may accord with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it,

<BR>Give me yourself, for I see that you belong to me now above

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all, and are folded inseparably together,

you love and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death are,

<BR>Nor will I allow you to balk me any more with what I was

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; calling life,

<BR>For now it is convey'd to me that you are the purports

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; essential,

<BR>That you hide in these shifting forms of life, for reasons, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that they are mainly for you,

<BR>That you beyond them come forth to remain, the real reality,

<BR>That behind the mask of materials you patiently wait, no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; matter how long,

<BR>That you will one day perhaps take control of all,

<BR>That you will perhaps dissipate this entire show of appearance,

<BR>That may-be you are what it is all for, but it does not last so

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; very long,

<BR>But you will last very long.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHOEVER YOU ARE HOLDING ME NOW IN HAND</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HOEVER</FONT> you are holding me now in hand,

<BR>Without one thing all will be useless,

<BR>I give you fair warning before you attempt me further,

<BR>I am not what you supposed, but far different.



<P>&nbsp;Who is he that would become my follower?

<BR>Who would sign himself a candidate for my affections?



<P>&nbsp;The way is suspicious, the result uncertain, perhaps

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; destructive,

<BR>You would have to give up all else, I alone would expect to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be your sole and exclusive standard,

<BR>Your novitiate would even then be long and exhausting,



<P>&nbsp;The whole past theory of your life and all conformity to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lives around you would have to be abandon'd,

<BR>Therefore release me now before troubling yourself any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; further, let go your hand from my shoulders,

<BR>Put me down and depart on your way.



<P>&nbsp;Or else by stealth in some wood for trial,

<BR>Or back of a rock in the open air,

<BR>(For in any roof'd room of a house I emerge not, nor in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; company,

<BR>And in libraries I lie as one dumb, a gawk, or unborn, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dead,)

<BR>But just possibly with you on a high hill, first watching lest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; any person for miles around approach unawares,

<BR>Or possibly with you sailing at sea, or on the beach of the sea

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or some quiet island,

<BR>Here to put your lips upon mine I permit you,

<BR>With the comrade's long-dwelling kiss or the new husband's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; kiss,

<BR>For I am the new husband and I am the comrade.



<P>&nbsp;Or if you will, thrusting me beneath your clothing,

<BR>Where I may feel the throbs of your heart or rest upon your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hip,

<BR>Carry me when you go forth over land or sea;

<BR>For thus merely touching you is enough, is best,

<BR>And thus touching you would I silently sleep and be carried

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eternally.



<P>&nbsp;But these leaves conning you con at peril,

<BR>For these leaves and me you will not understand,

<BR>They will elude you at first and still more afterward, I will

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; certainly elude you,

<BR>Even while you should think you had unquestionably caught

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me, behold!

<BR>Already you see I have escaped from you.



<P>&nbsp;For it is not for what I have put into it that I have written

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this book,

<BR>Nor is it by reading it you will acquire it,



<P>&nbsp;Nor do those know me best who admire me and vauntingly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; praise me,

<BR>Nor will the candidates for my love (unless at most a very

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; few) prove victorious,

<BR>Nor will my poems do good only, they will do just as much

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; evil, perhaps more,

<BR>For all is useless without that which you may guess at many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; times and not hit, that which I hinted at;

<BR>Therefore release me and depart on your way.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FOR YOU O DEMOCRACY</H2></CENTER>

C<FONT SIZE=-1>OME</FONT>, I will make the continent indissoluble,

<BR>I will make the most splendid race the sun ever shone upon,

<BR>I will make divine magnetic lands,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

With the love of comrades,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

With the life-long love of comrades.



<P>&nbsp;I will plant companionship thick as trees along all the rivers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of America, and along the shores of the great

lakes, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all over the prairies,

<BR>I will make inseparable cities with their arms about each

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; other's necks,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

By the love of comrades,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

By the manly love of comrades.



<P>&nbsp;For you these from me, O Democracy, to serve you ma

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; femme!

<BR>For you, for you I am trilling these songs.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THESE I SINGING IN SPRING</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HESE</FONT> I singing in spring collect for lovers,

<BR>(For who but I should understand lovers and all their sorrow

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and joy?

<BR>And who but I should be the poet of comrades?)

<BR>Collecting I traverse the garden the world, but soon I pass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the gates,

<BR>Now along the pond-side, now wading in a little, fearing not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the wet,



<P>&nbsp;Now by the post-and-rail fences where the old stones thrown

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there, pick'd from the fields, have accumulated,

<BR>(Wild-flowers and vines and weeds come up through the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stones and partly cover them, beyond these

I pass,)

<BR>Far, far in the forest, or sauntering later in summer, before I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; think where I go,

<BR>Solitary, smelling the earthy smell, stopping now and then in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the silence,

<BR>Alone I had thought, yet soon a troop gathers around me,

<BR>Some walk by my side and some behind, and some embrace

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my arms or neck,

<BR>They the spirits of dear friends dead or alive, thicker they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; come, a great crowd, and I in the middle,

<BR>Collecting, dispensing, singing, there I wander with them,

<BR>Plucking something for tokens, tossing toward whoever is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; near me,

<BR>Here, lilac, with a branch of pine,

<BR>Here, out of my pocket, some moss which I pull'd off a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; live-oak in Florida as it hung trailing down,

<BR>Here, some pinks and laurel leaves, and a handful of sage,

<BR>And here what I now draw from the water, wading in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pond-side,

<BR>(O here I last saw him that tenderly loves me, and returns

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; again never to separate from me,

<BR>And this, O this shall henceforth be the token of comrades,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this calamus-root shall,

<BR>Interchange it youths with each other! let none render it back!)

<BR>And twigs of maple and a bunch of wild orange and chestnut,

<BR>And stems of currants and plum-blows, and the aromatic

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cedar,

<BR>These I compass'd around by a thick cloud of spirits,

<BR>Wandering, point to or touch as I pass, or throw them loosely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from me,

<BR>Indicating to each one what he shall have, giving something

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to each;

<BR>But what I drew from the water by the pond-side, that I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reserve,

<BR>I will give of it, but only to them that love as I myself am

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; capable of loving.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

NOT HEAVING FROM MY RIBB'D BREAST ONLY</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>OT</FONT> heaving from my ribb'd breast only,

<BR>Not in sighs at night in rage dissatisfied with myself,

<BR>Not in those long-drawn, ill-supprest sighs,

<BR>Not in many an oath and promise broken,

<BR>Not in my wilful and savage soul's volition,

<BR>Not in the subtle nourishment of the air,

<BR>Not in this beating and pounding at my temples and wrists,

<BR>Not in the curious systole and diastole within which will one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day cease,

<BR>Not in many a hungry wish told to the skies only,

<BR>Not in cries, laughter, defiances, thrown from me when alone

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; far in the wilds,

<BR>Not in husky pantings through clinch'd teeth,

<BR>Not in sounded and resounded words, chattering words,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; echoes, dead words,

<BR>Not in the murmurs of my dreams while I sleep,

<BR>Nor the other murmurs of these incredible dreams of every

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day,

<BR>Nor in the limbs and senses of my body that take you and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dismiss you continually&amp;emdash;not there,

<BR>Not in any or all of them O adhesiveness! O pulse of my life!

<BR>Need I that you exist and show yourself any more than in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; these songs.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OF THE TERRIBLE DOUBT OF APPEARANCES</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>F</FONT> the terrible doubt of appearances,

<BR>Of the uncertainty after all, that we may be deluded,

<BR>That may-be reliance and hope are but speculations after all,

<BR>That may-be identity beyond the grave is a beautiful fable

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; only,

<BR>May-be the things I perceive, the animals, plants, men, hills,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shining and flowing waters,

<BR>The skies of day and night, colors, densities, forms, may-be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; these are (as doubtless they are) only apparitions,

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the real something has yet to be known,

<BR>(How often they dart out of themselves as if to confound me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and mock me!



<P>&nbsp;How often I think neither I know, nor any man knows, aught

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of them,)

<BR>May-be seeming to me what they are (as doubtless they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indeed but seem) as from my present point

of view, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; might prove (as of course they would) nought

of what

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they appear, or nought anyhow, from entirely

changed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; points of view;

<BR>To me these and the like of these are curiously answer'd by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my lovers, my dear friends,

<BR>When he whom I love travels with me or sits a long while

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; holding me by the hand,

<BR>When the subtle air, the impalpable, the sense that words and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reason hold not, surround us and pervade us,

<BR>Then I am charged with untold and untellable wisdom, I am

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; silent, I require nothing further,

<BR>I cannot answer the question of appearances or that of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; identity beyond the grave,

<BR>But I walk or sit indifferent, I am satisfied,

<BR>He ahold of my hand has completely satisfied me.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE BASE OF ALL METAPHYSICS</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>ND</FONT> now gentlemen,

<BR>A word I give to remain in your memories and minds,

<BR>As base and final&egrave; too for all metaphysics.



<P>&nbsp;(So to the students the old professor,

<BR>At the close of his crowded course.)



<P>&nbsp;Having studied the new and antique, the Greek and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Germanic systems,

<BR>Kant having studied and stated, Fichte and Schelling and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Hegel,

<BR>Stated the lore of Plato, and Socrates greater than Plato,

<BR>And greater than Socrates sought and stated, Christ divine

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; having studied long,

<BR>I see reminiscent to-day those Greek and Germanic systems,

<BR>See the philosophies all, Christian churches and tenets see,

<BR>Yet underneath Socrates clearly see, and underneath Christ

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the divine I see,



<P>&nbsp;The dear love of man for his comrade, the attraction of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; friend to friend,

<BR>Of the well-married husband and wife, of children and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; parents,

<BR>Of city for city and land for land.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

RECORDERS AGES HENCE</H2></CENTER>

R<FONT SIZE=-1>ECORDERS</FONT> ages hence,

<BR>Come, I will take you down underneath this impassive exterior,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I will tell you what to say of me,

<BR>Publish my name and hang up my picture as that of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tenderest lover,

<BR>The friend the lover's portrait, of whom his friend his lover

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; was fondest,

<BR>Who was not proud of his songs, but of the measureless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ocean of love within him, and freely pour'd

it forth,

<BR>Who often walk'd lonesome walks thinking of his dear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; friends, his lovers,

<BR>Who pensive away from one he lov'd often lay sleepless and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dissatisfied at night,

<BR>Who knew too well the sick, sick dread lest the one he lov'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; might secretly be indifferent to him,

<BR>Whose happiest days were far away through fields, in woods,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; on hills, he and another wandering hand in

hand, they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; twain apart from other men,

<BR>Who oft as he saunter'd the streets curv'd with his arm the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shoulder of his friend, while the arm of his

friend rested

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon him also.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHEN I HEARD AT THE CLOSE OF THE DAY</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HEN</FONT> I heard at the close of the day how my name had

been

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; receiv'd with plaudits in the capitol, still

it was not a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; happy night for me that follow'd,

<BR>And else when I carous'd, or when my plans were

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accomplish'd, still I was not happy,

<BR>But the day when I rose at dawn from the bed of perfect

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; health, refresh'd, singing, inhaling the ripe

breath of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; autumn,



<P>&nbsp;When I saw the full moon in the west grow pale and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; disappear in the morning light,

<BR>When I wander'd alone over the beach, and undressing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bathed, laughing with the cool waters, and

saw the sun

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rise,

<BR>And when I thought how my dear friend my lover was on his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; way coming, O then I was happy,

<BR>O then each breath tasted sweeter, and all that day my food

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nourish'd me more, and the beautiful day pass'd

well,

<BR>And the next came with equal joy, and with the next at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; evening came my friend,

<BR>And that night while all was still I heard the waters roll slowly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; continually up the shores,

<BR>I heard the hissing rustle of the liquid and sands as directed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me whispering to congratulate me,

<BR>For the one I love most lay sleeping by me under the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cover in the cool night,

<BR>In the stillness in the autumn moonbeams his face was

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inclined toward me,

<BR>And his arm lay lightly around my breast&amp;emdash;and that night

I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; was happy.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ARE YOU THE NEW PERSON DRAWN<BR>

TOWARD ME?</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>RE</FONT> you the new person drawn toward me?

<BR>To begin with take warning, I am surely far different from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what you suppose;

<BR>Do you suppose you will find in me your ideal?

<BR>Do you think it is so easy to have me become your lover?

<BR>Do you think the friendship of me would be unalloy'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; satisfaction?

<BR>Do you think I am trusty and faithful?

<BR>Do you see no further than this fa&ccedil;ade, this smooth and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tolerant manner of me?

<BR>Do you suppose yourself advancing on real ground toward a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; real heroic man?

<BR>Have you no thought O dreamer that it may be all maya,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; illusion?

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ROOTS AND LEAVES THEMSELVES ALONE</H2></CENTER>

R<FONT SIZE=-1>OOTS</FONT> and leaves themselves alone are these,

<BR>Scents brought to men and women from the wild woods and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pond-side,

<BR>Breast-sorrel and pinks of love, fingers that wind around

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tighter than vines,

<BR>Gushes from the throats of birds hid in the foliage of trees as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sun is risen,

<BR>Breezes of land and love set from living shores to you on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; living sea, to you O sailors!

<BR>Frost-mellow'd berries and Third-month twigs offer'd fresh

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to young persons wandering out in the fields

when the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; winter breaks up,

<BR>Love-buds put before you and within you whoever you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are,

<BR>Buds to be unfolded on the old terms,

<BR>If you bring the warmth of the sun to them they will open

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and bring form, color, perfume, to you,

<BR>If you become the aliment and the wet they will become

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flowers, fruits, tall branches and trees.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

NOT HEAT FLAMES UP AND CONSUMES</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>OT</FONT> heat flames up and consumes,

<BR>Not sea-waves hurry in and out,

<BR>Not the air delicious and dry, the air of ripe summer, bears

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lightly along white down-balls of myriads

of seeds,

<BR>Wafted, sailing gracefully, to drop where they may;

<BR>Not these, O none of these more than the flames of me,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consuming, burning for his love whom I love,

<BR>O none more than I hurrying in and out;

<BR>Does the tide hurry, seeking something, and never give up?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; O I the same,

<BR>O nor down-balls nor perfumes, nor the high rain-emitting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clouds, are borne through the open air,

<BR>Any more than my soul is borne through the open air,

<BR>Wafted in all directions O love, for friendship, for you.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TRICKLE DROPS</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>RICKLE</FONT> drops! my blue veins leaving!

<BR>O drops of me! trickle, slow drops,

<BR>Candid from me falling, drip, bleeding drops,

<BR>From wounds made to free you whence you were prison'd,

<BR>From my face, from my forehead and lips,

<BR>From my breast, from within where I was conceal'd, press

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forth red drops, confession drops,

<BR>Stain every page, stain every song I sing, every word I say,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bloody drops,

<BR>Let them know your scarlet heat, let them glisten,

<BR>Saturate them with yourself all ashamed and wet,

<BR>Glow upon all I have written or shall write, bleeding drops,

<BR>Let it all be seen in your light, blushing drops.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

CITY OF ORGIES</H2></CENTER>

C<FONT SIZE=-1>ITY</FONT> of orgies, walks and joys,

<BR>City whom that I have lived and sung in your midst will one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day make you illustrious,

<BR>Not the pageants of you, not your shifting tableaus, your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spectacles, repay me,

<BR>Not the interminable rows of your houses, nor the ships at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the wharves,

<BR>Nor the processions in the streets, nor the bright windows

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with goods in them,

<BR>Nor to converse with learn'd persons, or bear my share in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soiree or feast;

<BR>Not those, but as I pass O Manhattan, your frequent and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swift flash of eyes offering me love,

<BR>Offering response to my own&amp;emdash;these repay me,

<BR>Lovers, continual lovers, only repay me.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

BEHOLD THIS SWARTHY FACE</H2></CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>EHOLD</FONT> this swarthy face, these gray eyes,

<BR>This beard, the white wool unclipt upon my neck,

<BR>My brown hands and the silent manner of me without charm;



<P>&nbsp;Yet comes one a Manhattanese and ever at parting kisses me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lightly on the lips with robust love,

<BR>And I on the crossing of the street or on the ship's deck give a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; kiss in return,

<BR>We observe that salute of American comrades land and sea,

<BR>We are those two natural and nonchalant persons.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

I SAW IN LOUISIANA A LIVE-OAK GROWING</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>SAW</FONT> in Louisiana a live-oak growing,

<BR>All alone stood it and the moss hung down from the branches,

<BR>Without any companion it grew there uttering joyous leaves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of dark green,

<BR>And its look, rude, unbending, lusty, made me think of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself,

<BR>But I wonder'd how it could utter joyous leaves standing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; alone there without its friend near, for I

knew I could not,

<BR>And I broke off a twig with a certain number of leaves upon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it, and twined around it a little moss,

<BR>And brought it away, and I have placed it in sight, in my room,

<BR>It is not needed to remind me as of my own dear friends,

<BR>(For I believe lately I think of little else than of them,)

<BR>Yet it remains to me a curious token, it makes me think of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; manly love;

<BR>For all that, and though the live-oak glistens there in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Louisiana solitary in a wide flat space,

<BR>Uttering joyous leaves all its life without a friend a lover near,

<BR>I know very well I could not.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO A STRANGER</H2></CENTER>

P<FONT SIZE=-1>ASSING</FONT> stranger! you do not know how longingly I

look

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon you,

<BR>You must be he I was seeking, or she I was seeking, (it comes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me as of a dream,)

<BR>I have somewhere surely lived a life of joy with you,

<BR>All is recall'd as we flit by each other, fluid, affectionate,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chaste, matured,



<P>&nbsp;You grew up with me, were a boy with me or a girl with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>I ate with you and slept with you, your body has become not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yours only nor left my body mine only,

<BR>You give me the pleasure of your eyes, face, flesh, as we pass,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you take of my beard, breast, hands, in return,

<BR>I am not to speak to you, I am to think of you when I sit

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; alone or wake at night alone,

<BR>I am to wait, I do not doubt I am to meet you again,

<BR>I am to see to it that I do not lose you.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THIS MOMENT YEARNING AND THOUGHTFUL</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HIS</FONT> moment yearning and thoughtful sitting alone,

<BR>It seems to me there are other men in other lands yearning

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and thoughtful,

<BR>It seems to me I can look over and behold them in Germany,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Italy, France, Spain,

<BR>Or far, far away, in China, or in Russia or Japan, talking

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; other dialects,

<BR>And it seems to me if I could know those men I should become

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; attached to them as I do to men in my own

lands,

<BR>O I know we should be brethren and lovers,

<BR>I know I should be happy with them.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

I HEAR IT WAS CHARGED AGAINST ME</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>HEAR</FONT> it was charged against me that I sought to

destroy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; institutions,

<BR>But really I am neither for nor against institutions,

<BR>(What indeed have I in common with them? or what with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; destruction of them?)

<BR>Only I will establish in the Mannahatta and in every city of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; these States inland and seaboard,

<BR>And in the fields and woods, and above every keel little or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; large that dents the water,

<BR>Without edifices or rules or trustees or any argument,

<BR>The institution of the dear love of comrades.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE PRAIRIE-GRASS DIVIDING</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> prairie-grass dividing, its special odor breathing,

<BR>I demand of it the spiritual corresponding,

<BR>Demand the most copious and close companionship of men,

<BR>Demand the blades to rise of words, acts, beings,

<BR>Those of the open atmosphere, coarse, sunlit, fresh,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nutritious,

<BR>Those that go their own gait, erect, stepping with freedom

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and command, leading not following,

<BR>Those with a never-quell'd audacity, those with sweet and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lusty flesh clear of taint,

<BR>Those that look carelessly in the faces of Presidents and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; governors, as to say <I>Who are you</I>?

<BR>Those of earth-born passion, simple, never constrain'd, never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; obedient,

<BR>Those of inland America.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHEN I PERUSE THE CONQUER'D FAME</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HEN</FONT> I peruse the conquer'd fame of heroes and the

victories

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of mighty generals, I do not envy the generals,

<BR>Nor the President in his Presidency, nor the rich in his great

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; house,

<BR>But when I hear of the brotherhood of lovers, how it was

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with them,

<BR>How together through life, through dangers, odium,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unchanging, long and long,

<BR>Through youth and through middle and old age, how

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unfaltering, how affectionate and faithful

they were,

<BR>Then I am pensive&amp;emdash;I hastily walk away fill'd with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bitterest envy.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WE TWO BOYS TOGETHER CLINGING</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>E</FONT> two boys together clinging,

<BR>One the other never leaving,

<BR>Up and down the roads going, North and South excursions

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; making,



<P>&nbsp;Power enjoying, elbows stretching, fingers clutching,

<BR>Arm'd and fearless, eating, drinking, sleeping, loving,

<BR>No law less than ourselves owning, sailing, soldiering,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thieving, threatening,

<BR>Misers, menials, priests alarming, air breathing, water

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drinking, on the turf or the sea-beach dancing,

<BR>Cities wrenching, ease scorning, statutes mocking, feebleness

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; chasing,

<BR>Fulfilling our foray.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A PROMISE TO CALIFORNIA</H2></CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>PROMISE</FONT> to California,

<BR>Or inland to the great pastoral Plains, and on to Puget sound

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and Oregon;

<BR>Sojourning east a while longer, soon I travel toward you, to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; remain, to teach robust American love,

<BR>For I know very well that I and robust love belong among

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you, inland, and along the Western sea;

<BR>For these States tend inland and toward the Western sea, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I will also.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

HERE THE FRAILEST LEAVES OF ME</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>ERE</FONT> the frailest leaves of me and yet my strongest

lasting,

<BR>Here I shade and hide my thoughts, I myself do not expose

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>And yet they expose me more than all my other poems.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

NO LABOR-SAVING MACHINE</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>O</FONT> labor-saving machine,

<BR>Nor discovery have I made,

<BR>Nor will I be able to leave behind me any wealthy bequest to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; found a hospital or library,

<BR>Nor reminiscence of any deed of courage for America,

<BR>Nor literary success nor intellect, nor book for the book-shelf,

<BR>But a few carols vibrating through the air I leave,

<BR>For comrades and lovers.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A GLIMPSE</H2></CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>GLIMPSE</FONT> through an interstice caught,

<BR>Of a crowd of workmen and drivers in a bar-room around

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the stove late of a winter night, and I unremark'd

seated

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in a corner,

<BR>Of a youth who loves me and whom I love, silently

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; approaching and seating himself near, that

he may hold

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me by the hand,

<BR>A long while amid the noises of coming and going, of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drinking and oath and smutty jest,

<BR>There we two, content, happy in being together, speaking

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; little, perhaps not a word.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A LEAF FOR HAND IN HAND</H2></CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>LEAF</FONT> for hand in hand;

<BR>You natural persons old and young!

<BR>You on the Mississippi and on all the branches and bayous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the Mississippi!

<BR>You friendly boatmen and mechanics! you roughs!

<BR>You twain! and all processions moving along the streets!

<BR>I wish to infuse myself among you till I see it common for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you to walk hand in hand.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

EARTH, MY LIKENESS</H2></CENTER>

E<FONT SIZE=-1>ARTH</FONT>, my likeness,

<BR>Though you look so impassive, ample and spheric there,

<BR>I now suspect that is not all;

<BR>I now suspect there is something fierce in you eligible to burst

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forth,

<BR>For an athlete is enamour'd of me, and I of him,

<BR>But toward him there is something fierce and terrible in me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eligible to burst forth,

<BR>I dare not tell it in words, not even in these songs.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

I DREAM'D IN A DREAM</H2></CENTER>
