I <FONT SIZE=-1>DREAM'D</FONT> in a dream I saw a city invincible to the

attacks of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the whole of the rest of the earth,

<BR>I dream'd that was the new city of Friends,

<BR>Nothing was greater there than the quality of robust love, it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; led the rest,

<BR>It was seen every hour in the actions of the men of that city,

<BR>And in all their looks and words.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHAT THINK YOU I TAKE MY PEN IN HAND?</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HAT</FONT> think you I take my pen in hand to record?

<BR>The battle-ship, perfect-model'd, majestic, that I saw pass the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; offing to-day under full sail?

<BR>The splendors of the past day? or the splendor of the night

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that envelops me?

<BR>Or the vaunted glory and growth of the great city spread

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; around me?&amp;emdash;no;

<BR>But merely of two simple men I saw to-day on the pier in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; midst of the crowd, parting the parting of

dear friends,

<BR>The one to remain hung on the other's neck and passionately

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; kiss'd him,

<BR>While the one to depart tightly prest the one to remain in his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arms.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO THE EAST AND TO THE WEST</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>O</FONT> the East and to the West,

<BR>To the man of the Seaside State and of Pennsylvania,

<BR>To the Kanadian of the north, to the Southerner I love,

<BR>These with perfect trust to depict you as myself, the germs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are in all men,

<BR>I believe the main purport of these States is to found a superb

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; friendship, exalt&egrave;, previously unknown,

<BR>Because I perceive it waits, and has been always waiting,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; latent in all men.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SOMETIMES WITH ONE I LOVE</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>OMETIMES</FONT> with one I love I fill myself with rage

for fear I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; effuse unreturn'd love,

<BR>But now I think there is no unreturn'd love, the pay is certain

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one way or another,

<BR>(I loved a certain person ardently and my love was not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; return'd,

<BR>Yet out of that I have written these songs.)

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO A WESTERN BOY</H2></CENTER>

M<FONT SIZE=-1>ANY</FONT> things to absorb I teach to help you become eleve

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mine;

<BR>Yet if blood like mine circle not in your veins,

<BR>If you be not silently selected by lovers and do not silently

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; select lovers,

<BR>Of what use is it that you seek to become eleve of mine?

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FAST-ANCHOR'D ETERNAL O LOVE!</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>AST-ANCHOR'D</FONT> eternal O love! O woman I love!

<BR>O bride! O wife! more resistless than I can tell, the thought

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of you!

<BR>Then separate, as disembodied or another born,

<BR>Ethereal, the last athletic reality, my consolation,

<BR>I ascend, I float in the regions of your love O man,

<BR>O sharer of my roving life.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AMONG THE MULTITUDE</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>MONG</FONT> the men and women the multitude,

<BR>I perceive one picking me out by secret and divine signs,

<BR>Acknowledging none else, not parent, wife, husband,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brother, child, any nearer than I am,

<BR>Some are baffled, but that one is not&amp;emdash;that one knows me.



<P>&nbsp;Ah lover and perfect equal,

<BR>I meant that you should discover me so by faint indirections,

<BR>And I when I meet you mean to discover you by the like in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

O YOU WHOM I OFTEN AND SILENTLY COME</H2></CENTER>

O <FONT SIZE=-1>YOU</FONT> whom I often and silently come where you are

that I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; may be with you,

<BR>As I walk by your side or sit near, or remain in the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; room with you,

<BR>Little you know the subtle electric fire that for your sake is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; playing within me.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1867</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THAT SHADOW MY LIKENESS</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HAT</FONT> shadow my likeness that goes to and fro seeking

a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; livelihood, chattering, chaffering,

<BR>How often I find myself standing and looking at it where it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flits,

<BR>How often I question and doubt whether that is really me;

<BR>But among my lovers and caroling these songs,

<BR>O I never doubt whether that is really me.

<PRE>(1859?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FULL OF LIFE NOW</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>ULL</FONT> of life now, compact, visible,

<BR>I, forty years old the eighty-third year of the States,

<BR>To one a century hence or any number of centuries hence,

<BR>To you yet unborn these, seeking you.



<P>&nbsp;When you read these I that was visible am become invisible,

<BR>Now it is you, compact, visible, realizing my poems, seeking

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>Fancying how happy you were if I could be with you and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; become your comrade;

<BR>Be it as if I were with you. (Be not too certain but I am now

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with you.)

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : By Blue Ontario's Shore</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>By Blue Ontario's Shore</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>y</FONT> blue Ontario's shore,

<BR>As I mused of these warlike days and of peace return'd, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the dead that return no more,

<BR>A Phantom gigantic superb, with stern visage accosted me,

<BR><I>Chant me the poem</I>, it said, <I>that comes from the soul of</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; America, chant me the carol of victory</I>,

<BR><I>And strike up the marches of Libertad, marches more powerful</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet</I>,

<BR><I>And sing me before you go the song of the throes of</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Democracy</I>.



<P>&nbsp;(Democracy, the destin'd conqueror, yet treacherous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lipsmiles everywhere,

<BR>And death and infidelity at every step.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

A Nation announcing itself,

<BR>I myself make the only growth by which I can be appreciated,

<BR>I reject none, accept all, then reproduce all in my own forms.



<P>&nbsp;A breed whose proof is in time and deeds,

<BR>What we are we are, nativity is answer enough to objections,

<BR>We wield ourselves as a weapon is wielded,

<BR>We are powerful and tremendous in ourselves,

<BR>We are executive in ourselves, we are sufficient in the variety

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of ourselves,

<BR>We are the most beautiful to ourselves and in ourselves,

<BR>We stand self-pois'd in the middle, branching thence over the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; world,

<BR>From Missouri, Nebraska, or Kansas, laughing attacks to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; scorn.

<BR>Nothing is sinful to us outside of ourselves,

<BR>Whatever appears, whatever does not appear, we are beautiful

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or sinful in ourselves only.



<P>&nbsp;(O Mother&amp;emdash;O Sisters dear!

<BR>If we are lost, no victor else has destroy'd us,

<BR>It is by ourselves we go down to eternal night.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

Have you thought there could be but a single supreme?

<BR>There can be any number of supremes&amp;emdash;one does not countervail

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; another any more than one eyesight countervails

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; another, or one life countervails another.



<P>&nbsp;All is eligible to all,

<BR>All is for individuals, all is for you,

<BR>No condition is prohibited, not God's or any.



<P>&nbsp;All comes by the body, only health puts you rapport with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; universe.



<P>&nbsp;Produce great Persons, the rest follows.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

Piety and conformity to them that like,

<BR>Peace, obesity, allegiance, to them that like,

<BR>I am he who tauntingly compels men, women, nations,

<BR>Crying, Leap from your seats and contend for your lives!



<P>&nbsp;I am he who walks the States with a barb'd tongue,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; questioning every one I meet,

<BR>Who are you that wanted only to be told what you knew

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before?

<BR>Who are you that wanted only a book to join you in your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nonsense?

<BR>(With pangs and cries as thine own O bearer of many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; children,

<BR>These clamors wild to a race of pride I give.)

<BR>O lands, would you be freer than all that has ever been

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before?

<BR>If you would be freer than all that has been before, come

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; listen to me.



<P>&nbsp;Fear grace, elegance, civilization, delicatesse,

<BR>Fear the mellow sweet, the sucking of honey-juice,

<BR>Beware the advancing mortal ripening of Nature,

<BR>Beware what precedes the decay of the ruggedness of states

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and men.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>5</CENTER>

Ages, precedents, have long been accumulating undirected

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; materials,

<BR>America brings builders, and brings its own styles.



<P>&nbsp;The immortal poets of Asia and Europe have done their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; work and pass'd to other spheres,

<BR>A work remains, the work of surpassing all they have done.



<P>&nbsp;America, curious toward foreign characters, stands by its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; own at all hazards,

<BR>Stands removed, spacious, composite, sound, initiates the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; true use of precedents,

<BR>Does not repel them or the past or what they have produced

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; under their forms,

<BR>Takes the lesson with calmness, perceives the corpse slowly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; borne from the house,

<BR>Perceives that it waits a little while in the door, that it was

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fittest for its days,

<BR>That its life has descended to the stalwart and well-shaped

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heir who approaches,

<BR>And that he shall be fittest for his days.



<P>&nbsp;Any period one nation must lead,

<BR>One land must be the promise and reliance of the future.



<P>&nbsp;These States are the amplest poem,

<BR>Here is not merely a nation but a teeming Nation of nations,

<BR>Here the doings of men correspond with the broadcast

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; doings of the day and night,



<P>&nbsp;Here is what moves in magnificent masses careless of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; particulars,

<BR>Here are the roughs, beards, friendliness, combativeness, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soul loves,

<BR>Here the flowing trains, here the crowds, equality, diversity,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the soul loves.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>6</CENTER>

Land of lands and bards to corroborate!

<BR>Of them standing among them, one lifts to the light a west-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bred face,

<BR>To him the hereditary countenance bequeath'd both mother's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and father's,

<BR>His first parts substances, earth, water, animals, trees,

<BR>Built of the common stock, having room for far and near,

<BR>Used to dispense with other lands, incarnating this land,

<BR>Attracting it body and soul to himself, hanging on its neck

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with incomparable love,

<BR>Plunging his seminal muscle into its merits and demerits,

<BR>Making its cities, beginnings, events, diversities, wars, vocal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in him,

<BR>Making its rivers, lakes, bays, embouchure in him,

<BR>Mississippi with yearly freshets and changing chutes, Columbia,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Niagara, Hudson, spending themselves lovingly

in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; him,

<BR>If the Atlantic coast stretch or the Pacific coast stretch, he

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stretching with them North or South,

<BR>Spanning between them East and West, and touching whatever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is between them,

<BR>Growths growing from him to offset the growths of pine,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cedar, hemlock, live-oak, locust, chestnut,

hickory,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cottonwood, orange, magnolia,

<BR>Tangles as tangled in him as any cranebake or swamp,

<BR>He likening sides and peaks of mountains, forests coated

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with northern transparent ice,

<BR>Off him pasturage sweet and natural as savanna, upland,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prairie,

<BR>Through him flights, whirls, screams, answering those of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fish-hawk, mocking-bird, night-heron, and

eagle,



<P>&nbsp;His spirit surrounding his country's spirit, unclosed to good

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and evil,

<BR>Surrounding the essences of real things, old times and pre

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sent times,

<BR>Surrounding just found shores, islands, tribes of red

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; aborigines,

<BR>Weather-beaten vessels, landings, settlements, embryo

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stature and muscle,

<BR>The haughty defiance of the Year One, war, peace, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; formation of the Constitution,

<BR>The separate States, the simple elastic scheme, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; immigrants,

<BR>The Union always swarming with blatherers and always sure

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and impregnable,

<BR>The unsurvey'd interior, log-houses, clearings, wild animals,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hunters, trappers,

<BR>Surrounding the multiform agriculture, mines, temperature,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the gestation of new States,

<BR>Congress convening every Twelfth-month, the members duly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; coming up from the uttermost parts,

<BR>Surrounding the noble character of mechanics and farmers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; especially the young men,

<BR>Responding their manners, speech, dress, friendships,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the gait they have of persons who never knew

how it felt to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stand in the presence of superiors,

<BR>The freshness and candor of their physiognomy,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the copiousness and decision of their phrenology,

<BR>The picturesque looseness of their carriage, their fierceness

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; when wrong'd,

<BR>The fluency of their speech, their delight in music, their curiosity,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; good temper and open-handedness, the whole

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; composite make,

<BR>The prevailing ardor and enterprise, the large

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amativeness,

<BR>The perfect equality of the female with the male, the fluid

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; movement of the population,

<BR>The superior marine, free commerce, fisheries, whaling,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; golddigging,

<BR>Wharf-hemm'd cities, railroad and steamboat lines

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; intersecting all points,

<BR>Factories, mercantile life, labor-saving machinery, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Northeast, Northwest, Southwest,

<BR>Manhattan firemen, the Yankee swap, southern plantation

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; life,

<BR>Slavery&amp;emdash;the murderous, treacherous conspiracy to raise it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon the ruins of all the rest,

<BR>On and on to the grapple with it&amp;emdash;Assassin! then your life

or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ours be the stake, and respite no more.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>7</CENTER>

(Lo, high toward heaven, this day,

<BR>Libertad, from the conqueress' field return'd,

<BR>I mark the new aureola around your head,

<BR>No more of soft astral, but dazzling and fierce,

<BR>With war's flames and the lambent lightings playing,

<BR>And your port immovable where you stand,

<BR>With still the inextinguishable glance and the clinch'd and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lifted fist,

<BR>And your foot on the neck of the menacing one, the scorner

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; utterly crush'd beneath you,

<BR>The menacing arrogant one that strode and advanced with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his senseless scorn, bearing the murderous

knife,

<BR>The wide-swelling one, the braggart that would yesterday do

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; so much,

<BR>To-day a carrion dead and damn'd, the despised of all the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth,

<BR>An offal rank, to the dunghill maggots spurn'd.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>8</CENTER>

Others take finish, but the Republic is ever constructive and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ever keeps vista,

<BR>Others adorn the past, but you O days of the present, I adorn

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you,

<BR>O days of the future I believe in you&amp;emdash;I isolate myself for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your sake,

<BR>O America because you build for mankind I build for you,

<BR>O well-beloved stone-cutters, I lead them who plan with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; decision and science,

<BR>Lead the present with friendly hand toward the future.

<BR>(Bravas to all impulses sending sane children to the next

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; age!

<BR>But damn that which spends itself with no thought of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stain, pains, dismay, feebleness, it is bequeathing.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>9</CENTER>

I listened to the Phantom by Ontario's shore,

<BR>I heard the voice arising demanding bards,

<BR>By them all native and grand, by them alone can these States

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be fused into the compact organism of a Nation.



<P>&nbsp;To hold men together by paper and seal or by compulsion is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; no account,

<BR>That only holds men together which aggregates all in a living

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; principle, as the hold of the limbs of the

body or the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fibres of plants.



<P>&nbsp;Of all races and eras these States with veins full of poetica

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stuff most need poets, and are to have the

greatest, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; use them the greatest,

<BR>Their Presidents shall not be their common referee so much

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as their poets shall.



<P>&nbsp;(Soul of love and tongue of fire!

<BR>Eye to pierce the deepest deeps and sweep the world!

<BR>Ah Mother, prolific and full in all besides, yet how long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; barren, barren?)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>10</CENTER>

Of these States the poet is the equable man,

<BR>Not in him but off from him things are grotesque, eccentric,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fail of their full returns,

<BR>Nothing out of its place is good, nothing in its place is bad,

<BR>He bestows on every object or quality its fit proportion,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; neither more nor less,

<BR>He is the arbiter of the diverse, he is the key,

<BR>He is the equalizer of his age and land,

<BR>He supplies what wants supplying, he checks what wants

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; checking,



<P>&nbsp;In peace out of him speaks the spirit of peace, large, rich,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thrifty, building populous towns, encouraging

agriculture,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arts, commerce, lighting the study of man,

the soul,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; health, immortality, government,

<BR>In war he is the best backer of the war, he fetches artillery

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as good as the engineer's, he can make every

word he

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; speaks draw blood,

<BR>The years straying toward infidelity he withholds by his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; steady faith,

<BR>He is no arguer, he is judgment, (Nature accepts him

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; absolutely,)

<BR>He judges not as the judge judges but as the sun falling round

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a helpless thing,

<BR>As he sees the farthest he has the most faith,

<BR>His thoughts are the hymns of the praise of things,

<BR>In the dispute on God and eternity he is silent,

<BR>He sees eternity less like a play with a prologue and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; denouement,

<BR>He sees eternity in men and women, he does not see men and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; women as dreams or dots.



<P>&nbsp;For the great Idea, the idea of perfect and free individuals,

<BR>For that, the bard walks in advance, leader of leaders,

<BR>The attitude of him cheers up slaves and horrifies foreign

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; despots.



<P>&nbsp;Without extinction is Liberty, without retrograde is Equality,

<BR>They live in the feelings of young men and the best women,

<BR>(Not for nothing have the indomitable heads of the earth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; been always ready to fall for Liberty.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>11</CENTER>

For the great Idea,

<BR>That, O my brethren, that is the mission of poets.



<P>&nbsp;Songs of stern defiance ever ready,

<BR>Songs of the rapid arming and the march,

<BR>The flag of peace quick-folded, and instead the flag we know,

<BR>Warlike flag of the great Idea.



<P>&nbsp;(Angry cloth I saw there leaping!

<BR>I stand again in leaden rain your flapping folds saluting,

<BR>I sing you over all, flying beckoning through the fight&amp;emdash;O

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hard-contested fight!

<BR>The cannons ope their rosy-flashing muzzles&amp;emdash;the hurtled

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; balls scream,

<BR>The battle-front forms amid the smoke&amp;emdash;the volleys pour

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; incessant from the line,

<BR>Hark, the ringing word <I>Charge</I>!&amp;emdash;now the tussle and

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; furious maddening yells,

<BR>Now the corpses tumble curl'd upon the ground,

<BR>Cold, cold in death, for precious life of you,

<BR>Angry cloth I saw there leaping.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>12</CENTER>

Are you he who would assume a place to teach or be a poet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; here in the States?

<BR>The place is august, the terms obdurate.



<P>&nbsp;Who would assume to teach here may well prepare himself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; body and mind,

<BR>He may well survey, ponder, arm, fortify, harden, make lithe

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; himself,

<BR>He shall surely be question'd beforehand by me with many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and stern questions.



<P>&nbsp;Who are you indeed who would talk or sing to America?

<BR>Have you studied out the land, its idioms and men?

<BR>Have you learn'd the physiology, phrenology, politics,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; geography, pride, freedom, friendship of the

land? its

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; substratums and objects?

<BR>Have you consider'd the organic compact of the first day of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the first year of Independence, sign'd by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Commissioners, ratified by the States, and

read by Washington

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at the head of the army?

<BR>Have you possess'd yourself of the Federal Constitution?

<BR>Do you see who have left all feudal processes and poems

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; behind them, and assumed the poems and processes

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Democracy?



<P>&nbsp;Are you faithful to things? do you teach what the land and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea, the bodies of men, womanhood, amativeness,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heroic angers, teach?

<BR>Have you sped through fleeting customs, popularities?

<BR>Can you hold your hand against all seductions, follies, whirls,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fierce contentions? are you very strong? are

you really of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whole People?

<BR>Are you not of some coterie? some school or mere religion?

<BR>Are you done with reviews and criticisms of life? animating

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; now to life itself?

<BR>Have you vivified yourself from the maternity of these States?

<BR>Have you too the old ever-fresh forbearance and impartiality?

<BR>Do you hold the like love for those hardening to maturity?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for the last-born? little and big? and for

the errant?



<P>&nbsp;What is this you bring my America?

<BR>Is it uniform with my country?

<BR>Is it not something that has been better told or done before?

<BR>Have you not imported this or the spirit of it in some ship?

<BR>Is it not a mere tale? a rhyme? a prettiness?&amp;emdash;is the good

old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cause in it?

<BR>Has it not dangled long at the heels of the poets, politicians,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; literats, of enemies' lands?

<BR>Does it not assume that what is notoriously gone is still here?

<BR>Does it answer universal needs? will it improve manners?

<BR>Does it sound with trumpet-voice the proud victory of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Union in that secession war?

<BR>Can your performance face the open fields and the seaside?

<BR>Will it absorb into me as I absorb food, air, to appear again

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in my strength, gait, face?

<BR>Have real employments contributed to it? original makers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; not mere amanuenses?

<BR>Does it meet modern discoveries, calibres, facts, face to face?

<BR>What does it mean to American persons, progresses, cities?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Chicago, Kanada, Arkansas?

<BR>Does it see behind the apparent custodians the real custodians

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; standing, menacing, silent, the mechanics,

Manhattanese,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Western men, Southerners, significant alike

in their apathy,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and in the promptness of their love?



<P>&nbsp;Does it see what finally befalls, and has always finally

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; befallen, each temporizer, patcher, outsider,

partialist, alarmist,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; infidel, who has ever ask'd any thing of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; America?

<BR>What mocking and scornful negligence?

<BR>The track strew'd with the dust of skeletons,

<BR>By the roadside others disdainfully toss'd.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>13</CENTER>

Rhymes and rhymers pass away, poems distill'd from poems

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pass away,

<BR>The swarms of reflectors and the polite pass, and leave ashes,

<BR>Admirers, importers, obedient persons, make but the soil of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; literature,

<BR>America justifies itself, give it time, no disguise can deceive it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or conceal from it, it is impassive enough,

<BR>Only toward the likes of itself will it advance to meet them,

<BR>If its poets appear it will in due time advance to meet them,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there is no fear of mistake,

<BR>(The proof of a poet shall be sternly deferr'd till his country

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; absorbs him as affectionately as he has absorb'd

it.)



<P>&nbsp;He masters whose spirit masters, he tastes sweetest who

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; results sweetest in the long run,

<BR>The blood of the brawn beloved of time is unconstraint;

<BR>In the need of songs, philosophy, an appropriate native

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grand-opera, shipcraft, any craft,

<BR>He or she is greatest who contributes the greatest original

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; practical example.



<P>&nbsp;Already a nonchalant breed, silently emerging, appears on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the streets,

<BR>People's lips salute only doers, lovers, satisfiers, positive

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; knowers,

<BR>There will shortly be no more priests, I say their work is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; done,

<BR>Death is without emergencies here, but life is perpetual

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; emergencies here,

<BR>Are your body, days, manners, superb? after death you shall

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be superb,

<BR>Justice, health, self-esteem, clear the way with irresistible

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; power;

<BR>How dare you place any thing before a man?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>14</CENTER>

Fall behind me States!

<BR>A man before all&amp;emdash;myself, typical, before all.



<P>&nbsp;Give me the pay I have served for,

<BR>Give to sing the songs of the great Idea, take all the rest,

<BR>I have loved the earth, sun, animals, I have despised riches,

<BR>I have given alms to every one that ask'd, stood up for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stupid and crazy, devoted my income and labor

to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; others,

<BR>Hated tyrants, argued not concerning God, had patience and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; indulgence toward the people, taken off my

hat to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nothing known or unknown,

<BR>Gone freely with powerful uneducated persons and with the young,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and with the mothers of families,

<BR>Read these leaves to myself in the open air, tried them by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; trees, stars, rivers,

<BR>Dismiss'd whatever insulted my own soul or defiled my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; body,

<BR>Claim'd nothing to myself which I have not carefully claim'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for others on the same terms,

<BR>Sped to the camps, and comrades found and accepted from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every state,

<BR>(Upon this breast has many a dying soldier lean'd to breathe

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his last,

<BR>This arm, this hand, this voice, have nourish'd, rais'd,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; restored,

<BR>To life recalling many a prostrate form;)

<BR>I am willing to wait to be understood by the growth of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; taste of myself,

<BR>Rejecting none, permitting all.



<P>&nbsp;(Say O Mother, have I not to your thought been faithful?

<BR>Have I not through life kept you and yours before me?)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>15</CENTER>

I swear I begin to see the meaning of these things,

<BR>It is not the earth, it is not America who is so great,

<BR>It is I who am great or to be great, it is You up there, or any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one,

<BR>It is to walk rapidly through civilizations, governments,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; theories,

<BR>Through poems, pageants, shows, to form individuals.



<P>&nbsp;Underneath all, individuals,

<BR>I swear nothing is good to me now that ignores individuals,

<BR>The American compact is altogether with individuals,

<BR>The only government is that which makes minute of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; individuals,

<BR>The whole theory of the universe is directed unerringly to one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; single individual&amp;emdash;namely to You.



<P>&nbsp;(Mother! with subtle sense severe, with the naked sword in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your hand,

<BR>I saw you at last refuse to treat but directly with individuals.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>16</CENTER>

Underneath all, Nativity,

<BR>I swear I will stand by my own nativity, pious or impious so

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be it;

<BR>I swear I am charm'd with nothing except nativity,

<BR>Men, women, cities, nations, are only beautiful from nativity.



<P>&nbsp;Underneath all is the Expression of love for men and women,

<BR>(I swear I have seen enough of mean and impotent modes of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; expressing love for men and women,

<BR>After this day I take my own modes of expressing love for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men and women.)



<P>&nbsp;I swear I will have each quality of my race in myself,

<BR>(Talk as you like, he only suits these States whose manners

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; favor the audacity and sublime turbulence

of the States.)



<P>&nbsp;Underneath the lessons of things, spirits, Nature, governments,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ownerships, I swear I perceive other lessons,



<P>&nbsp;Underneath all to me is myself, to you yourself, (the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; monotonous old song.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>17</CENTER>

O I see flashing that this America is only you and me,

<BR>Its power, weapons, testimony, are you and me,

<BR>Its crimes, lies, thefts, defections, are you and me,

<BR>Its Congress is you and me, the officers, capitols, armies,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ships, are you and me,

<BR>Its endless gestations of new States are you and me,

<BR>The war, (that war so bloody and grim, the war I will hence-forth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forget), was you and me,

<BR>Natural and artificial are you and me,

<BR>Freedom, language, poems, employments, are you and me,

<BR>Past, present, future, are you and me.



<P>&nbsp;I dare not shirk any part of myself,

<BR>Not any part of America good or bad,

<BR>Not to build for that which builds for mankind,

<BR>Not to balance ranks, complexions, creeds, and the sexes,

<BR>Not to justify science nor the march of equality,

<BR>Nor to feed the arrogant blood of the brawn belov'd of time.



<P>&nbsp;I am for those that have never been master'd,

<BR>For men and women whose tempers have never been

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; master'd,

<BR>For those whom laws, theories, conventions, can never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; master.



<P>&nbsp;I am for those who walk abreast with the whole earth,

<BR>Who inaugurate one to inaugurate all.



<P>&nbsp;I will not be outfaced by irrational things,

<BR>I will penetrate what it is in them that is sarcastic upon me,

<BR>I will make cities and civilizations defer to me,

<BR>This is what I have learnt from America&amp;emdash;it is the amount,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and it I teach again.



<P>&nbsp;(Democracy, while weapons were everywhere aim'd at your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breast,

<BR>I saw you serenely give birth to immortal children, saw in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dreams your dilating form,

<BR>Saw you with spreading mantle covering the world.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>18</CENTER>

I will confront these shows of the day and night,

<BR>I will know if I am to be less than they,

<BR>I will see if I am not as majestic as they,

<BR>I will see if I am not as subtle and real as they,

<BR>I will see if I am to be less generous than they,

<BR>I will see if I have no meaning, while the houses and ships

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; have meaning,

<BR>I will see if the fishes and birds are to be enough for themselves,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and I am not to be enough for myself.



<P>&nbsp;I match my spirit against yours you orbs, growths, mountains,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brutes,

<BR>Copious as you are I absorb you all in myself, and become

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the master myself,

<BR>America isolated yet embodying all, what is it finally except

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself?

<BR>These States, what are they except myself?



<P>&nbsp;I know now why the earth is gross, tantalizing, wicked, it is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for my sake,

<BR>I take you specially to be mine, you terrible, rude forms.



<P>&nbsp;(Mother, bend down, bend close to me your face,

<BR>I know not what these plots and wards and deferments are for,

<BR>I know not fruition's success, but I know that through war

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and crime your work goes on, and must yet

go on.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>19</CENTER>

Thus by blue Ontario's shore,

<BR>While the winds fann'd me and the waves came trooping

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; toward me,

<BR>I thrill'd with the power's pulsations, and the charm of my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; theme was upon me,

<BR>Till the tissues that held me parted their ties upon me.



<P>&nbsp;And I saw the free souls of poets,

<BR>The loftiest bards of past ages strode before me,

<BR>Strange large men, long unwaked, undisclosed, were disclosed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>20</CENTER>

O my rapt verse, my call, mock me not!

<BR>Not for the bards of the past, not to invoke them have I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; launch'd you forth,

<BR>Not to call even those lofty bards here by Ontario's shores,

<BR>Have I sung so capricious and loud my savage song.



<P>&nbsp;Bards for my own land only I invoke,

<BR>(For the war, the war is over, the field is clear'd,)

<BR>Till they strike up marches henceforth triumphant and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; onward,

<BR>To cheer O Mother your boundless expectant soul.



<P>&nbsp;Bards of the great Idea! bards of the peaceful inventions!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (for the war, the war is over!)

<BR>Yet bards of latent armies, a million soldiers waiting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; everready,

<BR>Bards with songs as from burning coals or the lightning's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fork'd stripes!

<BR>Ample Ohio's, Kanada's bards&amp;emdash;bards of California! inland

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bards&amp;emdash;bards of the war!

<BR>You by my charm I invoke.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

REVERSALS</H2></CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>et</FONT> that which stood in front go behind,

<BR>Let that which was behind advance to the front,

<BR>Let bigots, fools, unclean persons, offer new propositions,

<BR>Let the old propositions be postponed,

<BR>Let a man seek pleasure everywhere except in himself,

<BR>Let a woman seek happiness everywhere except in herself.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Sands at Seventy</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Sands at Seventy</I></H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>[<I>First Annex</I>]</CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MANNAHATTA</H2></CENTER>

M<FONT SIZE=-1>Y</FONT> city's fit and noble name resumed,

<BR>Choice aboriginal name, with marvellous beauty, meaning,

<BR><I>A rocky founded island &amp;emdash; shores where ever</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gayly dash the coming, going, hurrying

sea waves</I>.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

PAUMANOK</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>EA-BEAUTY</FONT>! stretch'd and basking!

<BR>One side thy inland ocean laving, broad, with copious

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; commerce, steamers, sails,

<BR>And one the Atlantic's wind caressing, fierce or gentle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; mighty hulls dark-gliding in

the distance.

<BR>Isle of sweet brooks of drinking-water &amp;emdash; healthy

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; air and soil!

<BR>Isle of the salty shore and breeze and brine!

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FROM MONTAUK POINT</H2></CENTER>

I <FONT SIZE=-1>STAND</FONT> as on some mighty eagle's beak,

<BR>Eastward the sea absorbing, viewing, (nothing but sea and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sky,)

<BR>The tossing waves, the foam, the ships in the distance.

<BR>The wild unrest, the snowy, curling caps &amp;emdash; that

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inbound urge and urge of waves,

<BR>Seeking the shores forever.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO THOSE WHO'VE FAIL'D</H2></CENTER>

To those who've fail'd, in aspiration vast,

<BR>To unnam'd soldiers fallen in front on the lead,

<BR>To calm, devoted engineers &amp;emdash; to over-ardent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; travelers &amp;emdash; to pilots on their

ships,

<BR>To many a lofty song and picture without recognition

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; I'd rear a laurel-cover'd monument,

<BR>High, high above the rest &amp;emdash; To all cut off

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before their time,

<BR>Possess'd by some strange spirit of fire,

<BR>Quench'd by an early death.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A CAROL CLOSING SIXTY-NINE</H2></CENTER>

A <FONT SIZE=-1>CAROL</FONT> closing sixty-nine &amp;emdash; a <I>r&eacute;sum&eacute;</I>

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; a repetition,

<BR>My lines in joy and hope continuing on the same,

<BR>Of ye, O God, Life, Nature, Freedom, Poetry;

<BR>Of you, my Land &amp;emdash; your rivers, prairies,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; States &amp;emdash; you, mottled

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Flag I love,

<BR>Your aggregate retain'd entire &amp;emdash; Of north,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; south, east and west, your items all;

<BR>Of me myself &amp;emdash; the jocund heart yet beating

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in my breast,

<BR>The body wreck'd, old, poor and paralyzed &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the strange inertia falling pall-like round

me,

<BR>The burning fires down in my sluggish blood not yet extinct,

<BR>The undiminish'd faith &amp;emdash; the groups of loving friends.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE BRAVEST SOLDIERS</H2></CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>RAVE</FONT>, brave were the soldiers (high named to-day)

who

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lived through the fight;

<BR>But the bravest press'd to the front and fell, unnamed,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unknown.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A FONT OF TYPE</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HIS</FONT> latent mine &amp;emdash; these unlaunch'd voices

&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; passionate powers,

<BR>Wrath, argument, or praise, or comic leer, or prayer devout,

<BR>(Not nonpareil, brevier, bourgeois, long primer merely,)

<BR>These ocean waves arousable to fury and to death,

<BR>Or sooth'd to ease and sheeny sun and sleep,

<BR>Within the pallid slivers slumbering.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AS I SIT WRITING HERE</H2></CENTER>

As I sit writing here, sick and grown old,

<BR>Not my least burden is that dulness of the years, querilities,

<BR>Ungracious glooms, aches, lethargy, constipation, whimpering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <I>ennui</I>,

<BR>May filter in my daily songs.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MY CANARY BIRD</H2></CENTER>

D<FONT SIZE=-1>ID</FONT> we count great, O soul, to penetrate the themes

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mighty books,

<BR>Absorbing deep and full from thoughts, plays, speculations?

<BR>But now from thee to me, caged bird, to feel thy joyous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; warble,

<BR>Filling the air, the lonesome room, the long forenoon,

<BR>Is it not just as great, O soul?

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

QUERIES TO MY SEVENTIETH YEAR</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>PPROACHING</FONT>, nearing, curious,

<BR>Thou dim, uncertain spectre &amp;emdash; bringest thou life

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or death?

<BR>Strength, weakness, blindness, more paralysis and heavier?

<BR>Or placid skies and sun? Wilt stir the waters yet?

<BR>Or haply cut me short for good? Or leave me here as now,

<BR>Dull, parrot-like and old, with crack'd voice harping,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; screeching?

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE WALLABOUT MARTYRS</H2></CENTER>

(<I>In Brooklyn, in an old vault, mark'd by no special recognition, lie

huddled at this moment the undoubtedly authentic remains of the stanchest

and earliest Revolutionary patriots from the British prison ships and prisons

of the times of</I> 1776-83, <I>in and around New York, and from all over

Long Island; originally buried &amp;emdash; many thousands of them &amp;emdash;

in trenches in the Wallabout sands</I>.)



<P>&nbsp;G<FONT SIZE=-1>REATER</FONT> than memory of Achilles or Ulysses,

<BR>More, more by far to thee than tomb of Alexander,



<P>&nbsp;Those cart loads of old charnel ashes, scales and splints of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mouldy bones,

<BR>Once living men &amp;emdash; once resolute courage, aspiration,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; strength,

<BR>The stepping stones to thee to-day and here, America.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE FIRST DANDELION</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>IMPLE</FONT> and fresh and fair from winter's close emerging,

<BR>As if no artifice of fashion, business, politics, had ever

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; been,

<BR>Forth from its sunny nook of shelter'd grass &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; innocent, golden, calm as the dawn,

<BR>The spring's first dandelion shows its trustful face.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AMERICA</H2></CENTER>

C<FONT SIZE=-1>ENTRE</FONT> of equal daughters, equal sons,

<BR>All, all alike endear'd, grown, ungrown, young or old,

<BR>Strong, ample, fair, enduring, capable, rich,

<BR>Perennial with the Earth, with Freedom, Law and Love,

<BR>A grand, sane, towering, seated Mother,

<BR>Chair'd in the adamant of Time.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

MEMORIES</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>OW</FONT> sweet the silent backward tracings!

<BR>The wanderings as in dreams &amp;emdash; the meditation

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of old times resumed &amp;emdash; their loves,

joys,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; persons, voyages.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO-DAY AND THEE</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> appointed winners in a long-stretch'd game;

<BR>The course of Time and nations &amp;emdash; Egypt,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; India, Greece and Rome;

<BR>The past entire, with all its heroes, histories, arts,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; experiments,

<BR>Its store of songs, inventions, voyages, teachers, books,

<BR>Garner'd for now and thee &amp;emdash; To think of it!

<BR>The heirdom all converged in thee!

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AFTER THE DAZZLE OF DAY</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>FTER</FONT> the dazzle of day is gone,

<BR>Only the dark, dark night shows to my eyes the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stars;

<BR>After the clangor of organ majestic, or chorus,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or perfect band,

<BR>Silent, athwart my soul, moves the symphony true.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ABRAHAM LINCOLN, BORN FEB. 12, 1809</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>Publish'd Feb</I>. 12, 1888)</CENTER>





<P>T<FONT SIZE=-1>O-DAY</FONT>, from each and all, a breath of prayer &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a pulse of thought,

<BR>To memory of Him &amp;emdash; to birth of Him.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OUT OF MAY'S SHOWS SELECTED</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>PPLE</FONT> orchards, the trees all cover'd with blossoms;

<BR>Wheat fields carpeted far and near in vital emerald green;

<BR>The eternal, exhaustless freshness of each early morning;

<BR>The yellow, golden, transparent haze of the warm afternoon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sun;

<BR>The aspiring lilac bushes with profuse purple or white

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flowers.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

HALCYON DAYS</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>OT</FONT> from successful love alone,

<BR>Nor wealth, nor honor'd middle age, nor victories of politics

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or war;

<BR>But as life wanes, and all the turbulent passions calm,

<BR>As gorgeous, vapory, silent hues cover the evening sky,

<BR>As softness, fulness, rest, suffuse the frame, like fresher,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; balmier air,

<BR>As the days take on a mellower light, and the apple at

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; last hangs really finish'd and indolent-ripe

on the tree,

<BR>Then for the teeming quietest, happiest days of all!

<BR>The brooding and blissful halcyon days!

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

FANCIES AT NAVESINK</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE PILOT IN THE MIST</H2></CENTER>

Steaming the northern rapids &amp;emdash; (an old St.

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Lawrence reminiscence,

<BR>A sudden memory-flash comes back, I know not why,

<BR>Here waiting for the sunrise, gazing from this hill;)<SUP><FONT SIZE=-2><A HREF="sand.html#ftn1">*</A></FONT></SUP>

<BR>Again 'tis just at morning &amp;emdash; a heavy haze

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contends with daybreak,

<BR>Again the trembling, laboring vessel veers me &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I press through foam-dash'd rocks that almost

touch me,

<BR>Again I mark where aft the small thin Indian helmsman

<BR>Looms in the mist, with brow elate and governing hand.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

HAD I THE CHOICE</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>AD</FONT> I the choice to tally greatest bards,

<BR>To limn their portraits, stately, beautiful, and emulate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at will,

<BR>Homer with all his wars and warriors &amp;emdash; Hector,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Achilles, Ajax,

<BR>Or Shakspere's woe-entangled Hamlet, Lear, Othello

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; Tennyson's fair ladies,

<BR>Metre or wit the best, or choice conceit to wield in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; perfect rhyme, delight of singers;

<BR>These, these, O sea, all these I'd gladly barter,

<BR>Would you the undulation of one wave, its trick to me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; transfer,

<BR>Or breathe one breath of yours upon my verse,

<BR>And leave its odor there,



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

YOU TIDES WITH CEASELESS SWELL</H2></CENTER>

Y<FONT SIZE=-1>OU</FONT> tides with ceaseless swell! you power that does

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this work!

<BR>You unseen force, centripetal, centrifugal, through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; space's spread,

<BR>Rapport of sun, moon, earth, and all the constellations,



<P>&nbsp;What are the messages by you from distant stars to us?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what Sirius? what Capella's?

<BR>What central heart &amp;emdash; and you the pulse &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; vivifies all? what boundless aggregate of

all?

<BR>What subtle indirection and significance in you? what clue

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to all in you? what fluid, vast identity,

<BR>Holding the universe with all its parts as one &amp;emdash; as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sailing in a ship?



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

LAST OF EBB, AND DAYLIGHT WANING</H2></CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>AST</FONT> of ebb, and daylight waning,

<BR>Scented sea-cool landward making, smells of sedge

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and salt incoming,

<BR>With many a half-caught voice sent up from the eddies,

<BR>Many a muffled confession &amp;emdash; many a sob and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whisper'd word,

<BR>As of speakers far or hid.



<P>&nbsp;How they sweep down and out! how they mutter!

<BR>Poets unnamed &amp;emdash; artists greatest of any, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cherish'd lost designs,

<BR>Love's unresponse &amp;emdash; a chorus of age's complaints

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; hope's last words,

<BR>Some suicide's despairing cry, <I>Away to the boundless</I>

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <I>waste, and never again return</I>.



<P>&nbsp;On to oblivion then!

<BR>On, on, and do your part, ye burying, ebbing tide!

<BR>On for your time, ye furious debouch&eacute;!



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

AND YET NOT YOU ALONE</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>ND</FONT> yet not you alone, twilight and burying ebb,

<BR>Nor you, ye lost designs alone &amp;emdash; nor failures,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; aspirations;

<BR>I know, divine deceitful ones, your glamour's seeming;

<BR>Duly by you, from you, the tide and light again &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; duly the hinges turning,

<BR>Duly the needed discord-parts offsetting, blending,

<BR>Weaving from you, from Sleep, Night, Death itself,

<BR>The rhythmus of Birth eternal.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

PROUDLY THE FLOOD COMES IN</H2></CENTER>

P<FONT SIZE=-1>ROUDLY</FONT> the flood comes in, shouting, foaming, advancing,

<BR>Long it holds at the high, with bosom broad outswelling,

<BR>All throbs, dilates&amp;emdash;the farms, woods, streets of cities

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;workmen at work,

<BR>Mainsails, topsails, jibs, appear in the offing&amp;emdash;steamers'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pennants of smoke&amp;emdash;and under the

forenoon sun,

<BR>Freighted with human lives, gaily the outward bound, gaily

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the inward bound,

<BR>Flaunting from many a spar the flag I love.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

BY THAT LONG SCAN OF WAVES</H2></CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>Y</FONT> that long scan of waves, myself call'd back, resumed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon myself,

<BR>In every crest some undulating light or shade&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; some retrospect,

<BR>Joys, travels, studies, silent panoramas&amp;emdash;scenes,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ephemeral,

<BR>The long past war, the battles, hospital sights, the wounded

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the dead,

<BR>Myself through every by-gone phase&amp;emdash;my idle

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; youth&amp;emdash;old age at hand,

<BR>My three-score years of life summ'd up, and more, and past,

<BR>By any grand ideal tried, intentionless, the whole a nothing,

<BR>And haply yet some drop within God's scheme's ensemble

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;some wave, or part of wave,

<BR>Like one of yours, ye multitudinous ocean.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>

<H2>

THEN LAST OF ALL</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HEN</FONT> last of all, caught from these shores, this hill,

<BR>Of you O tides, the mystic human meaning:

<BR>Only by law of you, your swell and ebb, enclosing me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the same,

<BR>The brain that shapes, the voice that chants this song.

<PRE>1885&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ELECTION DAY, NOVEMBER, 1884</H2></CENTER>

I<FONT SIZE=-1>F</FONT> I should need to name, O Western World, your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; powerfulest scene and show,

<BR>'Twould not be you, Niagara&amp;emdash;nor you, ye

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; limitless prairies &amp;emdash;nor your huge

rifts of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; canyons, Colorado,

<BR>Nor you, Yosemite&amp;emdash;nor Yellowstone, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all its spasmic geyser loops ascending to

the skies,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; appearing and disappearing,

<BR>Nor Oregon's white cones&amp;emdash;nor Huron's belt

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of mighty lakes&amp;emdash;nor Mississippi's

stream:

<BR>&amp;emdash;This seething hemisphere's humanity, as now,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I'd name &amp;emdash;<I>the still small voice</I>

vibrating

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;America's choosing day,

<BR>(The heart of it not in the chosen&amp;emdash;the act itself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the main, the quadrennial choosing,)

<BR>The stretch of North and South arous'd&amp;emdash;sea-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; board and&amp;emdash; inland Texas to Maine&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Prairie States&amp;emdash; Vermont, Virginia,

California,

<BR>The final ballot-shower from East to West&amp;emdash;the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; paradox and conflict,

<BR>The countless snow-flakes falling&amp;emdash;(a swordless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; conflict,

<BR>Yet more than all Rome's wars of old, or modern

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Napoleon's:) the peaceful choice of all,

<BR>Or good or ill humanity&amp;emdash;welcoming the darker

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; odds, the dross:

<BR>&amp;emdash;Foams and ferments the wine? it serves to purify

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;while the heart pants, life glows:

<BR>These stormy gusts and winds waft precious ships,

<BR>Swell'd Washington's, Jefferson's, Lincoln's sails.

<PRE>1884&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WITH HUSKY-HAUGHTY LIPS, O SEA!</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>ITH</FONT> husky-haughty lips, O sea!

<BR>Where day and night I wend thy surf-beat shore,

<BR>Imaging to my sense thy varied strange suggestions,

<BR>(I see and plainly list thy talk and conference here,)

<BR>Thy troops of white-maned racers racing to the goal,

<BR>Thy ample, smiling face, dash'd with the sparkling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dimples of the sun,

<BR>Thy brooding scowl and murk&amp;emdash;thy unloos'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hurricanes,



<P>&nbsp;Thy unsubduedness, caprices, wilfulness;

<BR>Great as thou art above the rest, thy many tears&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a lack from all eternity in thy content,

<BR>(Naught but the greatest struggles, wrongs, defeats, could

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; make thee greatest&amp;emdash;no less could

make thee,)

<BR>Thy lonely state&amp;emdash;something thou ever seek'st

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and seek'st, yet never gain'st,

<BR>Surely some right withheld&amp;emdash;some voice, in huge

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; monotonous rage, of freedom-lover pent,

<BR>Some vast heart, like a planet's, chain'd and chafing in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; those breakers,

<BR>By lengthen'd swell, and spasm, and panting breath,

<BR>And rhythmic rasping of thy sands and waves,

<BR>And serpent hiss, and savage peals of laughter,

<BR>And undertones of distant lion roar,

<BR>(Sounding, appealing to the sky's deaf ear&amp;emdash;but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; now, rapport for once,

<BR>A phantom in the night thy confidant for once,)

<BR>The first and last confession of the globe,

<BR>Outsurging, muttering from thy soul's abysms,

<BR>The tale of cosmic elemental passion,

<BR>Thou tellest to a kindred soul.

<PRE>(1883)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

DEATH OF GENERAL GRANT</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>S</FONT> one by one withdraw the lofty actors,

<BR>From that great play on history's stage eterne,

<BR>That lurid, partial act of war and peace&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of old and new contending,

<BR>Fought out through wrath, fears, dark dismays, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; many a long suspense;

<BR>All past&amp;emdash;and since, in countless graves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; receding, mellowing,

<BR>Victor's and vanquish'd&amp;emdash;Lincoln's and Lee's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;now thou, with them,

<BR>Man of the mighty days&amp;emdash;and equal to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; days!

<BR>Thou from the prairies!&amp;emdash;tangled and many-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; vein'd and hard has been thy part,

<BR>To admiration has it been enacted!

<PRE>1885&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

RED JACKET (FROM ALOFT)</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>Impromptu on Buffalo City's monument to, and re-burial of</I></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>the old Iroquois orator, October</I> 9, 1884)</CENTER>





<P>U<FONT SIZE=-1>PON</FONT> this scene, this show,

<BR>Yielded to-day by fashion, learning, wealth,

<BR>(Nor in caprice alone&amp;emdash;some grains

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of deepest meaning,)

<BR>Haply, aloft, (who knows?) from distant sky-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clouds' blended shapes,

<BR>As some old tree, or rock or cliff, thrill'd with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; its soul,

<BR>Product of Nature's sun, stars, earth direct

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; a towering human form,

<BR>In hunting-shirt of film, arm'd with the rifle, a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; half-ironical smile curving its phantom lips,

<BR>Like one of Ossian's ghosts looks down.

<PRE>(1884)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WASHINGTON'S MONUMENT, FEBRUARY, 1885</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>H</FONT>, not this marble, dead and cold:

<BR>Far from its base and shaft expanding&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the round zones circling, comprehending,

<BR>Thou, Washington, art all the world's, the continents'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; entire not yours alone, America,

<BR>Europe's as well, in every part, castle of lord or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; laborer's cot,

<BR>Or frozen North, or sultry South&amp;emdash;the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; African's &amp;emdash;the Arab's in his tent,

<BR>Old Asia's there with venerable smile, seated amid

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her ruins;

<BR>(Greets the antique the hero new? 'tis but the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the heir legitimate, continued ever,

<BR>The indomitable heart and arm&amp;emdash;proofs of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the never-broken line,

<BR>Courage, alertness, patience, faith, the same

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; e'en in defeat defeated not,

the same:)

<BR>Wherever sails a ship, or house is built on land, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; day or night,

<BR>Through teeming cities' streets, indoors or out,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; factories or farms,



<P>&nbsp;Now, or to come, or past&amp;emdash;where patriot

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wills existed or exist,

<BR>Wherever Freedom, pois'd by Toleration, sway'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by Law,

<BR>Stands or is rising thy true monument.

<PRE>(1885?)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OF THAT BLITHE THROAT OF THINE</H2></CENTER>

(<I>More than eighty-three degrees north&amp;emdash;about a good day's

steaming distance to the Pole by one of our fast oceaners in clear water&amp;emdash;Greely

the explorer heard the song of a single snow-bird merrily sounding over

the desolation.</I>)



<P>&nbsp;O<FONT SIZE=-1>F</FONT> that blithe throat of thine from arctic

bleak

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and blank,

<BR>I'll mind the lesson, solitary bird&amp;emdash;let me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; too welcome chilling drifts,

<BR>E'en the profoundest chill, as now&amp;emdash;a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; torpid pulse, a brain unnerv'd,

<BR>Old age land-lock'd within its winter bay&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (cold, cold, O cold!)

<BR>These snowy hairs, my feeble arm, my frozen feet,

<BR>For them thy faith, thy rule I take, and grave it to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the last;

<BR>Not summer's zones alone&amp;emdash;not chants of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; youth, or south's warm tides alone,

<BR>But held by sluggish floes, pack'd in the northern

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ice, the cumulus of years,

<BR>These with gay heart I also sing.

<PRE>(1884)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

BROADWAY</H2></CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>HAT</FONT> hurrying human tides, or day or night!

<BR>What passions, winnings, losses, ardors, swim

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy waters!

<BR>What whirls of evil, bliss and sorrow, stem thee!

<BR>What curious questioning glances&amp;emdash;glints

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of love!

<BR>Leer, envy, scorn, contempt, hope, aspiration!

<BR>Thou portal&amp;emdash;thou arena&amp;emdash;thou

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the myriad long-drawn lines and groups!

<BR>(Could but thy flagstones, curbs, fa&ccedil;ades, tell

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; their inimitable tales;

<BR>Thy windows rich, and huge hotels&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thy side-walks wide;)



<P>&nbsp;Thou of the endless sliding, mincing, shuffling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; feet!

<BR>Thou, like the parti-colored world itself&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; like infinite, teeming, mocking life!

<BR>Thou visor'd, vast, unspeakable show and lesson!

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TO GET THE FINAL LILT OF SONGS</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>O</FONT> get the final lilt of songs,

<BR>To penetrate the inmost lore of poets&amp;emdash;to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know the mighty ones,

<BR>Job, Homer, Eschylus, Dante, Shakspere,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Tennyson, Emerson;

<BR>To diagnose the shifting-delicate tints of love and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pride and doubt&amp;emdash;to truly understand,

<BR>To encompass these, the last keen faculty and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; entranceprice,

<BR>Old age, and what it brings from all its past

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; experiences.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OLD SALT KOSSABONE</H2></CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>AR</FONT> back, related on my mother's side,

<BR>Old Salt Kossabone, I'll tell you how he died:

<BR>(Had been a sailor all his life&amp;emdash;was nearly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 90&amp;emdash;lived with his married grandchild,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Jenny;
