<BR>House on a hill, with view of bay at hand, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; distant cape, and stretch to open sea;

<BR>The last of afternoons, the evening hours, for many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a year his regular custom,

<BR>In his great arm chair by the window seated,

<BR>(Sometimes, indeed, through half the day,)

<BR>Watching the coming, going of the vessels, he

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mutters to himself&amp;emdash;And now the

close

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of all:

<BR>One struggling outbound brig, one day, baffled for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long &amp;emdash;cross-tides and much wrong

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; going,

<BR>At last at nightfall strikes the breeze aright, her

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; whole luck veering,

<BR>And swiftly bending round the cape, the darkness

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; proudly entering, cleaving, as he watches,



<P>&nbsp;``She's free&amp;emdash;she's on her destination''

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;these the last words&amp;emdash;when

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Jenny came, he sat there dead,

<BR>Dutch Kossabone, Old Salt, related on my mother's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; side, far back.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE DEAD TENOR</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>S</FONT> down the stage again,

<BR>With Spanish hat and plumes, and gait inimitable,

<BR>Back from the fading lessons of the past, I'd call,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I'd tell and own,

<BR>How much from thee! the revelation of the singing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; voice from thee!

<BR>(So firm&amp;emdash;so liquid soft&amp;emdash;again

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that tremulous, manly timbre!

<BR>The perfect singing voice&amp;emdash;deepest of all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me the lesson&amp;emdash;trial and test

of all:)

<BR>How through those strains distill'd&amp;emdash;how

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the rapt ears, the soul of me, absorbing

<BR><I>Fernando's</I> heart, <I>Manrico's</I> passionate call,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <I>Ernani's,</I> sweet <I>Gennaro's,</I>

<BR>I fold thenceforth, or seek to fold, within my chants

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; transmuting,

<BR>Freedom's and Love's and Faith's unloos'd cantabile,

<BR>(As perfume's, color's, sunlight's correlation:)

<BR>From these, for these, with these, a hurried line,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dead tenor,

<BR>A wafted autumn leaf, dropt in the closing grave,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the shovel'd earth,

<BR>To memory of thee.

<PRE>1884&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

CONTINUITIES</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>From a talk I had lately with a German spiritualist</I>)</CENTER>





<P>N<FONT SIZE=-1>OTHING</FONT> is ever really lost, or can be lost,

<BR>No birth, identity, form&amp;emdash;no object

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the world,

<BR>Nor life, nor force, nor any visible thing;

<BR>Appearance must not foil, nor shifted sphere

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; confuse thy brain.

<BR>Ample are time and space&amp;emdash;ample the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fields of Nature.

<BR>The body, sluggish, aged, cold&amp;emdash;the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; embers left from earlier fires,



<P>&nbsp;The light in the eye grown dim, shall duly flame

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; again;

<BR>The sun now low in the west rises for mornings

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and for noons continual;

<BR>To frozen clods ever the spring's invisible law

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; returns,

<BR>With grass and flowers and summer fruits and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; corn.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

YONNONDIO</H2></CENTER>

(<I>The sense of the word is lament for the aborigines. It is an</I>

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <I>Iroquois term; and has been used for a

personal name.</I>)



<P>&nbsp;A <FONT SIZE=-1>SONG,</FONT> a poem of itself&amp;emdash;the word

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; itself a dirge,

<BR>Amid the wilds, the rocks, the storm and wintry

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; night,

<BR>To me such misty, strange tableaux the syllables

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; calling up;

<BR>Yonnondio&amp;emdash;I see, far in the west or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; north, a limitless ravine, with plains and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mountains dark,

<BR>I see swarms of stalwart chieftains, medicine-men,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and warriors,

<BR>As flitting by like clouds of ghosts, they pass and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are gone in the twilight,

<BR>(Race of the woods, the landscapes free, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; falls!

<BR>No picture, poem, statement, passing them to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; future:)

<BR>Yonnondio! Yonnondio!&amp;emdash;unlimn'd they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; disappear;

<BR>To-day gives place, and fades&amp;emdash;the cities,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; farms, factories fade;

<BR>A muffled sonorous sound, a wailing word is borne

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; through the air for a moment,

<BR>Then blank and gone and still, and utterly lost.

<PRE>1887&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

LIFE</H2></CENTER>

E<FONT SIZE=-1>VER</FONT> the undiscouraged, resolute, struggling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soul of man;

<BR>(Have former armies fail'd? then we send fresh

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; armies &amp;emdash;and fresh again;)

<BR>Ever the grappled mystery of all earth's ages old

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or new;

<BR>Ever the eager eyes, hurrahs, the welcome-clapping

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hands, the loud applause;

<BR>Ever the soul dissatisfied, curious, unconvinced at last;

<BR>Struggling to-day the same&amp;emdash;battling the same.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

``GOING SOMEWHERE''</H2></CENTER>

M<FONT SIZE=-1>Y</FONT> science-friend, my noblest woman-friend,

<BR>(Now buried in an English grave&amp;emdash;and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; this a memory-leaf for her dear sake,)

<BR>Ended our talk&amp;emdash;``The sum, concluding

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all we know of old or modern learning,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; intuitions deep,

<BR>``Of all Geologies&amp;emdash;Histories&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of all Astronomy&amp;emdash;of Evolution,

Meta-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; physics all,

<BR>``Is, that we all are onward, onward, speeding

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slowly, surely bettering,

<BR>``Life, life an endless march, an endless army, (no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; halt, but it is duly over,)

<BR>``The world, the race, the soul&amp;emdash;in space

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and time the universes,

<BR>``All bound as is befitting each&amp;emdash;all surely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; going somewhere.''

<PRE>1887&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SMALL THE THEME OF MY CHANT</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>From the</I> 1867 <I>edition ``L. of G.''</I>)</CENTER>





<P>S<FONT SIZE=-1>MALL</FONT> the theme of my Chant, yet the greatest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; namely, One's-Self&amp;emdash;a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; simple, separate person. That, for the use

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the New World, I sing,

<BR>Man's physiology complete, from top to toe, I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sing. Not physiognomy alone, nor brain alone,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is worthy for the Muse;&amp;emdash;I say

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Form complete is worthier far. The Female

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; equally with the Male, I sing.

<BR>Nor cease at the theme of One's-Self. I speak

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the word of the modern, the word En-Masse.

<BR>My Days I sing, and the Lands&amp;emdash;with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; interstice I knew of hapless War.

<BR>(O friend, whoe'er you are, at last arriving hither

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to commence, I feel through every leaf the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pressure of your hand, which I return.

<BR>And thus upon our journey, footing the road, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more than once, and link'd together let us

go.)

<PRE>1867&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TRUE CONQUERORS</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>LD</FONT> farmers, travelers, workmen (no matter how

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; crippled or bent,)

<BR>Old sailors, out of many a perilous voyage, storm

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and wreck,

<BR>Old soldiers from campaigns, with all their wounds,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; defeats and scars;

<BR>Enough that they've survived at all&amp;emdash;long life's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unflinching ones!

<BR>Forth from their struggles, trials, fights, to have emerged

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at all&amp;emdash;in that alone,

<BR>True conquerors o'er all the rest.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE UNITED STATES TO OLD WORLD CRITICS</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>ERE</FONT> first the duties of to-day, the lessons of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; concrete,

<BR>Wealth, order, travel, shelter, products, plenty;

<BR>As of the building of some varied, vast, perpetual

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; edifice,

<BR>Whence to arise inevitable in time, the towering

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; roofs, the lamps,

<BR>The solid-planted spires tall shooting to the stars.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE CALMING THOUGHT OF ALL</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HAT</FONT> coursing on, whate'er men's speculations,

<BR>Amid the changing schools, theologies, philosophies,

<BR>Amid the bawling presentations new and old,

<BR>The round earth's silent vital laws, facts, modes

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; continue.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THANKS IN OLD AGE</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HANKS</FONT> in old age&amp;emdash;thanks ere I go,

<BR>For health, the midday sun, the impalpable air

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; for life, mere life,

<BR>For precious ever-lingering memories, (of you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my mother dear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;you father&amp;emdash;you, brothers,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sisters, friends,)

<BR>For all my days&amp;emdash;not those of peace

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; alone&amp;emdash; the days of war the same,



<P>&nbsp;For gentle words, caresses, gifts from foreign

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lands,

<BR>For shelter, wine and meat&amp;emdash;for sweet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; appreciation,

<BR>(You distant, dim unknown&amp;emdash;or young

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or old&amp;emdash;countless, unspecified,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; readers belov'd,

<BR>We never met, and ne'er shall meet&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and yet our souls embrace, long, close and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; long;)

<BR>For beings, groups, love, deeds, words, books

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash; for colors, forms,

<BR>For all the brave strong men&amp;emdash;devoted,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hardy men&amp;emdash;who've forward sprung

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; in freedom's help, all years, all lands,

<BR>For braver, stronger, more devoted men&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (a special laurel ere I go, to life's war's

chosen

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ones,

<BR>The cannoneers of song and thought&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the great artillerists&amp;emdash; the foremost

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leaders, captains of the soul:)

<BR>As soldier from an ended war return'd&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As traveler out of myriads, to the long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; procession retrospective,

<BR>Thanks&amp;emdash;joyful thanks!&amp;emdash;a soldier's,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; traveler's thanks.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

LIFE AND DEATH</H2></CENTER>



<BLOCKQUOTE>T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> two old, simple problems ever intertwined,

<BR>Close home, elusive, present, baffled, grappled.

<BR>By each successive age insoluble, pass'd on,

<BR>To ours to-day&amp;emdash;and we pass on the same.</BLOCKQUOTE>



<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE VOICE OF THE RAIN</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>ND</FONT> who art thou? said I to the soft-falling shower,

<BR>Which, strange to tell, gave me an answer, as here

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; translated:

<BR>I am the Poem of Earth, said the voice of the rain,

<BR>Eternal I rise impalpable out of the land and the bottom-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; less sea,

<BR>Upward to heaven, whence, vaguely form'd, altogether

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; changed, and yet the same,

<BR>I descend to lave the drouths, atomies, dust-layers of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the globe,

<BR>And all that in them without me were seeds only, latent,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unborn;



<P>&nbsp;And forever, by day and night, I give back life to my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; own origin and make pure and beautify it;

<BR>(For song, issuing from its birth-place, after fulfilment,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wandering,

<BR>Reck'd or unreck'd, duly with love returns.)

<PRE>(1885)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

SOON SHALL THE WINTER'S FOIL BE HERE</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>OON</FONT> shall the winter's foil be here;

<BR>Soon shall these icy ligatures unbind and melt&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; A little while,

<BR>And air, soil, wave, suffused shall be in softness, bloom

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and growth&amp;emdash;a thousand forms shall

rise

<BR>From these dead clods and chills as from low burial graves.

<BR>Thine eyes, ears&amp;emdash;all thy best attributes&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all that takes cognizance of natural beauty,

<BR>Shall wake and fill. Thou shalt perceive the simple shows,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the delicate miracles of earth,

<BR>Dandelions, clover, the emerald grass, the early scents and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flowers,

<BR>The arbutus under foot, the willow's yellow-green, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; blossoming plum and cherry;

<BR>With these the robin, lark and thrush, singing their songs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the flitting bluebird;

<BR>For such the scenes the annual play brings on.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

WHILE NOT THE PAST FORGETTING</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>Publish'd May</I> 30, 1888)</CENTER>





<P>W<FONT SIZE=-1>HILE</FONT> not the past forgetting,

<BR>To-day, at least, contention sunk entire&amp;emdash;peace,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brotherhood uprisen;

<BR>For sign reciprocal our Northern, Southern hands,

<BR>Lay on the graves of all dead soldiers, North or South,

<BR>(Nor for the past alone&amp;emdash;for meanings to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; future,)

<BR>Wreaths of roses and branches of palm.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE DYING VETERAN</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>A Long Island incident&amp;emdash;early part of the nineteenth</I></CENTER>



<CENTER><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; century</I>)</CENTER>





<P>A<FONT SIZE=-1>MID</FONT> these days of order, ease, prosperity,

<BR>Amid the current songs of beauty, peace, decorum,

<BR>I cast a reminiscence&amp;emdash;(likely 'twill offend you,

<BR>I heard it in my boyhood;)&amp;emdash;More than a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; generation since,

<BR>A queer old savage man, a fighter under Washington

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; himself,

<BR>(Large, brave, cleanly, hot-blooded, no talker, rather

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spiritualistic,

<BR>Had fought in the ranks&amp;emdash;fought well&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; had been all through the Revolutionary war,)

<BR>Lay dying&amp;emdash;sons, daughters, church-deacons,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lovingly tending him,

<BR>Sharping their sense, their ears, towards his murmuring,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; half-caught words:

<BR>``Let me return again to my war-days,

<BR>To the sights and scenes&amp;emdash;to forming the line

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of battle,

<BR>To the scouts ahead reconnoitering,

<BR>To the cannons, the grim artillery,

<BR>To the galloping aids, carrying orders,

<BR>To the wounded, the fallen, the heat, the suspense,

<BR>The perfume strong, the smoke, the deafening noise;

<BR>Away with your life of peace!&amp;emdash;your joys of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; peace!

<BR>Give me my old wild battle-life again!''

<PRE>(1887)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

STRONGER LESSONS</H2></CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>AVE</FONT> you learn'd lessons only of those who admired

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you, and were tender with you, and stood aside

for you?

<BR>Have you not learn'd great lessons from those who reject

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you, and brace themselves against you? or

who treat

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you with contempt, or dispute the passage

with you?

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

A PRAIRIE SUNSET</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>HOT</FONT> gold, maroon and violet, dazzling silver, emerald,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fawn,

<BR>The earth's whole amplitude and Nature's multiform power

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consign'd for once to colors;

<BR>The light, the general air possess'd by them&amp;emdash;colors

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; till now unknown,

<BR>No limit, confine&amp;emdash;not the Western sky alone

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the high meridian&amp;emdash;North,

South, all,

<BR>Pure luminous color fighting the silent shadows to the last.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TWENTY YEARS</H2></CENTER>

D<FONT SIZE=-1>OWN</FONT> on the ancient wharf, the sand, I sit, with a

new

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -comer chatting:

<BR>He shipp'd as green-hand boy, and sail'd away, (took some

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sudden, vehement notion;)

<BR>Since, twenty years and more have circled round and round,

<BR>While he the globe was circling round and round,&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and now returns:

<BR>How changed the place&amp;emdash;all the old land-marks gone

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the parents dead;

<BR>(Yes, he comes back <I>to lay in port for good&amp;emdash;</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to settle</I>&amp;emdash;has a well-fill'd

purse&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; no spot will do but this;)

<BR>The little boat that scull'd him from the sloop, now held in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leash I see,

<BR>I hear the slapping waves, the restless keel, the rocking in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the sand,

<BR>I see the sailor kit, the canvas bag, the great box bound

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with brass,

<BR>I scan the face all berry-brown and bearded&amp;emdash;the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stout-strong frame,

<BR>Dress'd in its russet suit of good Scotch cloth:

<BR>(Then what the told-out story of those twenty years? What

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the future?)

<PRE>(1887)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

ORANGE BUDS BY MAIL FROM FLORIDA</H2></CENTER>

(<I>Voltaire closed a famous argument by claiming that a ship of war and

the grand opera were proofs enough of civilization's and France's progress,

in his day.</I>)



<P>&nbsp;A <FONT SIZE=-1>LESSER</FONT> proof than old Voltaire's, yet greater,

<BR>Proof of this present time, and thee, thy broad expanse,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; America,

<BR>To my plain Northern hut, in outside clouds and snow,

<BR>Brought safely for a thousand miles o'er land and tide,

<BR>Some three days since on their own soil live-sprouting,

<BR>Now here their sweetness through my room unfolding,

<BR>A bunch of orange buds by mail from Florida.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

TWILIGHT</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> soft voluptuous opiate shades,

<BR>The sun just gone, the eager light dispell'd&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (I too will soon be gone, dispell'd,)

<BR>A haze&amp;emdash;nirwana&amp;emdash;rest and night

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;oblivion.

<PRE>(1887)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

YOU LINGERING SPARSE LEAVES OF ME</H2></CENTER>

Y<FONT SIZE=-1>OU</FONT> lingering sparse leaves of me on winter-nearing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; boughs,

<BR>And I some well-shorn tree of field or orchard-row;

<BR>You tokens diminute and lorn&amp;emdash;(not now

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the flush of May, or July clover-bloom&amp;emdash;no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grain of August now;)

<BR>You pallid banner-staves&amp;emdash;you pennants value-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; less&amp;emdash;you overstay'd of time,

<BR>Yet me soul-dearest leaves confirming all the rest,

<BR>The faithfulest&amp;emdash;hardiest&amp;emdash;last.

<PRE>1887&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

NOT MEAGRE, LATENT BOUGHS ALONE</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>OT</FONT> meagre, latent boughs alone, O songs! (scaly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and bare, like eagles' talons,)

<BR>But haply for some sunny day (who knows?) some

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; future spring, some summer&amp;emdash;bursting

forth,

<BR>To verdant leaves, or sheltering shade&amp;emdash;to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nourishing fruit,

<BR>Apples and grapes&amp;emdash;the stalwart limbs of trees

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; emerging&amp;emdash; the fresh, free, open

air,

<BR>And love and faith, like scented roses blooming.

<PRE>1887&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE DEAD EMPEROR</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>Publish'd March</I> 10, 1888)</CENTER>





<P>T<FONT SIZE=-1>O-DAY,</FONT> with bending head and eyes, thou, too,

Columbia,

<BR>Less for the mighty crown laid low in sorrow&amp;emdash;less

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for the Emperor,

<BR>Thy true condolence breathest, sendest out o'er many a salt

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea mile,

<BR>Mourning a good old man&amp;emdash;a faithful shepherd, patriot.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AS THE GREEK'S SIGNAL FLAME</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>(<I>For Whittier's eightieth birthday, December</I> 17, 1887)</CENTER>



<BLOCKQUOTE>A<FONT SIZE=-1>S</FONT> the Greek's signal flame, by antique

records told,

<BR>Rose from the hill-top, like applause and glory,

<BR>Welcoming in fame some special veteran, hero,

<BR>With rosy tinge reddening the land he'd served,

<BR>So I aloft from Mannahatta's ship-fringed shore,

<BR>Lift high a kindled brand for thee, Old Poet.</BLOCKQUOTE>



<PRE>1887&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THE DISMANTLED SHIP</H2></CENTER>

I<FONT SIZE=-1>N</FONT> some unused lagoon, some nameless bay,

<BR>On sluggish, lonesome waters, anchor'd near the shore,

<BR>An old, dismasted, gray and batter'd ship, disabled, done,

<BR>After free voyages to all the seas of earth, haul'd up at last

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and hawser'd tight,

<BR>Lies rusting, mouldering.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

NOW PRECEDENT SONGS, FAREWELL</H2></CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>OW</FONT> precedent songs, farewell&amp;emdash;by every

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; name farewell,

<BR>(Trains of a staggering line in many a strange procession,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waggons,

<BR>From ups and downs&amp;emdash;with intervals&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from elder years, mid-age, or youth,)

<BR>``In Cabin'd Ships'', or ``Thee Old Cause'' or ``Poets to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Come''



<P>&nbsp;Or ``Paumanok'', ``Song of Myself'', ``Calamus'',

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or ``Adam'',

<BR>Or ``Beat! Beat! Drums!'' or ``To the Leaven'd Soil

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they Trod,''

<BR>Or ``Captain! My Captain!'' ``Kosmos'', ``Quicksand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Years'', or ``Thoughts'',

<BR>``Thou Mother with thy Equal Brood'', and many, many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more unspecified,

<BR>From fibre heart of mine&amp;emdash;from throat and tongue

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;(My life's hot pulsing blood,

<BR>The personal urge and form for me&amp;emdash;not merely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; paper, automatic type and ink,)

<BR>Each song of mine&amp;emdash;each utterance in the past

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;having its long, long history,

<BR>Of life or death, or soldier's wound, of country's loss or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; safety,

<BR>(O heaven! what flash and started endless train of all!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; compared indeed to that!

<BR>What wretched shred e'en at the best of all!)

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AN EVENING LULL</H2></CENTER>



<BLOCKQUOTE>A<FONT SIZE=-1>FTER</FONT> a week of physical anguish,

<BR>Unrest and pain, and feverish heat,

<BR>Toward the ending day a calm and lull comes on,

<BR>Three hours of peace and soothing rest of brain.<SUP><FONT SIZE=-2><A HREF="sand.html#ftn2">*</A></FONT></SUP></BLOCKQUOTE>



<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

OLD AGE'S LAMBENT PEAKS</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>HE</FONT> touch of flame

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;the illuminating fire&amp;emdash;the

loftiest look

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; at last,

<BR>O'er city, passion, sea&amp;emdash;o'er prairie, mountain,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wood&amp;emdash;the earth itself;

<BR>The airy, different, changing hues of all, in falling twilight,

<BR>Objects and groups, bearings, faces, reminiscences;



<P>&nbsp;The calmer sight&amp;emdash;the golden setting, clear and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; broad:

<BR>So much i' the atmosphere, the points of view, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; situations whence we scan,

<BR>Bro't out by them alone&amp;emdash;so much (perhaps the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; best) unreck'd before;

<BR>The lights indeed from them&amp;emdash;old age's lambent

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; peaks.

<PRE>1888&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1889</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AFTER THE SUPPER AND TALK</H2></CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>FTER</FONT> the supper and talk&amp;emdash;after the day

is done,

<BR>As a friend from friends his final withdrawal prolonging,

<BR>Good-bye and Good-bye with emotional lips repeating,

<BR>(So hard for his hand to release those hands&amp;emdash;no

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; more will they meet,

<BR>No more for communion of sorrow and joy, of old and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; young,

<BR>A far-stretching journey awaits him, to return no more,)

<BR>Shunning, postponing severance&amp;emdash;seeking to ward

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; off the last word ever so little,

<BR>E'en at the exit-door turning&amp;emdash;charges superfluous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; calling back&amp;emdash;e'en as he descends

the steps,

<BR>Something to eke out a minute additional&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shadows of nightfall deepening,

<BR>Farewells, messages lessening&amp;emdash;dimmer the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forthgoer's visage and form,

<BR>Soon to be lost for aye in the darkness&amp;emdash;loth,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; O so loth to depart!

<BR>Garrulous to the very last.

<PRE>1887&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1888-9</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR><A NAME="ftn1"></A><SUP><FONT SIZE=-2>*</FONT></SUP>Navesink &amp;emdash;

<FONT SIZE=-1>a sea-side mountain, lower entrance of New York Bay.</FONT>



<P>&nbsp;<A NAME="ftn2"></A><SUP><FONT SIZE=-2>*</FONT></SUP><FONT SIZE=-1>The

two songs on pages 476-477[``Now Precedent Songs, Farewell'' and ``an Evening

Lull''] are eked out during an afternoon, June, 1888, in my seventieth

year, at a critical spell of illness. Of course no reader and probably

no human being at any time will ever have such phases of emotional and

solemn action as these involve to me. I feel in them an end and close of

all.</FONT>

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Sea-Drift</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER><B><I><FONT SIZE=+3>Sea-Drift</FONT></I></B></CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>OUT OF THE CRADLE ENDLESSLY ROCKING</CENTER>



<CENTER>&nbsp;</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>ut</FONT> of the cradle endlessly rocking,

<BR>Out of the mocking-bird's throat, the musical shuttle,

<BR>Out of the Ninth-month midnight,

<BR>Over the sterile sands and the fields beyond, where the child

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leaving his bed wander'd alone, bareheaded,

barefoot,

<BR>Down from the shower'd halo,

<BR>Up from the mystic play of shadows twining and twisting as if

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they were alive,

<BR>Out from the patches of briers and blackberries,

<BR>From the memories of the bird that chanted to me,

<BR>From your memories sad brother, from the fitful risings and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fallings I heard,

<BR>From under that yellow half-moon late-risen and swollen as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; if with tears,

<BR>From those beginning notes of yearning and love there in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mist,

<BR>From the thousand responses of my heart never to cease,

<BR>From the myriad thence-arous'd words,

<BR>From the word stronger and more delicious than any,

<BR>From such as now they start the scene revisiting,

<BR>As a flock, twittering, rising, or overhead passing,

<BR>Borne hither, ere all eludes me, hurriedly,

<BR>A man, yet by these tears a little boy again,

<BR>Throwing myself on the sand, confronting the waves,

<BR>I, chanter of pains and joys, uniter of here and hereafter,

<BR>Taking all hints to use them, but swiftly leaping beyond them,

<BR>A reminiscence sing.



<P>&nbsp;Once Paumanok,

<BR>When the lilac-scent was in the air and Fifth-month grass

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; was growing,

<BR>Up this seashore in some briers,

<BR>Two feather'd guests from Alabama, two together,

<BR>And their nest, and four light-green eggs spotted with brown,

<BR>And every day the he-bird to and fro near at hand,

<BR>And every day the she-bird crouch'd on her nest, silent, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bright eyes,

<BR>And every day I, a curious boy, never too close, never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; disturbing them,

<BR>Cautiously peering, absorbing, translating.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Shine! shine! shine</I>!

<BR><I>Pour down your warmth, great sun</I>!

<BR><I>While we bask, we two together</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Two together</I>!

<BR><I>Winds blow south, or winds blow north</I>,

<BR><I>Day come white, or night come black</I>,

<BR><I>Home, or rivers and mountains from home</I>,

<BR><I>Singing all time, minding no time</I>,

<BR><I>While we two keep together</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Till of a sudden,

<BR>May-be kill'd, unknown to her mate,

<BR>One forenoon the she-bird crouch'd not on the nest,

<BR>Nor return'd that afternoon, nor the next,

<BR>Nor ever appear'd again.



<P>&nbsp;And thenceforward all summer in the sound of the sea,

<BR>And at night under the full of the moon in calmer weather,

<BR>Over the hoarse surging of the sea,

<BR>Or flitting from brier by day,

<BR>I saw, I heard at intervals the remaining one, the he-bird,

<BR>The solitary guest from Alabama.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Blow! blow! blow</I>!

<BR><I>Blow up sea-winds along Paumanok's shore</I>;

<BR><I>I wait and I wait till you blow my mate to me</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Yes, when the stars glisten'd,

<BR>All night long on the prong of a moss-scallop'd stake,

<BR>Down almost amid the slapping waves,

<BR>Sat the lone singer wonderful causing tears.



<P>&nbsp;He call'd on his mate,

<BR>He pour'd forth the meanings which I of all men know.



<P>&nbsp;Yes my brother I know,

<BR>The rest might not, but I have treasur'd every note,

<BR>For more than once dimly down to the beach gliding,

<BR>Silent, avoiding the moonbeams, blending myself with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shadows,

<BR>Recalling now the obscure shapes, the echoes, the sounds

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sights after their sorts,

<BR>The white arms out in the breakers tirelessly tossing,

<BR>I, with bare feet, a child, the wind wafting my hair,

<BR>Listen'd long and long.



<P>&nbsp;Listen'd to keep, to sing, now translating the notes,

<BR>Following you my brother.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Soothe! soothe! soothe</I>!

<BR><I>Close on its wave soothes the wave behind</I>,

<BR><I>And again another behind embracing and lapping, every one close</I>,

<BR><I>But my love soothes not me, not me</I>.

<BR>&nbsp;



<P><I>Low hangs the moon, it rose late</I>,

<BR><I>It is lagging &amp;emdash; O I think it is heavy with love, with

love</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>O madly the sea pushes upon the land</I>,

<BR><I>With love, with love</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>O night! do I not see my love fluttering out among the</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breakers</I>?

<BR><I>What is that little black thing I see there in the white</I>?



<P>&nbsp;<I>Loud! loud! loud</I>!

<BR><I>Loud I call to you, my love</I>!

<BR><I>High and clear I shoot my voice over the waves</I>,

<BR><I>Surely you must know who is here, is here</I>,

<BR><I>You must know who I am, my love</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Low-hanging moon</I>!

<BR><I>What is that dusky spot in your brown yellow</I>?

<BR><I>O it is the shape, the shape of my mate</I>!

<BR><I>O moon do not keep her from me any longer</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Land! land! O land</I>!

<BR><I>Whichever way I turn, O I think you could give me my mate</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; back again if you only would</I>,

<BR><I>For I am almost sure I see her dimly whichever way I look</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>O rising stars</I>!

<BR><I>Perhaps the one I want so much will rise, will rise with some</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of you</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>O throat! O trembling throat</I>!

<BR><I>Sound clearer through the atmosphere</I>!

<BR><I>Pierce the woods, the earth</I>,

<BR><I>Somewhere listening to catch you must be the one I want</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Shake out carols</I>!

<BR><I>Solitary here, the night's carols</I>!

<BR><I>Carols of lonesome love! death's carols</I>!

<BR><I>Carols under that lagging, yellow, waning moon</I>!

<BR><I>O under that moon where she droops almost down into the sea</I>!

<BR><I>O reckless despairing carols</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>But soft! sink low</I>!

<BR><I>Soft! let me just murmur</I>,

<BR><I>And do you wait a moment you husky-nois'd sea</I>,

<BR><I>For somewhere I believe I heard my mate responding to me</I>,

<BR><I>So faint, I must be still, be still to listen</I>,

<BR><I>But not altogether still, for then she might not come immediately</I>

<BR><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Hither my love</I>!

<BR><I>Here I am! here</I>!

<BR><I>With this just-sustain'd note I announce myself to you</I>,

<BR><I>This gentle call is for you my love, for you</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>Do not be decoy'd elsewhere</I>,

<BR><I>That is the whistle of the wind, it is not my voice</I>,

<BR><I>That is the fluttering, the fluttering of the spray</I>,

<BR><I>Those are the shadows of leaves</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>O darkness! O in vain</I>!

<BR><I>O I am very sick and sorrowful</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>O brown halo in the sky near the moon, drooping upon the sea</I>!

<BR><I>O troubled reflection in the sea</I>!

<BR><I>O throat! O throbbing heart</I>!

<BR><I>And I singing uselessly, uselessly all the night</I>.



<P>&nbsp;<I>O past! O happy life! O songs of joy</I>!

<BR><I>In the air, in the woods, over fields</I>,

<BR><I>Loved! loved! loved! loved! loved</I>!

<BR><I>But my mate no more, no more with me</I>!

<BR><I>We two together no more</I>.



<P>&nbsp;The aria sinking,

<BR>All else continuing, the stars shining,

<BR>The winds blowing, the notes of the bird continuous echoing,

<BR>With angry moans the fierce old mother incessantly moaning,

<BR>On the sands of Paumanok's shore gray and rustling,

<BR>The yellow half-moon enlarged, sagging down, drooping, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; face of the sea almost touching,

<BR>The boy ecstatic, with his bare feet the waves, with his hair the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; atmosphere dallying,

<BR>The love in the heart long pent, now loose, now at last

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tumultuously bursting,

<BR>The aria's meaning, the ears, the soul, swiftly depositing,

<BR>The strange tears down the cheeks coursing,

<BR>The colloquy there, the trio, each uttering,

<BR>The undertone, the savage old mother incessantly crying,

<BR>To the boy's soul's questions sullenly timing, some drown'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; secret hissing,

<BR>To the outsetting bard.



<P>&nbsp;Demon or bird! (said the boy's soul,)

<BR>Is it indeed toward your mate you sing? or is it really to me?

<BR>For I, that was a child, my tongue's use sleeping, now I have

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heard you,

<BR>Now in a moment I know what I am for, I awake,

<BR>And already a thousand singers, a thousand songs, clearer,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; louder and more sorrowful than yours,

<BR>A thousand warbling echoes have started to life within me,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; never to die.



<P>&nbsp;O you singer solitary, singing by yourself, projecting me,

<BR>O solitary me listening, never more shall I cease perpetuating

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you,

<BR>Never more shall I escape, never more the reverberations,

<BR>Never more the cries of unsatisfied love be absent from me,

<BR>Never again leave me to be the peaceful child I was before

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; what there in the night,

<BR>By the sea under the yellow and sagging moon,

<BR>The messenger there arous'd, the fire, the sweet hell within,

<BR>The unknown want, the destiny of me.



<P>&nbsp;O give me the clew! (it lurks in the night here somewhere,)

<BR>O if I am to have so much, let me have more!



<P>&nbsp;A word then, (for I will conquer it,)

<BR>The word final, superior to all,

<BR>Subtle, sent up &amp;emdash; what is it? &amp;emdash; I listen;

<BR>Are you whispering it, and have been all the time, you sea

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; waves?

<BR>Is that it from your liquid rims and wet sands?

<BR>Whereto answering, the sea,

<BR>Delaying not, hurrying not,

<BR>Whisper'd me through the night, and very plainly before

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; daybreak,

<BR>Lisp'd to me the low and delicious word death,

<BR>And again death, death, death, death,

<BR>Hissing melodious, neither like the bird nor like my arous'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; child's heart,

<BR>But edging near as privately for me rustling at my feet,

<BR>Creeping thence steadily up to my ears and laving me softly

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all over,

<BR>Death, death, death, death, death.



<P>&nbsp;Which I do not forget,

<BR>But fuse the song of my dusky demon and brother,

<BR>That he sang to me in the moonlight on Paumanok's gray

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beach,

<BR>With the thousand responsive songs at random,

<BR>My own songs awaked from that hour,

<BR>And with them the key, the word up from the waves,

<BR>The word of the sweetest song and all songs,

<BR>That strong and delicious word which, creeping to my feet,

<BR>(Or like some old crone rocking the cradle, swathed in sweet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; garments, bending aside,)

<BR>The sea whisper'd me.

<PRE>1859&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>AS I EBB'D WITH THE OCEAN OF LIFE</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

As I ebb'd with the ocean of life,

<BR>As I wended the shores I know,

<BR>As I walk'd where the ripples continually wash you Paumanok,

<BR>Where they rustle up hoarse and sibilant,

<BR>Where the fierce old mother endlessly cries for her castaways,

<BR>I musing late in the autumn day, gazing off southward,

<BR>Held by this electric self out of the pride of which I utter

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poems,

<BR>Was seiz'd by the spirit that trails in the lines underfoot,

<BR>The rim, the sediment that stands for all the water and all the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land of the globe.



<P>&nbsp;Fascinated, my eyes reverting from the south, dropt, to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; follow those slender windrows,

<BR>Chaff, straw, splinters of wood, weeds, and the sea-gluten,

<BR>Scum, scales from shining rocks, leaves of salt-lettuce, left by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the tide,

<BR>Miles walking, the sound of breaking waves the other side of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me,

<BR>Paumanok there and then as I thought the old thought of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; likenesses,

<BR>These you presented to me you fish-shaped island,

<BR>As I wended the shores I know,

<BR>As I walk'd with that electric self seeking types.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>

As I wend to the shores I know not,

<BR>As I list to the dirge, the voices of men and women wreck'd,

<BR>As I inhale the impalpable breezes that set in upon me,

<BR>As the ocean so mysterious rolls toward me closer and closer,

<BR>I too but signify at the utmost a little wash'd-up drift,

<BR>A few sands and dead leaves to gather,

<BR>Gather, and merge myself as part of the sands and drift.



<P>&nbsp;O baffled, balk'd, bent to the very earth,

<BR>Oppress'd with myself that I have dared to open my mouth,

<BR>Aware now that amid all that blab whose echoes recoil upon

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me I have not once had the least idea who

or what I am,

<BR>But that before all my arrogant poems the real Me stands yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; untouch'd, untold, altogether unreach'd,

<BR>Withdrawn far, mocking me with mock-congratulatory signs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and bows,

<BR>With peals of distant ironical laughter at every word I have

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; written,

<BR>Pointing in silence to these songs, and then to the sand

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beneath.

<BR>I perceive I have not really understood any thing, not a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; single object, and that no man ever can,

<BR>Nature here in sight of the sea taking advantage of me to dart

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon me and sting me,

<BR>Because I have dared to open my mouth to sing at all.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>

You oceans both, I close with you,

<BR>We murmur alike reproachfully rolling sands and drift,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; knowing not why,

<BR>These little shreds indeed standing for you and me and all.



<P>&nbsp;You friable shore with trails of debris,

<BR>You fish-shaped island, I take what is underfoot,

<BR>What is yours is mine my father.



<P>&nbsp;I too Paumanok,

<BR>I too have bubbled up, floated the measureless float, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; been wash'd on your shores,

<BR>I too am but a trail of drift and debris,

<BR>I too leave little wrecks upon you, you fish-shaped island.



<P>&nbsp;I throw myself upon your breast my father,

<BR>I cling to you so that you cannot unloose me,

<BR>I hold you so firm till you answer me something.



<P>&nbsp;Kiss me my father,

<BR>Touch me with your lips as I touch those I love,

<BR>Breathe to me while I hold you close the secret of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; murmuring I envy.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>

Ebb, ocean of life, (the flow will return,)

<BR>Cease not your moaning you fierce old mother,

<BR>Endlessly cry for your castaways, but fear not, deny not me,

<BR>Rustle not up so hoarse and angry against my feet as I touch

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you or gather from you.



<P>&nbsp;I mean tenderly by you and all,

<BR>I gather for myself and for this phantom looking down where

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; we lead, and following me and mine.



<P>&nbsp;Me and mine, loose windrows, little corpses,

<BR>Froth, snowy white, and bubbles,

<BR>(See, from my dead lips the ooze exuding at last,

<BR>See, the prismatic colors glistening and rolling,)

<BR>Tufts of straw, sands, fragments,

<BR>Buoy'd hither from many moods, one contradicting another,

<BR>From the storm, the long calm, the darkness, the swell,

<BR>Musing, pondering, a breath, a briny tear, a dab of liquid or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; soil,

<BR>Up just as much out of fathomless workings fermented and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thrown,

<BR>A limp blossom or two, torn, just as much over waves floating,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drifted at random,

<BR>Just as much for us that sobbing dirge of Nature,

<BR>Just as much whence we come that blare of the cloud-trumpets,

<BR>We, capricious, brought hither we know not whence, spread

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; out before you,

<BR>You up there walking or sitting,

<BR>Whoever you are, we too lie in drifts at your feet.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>TEARS</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>ears</FONT>! tears! tears!

<BR>In the night, in solitude, tears,

<BR>On the white shore dripping, dripping, suck'd in by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sand,

<BR>Tears, not a star shining, all dark and desolate,

<BR>Moist tears from the eyes of a muffled head;

<BR>O who is that ghost? that form in the dark, with tears?

<BR>What shapeless lump is that, bent, crouch'd there on the sand?

<BR>Streaming tears, sobbing tears, throes, choked with wild

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; cries;

<BR>O storm, embodied, rising, careering with swift steps along

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the beach!

<BR>O wild and dismal night storm, with wind &amp;emdash; O belching and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; desperate!

<BR>O shade so sedate and decorous by day, with calm countenance and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; regulated pace,

<BR>But away at night as you fly, none looking &amp;emdash; O then the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unloosen'd ocean,

<BR>Of tears! tears! tears!

<PRE>1867&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>TO THE MAN-OF-WAR-BIRD</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>hou</FONT> who hast slept all night upon the storm,

<BR>Waking renew'd on thy prodigious pinions,

<BR>(Burst the wild storm? above it thou ascended'st,

<BR>And rested on the sky, thy slave that cradled thee,)

<BR>Now a blue point, far, far in heaven floating,

<BR>As to the light emerging here on deck I watch thee,

<BR>(Myself a speck, a point on the world's floating vast.)

<BR>Far, far at sea,

<BR>After the night's fierce drifts have strewn the shore with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wrecks,

<BR>With re-appearing day as now so happy and serene,

<BR>The rosy and elastic dawn, the flashing sun,

<BR>The limpid spread of air cerulean,

<BR>Thou also re-appearest.



<P>&nbsp;Thou born to match the gale, (thou art all wings,)

<BR>To cope with heaven and earth and sea and hurricane,

<BR>Thou ship of air that never furl'st thy sails,

<BR>Days, even weeks untired and onward, through spaces,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; realms gyrating,

<BR>At dusk that look'st on Senegal, at morn America,

<BR>That sport'st amid the lightning-flash and thunder-cloud,

<BR>In them, in thy experiences, had'st thou my soul,

<BR>What joys! what joys were thine!

<PRE>1876&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>ABOARD AT A SHIP'S HELM</CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>board</FONT> at a ship's helm,

<BR>A young steersman steering with care.



<P>&nbsp;Through fog on a sea-coast dolefully ringing,

<BR>An ocean-bell &amp;emdash; O a warning bell, rock'd by the waves.



<P>&nbsp;O you give good notice indeed, you bell by the sea-reefs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ringing,

<BR>Ringing, ringing, to warn the ship from its wreck-place.



<P>&nbsp;For as on the alert O steersman, you mind the loud admonition,

<BR>The bows turn, the freighted ship tacking speeds away under

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her gray sails,



<P>&nbsp;The beautiful and noble ship with all her precious wealth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; speeds away gayly and safe.

<BR>But O the ship, the immortal ship! O ship aboard the ship!

<BR>Ship of the body, ship of the soul, voyaging, voyaging,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; voyaging.

<PRE>1867&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>ON THE BEACH AT NIGHT</CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>n</FONT> the beach at night,

<BR>Stands a child with her father,

<BR>Watching the east, the autumn sky.



<P>&nbsp;Up through the darkness,

<BR>While ravening clouds, the burial clouds, in black masses

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spreading,

<BR>Lower sullen and fast athwart and down the sky,

<BR>Amid a transparent clear belt of ether yet left in the east,

<BR>Ascends large and calm the lord-star Jupiter,

<BR>And nigh at hand, only a very little above,

<BR>Swim the delicate sisters the Pleiades.



<P>&nbsp;From the beach the child holding the hand of her father,

<BR>Those burial clouds that lower victorious soon to devour all,

<BR>Watching, silently weeps.



<P>&nbsp;Weep not, child,

<BR>Weep not, my darling,

<BR>With these kisses let me remove your tears,

<BR>The ravening clouds shall not long be victorious,

<BR>They shall not long possess the sky, they devour the stars

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; only in apparition,

<BR>Jupiter shall emerge, be patient, watch again another night,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the Pleiades shall emerge,

<BR>They are immortal, all those stars both silvery and golden

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall shine out again,

<BR>The great stars and the little ones shall shine out again, they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; endure,

<BR>The vast immortal suns and the long-enduring pensive moons

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall again shine.



<P>&nbsp;Then dearest child mournest thou only for Jupiter?

<BR>Considerest thou alone the burial of the stars?

<BR>Something there is,

<BR>(With my lips soothing thee, adding I whisper,

<BR>I give thee the first suggestion, the problem and indirection,)

<BR>Something there is more immortal even than the stars,

<BR>(Many the burials, many the days and nights, passing away,)

<BR>Something that shall endure longer even than lustrous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Jupiter,

<BR>Longer than sun or any revolving satellite,

<BR>Or the radiant sisters the Pleiades.

<PRE>1871&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>THE WORLD BELOW THE BRINE</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>he</FONT> world below the brine,

<BR>Forests at the bottom of the sea, the branches and leaves,

<BR>Sea-lettuce, vast lichens, strange flowers and seeds, the thick

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tangle, openings, and pink turf,

<BR>Different colors, pale gray and green, purple, white, and gold,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the play of light through the water,

<BR>Dumb swimmers there among the rocks, coral, gluten, grass,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rushes, and the aliment of the swimmers,

<BR>Sluggish existences grazing there suspended, or slowly crawling

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; close to the bottom,

<BR>The sperm-whale at the surface blowing air and spray, or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; disporting with his flukes,

<BR>The leaden-eyed shark, the walrus, the turtle, the hairy sea-leopard,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the sting-ray,

<BR>Passions there, wars, pursuits, tribes, sight in those ocean-depths,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breathing that thick-breathing air, as so

many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; do,

<BR>The change thence to the sight here, and to the subtle air

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; breathed by beings like us who walk this sphere,

<BR>The change onward from ours to that of beings who walk

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; other spheres.

<PRE>1860&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1871</PRE>



<CENTER>ON THE BEACH AT NIGHT ALONE</CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>n</FONT> the beach at night alone,

<BR>As the old mother sways her to and fro singing her husky

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; song,

<BR>As I watch the bright stars shining, I think a thought of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clef of the universes and of the future.

<BR>A vast similitude interlocks all,

<BR>All spheres, grown, ungrown, small, large, suns, moons,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; planets,

<BR>All distances of place however wide,

<BR>All distances of time, all inanimate forms,

<BR>All souls, all living bodies though they be ever so different,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or in different worlds,

<BR>All gaseous, watery, vegetable, mineral processes, the fishes,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the brutes,

<BR>All nations, colors, barbarisms, civilizations, languages,

<BR>All identities that have existed or may exist on this globe,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or any globe,

<BR>All lives and deaths, all of the past, present, future,

<BR>This vast similitude spans them, and always has spann'd,

<BR>And shall forever span them and compactly hold and enclose

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them.

<PRE>1856&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>SONG FOR ALL SEAS, ALL SHIPS</CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>o-day</FONT> a rude brief recitative,

<BR>Of ships sailing the seas, each with its special flag or ship

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; signal,

<BR>Of unnamed heroes in the ships&amp;emdash;of waves spreading and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spreading far as the eye can reach,

<BR>Of dashing spray, and the winds piping and blowing,

<BR>And out of these a chant for the sailors of all nations,

<BR>Fitful, like a surge.



<P>&nbsp;Of sea-captains young or old, and the mates, and of all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; intrepid sailors,

<BR>Of the few, very choice, taciturn, whom fate can never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; surprise nor death dismay,

<BR>Pick'd sparingly without noise by thee old ocean, chosen by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thee,

<BR>Thou sea that pickest and cullest the race in time, and unitest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; nations,

<BR>Suckled by thee, old husky nurse, embodying thee,

<BR>Indomitable, untamed as thee.

<BR>(Ever the heroes on water or on land, by ones or twos

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; appearing,

<BR>Ever the stock preserv'd and never lost, though rare, enough

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for seed preserv'd.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>

Flaunt out O sea your separate flags of nations!

<BR>Flaunt out visible as ever the various ship-signals!

<BR>But do you reserve especially for yourself and for the soul of man

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one flag above all the rest,

<BR>A spiritual woven signal for all nations, emblem of man elate

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; above death,

<BR>Token of all brave captains and all intrepid sailors and mates,

<BR>And all that went down doing their duty,

<BR>Reminiscent of them, twined from all intrepid captains

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; young or old,

<BR>A pennant universal, subtly waving all time, o'er all brave

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sailors,

<BR>All seas, all ships.

<PRE>1873&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>PATROLING BARNEGAT</CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>ild</FONT>, wild the storm, and the sea high running,

<BR>Steady the roar of the gale, with incessant undertone

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; muttering,

<BR>Shouts of demoniac laughter fitfully piercing and pealing,

<BR>Waves, air, midnight, their savagest trinity lashing,

<BR>Out in the shadows there milk-white combs careering,

<BR>On beachy slush and sand spirts of snow fierce slanting,

<BR>Where through the murk the easterly death-wind breasting,

<BR>Through cutting swirl and spray watchful and firm advancing,

<BR>(That in the distance! is that a wreck? is the red signal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flaring?)

<BR>Slush and sand of the beach tireless till daylight wending,

<BR>Steadily, slowly, through hoarse roar never remitting,

<BR>Along the midnight edge by those milk-white combs careering,

<BR>A group of dim, weird forms, struggling, the night confronting,

<BR>That savage trinity warily watching.

<PRE>1880&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<CENTER>AFTER THE SEA-SHIP</CENTER>

A<FONT SIZE=-1>fter</FONT> the sea-ship, after the whistling winds,

<BR>After the white-gray sails taut to their spars and ropes,

<BR>Below, a myriad myriad waves hastening, lifting up their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; necks,

<BR>Tending in ceaseless flow toward the track of the ship,

<BR>Waves of the ocean bubbling and gurgling, blithely prying,

<BR>Waves, undulating waves, liquid, uneven, emulous waves,

<BR>Toward that whirling current, laughing and buoyant, with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; curves,

<BR>Where the great vessel sailing and tacking displaced the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; surface,

<BR>Larger and smaller waves in the spread of the ocean yearnfully

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; flowing,

<BR>The wake of the sea-ship after she passes, flashing and frolicsome

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; under the sun,

<BR>A motley procession with many a fleck of foam and many

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fragments,

<BR>Following the stately and rapid ship, in the wake following.

<PRE>1874&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Uncollected and Rejected Poems</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

Uncollected and Rejected Poems</H1></CENTER>



<CENTER>

<H2>

AMBITION</H2></CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>ne</FONT> day an obscure youth, a wanderer,

<BR>Known but to few, lay musing with himself

<BR>About the chances of his future life.

<BR>In that youth's heart, there dwelt the coal Ambition,

<BR>Burning and glowing; and he asked himself,

<BR>"Shall I, in time to come, be great and famed?"

<BR>Now soon an answer wild and mystical

<BR>Seemed to sound forth from out the depths of air;

<BR>And to the gazer's eye appeared a shape

<BR>Like one as of a cloud &amp;emdash; and thus it spoke:



<P>&nbsp;"O, many a panting, noble heart

<BR>Cherishes in its deep recess

<BR>The hope to win renown o'er earth

<BR>From Glory's prized caress.



<P>&nbsp;"And some will win that envied goal,

<BR>And have their deeds known far and wide;

<BR>And some &amp;emdash; by far the most &amp;emdash; will sink

<BR>Down in oblivion's tide.



<P>&nbsp;"But <I>thou</I>, who visions bright dost cull

<BR>From the imagination's store,

<BR>With dreams, such as the youthful dream

<BR>Of grandeur, love, and power,



<P>&nbsp;"Fanciest that thou shalt build a name

<BR>And come to have the nations know

<BR>What conscious might dwells in the brain

<BR>That throbs beneath that brow?



<P>&nbsp;"And see thick countless ranks of men

<BR>Fix upon <I>thee</I> their reverent gaze &amp;emdash;

<BR>And listen to the plaudits loud

<BR>To <I>thee</I> that thousands raise?



<P>&nbsp;"Weak, childish soul! the very place

<BR>That pride has made for folly's rest;

<BR>What thoughts, with vanity all rife,

<BR>Fill up thy heaving breast!



<P>&nbsp;"At night, go view the solemn stars

<BR>Those wheeling worlds through time the same &amp;emdash;

<BR>How puny seem the widest power,

<BR>The proudest mortal name!



<P>&nbsp;"Think too, that all, lowly and rich,

<BR>Dull idiot mind and teeming sense,

<BR>Alike must sleep the endless sleep,

<BR>A hundred seasons hence.



<P>&nbsp;"So, frail one, never more repine,

<BR>Though thou livest on obscure, unknown;

<BR>Though after death unsought may be

<BR>Thy markless resting stone."



<P>&nbsp;And as these accents dropped in the youth's ears,

<BR>He felt him sick at heart; for many a month

<BR>His fancy had amused and charmed itself

<BR>With lofty aspirations, visions fair

<BR>Of what he <I>might be</I>. And it pierced him sore

<BR>To have his airy castles thus dashed down.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1842</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

BLOOD-MONEY</H2></CENTER>

"<I>Guilty of the body and the blood of Christ</I>"



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>O<FONT SIZE=-1>f</FONT> olden time, when it came to pass

<BR>That the beautiful god, Jesus, should finish his work on earth

<BR>Then went Judas, and sold the divine youth,

<BR>And took pay for his body.



<P>&nbsp;Curs'd was the deed, even before the sweat of the clutching

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hand grew dry;

<BR>And darkness frown'd upon the seller of the like of God,

<BR>Where, as though earth lifted her breast to throw him from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; her, and heaven refused him,

<BR>He hung in the air, self-slaughter'd.



<P>&nbsp;The cycles, with their long shadows, have stalk'd silently

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forward,

<BR>Since those ancient days &amp;emdash; many a pouch enwrapping mean

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; while

<BR>Its fee, like that paid for the son of Mary.



<P>&nbsp;And still goes one, saying,

<BR>"What will ye give me, and I will deliver this man unto

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you?"

<BR>And they make the covenant, and pay the pieces of silver.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Look forth, deliverer,

<BR>Look forth, first-born of the dead,

<BR>Over the tree-tops of Paradise;

<BR>See thyself in yet continued bonds,

<BR>Toilsome and poor, thou bear'st man's form again,

<BR>Thou art reviled, scourged, put into prison,

<BR>Hunted from the arrogant equality of the rest;

<BR>With staves and swords throng the willing servants of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; authority,

<BR>Again they surround thee, mad with devilish spite;

<BR>Toward thee stretch the hands of a multitude, like vultures'

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; talons,

<BR>The meanest spit in thy face, they smite thee with their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; palms;

<BR>Bruised, bloody, and pinion'd is thy body,

<BR>More sorrowful than death is thy soul.



<P>&nbsp;Witness of anguish, brother of slaves,

<BR>Not with thy price closed the price of thine image:

<BR>And still Iscariot plies his trade.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1850</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

RESURGEMUS</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>uddenly</FONT>, out of its stale and drowsy air, the air

of slaves,

<BR>Like lightning Europe le'pt forth,

<BR>Sombre, superb and terrible,

<BR>As Ahimoth, brother of Death.

<BR>God, 'twas delicious!

<BR>That brief, tight, glorious grip

<BR>Upon the throats of kings.

<BR>You liars paid to defile the People,



<P>&nbsp;Mark you now:

<BR>Not for numberless agonies, murders, lusts,

<BR>For court thieving in its manifold mean forms,

<BR>Worming from his simplicity the poor man's wages;

<BR>For many a promise sworn by royal lips

<BR>And broken, and laughed at in the breaking;

<BR>Then, in their power, not for all these,

<BR>Did a blow fall in personal revenge,

<BR>Or a hair draggle in blood:

<BR>The People scorned the ferocity of kings.



<P>&nbsp;But the sweetness of mercy brewed bitter destruction,

<BR>And frightened rulers come back:

<BR>Each comes in state, with his train,

<BR>Hangman, priest, and tax-gatherer,

<BR>Soldier, lawyer, and sycophant;

<BR>As appalling procession of locusts,

<BR>And the king struts grandly again.



<P>&nbsp;Yet behind all, lo, a Shape

<BR>Vague as the night, draped interminably,

<BR>Head, front and form, in scarlet folds,

<BR>Whose face and eyes none may see,

<BR>Out of its robes only this,

<BR>The red robes, lifted by the arm,

<BR>One finger pointed high over the top,

<BR>Like the head of a snake appears.



<P>&nbsp;Meanwhile, corpses lie in new-made graves,

<BR>Bloody corpses of young men;

<BR>The rope of the gibbet hangs heavily,

<BR>The bullets of tyrants are flying,

<BR>The creatures of power laugh aloud:

<BR>And all these things bear fruits, and they are good.



<P>&nbsp;Those corpses of young men,

<BR>Those martyrs that hang from the gibbets,

<BR>Those hearts pierced by the grey lead,

<BR>Cold and motionless as they seem,

<BR>Live elsewhere with undying vitality;

<BR>They live in other young men, O, kings,

<BR>They live in brothers, again ready to defy you;

<BR>They were purified by death,

<BR>They were taught and exalted.

<BR>Not a grave of those slaughtered ones,

<BR>But is growing its seed of freedom,

<BR>In its turn to bear seed,

<BR>Which the winds shall carry afar and resow,

<BR>And the rain nourish.

<BR>Not a disembodied spirit

<BR>Can the weapon of tyrants let loose,

<BR>But it shall stalk invisibly over the earth,

<BR>Whispering, counselling, cautioning.



<P>&nbsp;Liberty, let others despair of thee,

<BR>But I will never despair of thee:

<BR>Is the house shut? Is the master away?

<BR>Nevertheless, be ready, be not weary of watching,

<BR>He will surely return; his messengers come anon.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1850</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

GREAT ARE THE MYTHS</H2></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>G<FONT SIZE=-1>reat</FONT> are the myths &amp;emdash; I too delight

in them;

<BR>Great are Adam and Eve &amp;emdash; I too look back and accept them;

<BR>Great the risen and fallen nations, and their poets, women,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sages, inventors, rulers, warriors, and priests.



<P>&nbsp;Great is Liberty! great is Equality! I am their follower;

<BR>Helmsmen of nations, choose your craft! where you sail, I sail,

<BR>I weather it out with you, or sink with you.



<P>&nbsp;Great is Youth &amp;emdash; equally great is Old Age &amp;emdash;
