great are the Day

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and Night;

<BR>Great is Wealth &amp;emdash; great is Poverty &amp;emdash; great is

Expression &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; great is Silence.



<P>&nbsp;Youth, large, lusty, loving &amp;emdash; Youth, full of grace,

force,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fascination!

<BR>Do you know that Old Age may come after you, with equal

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; grace, force, fascination?



<P>&nbsp;Day, full-blown and splendid &amp;emdash; Day of the immense sun,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; action, ambition, laughter,

<BR>The Night follows close, with millions of suns, and sleep, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; restoring darkness.



<P>&nbsp;Wealth, with the flush hand, fine clothes, hospitality;

<BR>But then the Soul's wealth, which is candor, knowledge,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pride, enfolding love;

<BR>(Who goes for men and women showing Poverty richer than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; wealth?)



<P>&nbsp;Expression of speech! in what is written or said, forget not

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that Silence is also expressive,

<BR>That anguish as hot as the hottest, and contempt as cold as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the coldest, may be without words.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Great is the Earth, and the way it became what it is;

<BR>Do you imagine it has stopt at this? the increase aban

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; don'd?

<BR>Understand then that it goes as far onward from this, as this

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; is from the times when it lay in covering waters

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gases, before man had appear'd.



<P>&nbsp;Great is the quality of Truth in man;

<BR>The quality of truth in man supports itself through all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; changes,

<BR>It is inevitably in the man &amp;emdash; he and it are in love, and

never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; leave each other.



<P>&nbsp;The truth in man is no dictum, it is vital as eyesight;

<BR>If there be any Soul, there is truth &amp;emdash; if there be man or

woman

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; there is truth &amp;emdash; if there be physical

or moral, there is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; truth;

<BR>If there be equilibrium or volition, there is truth &amp;emdash; if

there be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; things at all upon the earth, there is truth.



<P>&nbsp;O truth of the earth! I am determin'd to press my way

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; toward you;

<BR>Sound your voice! I scale mountains, or dive in the sea after

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>Great is Language &amp;emdash; it is the mightiest of the sciences,

<BR>It is the fulness, color, form, diversity of the earth, and of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; men and women, and of all qualities and processes;

<BR>It is greater than wealth &amp;emdash; it is greater than buildings,

ships,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; religions, paintings, music.



<P>&nbsp;Great is the English speech &amp;emdash; what speech is so great

as the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; English?

<BR>Great is the English brood &amp;emdash; what brood has so vast a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; destiny as the English?

<BR>It is the mother of the brood that must rule the earth with the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; new rule;

<BR>The new rule shall rule as the Soul rules, and as the love,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; justice, equality in the Soul rule.



<P>&nbsp;Great is Law &amp;emdash; great are the few old land-marks of

the law,

<BR>They are the same in all times, and shall not be disturb'd.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>Great is Justice!

<BR>Justice is not settled by legislators and laws &amp;emdash; it is in

the Soul;

<BR>It cannot be varied by statutes, any more than love, pride,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the attraction of gravity, can;

<BR>It is immutable &amp;emdash; it does not depend on majorities &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; majorities or what not, come at last before the

same passionless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and exact tribunal.



<P>&nbsp;For justice are the grand natural lawyers, and perfect judges

&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it is in their Souls;

<BR>It is well assorted &amp;emdash; they have not studied for nothing

&amp;emdash; the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; great includes the less;

<BR>They rule on the highest grounds &amp;emdash; they oversee all eras,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; states, administrations.



<P>&nbsp;The perfect judge fears nothing &amp;emdash; he could go front

to front

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before God;

<BR>Before the perfect judge all shall stand back &amp;emdash; life and

death

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shall stand back &amp;emdash; heaven and hell shall

stand back.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>Great is Life, real and mystical, wherever and whoever;

<BR>Great is Death &amp;emdash; sure as life holds all parts together,

Death

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; holds all parts together.



<P>&nbsp;Has Life much purport? &amp;emdash; Ah, Death has the greatest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; purport.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1855</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

POEM OF REMEMBRANCE FOR A GIRL OR A BOY OF THESE STATES</H2></CENTER>

Y<FONT SIZE=-1>ou</FONT> just maturing youth! You male or female!

<BR>Remember the organic compact of These States,

<BR>Remember the pledge of the Old Thirteen thenceforward to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the rights, life, liberty, equality of man,

<BR>Remember what was promulged by the founders, ratified by

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The States, signed in black and white by the Commissioners,

and read by Washington at the head of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; army,

<BR>Remember the purposes of the founders, &amp;emdash; Remember

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Washington;

<BR>Remember the copious humanity streaming from every

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; direction toward America;

<BR>Remember the hospitality that belongs to nations and men;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (Cursed be nation, woman, man, without hospitality!)

<BR>Remember, government is to subserve individuals,



<P>&nbsp;Not any, not the President, is to have one jot more than you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or me,

<BR>Not any habitan of America is to have one jot less than you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or me.



<P>&nbsp;Anticipate when the thirty or fifty millions, are to become the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hundred or two hundred millions, of equal freemen

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; freewomen, amicably joined.



<P>&nbsp;Recall ages &amp;emdash; One age is but a part &amp;emdash; ages

are but a part;

<BR>Recall the angers, bickerings, delusions, superstitions, of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; idea of caste,

<BR>Recall the bloody cruelties and crimes.



<P>&nbsp;Anticipate the best women;

<BR>I say an unnumbered new race of hardy and well-defined

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; women are to spread through all These States,

<BR>I say a girl fit for These States must be free, capable,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dauntless, just the same as a boy.



<P>&nbsp;Anticipate your own life &amp;emdash; retract with merciless power,

<BR>Shirk nothing &amp;emdash; retract in time &amp;emdash; Do you see

those errors,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; diseases, weaknesses, lies, thefts?

<BR>Do you see that lost character? &amp;emdash; Do you see decay,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consumption, rum-drinking, dropsy, fever, mortal

cancer or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; inflammation?

<BR>Do you see death, and the approach of death?



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1856</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

THINK OF THE SOUL</H2></CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>hink</FONT> of the Soul;

<BR>I swear to you that body of yours gives proportions to your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Soul somehow to live in other spheres;

<BR>I do not know how, but I know it is so.



<P>&nbsp;Think of loving and being loved;

<BR>I swear to you, whoever you are, you can interfuse yourself

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; with such things that everybody that sees you shall

look

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; longingly upon you.

<BR>Think of the past;

<BR>I warn you that in a little while others will find their past in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you and your times.



<P>&nbsp;The race is never separated &amp;emdash; nor man nor woman escapes;

<BR>All is inextricable &amp;emdash; things, spirits, Nature, nations,

you too &amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from precedents you come.



<P>&nbsp;Recall the ever-welcome defiers, (The mothers precede them;)

<BR>Recall the sages, poets, saviors, inventors, lawgivers, of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; earth;

<BR>Recall Christ, brother of rejected persons &amp;emdash; brother of

slaves,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; felons, idiots, and of insane and diseas'd persons.



<P>&nbsp;Think of the time when you were not yet born;

<BR>Think of times you stood at the side of the dying;

<BR>Think of the time when your own body will be dying.



<P>&nbsp;Think of spiritual results,

<BR>Sure as the earth swims through the heavens, does every one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of its objects pass into spiritual results.



<P>&nbsp;Think of manhood, and you to be a man;

<BR>Do you count manhood, and the sweet of manhood, nothing?



<P>&nbsp;Think of womanhood, and you to be a woman;

<BR>The creation is womanhood;

<BR>Have I not said that womanhood involves all?

<BR>Have I not told how the universe has nothing better than the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; best womanhood?



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1856</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

RESPONDEZ!</H2></CENTER>

R<FONT SIZE=-1>espondez</FONT>! Respondez!

<BR>(The war is completed &amp;emdash; the price is paid &amp;emdash; the

title is settled

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beyond recall;)

<BR>Let every one answer! let those who sleep be waked! let none

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; evade!

<BR>Must we still go on with our affections and sneaking?



<P>&nbsp;Let me bring this to a close &amp;emdash; I pronounce openly for

a new

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; distribution of roles;

<BR>Let that which stood in front go behind! and let that which

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; was behind advance to the front and speak;

<BR>Let murderers, bigots, fools, unclean persons, offer new

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; propositions!

<BR>Let the old propositions be postponed!

<BR>Let faces and theories be turn'd inside out! let meanings be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; freely criminal, as well as results!

<BR>Let there be no suggestion above the suggestion of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; drudgery!

<BR>Let none be pointed toward his destination! (Say! do you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know your destination?)

<BR>Let men and women be mock'd with bodies and mock'd with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Souls!

<BR>Let the love that waits in them, wait! let it die, or pass still-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; born to other spheres!

<BR>Let the sympathy that waits in every man, wait! or let it also

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pass, a dwarf, to other spheres!

<BR>Let contradictions prevail! let one thing contradict another!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and let one line of my poems contradict another!

<BR>Let the people sprawl with yearning, aimless hands! let their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tongues be broken! let their eyes be discouraged!

let

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; none descend into their hearts with the fresh

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lusciousness of love!

<BR>(Stifled, O days! O lands! in every public and private

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; corruption!

<BR>Smother'd in thievery, impotence, shamelessness, mountain-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; high;

<BR>Brazen effrontery, scheming, rolling like ocean's waves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; around and upon you, O my days! my lands!

<BR>For not even those thunderstorms, nor fiercest lightnings of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the war, have purified the atmosphere;)

<BR>&amp;emdash; Let the theory of America still be management, caste,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; comparison! (Say! what other theory would you?)

<BR>Let them that distrust birth and death still lead the rest! (Say!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; why shall they not lead you?)

<BR>Let the crust of hell be neared and trod on! let the days be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; darker than the nights! let slumber bring less slumber

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; than waking time brings!



<P>&nbsp;Let the world never appear to him or her for whom it was all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; made!

<BR>Let the heart of the young man still exile itself from the heart

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the old man! and let the heart of the old man

be exiled

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; from that of the young man!

<BR>Let the sun and moon go! let scenery take the applause of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the audience! let there be apathy under the stars!

<BR>Let freedom prove no man's inalienable right! every one who

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; can tyrannize, let him tyrannize to his satisfaction!

<BR>Let none but infidels be countenanced!

<BR>Let the eminence of meanness, treachery, sarcasm, hate,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; greed, indecency, impotence, lust, be taken for

granted

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; above all! let writers, judges, governments, households,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; religions, philosophies, take such for granted above

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all!

<BR>Let the worst men beget children out of the worst women!

<BR>Let the priest still play at immortality!

<BR>Let death be inaugurated!

<BR>Let nothing remain but the ashes of teachers, artists,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; moralists, lawyers, and learn'd and polite persons!

<BR>Let him who is without my poems be assassinated!

<BR>Let the cow, the horse, the camel, the garden-bee &amp;emdash; let

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mud-fish, the lobster, the mussel, eel, the sting-ray,

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the grunting pig-fish &amp;emdash; let these, and

the like of these, be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; put on a perfect equality with man and woman!

<BR>Let churches accommodate serpents, vermin, and the corpses

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of those who have died of the most filthy of diseases!

<BR>Let marriage slip down among fools, and be for none but

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; fools!

<BR>Let men among themselves talk and think forever obscenely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of women! and let women among themselves talk and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; think obscenely of men!

<BR>Let us all, without missing one, be exposed in public, naked,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; monthly, at the peril of our lives! let our bodies

be freely

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; handled and examined by whoever chooses!

<BR>Let nothing but copies at second hand be permitted to exist

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; upon the earth!

<BR>Let the earth desert God, nor let there ever henceforth be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mention'd the name of God!

<BR>Let there be no God!



<P>&nbsp;Let there be money, business, imports, exports, custom,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; authority, precedents, pallor, dyspepsia, smut,

ignorance,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unbelief!

<BR>Let judges and criminals be transposed! let the prison-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; keepers be put in prison! let those that were prisoners

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; take the keys! (Say! why might they not just as

well be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; transposed?)

<BR>Let the slaves be masters! let the masters become slaves!

<BR>Let the reformers descend from the stands where they are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; forever bawling! let an idiot or insane person appear

on

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; each of the stands!

<BR>Let the Asiatic, the African, the European, the American,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and the Australian, go armed against the murderous

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stealthiness of each other! let them sleep armed!

let none

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; believe in good will!

<BR>Let there be no unfashionable wisdom! let such be scorn'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and derided off from the earth!

<BR>Let a floating cloud in the sky &amp;emdash; let a wave of the sea

&amp;emdash; let

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; growing mint, spinach, onions, tomatoes &amp;emdash;

let these be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; exhibited as shows, at a great price for admission!

<BR>Let all the men of These States stand aside for a few

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; smouchers! let the few seize on what they choose!

let the rest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gawk, giggle, starve, obey!

<BR>Let shadows be furnish'd with genitals! let substances be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; deprived of their genitals!

<BR>Let there be wealthy and immense cities &amp;emdash; but still through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; any of them, not a single poet, savior, knower,

lover!

<BR>Let the infidels of These States laugh all faith away!

<BR>If one man be found who has faith, let the rest set upon him!

<BR>Let them affright faith! let them destroy the power of breeding

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; faith!

<BR>Let the she-harlots and the he-harlots be prudent! let them

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dance on, while seeming lasts! (O seeming! seeming!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seeming!)

<BR>Let the preachers recite creeds! let them still teach only what

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they have been taught!

<BR>Let insanity still have charge of sanity!

<BR>Let books take the place of trees, animals, rivers, clouds!

<BR>Let the daub'd portraits of heroes supersede heroes!

<BR>Let the manhood of man never take steps after itself!



<P>&nbsp;Let it take steps after eunuchs, and after consumptive and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; genteel persons!

<BR>Let the white person again tread the black person under his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; heel! (Say! which is trodden under heel, after all?)

<BR>Let the reflections of the things of the world be studied in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mirrors! let the things themselves still continue

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unstudied!

<BR>Let a man seek pleasure everywhere except in himself!

<BR>Let a woman seek happiness everywhere except in herself!

<BR>(What real happiness have you had one single hour through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; your whole life?)

<BR>Let the limited years of life do nothing for the limitless years

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of death! (What do you suppose death will do, then?)



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1856</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

APOSTROPH</H2></CENTER>

O <FONT SIZE=-1>mater</FONT>! O fils!

<BR>O brood continental!

<BR>O flowers of the prairies!

<BR>O space boundless! O hum of mighty products!

<BR>O you teeming cities! O so invincible, turbulent, proud!

<BR>O race of the future! O women!

<BR>O fathers! O you men of passion and the storm!

<BR>O native power only! O beauty!

<BR>O yourself! O God! O divine average!

<BR>O you bearded roughs! O bards! O all those slumberers!

<BR>O arouse! the dawn-bird's throat sounds shrill! Do you not hear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the cock crowing?

<BR>O, as I walk'd the beach, I heard the mournful notes foreboding

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; a tempest &amp;emdash; the low, oft-repeated shriek

of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; diver, the long-lived loon;

<BR>O I heard, and yet hear, angry thunder; &amp;emdash; O you sailors!

O

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ships! make quick preparation!

<BR>O from his masterful sweep, the warning cry of the eagle!

<BR>(Give way there, all! It is useless! Give up your spoils;)

<BR>O sarcasms! Propositions! (O if the whole world should

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prove indeed a sham, a sell!)

<BR>O I believe there is nothing real but America and freedom!

<BR>O to sternly reject all except Democracy!

<BR>O imperator! O who dare confront you and me?



<P>&nbsp;O to promulgate our own! O to build for that which build

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; for mankind!

<BR>O feuillage! O North! O the slope drained by the Mexican

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sea!

<BR>O all, all inseparable &amp;emdash; ages, ages, ages!

<BR>O a curse on him that would dissever this Union for any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; reason whatever!

<BR>O climate, labors! O good and evil! O death!

<BR>O you strong with iron and wood! O Personality!

<BR>O the village or place which has the greatest man or woman!

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; even if it be only a few ragged huts;

<BR>O the city where women walk in public processions in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; streets, the same as the men;

<BR>O a wan and terrible emblem, by me adopted!

<BR>O shapes arising! shapes of the future centuries!

<BR>O muscle and pluck forever for me!

<BR>O workmen and workwomen forever for me!

<BR>O farmers and sailors! O drivers of horses forever for me!

<BR>O I will make the new bardic list of trades and tools!

<BR>O you coarse and wilful! I love you!

<BR>O South! O longings for my dear home! O soft and sunny

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; airs!

<BR>O pensive! O I must return where the palm grows and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mocking bird sings, or else I die!

<BR>O equality! O organic compacts! I am come to be your born

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; poet!

<BR>O whirl, contest, sounding and resounding! I am your poet,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; because I am part of you;

<BR>O days by-gone! Enthusiasts! Antecedents!

<BR>O vast preparations for These States! O years!

<BR>O what is now being sent forward thousands of years to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; come!

<BR>O mediums! O to teach! to convey the invisible faith!

<BR>To promulge real things! to journey through all The States!

<BR>O creation! O to-day! O laws! O unmitigated adoration!

<BR>O for mightier broods of orators, artists, and singers!

<BR>O for native songs! carpenter's, boatman's, ploughman's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; songs! shoemaker's songs!

<BR>O haughtiest growth of time! O free and extatic!

<BR>O what I, here, preparing, warble for!



<P>&nbsp;O you hastening light! O the sun of the world will ascend,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dazzling, and take his height &amp;emdash; and you

too will ascend;

<BR>O so amazing and so broad! up there resplendent, darting

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and burning;

<BR>O prophetic! O vision staggered with weight of light! with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pouring glories!

<BR>O copious! O hitherto unequalled!

<BR>O Libertad! O compact! O union impossible to dissever!

<BR>O my Soul! O lips becoming tremulous, powerless!

<BR>O centuries, centuries yet ahead!

<BR>O voices of greater orators! I pause &amp;emdash; I listen for you!

<BR>O you States! Cities! defiant of all outside authority! I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spring at once into your arms! you I most love!

<BR>O you grand Presidentiads! I wait for you!

<BR>New history! New heroes! I project you!

<BR>Visions of poets! only you really last! O sweep on! sweep on!

<BR>O Death! O you striding there! O I cannot yet!

<BR>O heights! O infinitely too swift and dizzy yet!

<BR>O purged lumine! you threaten me more than I can stand!

<BR>O present! I return while yet I may to you!

<BR>O poets to come, I depend upon you!



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

O SUN OF REAL PEACE</H2></CENTER>

O <FONT SIZE=-1>sun</FONT> of real peace! O hastening light!

<BR>O free and extatic! O what I here, preparing, warble for!

<BR>O the sun of the world will ascend, dazzling, and take his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; height &amp;emdash; and you too, O my Ideal will

surely ascend!

<BR>O so amazing and broad &amp;emdash; up there resplendent, darting and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; burning!

<BR>O vision prophetic, stagger'd with weight of light! with

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pouring glories!

<BR>O lips of my soul, already becoming powerless!

<BR>O ample and grand Presidentiads! Now the war, the war is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; over!

<BR>New history! new heroes! I project you!

<BR>Visions of poets! only you really last! sweep on! sweep on!

<BR>O heights too swift and dizzy yet!

<BR>O purged and luminous! you threaten me more than I can

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stand!

<BR>(I must not venture &amp;emdash; the ground under my feet menaces me

&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; it will not support me:

<BR>O future too immense,) &amp;emdash; O present, I return, while yet

I may,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to you.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

[SO FAR AND SO FAR, AND ON TOWARD THE END]</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>o</FONT> far, and so far, and on toward the end,

<BR>Singing what is sung in this book, from the irresistible

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; impulses of me;

<BR>But whether I continue beyond this book, to maturity,

<BR>Whether I shall dart forth the true rays, the ones that wait

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unfired,

<BR>(Did you think the sun was shining its brightest?

<BR>No &amp;emdash; it has not yet fully risen;)

<BR>Whether I shall complete what is here started,

<BR>Whether I shall attain my own height, to justify these, yet

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unfinished,

<BR>Whether I shall make <FONT SIZE=-1>the</FONT> P<FONT SIZE=-1>oem of

the</FONT> N<FONT SIZE=-1>ew</FONT> W<FONT SIZE=-1>orld</FONT>,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; transcending all others &amp;emdash; depends, rich

persons, upon you,

<BR>Depends, whoever you are now filling the current Presiden

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; tiad, upon you,

<BR>Upon you, Governor, Mayor, Congressman,

<BR>And you, contemporary America.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

IN THE NEW GARDEN, IN ALL THE PARTS</H2></CENTER>

I<FONT SIZE=-1>n</FONT> the new garden, in all the parts,

<BR>In cities now, modern, I wander,

<BR>Though the second or third result, or still further, primitive

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; yet,

<BR>Days, places, indifferent &amp;emdash; though various, the same,

<BR>Time, Paradise, the Mannahatta, the prairies, finding me

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unchanged,

<BR>Death indifferent &amp;emdash; Is it that I lived long since? Was I

buried

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; very long ago?

<BR>For all that, I may now be watching you here, this moment;



<P>&nbsp;For the future, with determined will, I seek &amp;emdash; the

woman of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the future,

<BR>You, born years, centuries after me, I seek.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

[STATES!]</H2></CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>tates</FONT>!

<BR>Were you looking to be held together by the lawyers?

<BR>By an agreement on a paper? Or by arms?



<P>&nbsp;Away!

<BR>I arrive, bringing these, beyond all the forces of courts and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; arms,

<BR>These! to hold you together as firmly as the earth itself is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; held together.



<P>&nbsp;The old breath of life, ever new,

<BR>Here! I pass it by contact to you, America.



<P>&nbsp;O mother! have you done much for me?

<BR>Behold, there shall from me be much done for you.



<P>&nbsp;There shall from me be a new friendship &amp;emdash; It shall

be called

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; after my name,

<BR>It shall circulate through The States, indifferent of place,

<BR>It shall twist and intertwist them through and around each

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; other &amp;emdash; Compact shall they be, showing

new signs,

<BR>Affection shall solve every one of the problems of freedom,

<BR>Those who love each other shall be invincible,

<BR>They shall finally make America completely victorious, in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; my name.



<P>&nbsp;One from Massachusetts shall be a comrade to a Missourian,

<BR>One from Maine or Vermont, and a Carolinian and an Ore

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; gonese, shall be friends triune, more precious to

each

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; other than all the riches of the earth.



<P>&nbsp;To Michigan shall be wafted perfume from Florida,

<BR>To the Mannahatta from Cuba or Mexico,

<BR>Not the perfume of flowers, but sweeter, and wafted beyond

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; death.



<P>&nbsp;No danger shall balk Columbia's lovers,

<BR>If need be, a thousand shall sternly immolate themselves for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; one,

<BR>The Kanuck shall be willing to lay down his life for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Kansian, and the Kansian for the Kanuck, on due

need.



<P>&nbsp;It shall be customary in all directions, in the houses and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; streets, to see manly affection,

<BR>The departing brother or friend shall salute the remaining

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brother or friend with a kiss.



<P>&nbsp;There shall be innovations,

<BR>There shall be countless linked hands &amp;emdash; namely, the North-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; easterner's, and the Northwesterner's, and the South-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; westerner's, and those of the interior, and all

their

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brood,

<BR>These shall be masters of the world under a new power,

<BR>They shall laugh to scorn the attacks of all the remainder of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the world.



<P>&nbsp;The most dauntless and rude shall touch face to face lightly,

<BR>The dependence of Liberty shall be lovers,

<BR>The continuance of Equality shall be comrades.



<P>&nbsp;These shall tie and band stronger than hoops of iron,

<BR>I, extatic, O partners! O lands! henceforth with the love of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lovers tie you.



<P>&nbsp;

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>

<H2>

[LONG I THOUGHT THAT KNOWLEDGE]</H2></CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>ong</FONT> I thought that knowledge alone would suffice

me &amp;emdash; O if

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I could but obtain knowledge!

<BR>Then my lands engrossed me &amp;emdash; Lands of the prairies, Ohio's

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land, the southern savannas, engrossed me &amp;emdash;

For them I

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; would live &amp;emdash; I would be their orator;

<BR>Then I met the examples of old and new heroes &amp;emdash; I heard

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; warriors, sailors, and all dauntless persons &amp;emdash;

And it

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; seemed to me that I too had it in me to be as dauntless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as any &amp;emdash; and would be so;

<BR>And then, to enclose all, it came to me to strike up the songs

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the New World&amp;emdash;And then I believed

my life must be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spent in singing;

<BR>But now take notice, land of the prairies, land of the south

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; savannas, Ohio's land,

<BR>Take notice, you Kanuck woods&amp;emdash;and you Lake Huron&amp;emdash;and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all that with you roll toward Niagara&amp;emdash;and

you

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Niagara also,

<BR>And you, Californian mountains&amp;emdash;That you each and all find

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; somebody else to be your singer of songs,

<BR>For I can be your singer of songs no longer&amp;emdash;One who loves

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me is jealous of me, and withdraws me from all but

love,

<BR>With the rest I dispense&amp;emdash;I sever from what I thought would

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; suffice me, for it does not&amp;emdash;it is now

empty and tasteless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to me,

<BR>I heed knowledge, and the grandeur of The States, and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; example of heroes, no more,

<BR>I am indifferent to my own songs&amp;emdash;I will go with him I love,

<BR>It is to be enough for us that we are together&amp;emdash;We never

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; separate again.

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>[HOURS CONTINUING LONG, SORE AND HEAVY-HEARTED]</CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>ours</FONT> continuing long, sore and heavy-hearted,

<BR>Hours of the dusk, when I withdraw to a lonesome and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; unfrequented spot, seating myself, leaning my face

in my

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; hands;

<BR>Hours sleepless, deep in the night, when I go forth, speeding

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; swiftly the country roads, or through the city streets,

or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pacing miles and miles, stifling plaintive cries;

<BR>Hours discouraged, distracted&amp;emdash;for the one I cannot content

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; myself without, soon I saw him content himself without

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; me;

<BR>Hours when I am forgotten, (O weeks and months are

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; passing, but I believe I am never to forget!)

<BR>Sullen and suffering hours! (I am ashamed&amp;emdash;but it is useless&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I am what I am;)

<BR>Hours of my torment&amp;emdash;I wonder if other men ever have the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; like, out of the like feelings?



<P>&nbsp;Is there even one other like me&amp;emdash;distracted&amp;emdash;his

friend, his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lover, lost to him?

<BR>Is he too as I am now? Does he still rise in the morning,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; dejected, thinking who is lost to him? and at night,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; awaking, think who is lost?

<BR>Does he too harbor his friendship silent and endless? harbor

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; his anguish and passion?

<BR>Does some stray reminder, or the casual mention of a name,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; bring the fit back upon him, taciturn and deprest?

<BR>Does he see himself reflected in me? In these hours, does he

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; see the face of his hours reflected?

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>[Who is now reading this?]</CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>ho</FONT> is now reading this?



<P>&nbsp;May-be one is now reading this who knows some wrongdoing

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of my past life,

<BR>Or may-be a stranger is reading this who has secretly loved me,

<BR>Or may-be one who meets all my grand assumptions and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; egotisms with derision,

<BR>Or may-be one who is puzzled at me.



<P>&nbsp;As if I were not puzzled at myself!

<BR>Or as if I never deride myself! (O conscience-struck! O self-

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; convicted!)

<BR>Or as if I do not secretly love strangers! (O tenderly, a long

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; time, and never avow it;)

<BR>Or as if I did not see, perfectly well, interior in myself, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stuff of wrong-doing,

<BR>Or as if it could cease transpiring from me until it must cease.

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>T<FONT SIZE=-1>o you</FONT></CENTER>

L<FONT SIZE=-1>et</FONT> us twain walk aside from the rest;

<BR>Now we are together privately, do you discard ceremony,

<BR>Come! vouchsafe to me what has yet been vouchsafed to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; none&amp;emdash;Tell me the whole story,

<BR>Tell me what you would not tell your brother, wife, husband,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or physician.

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>[O<FONT SIZE=-1>f the visages of things</FONT>]</CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>f</FONT> the visages of things&amp;emdash;And of piercing

through to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accepted hells beneath;

<BR>Of ugliness&amp;emdash;To me there is just as much in it as there is

in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beauty&amp;emdash;And now the ugliness of human

beings is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; acceptable to me;

<BR>Of detected persons&amp;emdash;To me, detected persons are not, in

any

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; respect, worse than undetected persons&amp;emdash;and

are not in

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; any respect worse than I am myself;

<BR>Of criminals&amp;emdash;To me, any judge, or any juror, is equally

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; criminal&amp;emdash;and any reputable person is

also&amp;emdash;and the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; President is also.

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>S<FONT SIZE=-1>ays</FONT></CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>say</FONT> whatever tastes sweet to the most perfect

person, that is

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; finally right.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>say</FONT> nourish a great intellect, a great brain;

<BR>If I have said anything to the contrary, I hereby retract it.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>3</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>say</FONT> man shall not hold property in man;

<BR>I say the least developed person on earth is just as important

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sacred to himself or herself, as the most developed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; person is to himself or herself.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>4</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>say</FONT> where liberty draws not the blood out of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; slavery, there slavery draws the blood out of liberty,

<BR>I say the word of the good old cause in These States, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; resound it hence over the world.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>5</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>say</FONT> the human shape or face is so great, it must

never be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; made ridiculous;

<BR>I say for ornaments nothing outre can be allowed,



<P>&nbsp;And that anything is most beautiful without ornament,

<BR>And that exaggerations will be sternly revenged in your own

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; physiology, and in other persons' physiology also;

<BR>And I say that clean-shaped children can be jetted and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; conceived only where natural forms prevail in public,

and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the human face and form are never caricatured;

<BR>And I say that genius need never more be turned to romances,

<BR>(For facts properly told, how mean appear all romances.)



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>6</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>say</FONT> the word of lands fearing nothing&amp;emdash;I

will have no other

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; land;

<BR>I say discuss all and expose all&amp;emdash;I am for every topic openly;

<BR>I say there can be no salvation for These States without

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; innovators&amp;emdash;without free tongues, and

ears willing to hear

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the tongues;

<BR>And I announce as a glory of These States, that they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; respectfully listen to propositions, reforms, fresh

views and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; doctrines, from successions of men and women,

<BR>Each age with its own growth.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>7</CENTER>





<P>I <FONT SIZE=-1>have</FONT> said many times that materials and the Soul

are great,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and that all depends on physique;

<BR>Now I reverse what I said, and affirm that all depends on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &aelig;sthetic or intellectual,

<BR>And that criticism is great&amp;emdash;and that refinement is greatest

of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all;

<BR>And I affirm now that the mind governs&amp;emdash;and that all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; depends on the mind.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>8</CENTER>





<P>W<FONT SIZE=-1>ith</FONT> one man or woman&amp;emdash;(no matter which

one&amp;emdash;I even

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pick out the lowest,)

<BR>With him or her I now illustrate the whole law;

<BR>I say that every right, in politics or what-not, shall be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; eligible to that one man or woman, on the same terms

as any.

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>DEBRIS</CENTER>

H<FONT SIZE=-1>e</FONT> is wisest who has the most caution,

<BR>He only wins who goes far enough.



<P>&nbsp;A<FONT SIZE=-1>ny</FONT> thing is as good as established, when

that is established

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that will produce and continue it.



<P>&nbsp;W<FONT SIZE=-1>hat</FONT> General has a good army in himself,

has a good army;

<BR>He happy in himself, or she happy in herself, is happy,

<BR>But I tell you you cannot be happy by others, any more than

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; you can beget or conceive a child by others.



<P>&nbsp;O<FONT SIZE=-1>ne</FONT> sweeps by, attended by an immense train,

<BR>All emblematic of peace&amp;emdash;not a soldier or menial among

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them.



<P>&nbsp;O<FONT SIZE=-1>ne</FONT> sweeps by, old, with black eyes, and

profuse white hair,

<BR>He has the simple magnificence of health and strength,

<BR>His face strikes as with flashes of lightning whoever it turns

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; toward.



<P>&nbsp;T<FONT SIZE=-1>hree</FONT> old men slowly pass, followed by three

others, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; they by three others,

<BR>They are beautiful&amp;emdash;the one in the middle of each group

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; holds his companions by the hand,

<BR>As they walk, they give out perfume wherever they walk.



<P>&nbsp;W<FONT SIZE=-1>hat</FONT> weeping face is that looking from the

window?

<BR>Why does it stream those sorrowful tears?

<BR>Is it for some burial place, vast and dry?

<BR>Is it to wet the soil of graves?



<P>&nbsp;I <FONT SIZE=-1>will</FONT> take an egg out of the robin's nest

in the orchard,

<BR>I will take a branch of gooseberries from the old bush in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; garden, and go and preach to the world;

<BR>You shall see I will not meet a single heretic or scorner,

<BR>You shall see how I stump clergymen, and confound them,

<BR>You shall see me showing a scarlet tomato, and a white

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pebble from the beach.



<P>&nbsp;B<FONT SIZE=-1>ehavior</FONT>&amp;emdash;fresh, native, copious,

each one for himself or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; herself,

<BR>Nature and the Soul expressed&amp;emdash;America and freedom expressed

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &amp;emdash;in it the finest art,

<BR>In it pride, cleanliness, sympathy, to have their chance,

<BR>In it physique, intellect, faith&amp;emdash;in it just as much as to

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; manage an army or a city, or to write a book&amp;emdash;perhaps

more,

<BR>The youth, the laboring person, the poor person, rivalling all

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the rest&amp;emdash;perhaps outdoing the rest,

<BR>The effects of the universe no greater than its;

<BR>For there is nothing in the whole universe that can be more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; effective than a man's or a woman's daily behavior

can

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; be,

<BR>In any position, in any one of These States.



<P>&nbsp;I <FONT SIZE=-1>thought</FONT> I was not alone, walking here by

the shore,

<BR>But the one I thought was with me, as now I walk by the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; shore,

<BR>As I lean and look through the glimmering light&amp;emdash;that one

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; has utterly disappeared,

<BR>And those appear that perplex me.

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>THOUGHT</CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>f</FONT> what I write from myself&amp;emdash;As if that

were not the resum&eacute;

<BR>Of Histories&amp;emdash;As if such, however complete, were not less

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; complete than the preceding poems;

<BR>As if those shreds, the records of nations, could possibly be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; as lasting as the preceding poems;

<BR>As if here were not the amount of all nations, and of all the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; lives of heroes.

<PRE>1860</PRE>



<CENTER>SOLID, IRONICAL, ROLLING ORB</CENTER>

S<FONT SIZE=-1>olid</FONT>, ironical, rolling orb!

<BR>Master of all, and matter of fact!&amp;emdash;at last I accept your

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; terms;

<BR>Bringing to practical, vulgar tests, of all my ideal dreams,

<BR>And of me, as lover and hero.

<PRE>1865</PRE>



<CENTER>BATHED IN WAR'S PERFUME</CENTER>

B<FONT SIZE=-1>athed</FONT> in war's perfume&amp;emdash;delicate flag!

<BR>(Should the days needing armies, needing fleets, come again,)

<BR>O to hear you call the sailors and the soldiers! flag like a

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; beautiful woman!

<BR>O to hear the tramp, tramp, of a million answering men! O

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the ships they arm with joy!

<BR>O to see you leap and beckon from the tall masts of ships!

<BR>O to see you peering down on the sailors on the decks!

<BR>Flag like the eyes of women.

<PRE>1865</PRE>



<CENTER>NOT MY ENEMIES EVER INVADE ME</CENTER>

N<FONT SIZE=-1>to</FONT> my enemies ever invade me&amp;emdash;no harm to

my pride from

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them I fear;

<BR>But the lovers I recklessly love&amp;emdash;lo! how they master me!

<BR>Lo! me, ever open and helpless, bereft of my strength!

<BR>Utterly abject, grovelling on the ground before them.

<PRE>1865-6</PRE>



<CENTER>THIS DAY, O SOUL</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>his</FONT> day, O Soul, I give you a wondrous mirror;

<BR>Long in the dark, in tarnish and cloud it lay&amp;emdash;But the cloud

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; has pass'd, and the tarnish gone;

<BR>. . .Behold, O Soul! it is now a clean and bright mirror,

<BR>Faithfully showing you all the things of the world.

<PRE>1865-6</PRE>



<CENTER>LESSONS</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>here</FONT> are who teach only the sweet lessons of peace

and safety;

<BR>But I teach lessons of war and death to those I love,

<BR>That they readily meet invasions, when they come.

<PRE>1871</PRE>



<CENTER>ONE SONG, AMERICA, BEFORE I GO</CENTER>

O<FONT SIZE=-1>ne</FONT> song, America, before I go,

<BR>I'd sing, o'er all the rest, with trumpet sound,

<BR>For thee&amp;emdash;the Future.



<P>&nbsp;I'd sow a seed for thee of endless Nationality;

<BR>I'd fashion thy Ensemble, including Body, and Soul;

<BR>I'd show, away ahead, the real Union, and how it may be

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accomplish'd.



<P>&nbsp;(The paths to the House I seek to make,

<BR>But leave to those to come, the House itself.)



<P>&nbsp;Belief I sing&amp;emdash;and Preparation;

<BR>As Life and Nature are not great with reference to the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Present only,

<BR>But greater still from what is to come,

<BR>Out of that formula for Thee I sing.

<PRE>1872</PRE>



<CENTER>AFTER AN INTERVAL</CENTER>





<P>(<I>Nov. 22, 1875, midnight&amp;emdash;Saturn and Mars in conjunction</I>)



<P>&nbsp;A<FONT SIZE=-1>fter</FONT> an interval, reading, here in the midnight,

<BR>With the great stars looking on&amp;emdash;all the stars of Orion looking,

<BR>And the silent Pleiades&amp;emdash;and the duo looking of Saturn and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ruddy Mars;

<BR>Pondering, reading my own songs, after a long interval,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (sorrow and death familiar now,)

<BR>Ere closing the book, what pride! what joy! to find them,

<BR>Standing so well the test of death and night!

<BR>And the duo of Saturn and Mars!

<PRE>1875</PRE>



<CENTER>THE BEAUTY OF THE SHIP</CENTER>

W<FONT SIZE=-1>hen</FONT>, staunchly entering port,

<BR>After long ventures, hauling up, worn and old,

<BR>Battered by sea and wind, torn by many a fight,

<BR>With the original sails all gone, replaced, or mended,

<BR>I only saw, at last, the beauty of the Ship.

<PRE>1876</PRE>



<CENTER>TWO RIVULETS</CENTER>

T<FONT SIZE=-1>wo</FONT> Rivulets side by side,

<BR>T<FONT SIZE=-1>wo</FONT> blended, parallel, strolling tides,

<BR>Companions, travelers, gossiping as they journey.



<P>&nbsp;For the Eternal Ocean bound,

<BR>These ripples, passing surges, streams of Death and Life,

<BR>Object and Subject hurrying, whirling by,

<BR>The Real and Ideal,



<P>&nbsp;Alternate ebb and flow the Days and Nights,

<BR>(Strands of a Trio twining, Present, Future, Past.)



<P>&nbsp;In You, whoe'ver you are, my book perusing,

<BR>In I myself&amp;emdash;in all the World&amp;emdash;these ripples flow,

<BR>All, all, toward the mystic Ocean tending.



<P>&nbsp;(O yearnful waves! the kisses of your lips!

<BR>Your breast so broad, with open arms, O firm, expanded shore!)

<PRE>1876</PRE>



<CENTER>OR FROM THAT SEA OF TIME</CENTER>



<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>1</CENTER>





<P>O<FONT SIZE=-1>r</FONT>, from that Sea of Time,

<BR>Spray, blown by the wind&amp;emdash;a double winrow-drift of weeds

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and shells;

<BR>(O little shells, so curious-convolute! so limpid-cold and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; voiceless!

<BR>Yet will you not, to the tympans of temples held,

<BR>Murmurs and echoes still bring up&amp;emdash;Eternity's music, faint

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and far,

<BR>Wafted inland, sent from Atlantica's rim&amp;emdash;strains for the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Soul of the Prairies,

<BR>Whisper'd reverberations&amp;emdash;chords for the ear of the West,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joyously sounding

<BR>Your tidings old, yet ever new and untranslatable;)

<BR>Infinitesimals out of my life, and many a life,

<BR>(For not my life and years alone I give&amp;emdash;all, all I give;)

<BR>These thoughts and Songs&amp;emdash;waifs from the deep&amp;emdash;here,

cast

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; high and dry,

<BR>Wash'd on America's shores.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>Currents of starting a Continent new,

<BR>Overtures sent to the solid out of the liquid,

<BR>Fusion of ocean and land&amp;emdash;tender and pensive waves,

<BR>(Not safe and peaceful only&amp;emdash;waves rous'd and ominous too.



<P>&nbsp;Out of the depths, the storm's abysms&amp;emdash;who knows whence?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Death's waves,

<BR>Raging over the vast, with many a broken spar and tatter'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sail.)

<BR>1876

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>FROM MY LAST YEARS</CENTER>

F<FONT SIZE=-1>rom</FONT> my last years, last thoughts I here bequeath,

<BR>Scatter'd and dropt, in seeds, and wafted to the West,

<BR>Through moisture of Ohio, prairie soil of Illinois&amp;emdash;through

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Colorado, California air,

<BR>For Time to germinate fully.

<PRE>1876</PRE>



<CENTER>IN FORMER SONGS</CENTER>

I<FONT SIZE=-1>n</FONT> former songs Pride have I sung, and Love, and passionate,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; joyful Life,

<BR>But here I twine the strands of Patriotism and Death.



<P>&nbsp;And now, Life, Pride, Love, Patriotism and Death,

<BR>To you, O F<FONT SIZE=-1>reedom</FONT>, purport of all!

<BR>(You that elude me most&amp;emdash;refusing to be caught in songs of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mine,)

<BR>I offer all to you.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER></CENTER>



<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>'Tis not for nothing, Death,

<BR>I sound out you, and words of you, with daring tone&amp;emdash;

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; embodying you,

<BR>In my new Democratic chants&amp;emdash;keeping you for a close,

<BR>For last impregnable retreat&amp;emdash;a citadel and tower,

<BR>For my last stand&amp;emdash;my pealing, final cry.

<PRE>1876</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Leaves Of Grass : Song of the Answerer</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">



<CENTER>

<H1>

<I>Song of the Answerer</I></H1></CENTER>

Now list to my morning's romanza, I tell the signs of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Answerer,

<BR>To the cities and farms I sing as they spread in the sunshine

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; before me.



<P>&nbsp;A young man comes to me bearing a message from his brother,

<BR>How shall the young man know the whether and when of his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; brother?

<BR>Tell him to send me the signs.



<P>&nbsp;And I stand before the young man face to face, and take his

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; right hand in my left hand and his left hand

in my right hand,

<BR>And I answer for his brother and for men, and I answer for him

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that answers for all, and send these signs.



<P>&nbsp;Him all wait for, him all yield up to, his word is decisive

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and final,

<BR>Him they accept, in him lave, in him perceive themselves as

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; amid light,

<BR>Him they immerse and he immerses them.



<P>&nbsp;Beautiful women, the haughtiest nations, laws, the landscape,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; people, animals,

<BR>The profound earth and its attributes and the unquiet ocean,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (so tell I my morning's romanza,)

<BR>All enjoyments and properties and money, and whatever money

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; will buy,

<BR>The best farms, others toiling and planting and he unavoidably reaps,

<BR>The noblest and costliest cities, others grading and building and he

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; domiciles there,

<BR>Nothing for any one but what is for him, near and far are for him,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the ships in the offing,

<BR>The perpetual shows and marches on land are for him if they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are for anybody.



<P>&nbsp;He puts things in their attitudes,

<BR>He puts to-day out of himself with plasticity and love,

<BR>He places his own times, reminiscences, parents, brothers and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sisters, associations, employment, politics,

so that the rest

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; never shame them afterward, nor assume to

command them.



<P>&nbsp;He is the Answerer,

<BR>What can be answer'd he answers, and what cannot be answer'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; he shows how it cannot be answer'd.



<P>&nbsp;A man is a summons and challenge,

<BR>(It is vain to skulk&amp;emdash;do you hear that mocking and laughter?

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; do you hear the ironical echoes?)



<P>&nbsp;Books, friendships, philosophers, priests, action, pleasure,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pride, beat up and down seeking to give satisfaction,

<BR>He indicates the satisfaction, and indicates them that beat up

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and down also.



<P>&nbsp;Whichever the sex, whatever the season or place, he may go

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; freshly and gently and safely by day or by

night,

<BR>He has the pass-key of hearts, to him the response of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; prying of hands on the knobs.



<P>&nbsp;His welcome is universal, the flow of beauty is not more

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; welcome or universal than he is,

<BR>The person he favors by day or sleeps with at night is blessed.



<P>&nbsp;Every existence has its idiom, every thing has an idiom and tongue,

<BR>He resolves all tongues into his own and bestows it upon men, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; any man translates, and any man translates

himself also,

<BR>One part does not counteract another part, he is the joiner,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; he sees how they join.



<P>&nbsp;He says indifferently and alike <I>How are you friend?</I> to

the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; President at his levee,

<BR>And he says <I>Good-day my brother</I>, to Cudge that hoes in the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sugar-field,

<BR>And both understand him and know that his speech is right.



<P>&nbsp;He walks with perfect ease in the capitol,

<BR>He walks among the Congress, and one Representative says

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to another, <I>Here is our equal appearing

and new</I>.



<P>&nbsp;Then the mechanics take him for a mechanic,

<BR>And the soldiers suppose him to be a soldier, and the sailors

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that he has follow'd the sea,

<BR>And the authors take him for an author, and the artists for

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; an artist,

<BR>And the laborers perceive he could labor with them and love

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; them,

<BR>No matter what the work is, that he is the one to follow it or

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; has follow'd it,

<BR>No matter what the nation, that he might find his brothers

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; and sisters there.



<P>&nbsp;The English believe he comes of their English stock,

<BR>A Jew to the Jew he seems, a Russ to the Russ, usual and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; near, removed from none.



<P>&nbsp;Whoever he looks at in the traveler's coffee-house claims him,

<BR>The Italian or Frenchman is sure, the German is sure, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Spaniard is sure, and the island Cuban is

sure,



<P>&nbsp;The engineer, the deck-hand on the great lakes, or on the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mississippi or St. Lawrence or Sacramento,

or Hudson

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or Paumanok sound, claims him.



<P>&nbsp;The gentleman of perfect blood acknowledges his perfect blood,

<BR>The insulter, the prostitute, the angry person, the beggar, see

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; themselves in the ways of him, he strangely

transmutes them,

<BR>They are not vile any more, they hardly know themselves they

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; are so grown.



<P>&nbsp;

<CENTER>2</CENTER>





<P>The indications and tally of time,

<BR>Perfect sanity shows the master among philosophs,

<BR>Time, always without break, indicates itself in parts,

<BR>What always indicates the poet is the crowd of the pleasant

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; company of singers, and their words,

<BR>The words of the singers are the hours or minutes of the light

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; or dark, but the words of the maker of poems

are the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; general light and dark,

<BR>The maker of poems settles justice, reality, immortality,

<BR>His insight and power encircle things and the human race,

<BR>He is the glory and extract thus far of things and of the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; human race.



<P>&nbsp;The singers do not beget, only the Poet begets,

<BR>The singers are welcom'd, understood, appear often enough,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; but rare has the day been, likewise the spot,

of the birth

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of the maker of poems, the Answerer,

<BR>(Not every century nor every five centuries has contain'd

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; such a day, for all its names.)



<P>&nbsp;The singers of successive hours of centuries may have ostensible

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; names, but the name of each of them is one

of the singers,

<BR>The name of each is, eye-singer, ear-singer, head-singer,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; sweet-singer, night-singer, parlor-singer,

love-singer,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; weird-singer, or something else.



<P>&nbsp;All this time and at all times wait the words of true poems,

<BR>The words of true poems do not merely please,

<BR>The true poets are not followers of beauty but the august

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; masters of beauty;

<BR>The greatness of sons is the exuding of the greatness of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; mothers and fathers,

<BR>The words of true poems are the tuft and final applause of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; science.



<P>&nbsp;Divine instinct, breadth of vision, the law of reason, health,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rudeness of body, withdrawnness,

<BR>Gayety, sun-tan, air-sweetness, such are some of the words

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of poems.



<P>&nbsp;The sailor and traveler underlie the maker of poems, the

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Answerer,

<BR>The builder, geometer, chemist, anatomist, phrenologist, artist,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all these underlie the maker of poems, the

Answerer.



<P>&nbsp;The words of the true poems give you more than poems,

<BR>They give you to form for yourself poems, religions, politics,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; war, peace, behavior, histories, essays, daily

life, and

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; every thing else,

<BR>They balance ranks, colors, races, creeds, and the sexes,

<BR>They do not seek beauty, they are sought,

<BR>Forever touching them or close upon them follows beauty,

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; longing, fain, love-sick.



<P>&nbsp;They prepare for death, yet they are not the finish, but rather

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the outset,

<BR>They bring none to his or her terminus or to be content and full,

<BR>Whom they take they take into space to behold the birth of

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; stars, to learn one of the meanings,

<BR>To launch off with absolute faith, to sweep through the ceaseless

<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; rings and never be quiet again.

<PRE>1855&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1881</PRE>



<HR width=60%>

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>
